Yet no official personage met them.\r\n\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov looked absent\xe2\x80\x90mindedly at the tombstones round the church, and\r\nwas on the point of saying that the dead buried here must have paid a\r\npretty penny for the right of lying in this \xe2\x80\x9choly place,\xe2\x80\x9d but\r\nrefrained. His liberal irony was rapidly changing almost into anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho the devil is there to ask in this imbecile place? We must find\r\nout, for time is passing,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed suddenly, as though speaking to\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nAll at once there came up a bald\xe2\x80\x90headed, elderly man with ingratiating\r\nlittle eyes, wearing a full, summer overcoat. Lifting his hat, he\r\nintroduced himself with a honeyed lisp as Maximov, a landowner of Tula.\r\nHe at once entered into our visitors\xe2\x80\x99 difficulty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Zossima lives in the hermitage, apart, four hundred paces from\r\nthe monastery, the other side of the copse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it\xe2\x80\x99s the other side of the copse,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Fyodor Pavlovitch,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut we don\xe2\x80\x99t remember the way. It is a long time since we\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis way, by this gate, and straight across the copse ... the copse.\r\nCome with me, won\xe2\x80\x99t you? I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you. I have to go.... I am going\r\nmyself. This way, this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey came out of the gate and turned towards the copse. Maximov, a man\r\nof sixty, ran rather than walked, turning sideways to stare at them\r\nall, with an incredible degree of nervous curiosity. His eyes looked\r\nstarting out of his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, we have come to the elder upon business of our own,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov severely. \xe2\x80\x9cThat personage has granted us an audience, so to\r\nspeak, and so, though we thank you for showing us the way, we cannot\r\nask you to accompany us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been there. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been already; _un chevalier parfait_,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nMaximov snapped his fingers in the air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is a _chevalier_?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mi\xc3\xbcsov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe elder, the splendid elder, the elder! The honor and glory of the\r\nmonastery, Zossima. Such an elder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut his incoherent talk was cut short by a very pale, wan\xe2\x80\x90looking monk\r\nof medium height, wearing a monk\xe2\x80\x99s cap, who overtook them. Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch and Mi\xc3\xbcsov stopped.\r\n\r\nThe monk, with an extremely courteous, profound bow, announced:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Father Superior invites all of you gentlemen to dine with him\r\nafter your visit to the hermitage. At one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, not later. And you\r\nalso,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, addressing Maximov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I certainly will, without fail,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch, hugely\r\ndelighted at the invitation. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd, believe me, we\xe2\x80\x99ve all given our word\r\nto behave properly here.... And you, Pyotr Alexandrovitch, will you go,\r\ntoo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, of course. What have I come for but to study all the customs\r\nhere? The only obstacle to me is your company....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Dmitri Fyodorovitch is non\xe2\x80\x90existent as yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be a capital thing if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t turn up. Do you suppose I\r\nlike all this business, and in your company, too? So we will come to\r\ndinner. Thank the Father Superior,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the monk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is my duty now to conduct you to the elder,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the monk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf so I\xe2\x80\x99ll go straight to the Father Superior\xe2\x80\x94to the Father Superior,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nbabbled Maximov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Father Superior is engaged just now. But as you please\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d the monk\r\nhesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpertinent old man!\xe2\x80\x9d Mi\xc3\xbcsov observed aloud, while Maximov ran back to\r\nthe monastery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s like von Sohn,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch said suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all you can think of?... In what way is he like von Sohn? Have\r\nyou ever seen von Sohn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve seen his portrait. It\xe2\x80\x99s not the features, but something\r\nindefinable. He\xe2\x80\x99s a second von Sohn. I can always tell from the\r\nphysiognomy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I dare say you are a connoisseur in that. But, look here, Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch, you said just now that we had given our word to behave\r\nproperly. Remember it. I advise you to control yourself. But, if you\r\nbegin to play the fool I don\xe2\x80\x99t intend to be associated with you\r\nhere.... You see what a man he is\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he turned to the monk\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid to\r\ngo among decent people with him.\xe2\x80\x9d A fine smile, not without a certain\r\nslyness, came on to the pale, bloodless lips of the monk, but he made\r\nno reply, and was evidently silent from a sense of his own dignity.\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov frowned more than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, devil take them all! An outer show elaborated through centuries,\r\nand nothing but charlatanism and nonsense underneath,\xe2\x80\x9d flashed through\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the hermitage. We\xe2\x80\x99ve arrived,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\ngates are shut.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he repeatedly made the sign of the cross to the saints painted\r\nabove and on the sides of the gates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you go to Rome you must do as the Romans do. Here in this\r\nhermitage there are twenty\xe2\x80\x90five saints being saved. They look at one\r\nanother, and eat cabbages. And not one woman goes in at this gate.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s what is remarkable. And that really is so. But I did hear that\r\nthe elder receives ladies,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked suddenly to the monk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWomen of the people are here too now, lying in the portico there\r\nwaiting. But for ladies of higher rank two rooms have been built\r\nadjoining the portico, but outside the precincts\xe2\x80\x94you can see the\r\nwindows\xe2\x80\x94and the elder goes out to them by an inner passage when he is\r\nwell enough. They are always outside the precincts. There is a Harkov\r\nlady, Madame Hohlakov, waiting there now with her sick daughter.\r\nProbably he has promised to come out to her, though of late he has been\r\nso weak that he has hardly shown himself even to the people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then there are loopholes, after all, to creep out of the hermitage\r\nto the ladies. Don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose, holy father, that I mean any harm. But do\r\nyou know that at Athos not only the visits of women are not allowed,\r\nbut no creature of the female sex\xe2\x80\x94no hens, nor turkey\xe2\x80\x90hens, nor cows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFyodor Pavlovitch, I warn you I shall go back and leave you here.\r\nThey\xe2\x80\x99ll turn you out when I\xe2\x80\x99m gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99m not interfering with you, Pyotr Alexandrovitch. Look,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncried suddenly, stepping within the precincts, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a vale of roses\r\nthey live in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough there were no roses now, there were numbers of rare and\r\nbeautiful autumn flowers growing wherever there was space for them, and\r\nevidently tended by a skillful hand; there were flower\xe2\x80\x90beds round the\r\nchurch, and between the tombs; and the one\xe2\x80\x90storied wooden house where\r\nthe elder lived was also surrounded with flowers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd was it like this in the time of the last elder, Varsonofy? He\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t care for such elegance. They say he used to jump up and thrash\r\neven ladies with a stick,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Fyodor Pavlovitch, as he went up\r\nthe steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe elder Varsonofy did sometimes seem rather strange, but a great\r\ndeal that\xe2\x80\x99s told is foolishness. He never thrashed any one,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nthe monk. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, gentlemen, if you will wait a minute I will announce\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFyodor Pavlovitch, for the last time, your compact, do you hear?\r\nBehave properly or I will pay you out!\xe2\x80\x9d Mi\xc3\xbcsov had time to mutter\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t think why you are so agitated,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch observed\r\nsarcastically. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you uneasy about your sins? They say he can tell by\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s eyes what one has come about. And what a lot you think of their\r\nopinion! you, a Parisian, and so advanced. I\xe2\x80\x99m surprised at you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Mi\xc3\xbcsov had no time to reply to this sarcasm. They were asked to\r\ncome in. He walked in, somewhat irritated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I know myself, I am annoyed, I shall lose my temper and begin to\r\nquarrel\xe2\x80\x94and lower myself and my ideas,\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II.\r\nThe Old Buffoon\r\n\r\n\r\nThey entered the room almost at the same moment that the elder came in\r\nfrom his bedroom. There were already in the cell, awaiting the elder,\r\ntwo monks of the hermitage, one the Father Librarian, and the other\r\nFather Pa\xc3\xafssy, a very learned man, so they said, in delicate health,\r\nthough not old. There was also a tall young man, who looked about two\r\nand twenty, standing in the corner throughout the interview. He had a\r\nbroad, fresh face, and clever, observant, narrow brown eyes, and was\r\nwearing ordinary dress. He was a divinity student, living under the\r\nprotection of the monastery. His expression was one of unquestioning,\r\nbut self\xe2\x80\x90respecting, reverence. Being in a subordinate and dependent\r\nposition, and so not on an equality with the guests, he did not greet\r\nthem with a bow.\r\n\r\nFather Zossima was accompanied by a novice, and by Alyosha. The two\r\nmonks rose and greeted him with a very deep bow, touching the ground\r\nwith their fingers; then kissed his hand. Blessing them, the elder\r\nreplied with as deep a reverence to them, and asked their blessing. The\r\nwhole ceremony was performed very seriously and with an appearance of\r\nfeeling, not like an everyday rite. But Mi\xc3\xbcsov fancied that it was all\r\ndone with intentional impressiveness. He stood in front of the other\r\nvisitors. He ought\xe2\x80\x94he had reflected upon it the evening before\xe2\x80\x94from\r\nsimple politeness, since it was the custom here, to have gone up to\r\nreceive the elder\xe2\x80\x99s blessing, even if he did not kiss his hand. But\r\nwhen he saw all this bowing and kissing on the part of the monks he\r\ninstantly changed his mind. With dignified gravity he made a rather\r\ndeep, conventional bow, and moved away to a chair. Fyodor Pavlovitch\r\ndid the same, mimicking Mi\xc3\xbcsov like an ape. Ivan bowed with great\r\ndignity and courtesy, but he too kept his hands at his sides, while\r\nKalganov was so confused that he did not bow at all. The elder let fall\r\nthe hand raised to bless them, and bowing to them again, asked them all\r\nto sit down. The blood rushed to Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks. He was ashamed. His\r\nforebodings were coming true.\r\n\r\nFather Zossima sat down on a very old\xe2\x80\x90fashioned mahogany sofa, covered\r\nwith leather, and made his visitors sit down in a row along the\r\nopposite wall on four mahogany chairs, covered with shabby black\r\nleather. The monks sat, one at the door and the other at the window.\r\nThe divinity student, the novice, and Alyosha remained standing. The\r\ncell was not very large and had a faded look. It contained nothing but\r\nthe most necessary furniture, of coarse and poor quality. There were\r\ntwo pots of flowers in the window, and a number of holy pictures in the\r\ncorner. Before one huge ancient ikon of the Virgin a lamp was burning.\r\nNear it were two other holy pictures in shining settings, and, next\r\nthem, carved cherubims, china eggs, a Catholic cross of ivory, with a\r\nMater Dolorosa embracing it, and several foreign engravings from the\r\ngreat Italian artists of past centuries. Next to these costly and\r\nartistic engravings were several of the roughest Russian prints of\r\nsaints and martyrs, such as are sold for a few farthings at all the\r\nfairs. On the other walls were portraits of Russian bishops, past and\r\npresent.\r\n\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov took a cursory glance at all these \xe2\x80\x9cconventional\xe2\x80\x9d surroundings\r\nand bent an intent look upon the elder. He had a high opinion of his\r\nown insight, a weakness excusable in him as he was fifty, an age at\r\nwhich a clever man of the world of established position can hardly help\r\ntaking himself rather seriously. At the first moment he did not like\r\nZossima. There was, indeed, something in the elder\xe2\x80\x99s face which many\r\npeople besides Mi\xc3\xbcsov might not have liked. He was a short, bent,\r\nlittle man, with very weak legs, and though he was only sixty\xe2\x80\x90five, he\r\nlooked at least ten years older. His face was very thin and covered\r\nwith a network of fine wrinkles, particularly numerous about his eyes,\r\nwhich were small, light\xe2\x80\x90colored, quick, and shining like two bright\r\npoints. He had a sprinkling of gray hair about his temples. His pointed\r\nbeard was small and scanty, and his lips, which smiled frequently, were\r\nas thin as two threads. His nose was not long, but sharp, like a bird\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo all appearances a malicious soul, full of petty pride,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov. He felt altogether dissatisfied with his position.\r\n\r\nA cheap little clock on the wall struck twelve hurriedly, and served to\r\nbegin the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely to our time,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch, \xe2\x80\x9cbut no sign of my\r\nson, Dmitri. I apologize for him, sacred elder!\xe2\x80\x9d (Alyosha shuddered all\r\nover at \xe2\x80\x9csacred elder.\xe2\x80\x9d) \xe2\x80\x9cI am always punctual myself, minute for\r\nminute, remembering that punctuality is the courtesy of kings....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are not a king, anyway,\xe2\x80\x9d Mi\xc3\xbcsov muttered, losing his self\xe2\x80\x90\r\nrestraint at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; that\xe2\x80\x99s true. I\xe2\x80\x99m not a king, and, would you believe it, Pyotr\r\nAlexandrovitch, I was aware of that myself. But, there! I always say\r\nthe wrong thing. Your reverence,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, with sudden pathos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nbehold before you a buffoon in earnest! I introduce myself as such.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s an old habit, alas! And if I sometimes talk nonsense out of place\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s with an object, with the object of amusing people and making\r\nmyself agreeable. One must be agreeable, mustn\xe2\x80\x99t one? I was seven years\r\nago in a little town where I had business, and I made friends with some\r\nmerchants there. We went to the captain of police because we had to see\r\nhim about something, and to ask him to dine with us. He was a tall,\r\nfat, fair, sulky man, the most dangerous type in such cases. It\xe2\x80\x99s their\r\nliver. I went straight up to him, and with the ease of a man of the\r\nworld, you know, \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Ispravnik,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98be our Napravnik.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98What do\r\nyou mean by Napravnik?\xe2\x80\x99 said he. I saw, at the first half\xe2\x80\x90second, that\r\nit had missed fire. He stood there so glum. \xe2\x80\x98I wanted to make a joke,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid I, \xe2\x80\x98for the general diversion, as Mr. Napravnik is our well\xe2\x80\x90known\r\nRussian orchestra conductor and what we need for the harmony of our\r\nundertaking is some one of that sort.\xe2\x80\x99 And I explained my comparison\r\nvery reasonably, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I? \xe2\x80\x98Excuse me,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98I am an Ispravnik,\r\nand I do not allow puns to be made on my calling.\xe2\x80\x99 He turned and walked\r\naway. I followed him, shouting, \xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes, you are an Ispravnik, not a\r\nNapravnik.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98since you called me a Napravnik I am one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nAnd would you believe it, it ruined our business! And I\xe2\x80\x99m always like\r\nthat, always like that. Always injuring myself with my politeness.\r\nOnce, many years ago, I said to an influential person: \xe2\x80\x98Your wife is a\r\nticklish lady,\xe2\x80\x99 in an honorable sense, of the moral qualities, so to\r\nspeak. But he asked me, \xe2\x80\x98Why, have you tickled her?\xe2\x80\x99 I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\npolite, so I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help saying, \xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 and he gave me a fine\r\ntickling on the spot. Only that happened long ago, so I\xe2\x80\x99m not ashamed\r\nto tell the story. I\xe2\x80\x99m always injuring myself like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re doing it now,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Mi\xc3\xbcsov, with disgust.\r\n\r\nFather Zossima scrutinized them both in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I? Would you believe it, I was aware of that, too, Pyotr\r\nAlexandrovitch, and let me tell you, indeed, I foresaw I should as soon\r\nas I began to speak. And do you know I foresaw, too, that you\xe2\x80\x99d be the\r\nfirst to remark on it. The minute I see my joke isn\xe2\x80\x99t coming off, your\r\nreverence, both my cheeks feel as though they were drawn down to the\r\nlower jaw and there is almost a spasm in them. That\xe2\x80\x99s been so since I\r\nwas young, when I had to make jokes for my living in noblemen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfamilies. I am an inveterate buffoon, and have been from birth up, your\r\nreverence, it\xe2\x80\x99s as though it were a craze in me. I dare say it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ndevil within me. But only a little one. A more serious one would have\r\nchosen another lodging. But not your soul, Pyotr Alexandrovitch; you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nnot a lodging worth having either. But I do believe\xe2\x80\x94I believe in God,\r\nthough I have had doubts of late. But now I sit and await words of\r\nwisdom. I\xe2\x80\x99m like the philosopher, Diderot, your reverence. Did you ever\r\nhear, most Holy Father, how Diderot went to see the Metropolitan\r\nPlaton, in the time of the Empress Catherine? He went in and said\r\nstraight out, \xe2\x80\x98There is no God.\xe2\x80\x99 To which the great bishop lifted up\r\nhis finger and answered, \xe2\x80\x98The fool hath said in his heart there is no\r\nGod.\xe2\x80\x99 And he fell down at his feet on the spot. \xe2\x80\x98I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 he cried,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and will be christened.\xe2\x80\x99 And so he was. Princess Dashkov was his\r\ngodmother, and Potyomkin his godfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFyodor Pavlovitch, this is unbearable! You know you\xe2\x80\x99re telling lies\r\nand that that stupid anecdote isn\xe2\x80\x99t true. Why are you playing the\r\nfool?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mi\xc3\xbcsov in a shaking voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suspected all my life that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t true,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch cried\r\nwith conviction. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you the whole truth, gentlemen. Great\r\nelder! Forgive me, the last thing about Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s christening I made up\r\njust now. I never thought of it before. I made it up to add piquancy. I\r\nplay the fool, Pyotr Alexandrovitch, to make myself agreeable. Though I\r\nreally don\xe2\x80\x99t know myself, sometimes, what I do it for. And as for\r\nDiderot, I heard as far as \xe2\x80\x98the fool hath said in his heart\xe2\x80\x99 twenty\r\ntimes from the gentry about here when I was young. I heard your aunt,\r\nPyotr Alexandrovitch, tell the story. They all believe to this day that\r\nthe infidel Diderot came to dispute about God with the Metropolitan\r\nPlaton....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMi\xc3\xbcsov got up, forgetting himself in his impatience. He was furious,\r\nand conscious of being ridiculous.\r\n\r\nWhat was taking place in the cell was really incredible. For forty or\r\nfifty years past, from the times of former elders, no visitors had\r\nentered that cell without feelings of the profoundest veneration.\r\nAlmost every one admitted to the cell felt that a great favor was being\r\nshown him. Many remained kneeling during the whole visit. Of those\r\nvisitors, many had been men of high rank and learning, some even\r\nfreethinkers, attracted by curiosity, but all without exception had\r\nshown the profoundest reverence and delicacy, for here there was no\r\nquestion of money, but only, on the one side love and kindness, and on\r\nthe other penitence and eager desire to decide some spiritual problem\r\nor crisis. So that such buffoonery amazed and bewildered the\r\nspectators, or at least some of them. The monks, with unchanged\r\ncountenances, waited, with earnest attention, to hear what the elder\r\nwould say, but seemed on the point of standing up, like Mi\xc3\xbcsov. Alyosha\r\nstood, with hanging head, on the verge of tears. What seemed to him\r\nstrangest of all was that his brother Ivan, on whom alone he had rested\r\nhis hopes, and who alone had such influence on his father that he could\r\nhave stopped him, sat now quite unmoved, with downcast eyes, apparently\r\nwaiting with interest to see how it would end, as though he had nothing\r\nto do with it. Alyosha did not dare to look at Rakitin, the divinity\r\nstudent, whom he knew almost intimately. He alone in the monastery knew\r\nRakitin\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d began Mi\xc3\xbcsov, addressing Father Zossima, \xe2\x80\x9cfor perhaps I\r\nseem to be taking part in this shameful foolery. I made a mistake in\r\nbelieving that even a man like Fyodor Pavlovitch would understand what\r\nwas due on a visit to so honored a personage. I did not suppose I\r\nshould have to apologize simply for having come with him....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPyotr Alexandrovitch could say no more, and was about to leave the\r\nroom, overwhelmed with confusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t distress yourself, I beg.\xe2\x80\x9d The elder got on to his feeble legs,\r\nand taking Pyotr Alexandrovitch by both hands, made him sit down again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you not to disturb yourself. I particularly beg you to be my\r\nguest.\xe2\x80\x9d And with a bow he went back and sat down again on his little\r\nsofa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat elder, speak! Make yourself\r\nquite at home. And, above all, do not be so ashamed of yourself, for\r\nthat is at the root of it all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite at home? To be my natural self? I will not go so\r\nfar as that myself. I warn you for your own sake. Well, the rest is\r\nstill plunged in the mists of uncertainty, though there are people\r\nwho\xe2\x80\x99d be pleased to describe me for you. I mean that for you, Pyotr\r\nAlexandrovitch. But as for you, holy being, let me tell you, I am\r\nbrimming over with ecstasy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe got up, and throwing up his hands, declaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cBlessed be the womb\r\nthat bare thee, and the paps that gave thee suck\xe2\x80\x94the paps especially.\r\nWhen you said just now, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be so ashamed of yourself, for that is\r\nat the root of it all,\xe2\x80\x99 you pierced right through me by that remark,\r\nand read me to the core. Indeed, I always feel when I meet people that\r\nI am lower than all, and that they all take me for a buffoon. So I say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me really play the buffoon. I am not afraid of your opinion, for\r\nyou are every one of you worse than I am.\xe2\x80\x99 That is why I am a buffoon.\r\nIt is from shame, great elder, from shame; it\xe2\x80\x99s simply\r\nover\xe2\x80\x90sensitiveness that makes me rowdy. If I had only been sure that\r\nevery one would accept me as the kindest and wisest of men, oh, Lord,\r\nwhat a good man I should have been then! Teacher!\xe2\x80\x9d he fell suddenly on\r\nhis knees, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat must I do to gain eternal life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was difficult even now to decide whether he was joking or really\r\nmoved.\r\n\r\nFather Zossima, lifting his eyes, looked at him, and said with a smile:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have known for a long time what you must do. You have sense\r\nenough: don\xe2\x80\x99t give way to drunkenness and incontinence of speech; don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngive way to sensual lust; and, above all, to the love of money. And\r\nclose your taverns. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t close all, at least two or three. And,\r\nabove all\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t lie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean about Diderot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not about Diderot. Above all, don\xe2\x80\x99t lie to yourself. The man who\r\nlies to himself and listens to his own lie comes to such a pass that he\r\ncannot distinguish the truth within him, or around him, and so loses\r\nall respect for himself and for others. And having no respect he ceases\r\nto love, and in order to occupy and distract himself without love he\r\ngives way to passions and coarse pleasures, and sinks to bestiality in\r\nhis vices, all from continual lying to other men and to himself. The\r\nman who lies to himself can be more easily offended than any one. You\r\nknow it is sometimes very pleasant to take offense, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? A man may\r\nknow that nobody has insulted him, but that he has invented the insult\r\nfor himself, has lied and exaggerated to make it picturesque, has\r\ncaught at a word and made a mountain out of a molehill\xe2\x80\x94he knows that\r\nhimself, yet he will be the first to take offense, and will revel in\r\nhis resentment till he feels great pleasure in it, and so pass to\r\ngenuine vindictiveness. But get up, sit down, I beg you. All this, too,\r\nis deceitful posturing....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlessed man! Give me your hand to kiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch skipped up, and imprinted a rapid kiss on the elder\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthin hand. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is, it is pleasant to take offense. You said that so\r\nwell, as I never heard it before. Yes, I have been all my life taking\r\noffense, to please myself, taking offense on esthetic grounds, for it\r\nis not so much pleasant as distinguished sometimes to be insulted\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nyou had forgotten, great elder, it is distinguished! I shall make a\r\nnote of that. But I have been lying, lying positively my whole life\r\nlong, every day and hour of it. Of a truth, I am a lie, and the father\r\nof lies. Though I believe I am not the father of lies. I am getting\r\nmixed in my texts. Say, the son of lies, and that will be enough. Only\r\n... my angel ... I may sometimes talk about Diderot! Diderot will do no\r\nharm, though sometimes a word will do harm. Great elder, by the way, I\r\nwas forgetting, though I had been meaning for the last two years to\r\ncome here on purpose to ask and to find out something. Only do tell\r\nPyotr Alexandrovitch not to interrupt me. Here is my question: Is it\r\ntrue, great Father, that the story is told somewhere in the _Lives of\r\nthe Saints_ of a holy saint martyred for his faith who, when his head\r\nwas cut off at last, stood up, picked up his head, and, \xe2\x80\x98courteously\r\nkissing it,\xe2\x80\x99 walked a long way, carrying it in his hands. Is that true\r\nor not, honored Father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is untrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said the elder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is nothing of the kind in all the lives of the saints. What\r\nsaint do you say the story is told of?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Father Librarian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know what saint. I do not know, and can\xe2\x80\x99t tell. I was\r\ndeceived. I was told the story. I had heard it, and do you know who\r\ntold it? Pyotr Alexandrovitch Mi\xc3\xbcsov here, who was so angry just now\r\nabout Diderot. He it was who told the story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have never told it you, I never speak to you at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true you did not tell me, but you told it when I was present. It\r\nwas three years ago. I mentioned it because by that ridiculous story\r\nyou shook my faith, Pyotr Alexandrovitch. You knew nothing of it, but I\r\nwent home with my faith shaken, and I have been getting more and more\r\nshaken ever since. Yes, Pyotr Alexandrovitch, you were the cause of a\r\ngreat fall. That was not a Diderot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch got excited and pathetic, though it was perfectly\r\nclear to every one by now that he was playing a part again. Yet Mi\xc3\xbcsov\r\nwas stung by his words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat nonsense, and it is all nonsense,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered. \xe2\x80\x9cI may really\r\nhave told it, some time or other ... but not to you. I was told it\r\nmyself. I heard it in Paris from a Frenchman. He told me it was read at\r\nour mass from the _Lives of the Saints_ ... he was a very learned man\r\nwho had made a special study of Russian statistics and had lived a long\r\ntime in Russia.... I have not read the _Lives of the Saints_ myself,\r\nand I am not going to read them ... all sorts of things are said at\r\ndinner\xe2\x80\x94we were dining then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you were dining then, and so I lost my faith!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch, mimicking him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I care for your faith?\xe2\x80\x9d Mi\xc3\xbcsov was on the point of shouting,\r\nbut he suddenly checked himself, and said with contempt, \xe2\x80\x9cYou defile\r\neverything you touch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe elder suddenly rose from his seat. \xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, gentlemen, for\r\nleaving you a few minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing all his guests. \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nvisitors awaiting me who arrived before you. But don\xe2\x80\x99t you tell lies\r\nall the same,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to Fyodor Pavlovitch with a\r\ngood\xe2\x80\x90humored face. He went out of the cell. Alyosha and the novice flew\r\nto escort him down the steps. Alyosha was breathless: he was glad to\r\nget away, but he was glad, too, that the elder was good\xe2\x80\x90humored and not\r\noffended. Father Zossima was going towards the portico to bless the\r\npeople waiting for him there. But Fyodor Pavlovitch persisted in\r\nstopping him at the door of the cell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlessed man!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, with feeling. \xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to kiss your hand once\r\nmore. Yes, with you I could still talk, I could still get on. Do you\r\nthink I always lie and play the fool like this? Believe me, I have been\r\nacting like this all the time on purpose to try you. I have been\r\ntesting you all the time to see whether I could get on with you. Is\r\nthere room for my humility beside your pride? I am ready to give you a\r\ntestimonial that one can get on with you! But now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be quiet; I\r\nwill keep quiet all the time. I\xe2\x80\x99ll sit in a chair and hold my tongue.\r\nNow it is for you to speak, Pyotr Alexandrovitch. You are the principal\r\nperson left now\xe2\x80\x94for ten minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III.\r\nPeasant Women Who Have Faith\r\n\r\n\r\nNear the wooden portico below, built on to the outer wall of the\r\nprecinct, there was a crowd of about twenty peasant women. They had\r\nbeen told that the elder was at last coming out, and they had gathered\r\ntogether in anticipation. Two ladies, Madame Hohlakov and her daughter,\r\nhad also come out into the portico to wait for the elder, but in a\r\nseparate part of it set aside for women of rank.\r\n\r\nMadame Hohlakov was a wealthy lady, still young and attractive, and\r\nalways dressed with taste. She was rather pale, and had lively black\r\neyes. She was not more than thirty\xe2\x80\x90three, and had been five years a\r\nwidow. Her daughter, a girl of fourteen, was partially paralyzed. The\r\npoor child had not been able to walk for the last six months, and was\r\nwheeled about in a long reclining chair. She had a charming little\r\nface, rather thin from illness, but full of gayety. There was a gleam\r\nof mischief in her big dark eyes with their long lashes. Her mother had\r\nbeen intending to take her abroad ever since the spring, but they had\r\nbeen detained all the summer by business connected with their estate.\r\nThey had been staying a week in our town, where they had come more for\r\npurposes of business than devotion, but had visited Father Zossima once\r\nalready, three days before. Though they knew that the elder scarcely\r\nsaw any one, they had now suddenly turned up again, and urgently\r\nentreated \xe2\x80\x9cthe happiness of looking once again on the great healer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother was sitting on a chair by the side of her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s invalid\r\ncarriage, and two paces from her stood an old monk, not one of our\r\nmonastery, but a visitor from an obscure religious house in the far\r\nnorth. He too sought the elder\xe2\x80\x99s blessing.\r\n\r\nBut Father Zossima, on entering the portico, went first straight to the\r\npeasants who were crowded at the foot of the three steps that led up\r\ninto the portico. Father Zossima stood on the top step, put on his\r\nstole, and began blessing the women who thronged about him. One crazy\r\nwoman was led up to him. As soon as she caught sight of the elder she\r\nbegan shrieking and writhing as though in the pains of childbirth.\r\nLaying the stole on her forehead, he read a short prayer over her, and\r\nshe was at once soothed and quieted.\r\n\r\nI do not know how it may be now, but in my childhood I often happened\r\nto see and hear these \xe2\x80\x9cpossessed\xe2\x80\x9d women in the villages and\r\nmonasteries. They used to be brought to mass; they would squeal and\r\nbark like a dog so that they were heard all over the church. But when\r\nthe sacrament was carried in and they were led up to it, at once the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpossession\xe2\x80\x9d ceased, and the sick women were always soothed for a time.\r\nI was greatly impressed and amazed at this as a child; but then I heard\r\nfrom country neighbors and from my town teachers that the whole illness\r\nwas simulated to avoid work, and that it could always be cured by\r\nsuitable severity; various anecdotes were told to confirm this. But\r\nlater on I learnt with astonishment from medical specialists that there\r\nis no pretense about it, that it is a terrible illness to which women\r\nare subject, specially prevalent among us in Russia, and that it is due\r\nto the hard lot of the peasant women. It is a disease, I was told,\r\narising from exhausting toil too soon after hard, abnormal and\r\nunassisted labor in childbirth, and from the hopeless misery, from\r\nbeatings, and so on, which some women were not able to endure like\r\nothers. The strange and instant healing of the frantic and struggling\r\nwoman as soon as she was led up to the holy sacrament, which had been\r\nexplained to me as due to malingering and the trickery of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cclericals,\xe2\x80\x9d arose probably in the most natural manner. Both the women\r\nwho supported her and the invalid herself fully believed as a truth\r\nbeyond question that the evil spirit in possession of her could not\r\nhold out if the sick woman were brought to the sacrament and made to\r\nbow down before it. And so, with a nervous and psychically deranged\r\nwoman, a sort of convulsion of the whole organism always took place,\r\nand was bound to take place, at the moment of bowing down to the\r\nsacrament, aroused by the expectation of the miracle of healing and the\r\nimplicit belief that it would come to pass; and it did come to pass,\r\nthough only for a moment. It was exactly the same now as soon as the\r\nelder touched the sick woman with the stole.\r\n\r\nMany of the women in the crowd were moved to tears of ecstasy by the\r\neffect of the moment: some strove to kiss the hem of his garment,\r\nothers cried out in sing\xe2\x80\x90song voices.\r\n\r\nHe blessed them all and talked with some of them. The \xe2\x80\x9cpossessed\xe2\x80\x9d woman\r\nhe knew already. She came from a village only six versts from the\r\nmonastery, and had been brought to him before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut here is one from afar.\xe2\x80\x9d He pointed to a woman by no means old but\r\nvery thin and wasted, with a face not merely sunburnt but almost\r\nblackened by exposure. She was kneeling and gazing with a fixed stare\r\nat the elder; there was something almost frenzied in her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom afar off, Father, from afar off! From two hundred miles from\r\nhere. From afar off, Father, from afar off!\xe2\x80\x9d the woman began in a\r\nsing\xe2\x80\x90song voice as though she were chanting a dirge, swaying her head\r\nfrom side to side with her cheek resting in her hand.\r\n\r\nThere is silent and long\xe2\x80\x90suffering sorrow to be met with among the\r\npeasantry. It withdraws into itself and is still. But there is a grief\r\nthat breaks out, and from that minute it bursts into tears and finds\r\nvent in wailing. This is particularly common with women. But it is no\r\nlighter a grief than the silent. Lamentations comfort only by\r\nlacerating the heart still more. Such grief does not desire\r\nconsolation. It feeds on the sense of its hopelessness. Lamentations\r\nspring only from the constant craving to reopen the wound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are of the tradesman class?\xe2\x80\x9d said Father Zossima, looking\r\ncuriously at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTownfolk we are, Father, townfolk. Yet we are peasants though we live\r\nin the town. I have come to see you, O Father! We heard of you, Father,\r\nwe heard of you. I have buried my little son, and I have come on a\r\npilgrimage. I have been in three monasteries, but they told me, \xe2\x80\x98Go,\r\nNastasya, go to them\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94that is to you. I have come; I was yesterday at\r\nthe service, and to\xe2\x80\x90day I have come to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you weeping for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my little son I\xe2\x80\x99m grieving for, Father. He was three years\r\nold\xe2\x80\x94three years all but three months. For my little boy, Father, I\xe2\x80\x99m in\r\nanguish, for my little boy. He was the last one left. We had four, my\r\nNikita and I, and now we\xe2\x80\x99ve no children, our dear ones have all gone. I\r\nburied the first three without grieving overmuch, and now I have buried\r\nthe last I can\xe2\x80\x99t forget him. He seems always standing before me. He\r\nnever leaves me. He has withered my heart. I look at his little\r\nclothes, his little shirt, his little boots, and I wail. I lay out all\r\nthat is left of him, all his little things. I look at them and wail. I\r\nsay to Nikita, my husband, \xe2\x80\x98Let me go on a pilgrimage, master.\xe2\x80\x99 He is a\r\ndriver. We\xe2\x80\x99re not poor people, Father, not poor; he drives our own\r\nhorse. It\xe2\x80\x99s all our own, the horse and the carriage. And what good is\r\nit all to us now? My Nikita has begun drinking while I am away. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsure to. It used to be so before. As soon as I turn my back he gives\r\nway to it. But now I don\xe2\x80\x99t think about him. It\xe2\x80\x99s three months since I\r\nleft home. I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten him. I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten everything. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nto remember. And what would our life be now together? I\xe2\x80\x99ve done with\r\nhim, I\xe2\x80\x99ve done. I\xe2\x80\x99ve done with them all. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care to look upon my\r\nhouse and my goods. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care to see anything at all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the elder. \xe2\x80\x9cOnce in olden times a holy saint saw\r\nin the Temple a mother like you weeping for her little one, her only\r\none, whom God had taken. \xe2\x80\x98Knowest thou not,\xe2\x80\x99 said the saint to her,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98how bold these little ones are before the throne of God? Verily there\r\nare none bolder than they in the Kingdom of Heaven. \xe2\x80\x9cThou didst give us\r\nlife, O Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d they say, \xe2\x80\x9cand scarcely had we looked upon it when Thou\r\ndidst take it back again.\xe2\x80\x9d And so boldly they ask and ask again that\r\nGod gives them at once the rank of angels. Therefore,\xe2\x80\x99 said the saint,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98thou, too, O mother, rejoice and weep not, for thy little son is with\r\nthe Lord in the fellowship of the angels.\xe2\x80\x99 That\xe2\x80\x99s what the saint said\r\nto the weeping mother of old. He was a great saint and he could not\r\nhave spoken falsely. Therefore you too, mother, know that your little\r\none is surely before the throne of God, is rejoicing and happy, and\r\npraying to God for you, and therefore weep not, but rejoice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman listened to him, looking down with her cheek in her hand. She\r\nsighed deeply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Nikita tried to comfort me with the same words as you. \xe2\x80\x98Foolish\r\none,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98why weep? Our son is no doubt singing with the angels\r\nbefore God.\xe2\x80\x99 He says that to me, but he weeps himself. I see that he\r\ncries like me. \xe2\x80\x98I know, Nikita,\xe2\x80\x99 said I. \xe2\x80\x98Where could he be if not with\r\nthe Lord God? Only, here with us now he is not as he used to sit beside\r\nus before.\xe2\x80\x99 And if only I could look upon him one little time, if only\r\nI could peep at him one little time, without going up to him, without\r\nspeaking, if I could be hidden in a corner and only see him for one\r\nlittle minute, hear him playing in the yard, calling in his little\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x98Mammy, where are you?\xe2\x80\x99 If only I could hear him pattering with\r\nhis little feet about the room just once, only once; for so often, so\r\noften I remember how he used to run to me and shout and laugh, if only\r\nI could hear his little feet I should know him! But he\xe2\x80\x99s gone, Father,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s gone, and I shall never hear him again. Here\xe2\x80\x99s his little sash,\r\nbut him I shall never see or hear now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe drew out of her bosom her boy\xe2\x80\x99s little embroidered sash, and as\r\nsoon as she looked at it she began shaking with sobs, hiding her eyes\r\nwith her fingers through which the tears flowed in a sudden stream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Rachel of old,\xe2\x80\x9d said the elder, \xe2\x80\x9cweeping for her children, and\r\nwill not be comforted because they are not. Such is the lot set on\r\nearth for you mothers. Be not comforted. Consolation is not what you\r\nneed. Weep and be not consoled, but weep. Only every time that you weep\r\nbe sure to remember that your little son is one of the angels of God,\r\nthat he looks down from there at you and sees you, and rejoices at your\r\ntears, and points at them to the Lord God; and a long while yet will\r\nyou keep that great mother\xe2\x80\x99s grief. But it will turn in the end into\r\nquiet joy, and your bitter tears will be only tears of tender sorrow\r\nthat purifies the heart and delivers it from sin. And I shall pray for\r\nthe peace of your child\xe2\x80\x99s soul. What was his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlexey, Father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sweet name. After Alexey, the man of God?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a saint he was! I will remember him, mother, and your grief in my\r\nprayers, and I will pray for your husband\xe2\x80\x99s health. It is a sin for you\r\nto leave him. Your little one will see from heaven that you have\r\nforsaken his father, and will weep over you. Why do you trouble his\r\nhappiness? He is living, for the soul lives for ever, and though he is\r\nnot in the house he is near you, unseen. How can he go into the house\r\nwhen you say that the house is hateful to you? To whom is he to go if\r\nhe find you not together, his father and mother? He comes to you in\r\ndreams now, and you grieve. But then he will send you gentle dreams. Go\r\nto your husband, mother; go this very day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go, Father, at your word. I will go. You\xe2\x80\x99ve gone straight to my\r\nheart. My Nikita, my Nikita, you are waiting for me,\xe2\x80\x9d the woman began\r\nin a sing\xe2\x80\x90song voice; but the elder had already turned away to a very\r\nold woman, dressed like a dweller in the town, not like a pilgrim. Her\r\neyes showed that she had come with an object, and in order to say\r\nsomething. She said she was the widow of a non\xe2\x80\x90commissioned officer,\r\nand lived close by in the town. Her son Vasenka was in the commissariat\r\nservice, and had gone to Irkutsk in Siberia. He had written twice from\r\nthere, but now a year had passed since he had written. She did inquire\r\nabout him, but she did not know the proper place to inquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly the other day Stepanida Ilyinishna\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s a rich merchant\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x94said to me, \xe2\x80\x98You go, Prohorovna, and put your son\xe2\x80\x99s name down for\r\nprayer in the church, and pray for the peace of his soul as though he\r\nwere dead. His soul will be troubled,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98and he will write you\r\na letter.\xe2\x80\x99 And Stepanida Ilyinishna told me it was a certain thing\r\nwhich had been many times tried. Only I am in doubt.... Oh, you light\r\nof ours! is it true or false, and would it be right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think of it. It\xe2\x80\x99s shameful to ask the question. How is it\r\npossible to pray for the peace of a living soul? And his own mother\r\ntoo! It\xe2\x80\x99s a great sin, akin to sorcery. Only for your ignorance it is\r\nforgiven you. Better pray to the Queen of Heaven, our swift defense and\r\nhelp, for his good health, and that she may forgive you for your error.\r\nAnd another thing I will tell you, Prohorovna. Either he will soon come\r\nback to you, your son, or he will be sure to send a letter. Go, and\r\nhenceforward be in peace. Your son is alive, I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Father, God reward you, our benefactor, who prays for all of us\r\nand for our sins!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the elder had already noticed in the crowd two glowing eyes fixed\r\nupon him. An exhausted, consumptive\xe2\x80\x90looking, though young peasant woman\r\nwas gazing at him in silence. Her eyes besought him, but she seemed\r\nafraid to approach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, my child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolve my soul, Father,\xe2\x80\x9d she articulated softly, and slowly sank on\r\nher knees and bowed down at his feet. \xe2\x80\x9cI have sinned, Father. I am\r\nafraid of my sin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe elder sat down on the lower step. The woman crept closer to him,\r\nstill on her knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a widow these three years,\xe2\x80\x9d she began in a half\xe2\x80\x90whisper, with a\r\nsort of shudder. \xe2\x80\x9cI had a hard life with my husband. He was an old man.\r\nHe used to beat me cruelly. He lay ill; I thought looking at him, if he\r\nwere to get well, if he were to get up again, what then? And then the\r\nthought came to me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d said the elder, and he put his ear close to her lips.\r\n\r\nThe woman went on in a low whisper, so that it was almost impossible to\r\ncatch anything. She had soon done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree years ago?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the elder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree years. At first I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think about it, but now I\xe2\x80\x99ve begun to\r\nbe ill, and the thought never leaves me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you come from far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver three hundred miles away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you told it in confession?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have confessed it. Twice I have confessed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you been admitted to Communion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I am afraid. I am afraid to die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear nothing and never be afraid; and don\xe2\x80\x99t fret. If only your\r\npenitence fail not, God will forgive all. There is no sin, and there\r\ncan be no sin on all the earth, which the Lord will not forgive to the\r\ntruly repentant! Man cannot commit a sin so great as to exhaust the\r\ninfinite love of God. Can there be a sin which could exceed the love of\r\nGod? Think only of repentance, continual repentance, but dismiss fear\r\naltogether. Believe that God loves you as you cannot conceive; that He\r\nloves you with your sin, in your sin. It has been said of old that over\r\none repentant sinner there is more joy in heaven than over ten\r\nrighteous men. Go, and fear not. Be not bitter against men. Be not\r\nangry if you are wronged. Forgive the dead man in your heart what wrong\r\nhe did you. Be reconciled with him in truth. If you are penitent, you\r\nlove. And if you love you are of God. All things are atoned for, all\r\nthings are saved by love. If I, a sinner, even as you are, am tender\r\nwith you and have pity on you, how much more will God. Love is such a\r\npriceless treasure that you can redeem the whole world by it, and\r\nexpiate not only your own sins but the sins of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe signed her three times with the cross, took from his own neck a\r\nlittle ikon and put it upon her. She bowed down to the earth without\r\nspeaking.\r\n\r\nHe got up and looked cheerfully at a healthy peasant woman with a tiny\r\nbaby in her arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Vyshegorye, dear Father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive miles you have dragged yourself with the baby. What do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve come to look at you. I have been to you before\xe2\x80\x94or have you\r\nforgotten? You\xe2\x80\x99ve no great memory if you\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten me. They told us\r\nyou were ill. Thinks I, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and see him for myself. Now I see you,\r\nand you\xe2\x80\x99re not ill! You\xe2\x80\x99ll live another twenty years. God bless you!\r\nThere are plenty to pray for you; how should you be ill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you for all, daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, I have a thing to ask, not a great one. Here are sixty\r\ncopecks. Give them, dear Father, to some one poorer than me. I thought\r\nas I came along, better give through him. He\xe2\x80\x99ll know whom to give to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my dear, thanks! You are a good woman. I love you. I will do\r\nso certainly. Is that your little girl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy little girl, Father, Lizaveta.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the Lord bless you both, you and your babe Lizaveta! You have\r\ngladdened my heart, mother. Farewell, dear children, farewell, dear\r\nones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe blessed them all and bowed low to them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV.\r\nA Lady Of Little Faith\r\n\r\n\r\nA visitor looking on the scene of his conversation with the peasants\r\nand his blessing them shed silent tears and wiped them away with her\r\nhandkerchief. She was a sentimental society lady of genuinely good\r\ndisposition in many respects. When the elder went up to her at last she\r\nmet him enthusiastically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what I have been feeling, looking on at this touching scene!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nShe could not go on for emotion. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, I understand the people\xe2\x80\x99s love\r\nfor you. I love the people myself. I want to love them. And who could\r\nhelp loving them, our splendid Russian people, so simple in their\r\ngreatness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is your daughter\xe2\x80\x99s health? You wanted to talk to me again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I have been urgently begging for it, I have prayed for it! I was\r\nready to fall on my knees and kneel for three days at your windows\r\nuntil you let me in. We have come, great healer, to express our ardent\r\ngratitude. You have healed my Lise, healed her completely, merely by\r\npraying over her last Thursday and laying your hands upon her. We have\r\nhastened here to kiss those hands, to pour out our feelings and our\r\nhomage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by healed? But she is still lying down in her chair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut her night fevers have entirely ceased ever since Thursday,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe lady with nervous haste. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd that\xe2\x80\x99s not all. Her legs are\r\nstronger. This morning she got up well; she had slept all night. Look\r\nat her rosy cheeks, her bright eyes! She used to be always crying, but\r\nnow she laughs and is gay and happy. This morning she insisted on my\r\nletting her stand up, and she stood up for a whole minute without any\r\nsupport. She wagers that in a fortnight she\xe2\x80\x99ll be dancing a quadrille.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve called in Doctor Herzenstube. He shrugged his shoulders and said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am amazed; I can make nothing of it.\xe2\x80\x99 And would you have us not come\r\nhere to disturb you, not fly here to thank you? Lise, thank him\xe2\x80\x94thank\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLise\xe2\x80\x99s pretty little laughing face became suddenly serious. She rose in\r\nher chair as far as she could and, looking at the elder, clasped her\r\nhands before him, but could not restrain herself and broke into\r\nlaughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s at him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pointing to Alyosha, with childish vexation at\r\nherself for not being able to repress her mirth.\r\n\r\nIf any one had looked at Alyosha standing a step behind the elder, he\r\nwould have caught a quick flush crimsoning his cheeks in an instant.\r\nHis eyes shone and he looked down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has a message for you, Alexey Fyodorovitch. Lise assumed an important air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKaterina Ivanovna has sent you this through me.\xe2\x80\x9d She handed him a\r\nlittle note. \xe2\x80\x9cShe particularly begs you to go and see her as soon as\r\npossible; that you will not fail her, but will be sure to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe asks me to go and see her? Why, of course, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say. But she wants to\r\nsee you at once. And you will go to her, of course.
