Foma has a room in the house of these sluts here. Foma\r\ncomes from our parts; he was a soldier in our regiment. He does jobs\r\nfor them. He\xe2\x80\x99s watchman at night and goes grouse\xe2\x80\x90shooting in the\r\nday\xe2\x80\x90time; and that\xe2\x80\x99s how he lives. I\xe2\x80\x99ve established myself in his room.\r\nNeither he nor the women of the house know the secret\xe2\x80\x94that is, that I\r\nam on the watch here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one but Smerdyakov knows, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one else. He will let me know if she goes to the old man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was he told you about the money, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. It\xe2\x80\x99s a dead secret. Even Ivan doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know about the money, or\r\nanything. The old man is sending Ivan to Tchermashnya on a two or three\r\ndays\xe2\x80\x99 journey. A purchaser has turned up for the copse: he\xe2\x80\x99ll give\r\neight thousand for the timber. So the old man keeps asking Ivan to help\r\nhim by going to arrange it. It will take him two or three days. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat the old man wants, so that Grushenka can come while he\xe2\x80\x99s away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he\xe2\x80\x99s expecting Grushenka to\xe2\x80\x90day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she won\xe2\x80\x99t come to\xe2\x80\x90day; there are signs. She\xe2\x80\x99s certain not to\r\ncome,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cSmerdyakov thinks so, too. Father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndrinking now. He\xe2\x80\x99s sitting at table with Ivan. Go to him, Alyosha, and\r\nask for the three thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMitya, dear, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alyosha, jumping up\r\nfrom his place, and looking keenly at his brother\xe2\x80\x99s frenzied face. For\r\none moment the thought struck him that Dmitri was mad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? I\xe2\x80\x99m not insane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dmitri, looking intently and\r\nearnestly at him. \xe2\x80\x9cNo fear. I am sending you to father, and I know what\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m saying. I believe in miracles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn miracles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a miracle of Divine Providence. God knows my heart. He sees my\r\ndespair. He sees the whole picture. Surely He won\xe2\x80\x99t let something awful\r\nhappen. Alyosha, I believe in miracles. Go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going. Tell me, will you wait for me here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I know it will take some time. You can\xe2\x80\x99t go at him point blank.\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99s drunk now. I\xe2\x80\x99ll wait three hours\xe2\x80\x94four, five, six, seven. Only\r\nremember you must go to Katerina Ivanovna to\xe2\x80\x90day, if it has to be at\r\nmidnight, _with the money or without the money_, and say, \xe2\x80\x98He sends his\r\ncompliments to you.\xe2\x80\x99 I want you to say that verse to her: \xe2\x80\x98He sends his\r\ncompliments to you.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMitya! And what if Grushenka comes to\xe2\x80\x90day\xe2\x80\x94if not to\xe2\x80\x90day, to\xe2\x80\x90morrow, or\r\nthe next day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrushenka? I shall see her. I shall rush out and prevent it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there\xe2\x80\x99s an if, it will be murder. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t endure it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho will be murdered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old man. I shan\xe2\x80\x99t kill her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother, what are you saying?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.... I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Perhaps I shan\xe2\x80\x99t kill, and perhaps\r\nI shall. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid that he will suddenly become so loathsome to me\r\nwith his face at that moment. I hate his ugly throat, his nose, his\r\neyes, his shameless snigger. I feel a physical repulsion. That\xe2\x80\x99s what\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of. That\xe2\x80\x99s what may be too much for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go, Mitya. I believe that God will order things for the best,\r\nthat nothing awful may happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will sit and wait for the miracle. And if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come to\r\npass\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha went thoughtfully towards his father\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI.\r\nSmerdyakov\r\n\r\n\r\nHe did in fact find his father still at table. Though there was a\r\ndining\xe2\x80\x90 room in the house, the table was laid as usual in the\r\ndrawing\xe2\x80\x90room, which was the largest room, and furnished with\r\nold\xe2\x80\x90fashioned ostentation. The furniture was white and very old,\r\nupholstered in old, red, silky material. In the spaces between the\r\nwindows there were mirrors in elaborate white and gilt frames, of\r\nold\xe2\x80\x90fashioned carving. On the walls, covered with white paper, which\r\nwas torn in many places, there hung two large portraits\xe2\x80\x94one of some\r\nprince who had been governor of the district thirty years before, and\r\nthe other of some bishop, also long since dead. In the corner opposite\r\nthe door there were several ikons, before which a lamp was lighted at\r\nnightfall ... not so much for devotional purposes as to light the room.\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch used to go to bed very late, at three or four o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nin the morning, and would wander about the room at night or sit in an\r\narm\xe2\x80\x90chair, thinking. This had become a habit with him. He often slept\r\nquite alone in the house, sending his servants to the lodge; but\r\nusually Smerdyakov remained, sleeping on a bench in the hall.\r\n\r\nWhen Alyosha came in, dinner was over, but coffee and preserves had\r\nbeen served. Fyodor Pavlovitch liked sweet things with brandy after\r\ndinner. Ivan was also at table, sipping coffee. The servants, Grigory\r\nand Smerdyakov, were standing by. Both the gentlemen and the servants\r\nseemed in singularly good spirits. Fyodor Pavlovitch was roaring with\r\nlaughter. Before he entered the room, Alyosha heard the shrill laugh he\r\nknew so well, and could tell from the sound of it that his father had\r\nonly reached the good\xe2\x80\x90humored stage, and was far from being completely\r\ndrunk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere he is! Here he is!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled Fyodor Pavlovitch, highly delighted at\r\nseeing Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cJoin us. Sit down. Coffee is a lenten dish, but it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhot and good. I don\xe2\x80\x99t offer you brandy, you\xe2\x80\x99re keeping the fast. But\r\nwould you like some? No; I\xe2\x80\x99d better give you some of our famous\r\nliqueur. Smerdyakov, go to the cupboard, the second shelf on the right.\r\nHere are the keys. Look sharp!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha began refusing the liqueur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind. If you won\xe2\x80\x99t have it, we will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fyodor Pavlovitch,\r\nbeaming. \xe2\x80\x9cBut stay\xe2\x80\x94have you dined?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alyosha, who had in truth only eaten a piece of bread\r\nand drunk a glass of kvas in the Father Superior\xe2\x80\x99s kitchen. \xe2\x80\x9cThough I\r\nshould be pleased to have some hot coffee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, my darling! He\xe2\x80\x99ll have some coffee. Does it want warming? No,\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s boiling. It\xe2\x80\x99s capital coffee: Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s making. My Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nan artist at coffee and at fish patties, and at fish soup, too. You\r\nmust come one day and have some fish soup. Let me know beforehand....\r\nBut, stay; didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you this morning to come home with your\r\nmattress and pillow and all? Have you brought your mattress? He he he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, smiling, too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but you were frightened, you were frightened this morning, weren\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou? There, my darling, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do anything to vex you. Do you know,\r\nIvan, I can\xe2\x80\x99t resist the way he looks one straight in the face and\r\nlaughs? It makes me laugh all over. I\xe2\x80\x99m so fond of him. Alyosha, let me\r\ngive you my blessing\xe2\x80\x94a father\xe2\x80\x99s blessing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha rose, but Fyodor Pavlovitch had already changed his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll just make the sign of the cross over you, for\r\nnow. Sit still. Now we\xe2\x80\x99ve a treat for you, in your own line, too. It\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmake you laugh. Balaam\xe2\x80\x99s ass has begun talking to us here\xe2\x80\x94and how he\r\ntalks! How he talks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalaam\xe2\x80\x99s ass, it appeared, was the valet, Smerdyakov. He was a young\r\nman of about four and twenty, remarkably unsociable and taciturn. Not\r\nthat he was shy or bashful. On the contrary, he was conceited and\r\nseemed to despise everybody.\r\n\r\nBut we must pause to say a few words about him now. He was brought up\r\nby Grigory and Marfa, but the boy grew up \xe2\x80\x9cwith no sense of gratitude,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nas Grigory expressed it; he was an unfriendly boy, and seemed to look\r\nat the world mistrustfully. In his childhood he was very fond of\r\nhanging cats, and burying them with great ceremony. He used to dress up\r\nin a sheet as though it were a surplice, and sang, and waved some\r\nobject over the dead cat as though it were a censer. All this he did on\r\nthe sly, with the greatest secrecy. Grigory caught him once at this\r\ndiversion and gave him a sound beating. He shrank into a corner and\r\nsulked there for a week. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care for you or me, the monster,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nGrigory used to say to Marfa, \xe2\x80\x9cand he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care for any one. Are you\r\na human being?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing the boy directly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not a\r\nhuman being. You grew from the mildew in the bath\xe2\x80\x90house.[2] That\xe2\x80\x99s what\r\nyou are.\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov, it appeared afterwards, could never forgive him\r\nthose words. Grigory taught him to read and write, and when he was\r\ntwelve years old, began teaching him the Scriptures. But this teaching\r\ncame to nothing. At the second or third lesson the boy suddenly\r\ngrinned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Grigory, looking at him threateningly from\r\nunder his spectacles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing. God created light on the first day, and the sun, moon,\r\nand stars on the fourth day. Where did the light come from on the first\r\nday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrigory was thunderstruck. The boy looked sarcastically at his teacher.\r\nThere was something positively condescending in his expression. Grigory\r\ncould not restrain himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you where!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, and gave\r\nthe boy a violent slap on the cheek. The boy took the slap without a\r\nword, but withdrew into his corner again for some days. A week later he\r\nhad his first attack of the disease to which he was subject all the\r\nrest of his life\xe2\x80\x94epilepsy. When Fyodor Pavlovitch heard of it, his\r\nattitude to the boy seemed changed at once. Till then he had taken no\r\nnotice of him, though he never scolded him, and always gave him a\r\ncopeck when he met him. Sometimes, when he was in good humor, he would\r\nsend the boy something sweet from his table. But as soon as he heard of\r\nhis illness, he showed an active interest in him, sent for a doctor,\r\nand tried remedies, but the disease turned out to be incurable. The\r\nfits occurred, on an average, once a month, but at various intervals.\r\nThe fits varied too, in violence: some were light and some were very\r\nsevere. Fyodor Pavlovitch strictly forbade Grigory to use corporal\r\npunishment to the boy, and began allowing him to come upstairs to him.\r\nHe forbade him to be taught anything whatever for a time, too. One day\r\nwhen the boy was about fifteen, Fyodor Pavlovitch noticed him lingering\r\nby the bookcase, and reading the titles through the glass. Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch had a fair number of books\xe2\x80\x94over a hundred\xe2\x80\x94but no one ever\r\nsaw him reading. He at once gave Smerdyakov the key of the bookcase.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, read. You shall be my librarian. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be better sitting\r\nreading than hanging about the courtyard. Come, read this,\xe2\x80\x9d and Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch gave him _Evenings in a Cottage near Dikanka_.\r\n\r\nHe read a little but didn\xe2\x80\x99t like it. He did not once smile, and ended\r\nby frowning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it funny?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fyodor Pavlovitch.\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov did not speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer, stupid!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all untrue,\xe2\x80\x9d mumbled the boy, with a grin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen go to the devil! You have the soul of a lackey. Stay, here\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nSmaragdov\xe2\x80\x99s _Universal History_. That\xe2\x80\x99s all true. Read that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Smerdyakov did not get through ten pages of Smaragdov. He thought\r\nit dull. So the bookcase was closed again.\r\n\r\nShortly afterwards Marfa and Grigory reported to Fyodor Pavlovitch that\r\nSmerdyakov was gradually beginning to show an extraordinary\r\nfastidiousness. He would sit before his soup, take up his spoon and\r\nlook into the soup, bend over it, examine it, take a spoonful and hold\r\nit to the light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? A beetle?\xe2\x80\x9d Grigory would ask.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fly, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Marfa.\r\n\r\nThe squeamish youth never answered, but he did the same with his bread,\r\nhis meat, and everything he ate. He would hold a piece on his fork to\r\nthe light, scrutinize it microscopically, and only after long\r\ndeliberation decide to put it in his mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAch! What fine gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s airs!\xe2\x80\x9d Grigory muttered, looking at him.\r\n\r\nWhen Fyodor Pavlovitch heard of this development in Smerdyakov he\r\ndetermined to make him his cook, and sent him to Moscow to be trained.\r\nHe spent some years there and came back remarkably changed in\r\nappearance. He looked extraordinarily old for his age. His face had\r\ngrown wrinkled, yellow, and strangely emasculate. In character he\r\nseemed almost exactly the same as before he went away. He was just as\r\nunsociable, and showed not the slightest inclination for any\r\ncompanionship. In Moscow, too, as we heard afterwards, he had always\r\nbeen silent. Moscow itself had little interest for him; he saw very\r\nlittle there, and took scarcely any notice of anything. He went once to\r\nthe theater, but returned silent and displeased with it. On the other\r\nhand, he came back to us from Moscow well dressed, in a clean coat and\r\nclean linen. He brushed his clothes most scrupulously twice a day\r\ninvariably, and was very fond of cleaning his smart calf boots with a\r\nspecial English polish, so that they shone like mirrors. He turned out\r\na first\xe2\x80\x90rate cook. Fyodor Pavlovitch paid him a salary, almost the\r\nwhole of which Smerdyakov spent on clothes, pomade, perfumes, and such\r\nthings. But he seemed to have as much contempt for the female sex as\r\nfor men; he was discreet, almost unapproachable, with them. Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch began to regard him rather differently. His fits were\r\nbecoming more frequent, and on the days he was ill Marfa cooked, which\r\ndid not suit Fyodor Pavlovitch at all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are your fits getting worse?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fyodor Pavlovitch, looking\r\naskance at his new cook. \xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to get married? Shall I find\r\nyou a wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Smerdyakov turned pale with anger, and made no reply. Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch left him with an impatient gesture. The great thing was that\r\nhe had absolute confidence in his honesty. It happened once, when\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch was drunk, that he dropped in the muddy courtyard\r\nthree hundred\xe2\x80\x90rouble notes which he had only just received. He only\r\nmissed them next day, and was just hastening to search his pockets when\r\nhe saw the notes lying on the table. Where had they come from?\r\nSmerdyakov had picked them up and brought them in the day before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my lad, I\xe2\x80\x99ve never met any one like you,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch said\r\nshortly, and gave him ten roubles. We may add that he not only believed\r\nin his honesty, but had, for some reason, a liking for him, although\r\nthe young man looked as morosely at him as at every one and was always\r\nsilent. He rarely spoke. If it had occurred to any one to wonder at the\r\ntime what the young man was interested in, and what was in his mind, it\r\nwould have been impossible to tell by looking at him. Yet he used\r\nsometimes to stop suddenly in the house, or even in the yard or street,\r\nand would stand still for ten minutes, lost in thought. A physiognomist\r\nstudying his face would have said that there was no thought in it, no\r\nreflection, but only a sort of contemplation. There is a remarkable\r\npicture by the painter Kramskoy, called \xe2\x80\x9cContemplation.\xe2\x80\x9d There is a\r\nforest in winter, and on a roadway through the forest, in absolute\r\nsolitude, stands a peasant in a torn kaftan and bark shoes. He stands,\r\nas it were, lost in thought. Yet he is not thinking; he is\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccontemplating.\xe2\x80\x9d If any one touched him he would start and look at one\r\nas though awakening and bewildered. It\xe2\x80\x99s true he would come to himself\r\nimmediately; but if he were asked what he had been thinking about, he\r\nwould remember nothing. Yet probably he has, hidden within himself, the\r\nimpression which had dominated him during the period of contemplation.\r\nThose impressions are dear to him and no doubt he hoards them\r\nimperceptibly, and even unconsciously. How and why, of course, he does\r\nnot know either. He may suddenly, after hoarding impressions for many\r\nyears, abandon everything and go off to Jerusalem on a pilgrimage for\r\nhis soul\xe2\x80\x99s salvation, or perhaps he will suddenly set fire to his\r\nnative village, and perhaps do both. There are a good many\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccontemplatives\xe2\x80\x9d among the peasantry. Well, Smerdyakov was probably one\r\nof them, and he probably was greedily hoarding up his impressions,\r\nhardly knowing why.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\nThe Controversy\r\n\r\n\r\nBut Balaam\xe2\x80\x99s ass had suddenly spoken. The subject was a strange one.\r\nGrigory had gone in the morning to make purchases, and had heard from\r\nthe shopkeeper Lukyanov the story of a Russian soldier which had\r\nappeared in the newspaper of that day. This soldier had been taken\r\nprisoner in some remote part of Asia, and was threatened with an\r\nimmediate agonizing death if he did not renounce Christianity and\r\nfollow Islam. He refused to deny his faith, and was tortured, flayed\r\nalive, and died, praising and glorifying Christ. Grigory had related\r\nthe story at table. Fyodor Pavlovitch always liked, over the dessert\r\nafter dinner, to laugh and talk, if only with Grigory. This afternoon\r\nhe was in a particularly good\xe2\x80\x90humored and expansive mood. Sipping his\r\nbrandy and listening to the story, he observed that they ought to make\r\na saint of a soldier like that, and to take his skin to some monastery.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would make the people flock, and bring the money in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrigory frowned, seeing that Fyodor Pavlovitch was by no means touched,\r\nbut, as usual, was beginning to scoff. At that moment Smerdyakov, who\r\nwas standing by the door, smiled. Smerdyakov often waited at table\r\ntowards the end of dinner, and since Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s arrival in our town he had\r\ndone so every day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you grinning at?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fyodor Pavlovitch, catching the smile\r\ninstantly, and knowing that it referred to Grigory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my opinion is,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov began suddenly and unexpectedly in a\r\nloud voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if that laudable soldier\xe2\x80\x99s exploit was so very great\r\nthere would have been, to my thinking, no sin in it if he had on such\r\nan emergency renounced, so to speak, the name of Christ and his own\r\nchristening, to save by that same his life, for good deeds, by which,\r\nin the course of years to expiate his cowardice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could it not be a sin? You\xe2\x80\x99re talking nonsense. For that you\xe2\x80\x99ll go\r\nstraight to hell and be roasted there like mutton,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch.\r\n\r\nIt was at this point that Alyosha came in, and Fyodor Pavlovitch, as we\r\nhave seen, was highly delighted at his appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re on your subject, your subject,\xe2\x80\x9d he chuckled gleefully, making\r\nAlyosha sit down to listen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for mutton, that\xe2\x80\x99s not so, and there\xe2\x80\x99ll be nothing there for this,\r\nand there shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be either, if it\xe2\x80\x99s according to justice,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSmerdyakov maintained stoutly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you mean \xe2\x80\x98according to justice\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch cried still\r\nmore gayly, nudging Alyosha with his knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a rascal, that\xe2\x80\x99s what he is!\xe2\x80\x9d burst from Grigory. He looked\r\nSmerdyakov wrathfully in the face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for being a rascal, wait a little, Grigory Vassilyevitch,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nSmerdyakov with perfect composure. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better consider yourself\r\nthat, once I am taken prisoner by the enemies of the Christian race,\r\nand they demand from me to curse the name of God and to renounce my\r\nholy christening, I am fully entitled to act by my own reason, since\r\nthere would be no sin in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ve said that before. Don\xe2\x80\x99t waste words. Prove it,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoup\xe2\x80\x90maker!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Grigory contemptuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for being a soup\xe2\x80\x90maker, wait a bit, too, and consider for yourself,\r\nGrigory Vassilyevitch, without abusing me. For as soon as I say to\r\nthose enemies, \xe2\x80\x98No, I\xe2\x80\x99m not a Christian, and I curse my true God,\xe2\x80\x99 then\r\nat once, by God\xe2\x80\x99s high judgment, I become immediately and specially\r\nanathema accursed, and am cut off from the Holy Church, exactly as\r\nthough I were a heathen, so that at that very instant, not only when I\r\nsay it aloud, but when I think of saying it, before a quarter of a\r\nsecond has passed, I am cut off. Is that so or not, Grigory\r\nVassilyevitch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe addressed Grigory with obvious satisfaction, though he was really\r\nanswering Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s questions, and was well aware of it, and\r\nintentionally pretending that Grigory had asked the questions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIvan,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cstoop down for me to\r\nwhisper. He\xe2\x80\x99s got this all up for your benefit. He wants you to praise\r\nhim. Praise him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan listened with perfect seriousness to his father\xe2\x80\x99s excited whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Smerdyakov, be quiet a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch once\r\nmore. \xe2\x80\x9cIvan, your ear again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan bent down again with a perfectly grave face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love you as I do Alyosha. Don\xe2\x80\x99t think I don\xe2\x80\x99t love you. Some\r\nbrandy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x94But you\xe2\x80\x99re rather drunk yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Ivan, looking steadily\r\nat his father.\r\n\r\nHe was watching Smerdyakov with great curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re anathema accursed, as it is,\xe2\x80\x9d Grigory suddenly burst out, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nhow dare you argue, you rascal, after that, if\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t scold him, Grigory, don\xe2\x80\x99t scold him,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch cut him\r\nshort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should wait, Grigory Vassilyevitch, if only a short time, and\r\nlisten, for I haven\xe2\x80\x99t finished all I had to say. For at the very moment\r\nI become accursed, at that same highest moment, I become exactly like a\r\nheathen, and my christening is taken off me and becomes of no avail.\r\nIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake haste and finish, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d Fyodor Pavlovitch urged him, sipping\r\nfrom his wine\xe2\x80\x90glass with relish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I\xe2\x80\x99ve ceased to be a Christian, then I told no lie to the enemy\r\nwhen they asked whether I was a Christian or not a Christian, seeing I\r\nhad already been relieved by God Himself of my Christianity by reason\r\nof the thought alone, before I had time to utter a word to the enemy.\r\nAnd if I have already been discharged, in what manner and with what\r\nsort of justice can I be held responsible as a Christian in the other\r\nworld for having denied Christ, when, through the very thought alone,\r\nbefore denying Him I had been relieved from my christening? If I\xe2\x80\x99m no\r\nlonger a Christian, then I can\xe2\x80\x99t renounce Christ, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing then\r\nto renounce. Who will hold an unclean Tatar responsible, Grigory\r\nVassilyevitch, even in heaven, for not having been born a Christian?\r\nAnd who would punish him for that, considering that you can\xe2\x80\x99t take two\r\nskins off one ox? For God Almighty Himself, even if He did make the\r\nTatar responsible, when he dies would give him the smallest possible\r\npunishment, I imagine (since he must be punished), judging that he is\r\nnot to blame if he has come into the world an unclean heathen, from\r\nheathen parents. The Lord God can\xe2\x80\x99t surely take a Tatar and say he was\r\na Christian? That would mean that the Almighty would tell a real\r\nuntruth. And can the Lord of Heaven and earth tell a lie, even in one\r\nword?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrigory was thunderstruck and looked at the orator, his eyes nearly\r\nstarting out of his head. Though he did not clearly understand what was\r\nsaid, he had caught something in this rigmarole, and stood, looking\r\nlike a man who has just hit his head against a wall. Fyodor Pavlovitch\r\nemptied his glass and went off into his shrill laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha! Alyosha! What do you say to that! Ah, you casuist! He must\r\nhave been with the Jesuits, somewhere, Ivan. Oh, you stinking Jesuit,\r\nwho taught you? But you\xe2\x80\x99re talking nonsense, you casuist, nonsense,\r\nnonsense, nonsense. Don\xe2\x80\x99t cry, Grigory, we\xe2\x80\x99ll reduce him to smoke and\r\nashes in a moment. Tell me this, O ass; you may be right before your\r\nenemies, but you have renounced your faith all the same in your own\r\nheart, and you say yourself that in that very hour you became anathema\r\naccursed. And if once you\xe2\x80\x99re anathema they won\xe2\x80\x99t pat you on the head\r\nfor it in hell. What do you say to that, my fine Jesuit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no doubt that I have renounced it in my own heart, but there\r\nwas no special sin in that. Or if there was sin, it was the most\r\nordinary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s that the most ordinary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie, accursed one!\xe2\x80\x9d hissed Grigory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsider yourself, Grigory Vassilyevitch,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov went on, staid\r\nand unruffled, conscious of his triumph, but, as it were, generous to\r\nthe vanquished foe. \xe2\x80\x9cConsider yourself, Grigory Vassilyevitch; it is\r\nsaid in the Scripture that if you have faith, even as a mustard seed,\r\nand bid a mountain move into the sea, it will move without the least\r\ndelay at your bidding. Well, Grigory Vassilyevitch, if I\xe2\x80\x99m without\r\nfaith and you have so great a faith that you are continually swearing\r\nat me, you try yourself telling this mountain, not to move into the sea\r\nfor that\xe2\x80\x99s a long way off, but even to our stinking little river which\r\nruns at the bottom of the garden. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see for yourself that it won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbudge, but will remain just where it is however much you shout at it,\r\nand that shows, Grigory Vassilyevitch, that you haven\xe2\x80\x99t faith in the\r\nproper manner, and only abuse others about it. Again, taking into\r\nconsideration that no one in our day, not only you, but actually no\r\none, from the highest person to the lowest peasant, can shove mountains\r\ninto the sea\xe2\x80\x94except perhaps some one man in the world, or, at most,\r\ntwo, and they most likely are saving their souls in secret somewhere in\r\nthe Egyptian desert, so you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t find them\xe2\x80\x94if so it be, if all the\r\nrest have no faith, will God curse all the rest? that is, the\r\npopulation of the whole earth, except about two hermits in the desert,\r\nand in His well\xe2\x80\x90known mercy will He not forgive one of them? And so I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\npersuaded that though I may once have doubted I shall be forgiven if I\r\nshed tears of repentance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Fyodor Pavlovitch, in a transport of delight. \xe2\x80\x9cSo you do\r\nsuppose there are two who can move mountains? Ivan, make a note of it,\r\nwrite it down. There you have the Russian all over!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re quite right in saying it\xe2\x80\x99s characteristic of the people\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfaith,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan assented, with an approving smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou agree. Then it must be so, if you agree. It\xe2\x80\x99s true, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it,\r\nAlyosha? That\xe2\x80\x99s the Russian faith all over, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Smerdyakov has not the Russian faith at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha firmly\r\nand gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not talking about his faith. I mean those two in the desert, only\r\nthat idea. Surely that\xe2\x80\x99s Russian, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s purely Russian,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour words are worth a gold piece, O ass, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll give it to you\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day. But as to the rest you talk nonsense, nonsense, nonsense. Let\r\nme tell you, stupid, that we here are all of little faith, only from\r\ncarelessness, because we haven\xe2\x80\x99t time; things are too much for us, and,\r\nin the second place, the Lord God has given us so little time, only\r\ntwenty\xe2\x80\x90four hours in the day, so that one hasn\xe2\x80\x99t even time to get sleep\r\nenough, much less to repent of one\xe2\x80\x99s sins. While you have denied your\r\nfaith to your enemies when you\xe2\x80\x99d nothing else to think about but to\r\nshow your faith! So I consider, brother, that it constitutes a sin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConstitute a sin it may, but consider yourself, Grigory Vassilyevitch,\r\nthat it only extenuates it, if it does constitute. If I had believed\r\nthen in very truth, as I ought to have believed, then it really would\r\nhave been sinful if I had not faced tortures for my faith, and had gone\r\nover to the pagan Mohammedan faith. But, of course, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\ncome to torture then, because I should only have had to say at that\r\ninstant to the mountain, \xe2\x80\x98Move and crush the tormentor,\xe2\x80\x99 and it would\r\nhave moved and at the very instant have crushed him like a\r\nblack\xe2\x80\x90beetle, and I should have walked away as though nothing had\r\nhappened, praising and glorifying God. But, suppose at that very moment\r\nI had tried all that, and cried to that mountain, \xe2\x80\x98Crush these\r\ntormentors,\xe2\x80\x99 and it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t crushed them, how could I have helped\r\ndoubting, pray, at such a time, and at such a dread hour of mortal\r\nterror? And apart from that, I should know already that I could not\r\nattain to the fullness of the Kingdom of Heaven (for since the mountain\r\nhad not moved at my word, they could not think very much of my faith up\r\naloft, and there could be no very great reward awaiting me in the world\r\nto come). So why should I let them flay the skin off me as well, and to\r\nno good purpose? For, even though they had flayed my skin half off my\r\nback, even then the mountain would not have moved at my word or at my\r\ncry. And at such a moment not only doubt might come over one but one\r\nmight lose one\xe2\x80\x99s reason from fear, so that one would not be able to\r\nthink at all. And, therefore, how should I be particularly to blame if\r\nnot seeing my advantage or reward there or here, I should, at least,\r\nsave my skin. And so trusting fully in the grace of the Lord I should\r\ncherish the hope that I might be altogether forgiven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.\r\nOver The Brandy\r\n\r\n\r\nThe controversy was over. But, strange to say, Fyodor Pavlovitch, who\r\nhad been so gay, suddenly began frowning. He frowned and gulped brandy,\r\nand it was already a glass too much.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet along with you, Jesuits!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried to the servants. \xe2\x80\x9cGo away,\r\nSmerdyakov. I\xe2\x80\x99ll send you the gold piece I promised you to\xe2\x80\x90day, but be\r\noff! Don\xe2\x80\x99t cry, Grigory. Go to Marfa. She\xe2\x80\x99ll comfort you and put you to\r\nbed. It\xe2\x80\x99s you he\xe2\x80\x99s so\r\ninterested in. What have you done to fascinate him?\xe2\x80\x9d he added to Ivan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s pleased to have a high opinion\r\nof me; he\xe2\x80\x99s a lackey and a mean soul. Raw material for revolution,\r\nhowever, when the time comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor revolution?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere will be others and better ones. But there will be some like him\r\nas well. His kind will come first, and better ones after.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when will the time come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rocket will go off and fizzle out, perhaps. The peasants are not\r\nvery fond of listening to these soup\xe2\x80\x90makers, so far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, brother, but a Balaam\xe2\x80\x99s ass like that thinks and thinks, and the\r\ndevil knows where he gets to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s storing up ideas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I know he can\xe2\x80\x99t bear me, nor any one else, even you, though\r\nyou fancy that he has a high opinion of you. But he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t steal, that\xe2\x80\x99s one thing, and he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot a gossip, he holds his tongue, and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t wash our dirty linen in\r\npublic. He makes capital fish pasties too. But, damn him, is he worth\r\ntalking about so much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course he isn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as for the ideas he may be hatching, the Russian peasant,\r\ngenerally speaking, needs thrashing. That I\xe2\x80\x99ve always maintained. Our\r\npeasants are swindlers, and don\xe2\x80\x99t deserve to be pitied, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a good\r\nthing they\xe2\x80\x99re still flogged sometimes. Russia is rich in birches. If\r\nthey destroyed the forests, it would be the ruin of Russia. I stand up\r\nfor the clever people. We\xe2\x80\x99ve left off thrashing the peasants, we\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngrown so clever, but they go on thrashing themselves. And a good thing\r\ntoo. \xe2\x80\x98For with what measure ye mete it shall be measured to you again,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nor how does it go? Anyhow, it will be measured. But Russia\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nswinishness. My dear, if you only knew how I hate Russia.... That is,\r\nnot Russia, but all this vice! But maybe I mean Russia. _Tout cela\r\nc\xe2\x80\x99est de la cochonnerie_.... Do you know what I like? I like wit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve had another glass. That\xe2\x80\x99s enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have one more, and then another, and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll stop.\r\nNo, stay, you interrupted me. At Mokroe I was talking to an old man,\r\nand he told me: \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing we like so much as sentencing girls to\r\nbe thrashed, and we always give the lads the job of thrashing them. No, you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it as I see from your eyes. You\r\nbelieve what people say, that I\xe2\x80\x99m nothing but a buffoon. That\xe2\x80\x99s why.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if Truth were to prevail, you know, you\xe2\x80\x99d be the first to be\r\nrobbed and suppressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! And we clever\r\npeople will sit snug and enjoy our brandy. You know, Ivan, it must have\r\nbeen so ordained by the Almighty Himself. Ivan, speak, is there a God\r\nor not? Stay, speak the truth, speak seriously. Why are you laughing\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m laughing that you should have made a clever remark just now about\r\nSmerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s belief in the existence of two saints who could move\r\nmountains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, am I like him now, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that shows I\xe2\x80\x99m a Russian, too, and I have a Russian\r\ncharacteristic. Describe the scene to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Ivan and Grigory had raised the old man and seated him in an\r\narm\xe2\x80\x90chair. His face was covered with blood, but he was conscious and\r\nlistened greedily to Dmitri\xe2\x80\x99s cries. He was still fancying that\r\nGrushenka really was somewhere in the house. Perhaps in nothing: it may all fizzle out.\r\nThat woman is a beast. In any case we must keep the old man indoors and\r\nnot let Dmitri in the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother, let me ask one thing more: has any man a right to look at\r\nother men and decide which is worthy to live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy bring in the question of worth? And as for\r\nrights\xe2\x80\x94who has not the right to wish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for another man\xe2\x80\x99s death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat even if for another man\xe2\x80\x99s death? In that case let\r\nme ask you, do you think me like Dmitri capable of shedding \xc3\x86sop\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nblood, murdering him, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you saying, Ivan? Alyosha felt\r\nthat his brother had taken the first step towards him, and that he had\r\ncertainly done this with some definite motive.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter X.\r\nBoth Together\r\n\r\n\r\nAlyosha left his father\xe2\x80\x99s house feeling even more exhausted and\r\ndejected in spirit than when he had entered it. His mind too seemed\r\nshattered and unhinged, while he felt that he was afraid to put\r\ntogether the disjointed fragments and form a general idea from all the\r\nagonizing and conflicting experiences of the day. He felt something\r\nbordering upon despair, which he had never known till then. Towering\r\nlike a mountain above all the rest stood the fatal, insoluble question:\r\nHow would things end between his father and his brother Dmitri with\r\nthis terrible woman? Now he had himself been a witness of it, he had\r\nbeen present and seen them face to face. Yet only his brother Dmitri\r\ncould be made unhappy, terribly, completely unhappy: there was trouble\r\nawaiting him. It appeared too that there were other people concerned,\r\nfar more so than Alyosha could have supposed before. There was\r\nsomething positively mysterious in it, too. Ivan had made a step\r\ntowards him, which was what Alyosha had been long desiring. Yet now he\r\nfelt for some reason that he was frightened at it. And these women?\r\nStrange to say, that morning he had set out for Katerina Ivanovna\xe2\x80\x99s in\r\nthe greatest embarrassment; now he felt nothing of the kind. On the\r\ncontrary, he was hastening there as though expecting to find guidance\r\nfrom her. Yet to give her this message was obviously more difficult\r\nthan before. The matter of the three thousand was decided irrevocably,\r\nand Dmitri, feeling himself dishonored and losing his last hope, might\r\nsink to any depth. He had, moreover, told him to describe to Katerina\r\nIvanovna the scene which had just taken place with his father.\r\n\r\nIt was by now seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and it was getting dark as Alyosha entered\r\nthe very spacious and convenient house in the High Street occupied by\r\nKaterina Ivanovna. Alyosha knew that she lived with two aunts. One of\r\nthem, a woman of little education, was that aunt of her half\xe2\x80\x90sister\r\nAgafya Ivanovna who had looked after her in her father\xe2\x80\x99s house when she\r\ncame from boarding\xe2\x80\x90school. The other aunt was a Moscow lady of style\r\nand consequence, though in straitened circumstances. It was said that\r\nthey both gave way in everything to Katerina Ivanovna, and that she\r\nonly kept them with her as chaperons. Katerina Ivanovna herself gave\r\nway to no one but her benefactress, the general\xe2\x80\x99s widow, who had been\r\nkept by illness in Moscow, and to whom she was obliged to write twice a\r\nweek a full account of all her doings.\r\n\r\nWhen Alyosha entered the hall and asked the maid who opened the door to\r\nhim to take his name up, it was evident that they were already aware of\r\nhis arrival. Possibly he had been noticed from the window. At least,\r\nAlyosha heard a noise, caught the sound of flying footsteps and\r\nrustling skirts. Two or three women, perhaps, had run out of the room.\r\n\r\nAlyosha thought it strange that his arrival should cause such\r\nexcitement. He was conducted however to the drawing\xe2\x80\x90room at once. It\r\nwas a large room, elegantly and amply furnished, not at all in\r\nprovincial style. There were many sofas, lounges, settees, big and\r\nlittle tables. There were pictures on the walls, vases and lamps on the\r\ntables, masses of flowers, and even an aquarium in the window. It was\r\ntwilight and rather dark. Alyosha made out a silk mantle thrown down on\r\nthe sofa, where people had evidently just been sitting; and on a table\r\nin front of the sofa were two unfinished cups of chocolate, cakes, a\r\nglass saucer with blue raisins, and another with sweetmeats. Alyosha\r\nsaw that he had interrupted visitors, and frowned. But at that instant\r\nthe porti\xc3\xa8re was raised, and with rapid, hurrying footsteps Katerina\r\nIvanovna came in, holding out both hands to Alyosha with a radiant\r\nsmile of delight. At the same instant a servant brought in two lighted\r\ncandles and set them on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God! At last you have come too! I\xe2\x80\x99ve been simply praying for you\r\nall day! Sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha had been struck by Katerina Ivanovna\xe2\x80\x99s beauty when, three weeks\r\nbefore, Dmitri had first brought him, at Katerina Ivanovna\xe2\x80\x99s special\r\nrequest, to be introduced to her. There had been no conversation\r\nbetween them at that interview, however. Supposing Alyosha to be very\r\nshy, Katerina Ivanovna had talked all the time to Dmitri to spare him.\r\nAlyosha had been silent, but he had seen a great deal very clearly. He\r\nwas struck by the imperiousness, proud ease, and self\xe2\x80\x90confidence of the\r\nhaughty girl. And all that was certain, Alyosha felt that he was not\r\nexaggerating it. He thought her great glowing black eyes were very\r\nfine, especially with her pale, even rather sallow, longish face. But\r\nin those eyes and in the lines of her exquisite lips there was\r\nsomething with which his brother might well be passionately in love,\r\nbut which perhaps could not be loved for long. He expressed this\r\nthought almost plainly to Dmitri when, after the visit, his brother\r\nbesought and insisted that he should not conceal his impressions on\r\nseeing his betrothed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll be happy with her, but perhaps\xe2\x80\x94not tranquilly happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite so, brother. Such people remain always the same. They don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyield to fate. So you think I shan\xe2\x80\x99t love her for ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; perhaps you will love her for ever. But perhaps you won\xe2\x80\x99t always\r\nbe happy with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha had given his opinion at the time, blushing, and angry with\r\nhimself for having yielded to his brother\xe2\x80\x99s entreaties and put such\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfoolish\xe2\x80\x9d ideas into words. For his opinion had struck him as awfully\r\nfoolish immediately after he had uttered it. He felt ashamed too of\r\nhaving given so confident an opinion about a woman. It was with the\r\nmore amazement that he felt now, at the first glance at Katerina\r\nIvanovna as she ran in to him, that he had perhaps been utterly\r\nmistaken. This time her face was beaming with spontaneous good\xe2\x80\x90natured\r\nkindliness, and direct warm\xe2\x80\x90hearted sincerity. The \xe2\x80\x9cpride and\r\nhaughtiness,\xe2\x80\x9d which had struck Alyosha so much before, was only\r\nbetrayed now in a frank, generous energy and a sort of bright, strong\r\nfaith in herself. Alyosha realized at the first glance, at the first\r\nword, that all the tragedy of her position in relation to the man she\r\nloved so dearly was no secret to her; that she perhaps already knew\r\neverything, positively everything. And yet, in spite of that, there was\r\nsuch brightness in her face, such faith in the future. Alyosha felt at\r\nonce that he had gravely wronged her in his thoughts. He was conquered\r\nand captivated immediately. Besides all this, he noticed at her first\r\nwords that she was in great excitement, an excitement perhaps quite\r\nexceptional and almost approaching ecstasy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was so eager to see you, because I can learn from you the whole\r\ntruth\xe2\x80\x94from you and no one else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Alyosha confusedly, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94he sent me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, he sent you! You\r\nsee, I know perhaps far more than you do yourself, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no need\r\nfor you to tell me anything. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I want from you. I want\r\nto know your own last impression of him. I want you to tell me most\r\ndirectly, plainly, coarsely even (oh, as coarsely as you like!), what\r\nyou thought of him just now and of his position after your meeting with\r\nhim to\xe2\x80\x90day. That will perhaps be better than if I had a personal\r\nexplanation with him, as he does not want to come to me. Do you\r\nunderstand what I want from you? Now, tell me simply, tell me every\r\nword of the message he sent you with (I knew he would send you).\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe told me to give you his compliments\xe2\x80\x94and to say that he would never\r\ncome again\xe2\x80\x94but to give you his compliments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis compliments? Was that what he said\xe2\x80\x94his own expression?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccidentally perhaps he made a mistake in the word, perhaps he did not\r\nuse the right word?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; he told me precisely to repeat that word. He begged me two or\r\nthree times not to forget to say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKaterina Ivanovna flushed hotly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp me now, Alexey Fyodorovitch. Now I really need your help.
