After a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence the guitar tinkled again, and he sang\r\nagain in the same falsetto:\r\n\r\nWhatever you may say,\r\nI shall go far away.\r\nLife will be bright and gay\r\nIn the city far away.\r\nI shall not grieve,\r\nI shall not grieve at all,\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t intend to grieve at all.\r\n\r\n\r\nThen something unexpected happened. Alyosha suddenly sneezed. They were\r\nsilent. Alyosha got up and walked towards them. He found Smerdyakov\r\ndressed up and wearing polished boots, his hair pomaded, and perhaps\r\ncurled. The guitar lay on the garden\xe2\x80\x90seat. His companion was the\r\ndaughter of the house, wearing a light\xe2\x80\x90blue dress with a train two\r\nyards long. She was young and would not have been bad\xe2\x80\x90looking, but that\r\nher face was so round and terribly freckled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill my brother Dmitri soon be back?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha with as much\r\ncomposure as he could.\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov got up slowly; Marya Kondratyevna rose too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I to know about Dmitri Fyodorovitch? It\xe2\x80\x99s not as if I were his\r\nkeeper,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Smerdyakov quietly, distinctly, and superciliously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I simply asked whether you do know?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha explained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing of his whereabouts and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut my brother told me that you let him know all that goes on in the\r\nhouse, and promised to let him know when Agrafena Alexandrovna comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov turned a deliberate, unmoved glance upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how did you get in this time, since the gate was bolted an hour\r\nago?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, looking at Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came in from the back\xe2\x80\x90alley, over the fence, and went straight to\r\nthe summer\xe2\x80\x90house. I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll forgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, addressing Marya\r\nKondratyevna. \xe2\x80\x9cI was in a hurry to find my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAch, as though we could take it amiss in you!\xe2\x80\x9d drawled Marya\r\nKondratyevna, flattered by Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s apology. \xe2\x80\x9cFor Dmitri Fyodorovitch\r\noften goes to the summer\xe2\x80\x90house in that way. We don\xe2\x80\x99t know he is here\r\nand he is sitting in the summer\xe2\x80\x90house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very anxious to find him, or to learn from you where he is now.\r\nBelieve me, it\xe2\x80\x99s on business of great importance to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe never tells us,\xe2\x80\x9d lisped Marya Kondratyevna.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThough I used to come here as a friend,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov began again,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDmitri Fyodorovitch has pestered me in a merciless way even here by\r\nhis incessant questions about the master. \xe2\x80\x98What news?\xe2\x80\x99 he\xe2\x80\x99ll ask.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s going on in there now? Who\xe2\x80\x99s coming and going?\xe2\x80\x99 and can\xe2\x80\x99t I\r\ntell him something more. Twice already he\xe2\x80\x99s threatened me with death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith death?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha exclaimed in surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you suppose he\xe2\x80\x99d think much of that, with his temper, which you had\r\na chance of observing yourself yesterday? He says if I let Agrafena\r\nAlexandrovna in and she passes the night there, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be the first to\r\nsuffer for it. I am terribly afraid of him, and if I were not even more\r\nafraid of doing so, I ought to let the police know. God only knows what\r\nhe might not do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis honor said to him the other day, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll pound you in a mortar!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded Marya Kondratyevna.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if it\xe2\x80\x99s pounding in a mortar, it may be only talk,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\nAlyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could meet him, I might speak to him about that too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the only thing I can tell you is this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov, as\r\nthough thinking better of it; \xe2\x80\x9cI am here as an old friend and neighbor,\r\nand it would be odd if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t come. On the other hand, Ivan\r\nFyodorovitch sent me first thing this morning to your brother\xe2\x80\x99s lodging\r\nin Lake Street, without a letter, but with a message to Dmitri\r\nFyodorovitch to go to dine with him at the restaurant here, in the\r\nmarket\xe2\x80\x90place. I went, but didn\xe2\x80\x99t find Dmitri Fyodorovitch at home,\r\nthough it was eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s been here, but he is quite gone,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthose were the very words of his landlady. It\xe2\x80\x99s as though there was an\r\nunderstanding between them. Perhaps at this moment he is in the\r\nrestaurant with Ivan Fyodorovitch, for Ivan Fyodorovitch has not been\r\nhome to dinner and Fyodor Pavlovitch dined alone an hour ago, and is\r\ngone to lie down. But I beg you most particularly not to speak of me\r\nand of what I have told you, for he\xe2\x80\x99d kill me for nothing at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother Ivan invited Dmitri to the restaurant to\xe2\x80\x90day?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated\r\nAlyosha quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Metropolis tavern in the market\xe2\x80\x90place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s quite likely,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alyosha, much excited. \xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\r\nSmerdyakov; that\xe2\x80\x99s important. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go there at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t betray me,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov called after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the tavern as though by chance. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut wait a minute, I\xe2\x80\x99ll open the gate to you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Marya\r\nKondratyevna.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; it\xe2\x80\x99s a short cut, I\xe2\x80\x99ll get over the fence again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat he had heard threw Alyosha into great agitation. He ran to the\r\ntavern. It was impossible for him to go into the tavern in his monastic\r\ndress, but he could inquire at the entrance for his brothers and call\r\nthem down. But just as he reached the tavern, a window was flung open,\r\nand his brother Ivan called down to him from it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha, can\xe2\x80\x99t you come up here to me? I shall be awfully grateful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure I can, only I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite know whether in this dress\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I am in a room apart. Come up the steps; I\xe2\x80\x99ll run down to meet\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA minute later Alyosha was sitting beside his brother. Ivan was alone\r\ndining.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III.\r\nThe Brothers Make Friends\r\n\r\n\r\nIvan was not, however, in a separate room, but only in a place shut off\r\nby a screen, so that it was unseen by other people in the room. It was\r\nthe first room from the entrance with a buffet along the wall. Waiters\r\nwere continually darting to and fro in it. The only customer in the\r\nroom was an old retired military man drinking tea in a corner. But\r\nthere was the usual bustle going on in the other rooms of the tavern;\r\nthere were shouts for the waiters, the sound of popping corks, the\r\nclick of billiard balls, the drone of the organ. Alyosha knew that Ivan\r\ndid not usually visit this tavern and disliked taverns in general. So\r\nhe must have come here, he reflected, simply to meet Dmitri by\r\narrangement. Yet Dmitri was not there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I order you fish, soup or anything. You don\xe2\x80\x99t live on tea alone,\r\nI suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan, apparently delighted at having got hold of\r\nAlyosha. He had finished dinner and was drinking tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me have soup, and tea afterwards, I am hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha\r\ngayly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd cherry jam? They have it here. You remember how you used to love\r\ncherry jam when you were little?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember that? Let me have jam too, I like it still.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan rang for the waiter and ordered soup, jam and tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember everything, Alyosha, I remember you till you were eleven, I\r\nwas nearly fifteen. There\xe2\x80\x99s such a difference between fifteen and\r\neleven that brothers are never companions at those ages. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhether I was fond of you even. When I went away to Moscow for the\r\nfirst few years I never thought of you at all. Then, when you came to\r\nMoscow yourself, we only met once somewhere, I believe. And now I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen here more than three months, and so far we have scarcely said a\r\nword to each other. To\xe2\x80\x90morrow I am going away, and I was just thinking\r\nas I sat here how I could see you to say good\xe2\x80\x90by and just then you\r\npassed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you very anxious to see me, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery. I want to get to know you once for all, and I want you to know\r\nme. And then to say good\xe2\x80\x90by. I believe it\xe2\x80\x99s always best to get to know\r\npeople just before leaving them. I\xe2\x80\x99ve noticed how you\xe2\x80\x99ve been looking\r\nat me these three months. There has been a continual look of\r\nexpectation in your eyes, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t endure that. That\xe2\x80\x99s how it is\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve kept away from you. But in the end I have learned to respect you.\r\nThe little man stands firm, I thought. Though I am laughing, I am\r\nserious. You do stand firm, don\xe2\x80\x99t you? I like people who are firm like\r\nthat whatever it is they stand by, even if they are such little fellows\r\nas you. Your expectant eyes ceased to annoy me, I grew fond of them in\r\nthe end, those expectant eyes. You seem to love me for some reason,\r\nAlyosha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do love you, Ivan. Dmitri says of you\xe2\x80\x94Ivan is a tomb! I say of you,\r\nIvan is a riddle. You are a riddle to me even now. But I understand\r\nsomething in you, and I did not understand it till this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t be angry?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha laughed too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you are just as young as other young men of three and twenty,\r\nthat you are just a young and fresh and nice boy, green in fact! Now,\r\nhave I insulted you dreadfully?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I am struck by a coincidence,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan, warmly and\r\ngood\xe2\x80\x90humoredly. \xe2\x80\x9cWould you believe it that ever since that scene with\r\nher, I have thought of nothing else but my youthful greenness, and just\r\nas though you guessed that, you begin about it. Do you know I\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nsitting here thinking to myself: that if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe in life, if I\r\nlost faith in the woman I love, lost faith in the order of things, were\r\nconvinced in fact that everything is a disorderly, damnable, and\r\nperhaps devil\xe2\x80\x90ridden chaos, if I were struck by every horror of man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisillusionment\xe2\x80\x94still I should want to live and, having once tasted of\r\nthe cup, I would not turn away from it till I had drained it! At\r\nthirty, though, I shall be sure to leave the cup, even if I\xe2\x80\x99ve not\r\nemptied it, and turn away\xe2\x80\x94where I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. But till I am thirty, I\r\nknow that my youth will triumph over everything\xe2\x80\x94every disillusionment,\r\nevery disgust with life. I\xe2\x80\x99ve asked myself many times whether there is\r\nin the world any despair that would overcome this frantic and perhaps\r\nunseemly thirst for life in me, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to the conclusion that\r\nthere isn\xe2\x80\x99t, that is till I am thirty, and then I shall lose it of\r\nmyself, I fancy. Some driveling consumptive moralists\xe2\x80\x94and poets\r\nespecially\xe2\x80\x94often call that thirst for life base. It\xe2\x80\x99s a feature of the\r\nKaramazovs, it\xe2\x80\x99s true, that thirst for life regardless of everything;\r\nyou have it no doubt too, but why is it base? The centripetal force on\r\nour planet is still fearfully strong, Alyosha. I have a longing for\r\nlife, and I go on living in spite of logic. Though I may not believe in\r\nthe order of the universe, yet I love the sticky little leaves as they\r\nopen in spring. I love the blue sky, I love some people, whom one loves\r\nyou know sometimes without knowing why. I love some great deeds done by\r\nmen, though I\xe2\x80\x99ve long ceased perhaps to have faith in them, yet from\r\nold habit one\xe2\x80\x99s heart prizes them. Here they have brought the soup for\r\nyou, eat it, it will do you good. It\xe2\x80\x99s first\xe2\x80\x90rate soup, they know how\r\nto make it here. I want to travel in Europe, Alyosha, I shall set off\r\nfrom here. And yet I know that I am only going to a graveyard, but it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na most precious graveyard, that\xe2\x80\x99s what it is! Precious are the dead\r\nthat lie there, every stone over them speaks of such burning life in\r\nthe past, of such passionate faith in their work, their truth, their\r\nstruggle and their science, that I know I shall fall on the ground and\r\nkiss those stones and weep over them; though I\xe2\x80\x99m convinced in my heart\r\nthat it\xe2\x80\x99s long been nothing but a graveyard. And I shall not weep from\r\ndespair, but simply because I shall be happy in my tears, I shall steep\r\nmy soul in my emotion. I love the sticky leaves in spring, the blue\r\nsky\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all it is. It\xe2\x80\x99s not a matter of intellect or logic, it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nloving with one\xe2\x80\x99s inside, with one\xe2\x80\x99s stomach. One loves the first\r\nstrength of one\xe2\x80\x99s youth. Do you understand anything of my tirade,\r\nAlyosha?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan laughed suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand too well, Ivan. One longs to love with one\xe2\x80\x99s inside, with\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s stomach. You said that so well and I am awfully glad that you\r\nhave such a longing for life,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cI think every one should\r\nlove life above everything in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove life more than the meaning of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, love it, regardless of logic as you say, it must be\r\nregardless of logic, and it\xe2\x80\x99s only then one will understand the meaning\r\nof it. I have thought so a long time. Half your work is done, Ivan, you\r\nlove life, now you\xe2\x80\x99ve only to try to do the second half and you are\r\nsaved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are trying to save me, but perhaps I am not lost! And what does\r\nyour second half mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, one has to raise up your dead, who perhaps have not died after\r\nall. Come, let me have tea. I am so glad of our talk, Ivan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see you are feeling inspired. I am awfully fond of such _professions\r\nde foi_ from such\xe2\x80\x94novices. You are a steadfast person, Alexey. Is it\r\ntrue that you mean to leave the monastery?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my elder sends me out into the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see each other then in the world. We shall meet before I am\r\nthirty, when I shall begin to turn aside from the cup. Father doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwant to turn aside from his cup till he is seventy, he dreams of\r\nhanging on to eighty in fact, so he says. He means it only too\r\nseriously, though he is a buffoon. He stands on a firm rock, too, he\r\nstands on his sensuality\xe2\x80\x94though after we are thirty, indeed, there may\r\nbe nothing else to stand on.... But to hang on to seventy is nasty,\r\nbetter only to thirty; one might retain \xe2\x80\x98a shadow of nobility\xe2\x80\x99 by\r\ndeceiving oneself. Have you seen Dmitri to\xe2\x80\x90day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I saw Smerdyakov,\xe2\x80\x9d and Alyosha rapidly, though minutely,\r\ndescribed his meeting with Smerdyakov. Ivan began listening anxiously\r\nand questioned him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he begged me not to tell Dmitri that he had told me about him,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded Alyosha. Ivan frowned and pondered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you frowning on Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s account?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, on his account. Damn him, I certainly did want to see Dmitri, but\r\nnow there\xe2\x80\x99s no need,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan reluctantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut are you really going so soon, brother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of Dmitri and father? how will it end?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are always harping upon it! What have I to do with it? Am I my\r\nbrother Dmitri\xe2\x80\x99s keeper?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan snapped irritably, but then he suddenly\r\nsmiled bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cCain\xe2\x80\x99s answer about his murdered brother, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\r\nPerhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s what you\xe2\x80\x99re thinking at this moment? Well, damn it all,\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here to be their keeper, can I? I\xe2\x80\x99ve finished what I had\r\nto do, and I am going. Do you imagine I am jealous of Dmitri, that I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen trying to steal his beautiful Katerina Ivanovna for the last three\r\nmonths? Nonsense, I had business of my own. I finished it. I am going.\r\nI finished it just now, you were witness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Katerina Ivanovna\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve released myself once for all. And after all, what have I\r\nto do with Dmitri? Dmitri doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come in. I had my own business to\r\nsettle with Katerina Ivanovna. You know, on the contrary, that Dmitri\r\nbehaved as though there was an understanding between us. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t ask\r\nhim to do it, but he solemnly handed her over to me and gave us his\r\nblessing. It\xe2\x80\x99s all too funny. Ah, Alyosha, if you only knew how light\r\nmy heart is now! Would you believe, it, I sat here eating my dinner and\r\nwas nearly ordering champagne to celebrate my first hour of freedom.\r\nTfoo! It\xe2\x80\x99s been going on nearly six months, and all at once I\xe2\x80\x99ve thrown\r\nit off. I could never have guessed even yesterday, how easy it would be\r\nto put an end to it if I wanted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are speaking of your love, Ivan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf my love, if you like. I fell in love with the young lady, I worried\r\nmyself over her and she worried me. I sat watching over her ... and all\r\nat once it\xe2\x80\x99s collapsed! I spoke this morning with inspiration, but I\r\nwent away and roared with laughter. Would you believe it? Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nliteral truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou seem very merry about it now,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Alyosha, looking into his\r\nface, which had suddenly grown brighter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could I tell that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t care for her a bit! Ha ha! It\r\nappears after all I didn\xe2\x80\x99t. And yet how she attracted me! How\r\nattractive she was just now when I made my speech! And do you know she\r\nattracts me awfully even now, yet how easy it is to leave her. Do you\r\nthink I am boasting?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, only perhaps it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t make reflections about love, it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nunseemly for you. How you rushed into the discussion this morning! I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nforgotten to kiss you for it.... But how she tormented me! It certainly\r\nwas sitting by a \xe2\x80\x98laceration.\xe2\x80\x99 Ah, she knew how I loved her! She loved\r\nme and not Dmitri,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan insisted gayly. \xe2\x80\x9cHer feeling for Dmitri was\r\nsimply a self\xe2\x80\x90 laceration. All I told her just now was perfectly true,\r\nbut the worst of it is, it may take her fifteen or twenty years to find\r\nout that she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care for Dmitri, and loves me whom she torments,\r\nand perhaps she may never find it out at all, in spite of her lesson\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day. Well, it\xe2\x80\x99s better so; I can simply go away for good. By the\r\nway, how is she now? What happened after I departed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha told him she had been hysterical, and that she was now, he\r\nheard, unconscious and delirious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t Madame Hohlakov laying it on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must find out. Nobody dies of hysterics, though. They don\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\r\nGod gave woman hysterics as a relief. I won\xe2\x80\x99t go to her at all. Why\r\npush myself forward again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you told her that she had never cared for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did that on purpose. Alyosha, shall I call for some champagne? Let\r\nus drink to my freedom. Ah, if only you knew how glad I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, brother, we had better not drink,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides\r\nI feel somehow depressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you\xe2\x80\x99ve been depressed a long time, I\xe2\x80\x99ve noticed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you settled to go to\xe2\x80\x90morrow morning, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorning? I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say I should go in the morning.... But perhaps it\r\nmay be the morning. Would you believe it, I dined here to\xe2\x80\x90day only to\r\navoid dining with the old man, I loathe him so. I should have left long\r\nago, so far as he is concerned. But why are you so worried about my\r\ngoing away? We\xe2\x80\x99ve plenty of time before I go, an eternity!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are going away to\xe2\x80\x90morrow, what do you mean by an eternity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what does it matter to us?\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve time enough for\r\nour talk, for what brought us here. Why do you look so surprised?\r\nAnswer: why have we met here? To talk of my love for Katerina Ivanovna,\r\nof the old man and Dmitri? of foreign travel? of the fatal position of\r\nRussia? Of the Emperor Napoleon? Is that it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you know what for. It\xe2\x80\x99s different for other people; but we in our\r\ngreen youth have to settle the eternal questions first of all. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat we care about. Young Russia is talking about nothing but the\r\neternal questions now. Just when the old folks are all taken up with\r\npractical questions. Why have you been looking at me in expectation for\r\nthe last three months? To ask me, \xe2\x80\x98What do you believe, or don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nbelieve at all?\xe2\x80\x99 That\xe2\x80\x99s what your eyes have been meaning for these\r\nthree months, haven\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so,\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are not laughing at me, now, Ivan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe laughing! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to wound my little brother who has been\r\nwatching me with such expectation for three months. Alyosha, look\r\nstraight at me! Of course I am just such a little boy as you are, only\r\nnot a novice. And what have Russian boys been doing up till now, some\r\nof them, I mean? In this stinking tavern, for instance, here, they meet\r\nand sit down in a corner. They\xe2\x80\x99ve never met in their lives before and,\r\nwhen they go out of the tavern, they won\xe2\x80\x99t meet again for forty years.\r\nAnd what do they talk about in that momentary halt in the tavern? Of\r\nthe eternal questions, of the existence of God and immortality. And\r\nthose who do not believe in God talk of socialism or anarchism, of the\r\ntransformation of all humanity on a new pattern, so that it all comes\r\nto the same, they\xe2\x80\x99re the same questions turned inside out. And masses,\r\nmasses of the most original Russian boys do nothing but talk of the\r\neternal questions! Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for real Russians the questions of God\xe2\x80\x99s existence and of\r\nimmortality, or, as you say, the same questions turned inside out, come\r\nfirst and foremost, of course, and so they should,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, still\r\nwatching his brother with the same gentle and inquiring smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Alyosha, it\xe2\x80\x99s sometimes very unwise to be a Russian at all, but\r\nanything stupider than the way Russian boys spend their time one can\r\nhardly imagine. But there\xe2\x80\x99s one Russian boy called Alyosha I am awfully\r\nfond of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow nicely you put that in!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha laughed suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, tell me where to begin, give your orders. The existence of God,\r\neh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegin where you like. You declared yesterday at father\xe2\x80\x99s that there\r\nwas no God.\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha looked searchingly at his brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said that yesterday at dinner on purpose to tease you and I saw your\r\neyes glow. But now I\xe2\x80\x99ve no objection to discussing with you, and I say\r\nso very seriously. I want to be friends with you, Alyosha, for I have\r\nno friends and want to try it. Well, only fancy, perhaps I too accept\r\nGod,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a surprise for you, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, of course, if you are not joking now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJoking? I was told at the elder\xe2\x80\x99s yesterday that I was joking. You\r\nknow, dear boy, there was an old sinner in the eighteenth century who\r\ndeclared that, if there were no God, he would have to be invented.\r\n_S\xe2\x80\x99il n\xe2\x80\x99existait pas Dieu, il faudrait l\xe2\x80\x99inventer._ And man has\r\nactually invented God. And what\xe2\x80\x99s strange, what would be marvelous, is\r\nnot that God should really exist; the marvel is that such an idea, the\r\nidea of the necessity of God, could enter the head of such a savage,\r\nvicious beast as man. So holy it is, so touching, so wise and so great\r\na credit it does to man. As for me, I\xe2\x80\x99ve long resolved not to think\r\nwhether man created God or God man. And I won\xe2\x80\x99t go through all the\r\naxioms laid down by Russian boys on that subject, all derived from\r\nEuropean hypotheses; for what\xe2\x80\x99s a hypothesis there, is an axiom with\r\nthe Russian boy, and not only with the boys but with their teachers\r\ntoo, for our Russian professors are often just the same boys\r\nthemselves. And so I omit all the hypotheses. For what are we aiming at\r\nnow? I am trying to explain as quickly as possible my essential nature,\r\nthat is what manner of man I am, what I believe in, and for what I\r\nhope, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? And therefore I tell you that I accept God\r\nsimply. But you must note this: if God exists and if He really did\r\ncreate the world, then, as we all know, He created it according to the\r\ngeometry of Euclid and the human mind with the conception of only three\r\ndimensions in space. Yet there have been and still are geometricians\r\nand philosophers, and even some of the most distinguished, who doubt\r\nwhether the whole universe, or to speak more widely the whole of being,\r\nwas only created in Euclid\xe2\x80\x99s geometry; they even dare to dream that two\r\nparallel lines, which according to Euclid can never meet on earth, may\r\nmeet somewhere in infinity. I have come to the conclusion that, since I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t understand even that, I can\xe2\x80\x99t expect to understand about God. I\r\nacknowledge humbly that I have no faculty for settling such questions,\r\nI have a Euclidian earthly mind, and how could I solve problems that\r\nare not of this world? And I advise you never to think about it either,\r\nmy dear Alyosha, especially about God, whether He exists or not. All\r\nsuch questions are utterly inappropriate for a mind created with an\r\nidea of only three dimensions. And so I accept God and am glad to, and\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s more, I accept His wisdom, His purpose\xe2\x80\x94which are utterly beyond\r\nour ken; I believe in the underlying order and the meaning of life; I\r\nbelieve in the eternal harmony in which they say we shall one day be\r\nblended. I believe in the Word to Which the universe is striving, and\r\nWhich Itself was \xe2\x80\x98with God,\xe2\x80\x99 and Which Itself is God and so on, and so\r\non, to infinity. There are all sorts of phrases for it. I seem to be on\r\nthe right path, don\xe2\x80\x99t I? Yet would you believe it, in the final result\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t accept this world of God\xe2\x80\x99s, and, although I know it exists, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t accept it at all. It\xe2\x80\x99s not that I don\xe2\x80\x99t accept God, you must\r\nunderstand, it\xe2\x80\x99s the world created by Him I don\xe2\x80\x99t and cannot accept.\r\nLet me make it plain. I believe like a child that suffering will be\r\nhealed and made up for, that all the humiliating absurdity of human\r\ncontradictions will vanish like a pitiful mirage, like the despicable\r\nfabrication of the impotent and infinitely small Euclidian mind of man,\r\nthat in the world\xe2\x80\x99s finale, at the moment of eternal harmony, something\r\nso precious will come to pass that it will suffice for all hearts, for\r\nthe comforting of all resentments, for the atonement of all the crimes\r\nof humanity, of all the blood they\xe2\x80\x99ve shed; that it will make it not\r\nonly possible to forgive but to justify all that has happened with\r\nmen\xe2\x80\x94but though all that may come to pass, I don\xe2\x80\x99t accept it. I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\naccept it. Even if parallel lines do meet and I see it myself, I shall\r\nsee it and say that they\xe2\x80\x99ve met, but still I won\xe2\x80\x99t accept it. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s at the root of me, Alyosha; that\xe2\x80\x99s my creed. I am in earnest in\r\nwhat I say. I began our talk as stupidly as I could on purpose, but\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve led up to my confession, for that\xe2\x80\x99s all you want. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nto hear about God, but only to know what the brother you love lives by.\r\nAnd so I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan concluded his long tirade with marked and unexpected feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why did you begin \xe2\x80\x98as stupidly as you could\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha,\r\nlooking dreamily at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo begin with, for the sake of being Russian. Russian conversations on\r\nsuch subjects are always carried on inconceivably stupidly. And\r\nsecondly, the stupider one is, the closer one is to reality. The\r\nstupider one is, the clearer one is. Stupidity is brief and artless,\r\nwhile intelligence wriggles and hides itself. Intelligence is a knave,\r\nbut stupidity is honest and straightforward. I\xe2\x80\x99ve led the conversation\r\nto my despair, and the more stupidly I have presented it, the better\r\nfor me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will explain why you don\xe2\x80\x99t accept the world?\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure I will, it\xe2\x80\x99s not a secret, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99ve been leading up\r\nto. Dear little brother, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to corrupt you or to turn you\r\nfrom your stronghold, perhaps I want to be healed by you.\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan smiled\r\nsuddenly quite like a little gentle child. Alyosha had never seen such\r\na smile on his face before.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV.\r\nRebellion\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must make you one confession,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan began. \xe2\x80\x9cI could never understand\r\nhow one can love one\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors. It\xe2\x80\x99s just one\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors, to my\r\nmind, that one can\xe2\x80\x99t love, though one might love those at a distance. I\r\nonce read somewhere of John the Merciful, a saint, that when a hungry,\r\nfrozen beggar came to him, he took him into his bed, held him in his\r\narms, and began breathing into his mouth, which was putrid and\r\nloathsome from some awful disease. I am convinced that he did that from\r\n\xe2\x80\x98self\xe2\x80\x90laceration,\xe2\x80\x99 from the self\xe2\x80\x90laceration of falsity, for the sake of\r\nthe charity imposed by duty, as a penance laid on him. For any one to\r\nlove a man, he must be hidden, for as soon as he shows his face, love\r\nis gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Zossima has talked of that more than once,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Alyosha;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9che, too, said that the face of a man often hinders many people not\r\npracticed in love, from loving him. But yet there\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal of\r\nlove in mankind, and almost Christ\xe2\x80\x90like love. I know that myself,\r\nIvan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I know nothing of it so far, and can\xe2\x80\x99t understand it, and the\r\ninnumerable mass of mankind are with me there. The question is, whether\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s due to men\xe2\x80\x99s bad qualities or whether it\xe2\x80\x99s inherent in their\r\nnature. To my thinking, Christ\xe2\x80\x90like love for men is a miracle\r\nimpossible on earth. He was God. But we are not gods. Suppose I, for\r\ninstance, suffer intensely. Another can never know how much I suffer,\r\nbecause he is another and not I. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more, a man is rarely ready\r\nto admit another\xe2\x80\x99s suffering (as though it were a distinction). Why\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t he admit it, do you think? Because I smell unpleasant, because I\r\nhave a stupid face, because I once trod on his foot. Besides, there is\r\nsuffering and suffering; degrading, humiliating suffering such as\r\nhumbles me\xe2\x80\x94hunger, for instance\xe2\x80\x94my benefactor will perhaps allow me;\r\nbut when you come to higher suffering\xe2\x80\x94for an idea, for instance\xe2\x80\x94he will\r\nvery rarely admit that, perhaps because my face strikes him as not at\r\nall what he fancies a man should have who suffers for an idea. And so\r\nhe deprives me instantly of his favor, and not at all from badness of\r\nheart. Beggars, especially genteel beggars, ought never to show\r\nthemselves, but to ask for charity through the newspapers. One can love\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors in the abstract, or even at a distance, but at close\r\nquarters it\xe2\x80\x99s almost impossible. If it were as on the stage, in the\r\nballet, where if beggars come in, they wear silken rags and tattered\r\nlace and beg for alms dancing gracefully, then one might like looking\r\nat them. But even then we should not love them. But enough of that. I\r\nsimply wanted to show you my point of view. I meant to speak of the\r\nsuffering of mankind generally, but we had better confine ourselves to\r\nthe sufferings of the children. That reduces the scope of my argument\r\nto a tenth of what it would be. Still we\xe2\x80\x99d better keep to the children,\r\nthough it does weaken my case. But, in the first place, children can be\r\nloved even at close quarters, even when they are dirty, even when they\r\nare ugly (I fancy, though, children never are ugly). The second reason\r\nwhy I won\xe2\x80\x99t speak of grown\xe2\x80\x90up people is that, besides being disgusting\r\nand unworthy of love, they have a compensation\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99ve eaten the apple\r\nand know good and evil, and they have become \xe2\x80\x98like gods.\xe2\x80\x99 They go on\r\neating it still. But the children haven\xe2\x80\x99t eaten anything, and are so\r\nfar innocent. Are you fond of children, Alyosha? I know you are, and\r\nyou will understand why I prefer to speak of them. If they, too, suffer\r\nhorribly on earth, they must suffer for their fathers\xe2\x80\x99 sins, they must\r\nbe punished for their fathers, who have eaten the apple; but that\r\nreasoning is of the other world and is incomprehensible for the heart\r\nof man here on earth. The innocent must not suffer for another\xe2\x80\x99s sins,\r\nand especially such innocents! You may be surprised at me, Alyosha, but\r\nI am awfully fond of children, too. And observe, cruel people, the\r\nviolent, the rapacious, the Karamazovs are sometimes very fond of\r\nchildren. Children while they are quite little\xe2\x80\x94up to seven, for\r\ninstance\xe2\x80\x94are so remote from grown\xe2\x80\x90up people; they are different\r\ncreatures, as it were, of a different species. I knew a criminal in\r\nprison who had, in the course of his career as a burglar, murdered\r\nwhole families, including several children. But when he was in prison,\r\nhe had a strange affection for them. He spent all his time at his\r\nwindow, watching the children playing in the prison yard. He trained\r\none little boy to come up to his window and made great friends with\r\nhim.... You don\xe2\x80\x99t know why I am telling you all this, Alyosha? My head\r\naches and I am sad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak with a strange air,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Alyosha uneasily, \xe2\x80\x9cas though\r\nyou were not quite yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, a Bulgarian I met lately in Moscow,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan went on, seeming\r\nnot to hear his brother\xe2\x80\x99s words, \xe2\x80\x9ctold me about the crimes committed by\r\nTurks and Circassians in all parts of Bulgaria through fear of a\r\ngeneral rising of the Slavs. They burn villages, murder, outrage women\r\nand children, they nail their prisoners by the ears to the fences,\r\nleave them so till morning, and in the morning they hang them\xe2\x80\x94all sorts\r\nof things you can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine. People talk sometimes of bestial cruelty,\r\nbut that\xe2\x80\x99s a great injustice and insult to the beasts; a beast can\r\nnever be so cruel as a man, so artistically cruel. The tiger only tears\r\nand gnaws, that\xe2\x80\x99s all he can do. He would never think of nailing people\r\nby the ears, even if he were able to do it. These Turks took a pleasure\r\nin torturing children, too; cutting the unborn child from the mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwomb, and tossing babies up in the air and catching them on the points\r\nof their bayonets before their mothers\xe2\x80\x99 eyes. Doing it before the\r\nmothers\xe2\x80\x99 eyes was what gave zest to the amusement. Here is another\r\nscene that I thought very interesting. Imagine a trembling mother with\r\nher baby in her arms, a circle of invading Turks around her. They\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nplanned a diversion: they pet the baby, laugh to make it laugh. They\r\nsucceed, the baby laughs. At that moment a Turk points a pistol four\r\ninches from the baby\xe2\x80\x99s face. The baby laughs with glee, holds out its\r\nlittle hands to the pistol, and he pulls the trigger in the baby\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\nand blows out its brains. Artistic, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it? By the way, Turks are\r\nparticularly fond of sweet things, they say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother, what are you driving at?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think if the devil doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exist, but man has created him, he has\r\ncreated him in his own image and likeness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as he did God, then?\xe2\x80\x9d observed Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful how you can turn words,\xe2\x80\x99 as Polonius says in\r\n_Hamlet_,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cYou turn my words against me. Well, I am\r\nglad. Yours must be a fine God, if man created Him in his image and\r\nlikeness. You asked just now what I was driving at. You see, I am fond\r\nof collecting certain facts, and, would you believe, I even copy\r\nanecdotes of a certain sort from newspapers and books, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve already\r\ngot a fine collection. The Turks, of course, have gone into it, but\r\nthey are foreigners. I have specimens from home that are even better\r\nthan the Turks. You know we prefer beating\xe2\x80\x94rods and scourges\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s our\r\nnational institution. Nailing ears is unthinkable for us, for we are,\r\nafter all, Europeans. But the rod and the scourge we have always with\r\nus and they cannot be taken from us. Abroad now they scarcely do any\r\nbeating. Manners are more humane, or laws have been passed, so that\r\nthey don\xe2\x80\x99t dare to flog men now. But they make up for it in another way\r\njust as national as ours. And so national that it would be practically\r\nimpossible among us, though I believe we are being inoculated with it,\r\nsince the religious movement began in our aristocracy. I have a\r\ncharming pamphlet, translated from the French, describing how, quite\r\nrecently, five years ago, a murderer, Richard, was executed\xe2\x80\x94a young\r\nman, I believe, of three and twenty, who repented and was converted to\r\nthe Christian faith at the very scaffold. This Richard was an\r\nillegitimate child who was given as a child of six by his parents to\r\nsome shepherds on the Swiss mountains. They brought him up to work for\r\nthem. He grew up like a little wild beast among them. The shepherds\r\ntaught him nothing, and scarcely fed or clothed him, but sent him out\r\nat seven to herd the flock in cold and wet, and no one hesitated or\r\nscrupled to treat him so. Quite the contrary, they thought they had\r\nevery right, for Richard had been given to them as a chattel, and they\r\ndid not even see the necessity of feeding him. Richard himself\r\ndescribes how in those years, like the Prodigal Son in the Gospel, he\r\nlonged to eat of the mash given to the pigs, which were fattened for\r\nsale. But they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t even give him that, and beat him when he stole\r\nfrom the pigs. And that was how he spent all his childhood and his\r\nyouth, till he grew up and was strong enough to go away and be a thief.\r\nThe savage began to earn his living as a day laborer in Geneva. He\r\ndrank what he earned, he lived like a brute, and finished by killing\r\nand robbing an old man. He was caught, tried, and condemned to death.\r\nThey are not sentimentalists there. And in prison he was immediately\r\nsurrounded by pastors, members of Christian brotherhoods, philanthropic\r\nladies, and the like. They taught him to read and write in prison, and\r\nexpounded the Gospel to him. They exhorted him, worked upon him,\r\ndrummed at him incessantly, till at last he solemnly confessed his\r\ncrime. He was converted. He wrote to the court himself that he was a\r\nmonster, but that in the end God had vouchsafed him light and shown\r\ngrace. All Geneva was in excitement about him\xe2\x80\x94all philanthropic and\r\nreligious Geneva. All the aristocratic and well\xe2\x80\x90bred society of the\r\ntown rushed to the prison, kissed Richard and embraced him; \xe2\x80\x98You are\r\nour brother, you have found grace.\xe2\x80\x99 And Richard does nothing but weep\r\nwith emotion, \xe2\x80\x98Yes, I\xe2\x80\x99ve found grace! All my youth and childhood I was\r\nglad of pigs\xe2\x80\x99 food, but now even I have found grace. I am dying in the\r\nLord.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Yes, Richard, die in the Lord; you have shed blood and must\r\ndie. Though it\xe2\x80\x99s not your fault that you knew not the Lord, when you\r\ncoveted the pigs\xe2\x80\x99 food and were beaten for stealing it (which was very\r\nwrong of you, for stealing is forbidden); but you\xe2\x80\x99ve shed blood and you\r\nmust die.\xe2\x80\x99 And on the last day, Richard, perfectly limp, did nothing\r\nbut cry and repeat every minute: \xe2\x80\x98This is my happiest day. I am going\r\nto the Lord.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 cry the pastors and the judges and philanthropic\r\nladies. \xe2\x80\x98This is the happiest day of your life, for you are going to\r\nthe Lord!\xe2\x80\x99 They all walk or drive to the scaffold in procession behind\r\nthe prison van. At the scaffold they call to Richard: \xe2\x80\x98Die, brother,\r\ndie in the Lord, for even thou hast found grace!\xe2\x80\x99 And so, covered with\r\nhis brothers\xe2\x80\x99 kisses, Richard is dragged on to the scaffold, and led to\r\nthe guillotine. And they chopped off his head in brotherly fashion,\r\nbecause he had found grace. Yes, that\xe2\x80\x99s characteristic. That pamphlet\r\nis translated into Russian by some Russian philanthropists of\r\naristocratic rank and evangelical aspirations, and has been distributed\r\ngratis for the enlightenment of the people. The case of Richard is\r\ninteresting because it\xe2\x80\x99s national. Though to us it\xe2\x80\x99s absurd to cut off\r\na man\xe2\x80\x99s head, because he has become our brother and has found grace,\r\nyet we have our own speciality, which is all but worse. Our historical\r\npastime is the direct satisfaction of inflicting pain. There are lines\r\nin Nekrassov describing how a peasant lashes a horse on the eyes, \xe2\x80\x98on\r\nits meek eyes,\xe2\x80\x99 every one must have seen it. It\xe2\x80\x99s peculiarly Russian.\r\nHe describes how a feeble little nag has foundered under too heavy a\r\nload and cannot move. The peasant beats it, beats it savagely, beats it\r\nat last not knowing what he is doing in the intoxication of cruelty,\r\nthrashes it mercilessly over and over again. \xe2\x80\x98However weak you are, you\r\nmust pull, if you die for it.\xe2\x80\x99 The nag strains, and then he begins\r\nlashing the poor defenseless creature on its weeping, on its \xe2\x80\x98meek\r\neyes.\xe2\x80\x99 The frantic beast tugs and draws the load, trembling all over,\r\ngasping for breath, moving sideways, with a sort of unnatural spasmodic\r\naction\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s awful in Nekrassov. But that\xe2\x80\x99s only a horse, and God has\r\ngiven horses to be beaten. So the Tatars have taught us, and they left\r\nus the knout as a remembrance of it. But men, too, can be beaten. A\r\nwell\xe2\x80\x90educated, cultured gentleman and his wife beat their own child\r\nwith a birch\xe2\x80\x90rod, a girl of seven. I have an exact account of it. The\r\npapa was glad that the birch was covered with twigs. \xe2\x80\x98It stings more,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid he, and so he began stinging his daughter. I know for a fact there\r\nare people who at every blow are worked up to sensuality, to literal\r\nsensuality, which increases progressively at every blow they inflict.\r\nThey beat for a minute, for five minutes, for ten minutes, more often\r\nand more savagely. The child screams. At last the child cannot scream,\r\nit gasps, \xe2\x80\x98Daddy! daddy!\xe2\x80\x99 By some diabolical unseemly chance the case\r\nwas brought into court. A counsel is engaged. The Russian people have\r\nlong called a barrister \xe2\x80\x98a conscience for hire.\xe2\x80\x99 The counsel protests\r\nin his client\xe2\x80\x99s defense. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s such a simple thing,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98an\r\neveryday domestic event. A father corrects his child. To our shame be\r\nit said, it is brought into court.\xe2\x80\x99 The jury, convinced by him, give a\r\nfavorable verdict. The public roars with delight that the torturer is\r\nacquitted. Ah, pity I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t there! I would have proposed to raise a\r\nsubscription in his honor! Charming pictures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99ve still better things about children. I\xe2\x80\x99ve collected a great,\r\ngreat deal about Russian children, Alyosha. There was a little girl of\r\nfive who was hated by her father and mother, \xe2\x80\x98most worthy and\r\nrespectable people, of good education and breeding.\xe2\x80\x99 You see, I must\r\nrepeat again, it is a peculiar characteristic of many people, this love\r\nof torturing children, and children only. To all other types of\r\nhumanity these torturers behave mildly and benevolently, like\r\ncultivated and humane Europeans; but they are very fond of tormenting\r\nchildren, even fond of children themselves in that sense. It\xe2\x80\x99s just\r\ntheir defenselessness that tempts the tormentor, just the angelic\r\nconfidence of the child who has no refuge and no appeal, that sets his\r\nvile blood on fire. In every man, of course, a demon lies hidden\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ndemon of rage, the demon of lustful heat at the screams of the tortured\r\nvictim, the demon of lawlessness let off the chain, the demon of\r\ndiseases that follow on vice, gout, kidney disease, and so on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis poor child of five was subjected to every possible torture by\r\nthose cultivated parents. They beat her, thrashed her, kicked her for\r\nno reason till her body was one bruise. Then, they went to greater\r\nrefinements of cruelty\xe2\x80\x94shut her up all night in the cold and frost in a\r\nprivy, and because she didn\xe2\x80\x99t ask to be taken up at night (as though a\r\nchild of five sleeping its angelic, sound sleep could be trained to\r\nwake and ask), they smeared her face and filled her mouth with\r\nexcrement, and it was her mother, her mother did this. And that mother\r\ncould sleep, hearing the poor child\xe2\x80\x99s groans! Can you understand why a\r\nlittle creature, who can\xe2\x80\x99t even understand what\xe2\x80\x99s done to her, should\r\nbeat her little aching heart with her tiny fist in the dark and the\r\ncold, and weep her meek unresentful tears to dear, kind God to protect\r\nher? Do you understand that, friend and brother, you pious and humble\r\nnovice? Do you understand why this infamy must be and is permitted?\r\nWithout it, I am told, man could not have existed on earth, for he\r\ncould not have known good and evil. Why should he know that diabolical\r\ngood and evil when it costs so much? Why, the whole world of knowledge\r\nis not worth that child\xe2\x80\x99s prayer to \xe2\x80\x98dear, kind God\xe2\x80\x99! I say nothing of\r\nthe sufferings of grown\xe2\x80\x90up people, they have eaten the apple, damn\r\nthem, and the devil take them all! But these little ones! I am making\r\nyou suffer, Alyosha, you are not yourself. I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave off if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind. I want to suffer too,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne picture, only one more, because it\xe2\x80\x99s so curious, so\r\ncharacteristic, and I have only just read it in some collection of\r\nRussian antiquities. I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten the name. I must look it up. It was\r\nin the darkest days of serfdom at the beginning of the century, and\r\nlong live the Liberator of the People! There was in those days a\r\ngeneral of aristocratic connections, the owner of great estates, one of\r\nthose men\xe2\x80\x94somewhat exceptional, I believe, even then\xe2\x80\x94who, retiring from\r\nthe service into a life of leisure, are convinced that they\xe2\x80\x99ve earned\r\nabsolute power over the lives of their subjects. There were such men\r\nthen. So our general, settled on his property of two thousand souls,\r\nlives in pomp, and domineers over his poor neighbors as though they\r\nwere dependents and buffoons. He has kennels of hundreds of hounds and\r\nnearly a hundred dog\xe2\x80\x90boys\xe2\x80\x94all mounted, and in uniform. One day a\r\nserf\xe2\x80\x90boy, a little child of eight, threw a stone in play and hurt the\r\npaw of the general\xe2\x80\x99s favorite hound. \xe2\x80\x98Why is my favorite dog lame?\xe2\x80\x99 He\r\nis told that the boy threw a stone that hurt the dog\xe2\x80\x99s paw. \xe2\x80\x98So you did\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99 The general looked the child up and down. \xe2\x80\x98Take him.\xe2\x80\x99 He was\r\ntaken\xe2\x80\x94taken from his mother and kept shut up all night. Early that\r\nmorning the general comes out on horseback, with the hounds, his\r\ndependents, dog\xe2\x80\x90boys, and huntsmen, all mounted around him in full\r\nhunting parade. The servants are summoned for their edification, and in\r\nfront of them all stands the mother of the child. The child is brought\r\nfrom the lock\xe2\x80\x90up. It\xe2\x80\x99s a gloomy, cold, foggy autumn day, a capital day\r\nfor hunting. The general orders the child to be undressed; the child is\r\nstripped naked. He shivers, numb with terror, not daring to cry....\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Make him run,\xe2\x80\x99 commands the general. \xe2\x80\x98Run! run!\xe2\x80\x99 shout the dog\xe2\x80\x90boys.\r\nThe boy runs.... \xe2\x80\x98At him!\xe2\x80\x99 yells the general, and he sets the whole\r\npack of hounds on the child. The hounds catch him, and tear him to\r\npieces before his mother\xe2\x80\x99s eyes!... I believe the general was\r\nafterwards declared incapable of administering his estates. Well\xe2\x80\x94what\r\ndid he deserve? To be shot? To be shot for the satisfaction of our\r\nmoral feelings? Speak, Alyosha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be shot,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Alyosha, lifting his eyes to Ivan with a pale,\r\ntwisted smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan, delighted. \xe2\x80\x9cIf even you say so.... You\xe2\x80\x99re a pretty\r\nmonk! So there is a little devil sitting in your heart, Alyosha\r\nKaramazov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I said was absurd, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the point, that \xe2\x80\x98but\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me tell you,\r\nnovice, that the absurd is only too necessary on earth. The world\r\nstands on absurdities, and perhaps nothing would have come to pass in\r\nit without them. We know what we know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan went on, as though in delirium. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwant to understand anything now. I want to stick to the fact. I made up\r\nmy mind long ago not to understand. If I try to understand anything, I\r\nshall be false to the fact, and I have determined to stick to the\r\nfact.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you trying me?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha cried, with sudden distress. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you\r\nsay what you mean at last?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I will; that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99ve been leading up to. You are dear\r\nto me, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to let you go, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t give you up to your\r\nZossima.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan for a minute was silent, his face became all at once very sad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen! I took the case of children only to make my case clearer. Of\r\nthe other tears of humanity with which the earth is soaked from its\r\ncrust to its center, I will say nothing. I have narrowed my subject on\r\npurpose. I am a bug, and I recognize in all humility that I cannot\r\nunderstand why the world is arranged as it is. Men are themselves to\r\nblame, I suppose; they were given paradise, they wanted freedom, and\r\nstole fire from heaven, though they knew they would become unhappy, so\r\nthere is no need to pity them. With my pitiful, earthly, Euclidian\r\nunderstanding, all I know is that there is suffering and that there are\r\nnone guilty; that cause follows effect, simply and directly; that\r\neverything flows and finds its level\xe2\x80\x94but that\xe2\x80\x99s only Euclidian\r\nnonsense, I know that, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t consent to live by it! What comfort\r\nis it to me that there are none guilty and that cause follows effect\r\nsimply and directly, and that I know it?\xe2\x80\x94I must have justice, or I will\r\ndestroy myself. And not justice in some remote infinite time and space,\r\nbut here on earth, and that I could see myself. I have believed in it.\r\nI want to see it, and if I am dead by then, let me rise again, for if\r\nit all happens without me, it will be too unfair. Surely I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsuffered, simply that I, my crimes and my sufferings, may manure the\r\nsoil of the future harmony for somebody else. I want to see with my own\r\neyes the hind lie down with the lion and the victim rise up and embrace\r\nhis murderer. I want to be there when every one suddenly understands\r\nwhat it has all been for. All the religions of the world are built on\r\nthis longing, and I am a believer. But then there are the children, and\r\nwhat am I to do about them? That\xe2\x80\x99s a question I can\xe2\x80\x99t answer. For the\r\nhundredth time I repeat, there are numbers of questions, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve only\r\ntaken the children, because in their case what I mean is so\r\nunanswerably clear. Listen! If all must suffer to pay for the eternal\r\nharmony, what have children to do with it, tell me, please? It\xe2\x80\x99s beyond\r\nall comprehension why they should suffer, and why they should pay for\r\nthe harmony. Why should they, too, furnish material to enrich the soil\r\nfor the harmony of the future? I understand solidarity in sin among\r\nmen. I understand solidarity in retribution, too; but there can be no\r\nsuch solidarity with children. And if it is really true that they must\r\nshare responsibility for all their fathers\xe2\x80\x99 crimes, such a truth is not\r\nof this world and is beyond my comprehension. Some jester will say,\r\nperhaps, that the child would have grown up and have sinned, but you\r\nsee he didn\xe2\x80\x99t grow up, he was torn to pieces by the dogs, at eight\r\nyears old. Oh, Alyosha, I am not blaspheming! I understand, of course,\r\nwhat an upheaval of the universe it will be, when everything in heaven\r\nand earth blends in one hymn of praise and everything that lives and\r\nhas lived cries aloud: \xe2\x80\x98Thou art just, O Lord, for Thy ways are\r\nrevealed.\xe2\x80\x99 When the mother embraces the fiend who threw her child to\r\nthe dogs, and all three cry aloud with tears, \xe2\x80\x98Thou art just, O Lord!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthen, of course, the crown of knowledge will be reached and all will be\r\nmade clear. But what pulls me up here is that I can\xe2\x80\x99t accept that\r\nharmony. And while I am on earth, I make haste to take my own measures.\r\nYou see, Alyosha, perhaps it really may happen that if I live to that\r\nmoment, or rise again to see it, I, too, perhaps, may cry aloud with\r\nthe rest, looking at the mother embracing the child\xe2\x80\x99s torturer, \xe2\x80\x98Thou\r\nart just, O Lord!\xe2\x80\x99 but I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to cry aloud then. While there is\r\nstill time, I hasten to protect myself, and so I renounce the higher\r\nharmony altogether. It\xe2\x80\x99s not worth the tears of that one tortured child\r\nwho beat itself on the breast with its little fist and prayed in its\r\nstinking outhouse, with its unexpiated tears to \xe2\x80\x98dear, kind God\xe2\x80\x99! It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot worth it, because those tears are unatoned for. They must be atoned\r\nfor, or there can be no harmony. But how? How are you going to atone\r\nfor them? Is it possible? By their being avenged? But what do I care\r\nfor avenging them? What do I care for a hell for oppressors? What good\r\ncan hell do, since those children have already been tortured? And what\r\nbecomes of harmony, if there is hell? I want to forgive. I want to\r\nembrace. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want more suffering. And if the sufferings of children\r\ngo to swell the sum of sufferings which was necessary to pay for truth,\r\nthen I protest that the truth is not worth such a price. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nthe mother to embrace the oppressor who threw her son to the dogs! She\r\ndare not forgive him! Let her forgive him for herself, if she will, let\r\nher forgive the torturer for the immeasurable suffering of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nheart. But the sufferings of her tortured child she has no right to\r\nforgive; she dare not forgive the torturer, even if the child were to\r\nforgive him! And if that is so, if they dare not forgive, what becomes\r\nof harmony? Is there in the whole world a being who would have the\r\nright to forgive and could forgive? I don\xe2\x80\x99t want harmony. From love for\r\nhumanity I don\xe2\x80\x99t want it. I would rather be left with the unavenged\r\nsuffering. I would rather remain with my unavenged suffering and\r\nunsatisfied indignation, _even if I were wrong_. Besides, too high a\r\nprice is asked for harmony; it\xe2\x80\x99s beyond our means to pay so much to\r\nenter on it. And so I hasten to give back my entrance ticket, and if I\r\nam an honest man I am bound to give it back as soon as possible. And\r\nthat I am doing. It\xe2\x80\x99s not God that I don\xe2\x80\x99t accept, Alyosha, only I most\r\nrespectfully return Him the ticket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s rebellion,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Alyosha, looking down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebellion? I am sorry you call it that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan earnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cOne can\r\nhardly live in rebellion, and I want to live. Tell me yourself, I\r\nchallenge you\xe2\x80\x94answer. Imagine that you are creating a fabric of human\r\ndestiny with the object of making men happy in the end, giving them\r\npeace and rest at last, but that it was essential and inevitable to\r\ntorture to death only one tiny creature\xe2\x80\x94that baby beating its breast\r\nwith its fist, for instance\xe2\x80\x94and to found that edifice on its unavenged\r\ntears, would you consent to be the architect on those conditions? Tell\r\nme, and tell the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t consent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd can you admit the idea that men for whom you are building it would\r\nagree to accept their happiness on the foundation of the unexpiated\r\nblood of a little victim? And accepting it would remain happy for\r\never?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I can\xe2\x80\x99t admit it. Brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha suddenly, with flashing\r\neyes, \xe2\x80\x9cyou said just now, is there a being in the whole world who would\r\nhave the right to forgive and could forgive? But there is a Being and\r\nHe can forgive everything, all and for all, because He gave His\r\ninnocent blood for all and everything. You have forgotten Him, and on\r\nHim is built the edifice, and it is to Him they cry aloud, \xe2\x80\x98Thou art\r\njust, O Lord, for Thy ways are revealed!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! the One without sin and His blood! No, I have not forgotten Him;\r\non the contrary I\xe2\x80\x99ve been wondering all the time how it was you did not\r\nbring Him in before, for usually all arguments on your side put Him in\r\nthe foreground. Do you know, Alyosha\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t laugh! I made a poem about a\r\nyear ago. If you can waste another ten minutes on me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell it to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wrote a poem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t write it,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Ivan, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ve never written two\r\nlines of poetry in my life. But I made up this poem in prose and I\r\nremembered it. I was carried away when I made it up. You will be my\r\nfirst reader\xe2\x80\x94that is listener. Why should an author forego even one\r\nlistener?\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I tell it to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poem is called \xe2\x80\x98The Grand Inquisitor\xe2\x80\x99; it\xe2\x80\x99s a ridiculous thing, but\r\nI want to tell it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter V.\r\nThe Grand Inquisitor\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven this must have a preface\xe2\x80\x94that is, a literary preface,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed\r\nIvan, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am a poor hand at making one. You see, my action takes\r\nplace in the sixteenth century, and at that time, as you probably\r\nlearnt at school, it was customary in poetry to bring down heavenly\r\npowers on earth. Not to speak of Dante, in France, clerks, as well as\r\nthe monks in the monasteries, used to give regular performances in\r\nwhich the Madonna, the saints, the angels, Christ, and God himself were\r\nbrought on the stage. In those days it was done in all simplicity. In\r\nVictor Hugo\xe2\x80\x99s _Notre Dame de Paris_ an edifying and gratuitous\r\nspectacle was provided for the people in the H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville of Paris in\r\nthe reign of Louis XI. in honor of the birth of the dauphin. It was\r\ncalled _Le bon jugement de la tr\xc3\xa8s sainte et gracieuse Vierge Marie_,\r\nand she appears herself on the stage and pronounces her _bon jugement_.\r\nSimilar plays, chiefly from the Old Testament, were occasionally\r\nperformed in Moscow too, up to the times of Peter the Great. But\r\nbesides plays there were all sorts of legends and ballads scattered\r\nabout the world, in which the saints and angels and all the powers of\r\nHeaven took part when required. In our monasteries the monks busied\r\nthemselves in translating, copying, and even composing such poems\xe2\x80\x94and\r\neven under the Tatars. There is, for instance, one such poem (of\r\ncourse, from the Greek), _The Wanderings of Our Lady through Hell_,\r\nwith descriptions as bold as Dante\xe2\x80\x99s. Our Lady visits hell, and the\r\nArchangel Michael leads her through the torments. She sees the sinners\r\nand their punishment. There she sees among others one noteworthy set of\r\nsinners in a burning lake; some of them sink to the bottom of the lake\r\nso that they can\xe2\x80\x99t swim out, and \xe2\x80\x98these God forgets\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94an expression of\r\nextraordinary depth and force. And so Our Lady, shocked and weeping,\r\nfalls before the throne of God and begs for mercy for all in hell\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nall she has seen there, indiscriminately. Her conversation with God is\r\nimmensely interesting. She beseeches Him, she will not desist, and when\r\nGod points to the hands and feet of her Son, nailed to the Cross, and\r\nasks, \xe2\x80\x98How can I forgive His tormentors?\xe2\x80\x99 she bids all the saints, all\r\nthe martyrs, all the angels and archangels to fall down with her and\r\npray for mercy on all without distinction. It ends by her winning from\r\nGod a respite of suffering every year from Good Friday till Trinity\r\nDay, and the sinners at once raise a cry of thankfulness from hell,\r\nchanting, \xe2\x80\x98Thou art just, O Lord, in this judgment.\xe2\x80\x99 Well, my poem\r\nwould have been of that kind if it had appeared at that time. He comes\r\non the scene in my poem, but He says nothing, only appears and passes\r\non. Fifteen centuries have passed since He promised to come in His\r\nglory, fifteen centuries since His prophet wrote, \xe2\x80\x98Behold, I come\r\nquickly\xe2\x80\x99; \xe2\x80\x98Of that day and that hour knoweth no man, neither the Son,\r\nbut the Father,\xe2\x80\x99 as He Himself predicted on earth. But humanity awaits\r\nhim with the same faith and with the same love. Oh, with greater faith,\r\nfor it is fifteen centuries since man has ceased to see signs from\r\nheaven.\r\n\r\nNo signs from heaven come to\xe2\x80\x90day\r\nTo add to what the heart doth say.\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was nothing left but faith in what the heart doth say. It is true\r\nthere were many miracles in those days. There were saints who performed\r\nmiraculous cures; some holy people, according to their biographies,\r\nwere visited by the Queen of Heaven herself. But the devil did not\r\nslumber, and doubts were already arising among men of the truth of\r\nthese miracles. And just then there appeared in the north of Germany a\r\nterrible new heresy. \xe2\x80\x9cA huge star like to a torch\xe2\x80\x9d (that is, to a\r\nchurch) \xe2\x80\x9cfell on the sources of the waters and they became bitter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThese heretics began blasphemously denying miracles. But those who\r\nremained faithful were all the more ardent in their faith. The tears of\r\nhumanity rose up to Him as before, awaited His coming, loved Him, hoped\r\nfor Him, yearned to suffer and die for Him as before. And so many ages\r\nmankind had prayed with faith and fervor, \xe2\x80\x9cO Lord our God, hasten Thy\r\ncoming,\xe2\x80\x9d so many ages called upon Him, that in His infinite mercy He\r\ndeigned to come down to His servants. Before that day He had come down,\r\nHe had visited some holy men, martyrs and hermits, as is written in\r\ntheir lives. Among us, Tyutchev, with absolute faith in the truth of\r\nhis words, bore witness that\r\n\r\nBearing the Cross, in slavish dress,\r\nWeary and worn, the Heavenly King\r\nOur mother, Russia, came to bless,\r\nAnd through our land went wandering.\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd that certainly was so, I assure you.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd behold, He deigned to appear for a moment to the people, to the\r\ntortured, suffering people, sunk in iniquity, but loving Him like\r\nchildren. My story is laid in Spain, in Seville, in the most terrible\r\ntime of the Inquisition, when fires were lighted every day to the glory\r\nof God, and \xe2\x80\x98in the splendid _auto da f\xc3\xa9_ the wicked heretics were\r\nburnt.\xe2\x80\x99 Oh, of course, this was not the coming in which He will appear\r\naccording to His promise at the end of time in all His heavenly glory,\r\nand which will be sudden \xe2\x80\x98as lightning flashing from east to west.\xe2\x80\x99 No,\r\nHe visited His children only for a moment, and there where the flames\r\nwere crackling round the heretics. In His infinite mercy He came once\r\nmore among men in that human shape in which He walked among men for\r\nthree years fifteen centuries ago. He came down to the \xe2\x80\x98hot pavements\xe2\x80\x99\r\nof the southern town in which on the day before almost a hundred\r\nheretics had, _ad majorem gloriam Dei_, been burnt by the cardinal, the\r\nGrand Inquisitor, in a magnificent _auto da f\xc3\xa9_, in the presence of the\r\nking, the court, the knights, the cardinals, the most charming ladies\r\nof the court, and the whole population of Seville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe came softly, unobserved, and yet, strange to say, every one\r\nrecognized Him. That might be one of the best passages in the poem. I\r\nmean, why they recognized Him. The people are irresistibly drawn to\r\nHim, they surround Him, they flock about Him, follow Him. He moves\r\nsilently in their midst with a gentle smile of infinite compassion. The\r\nsun of love burns in His heart, light and power shine from His eyes,\r\nand their radiance, shed on the people, stirs their hearts with\r\nresponsive love. He holds out His hands to them, blesses them, and a\r\nhealing virtue comes from contact with Him, even with His garments. An\r\nold man in the crowd, blind from childhood, cries out, \xe2\x80\x98O Lord, heal me\r\nand I shall see Thee!\xe2\x80\x99 and, as it were, scales fall from his eyes and\r\nthe blind man sees Him. The crowd weeps and kisses the earth under His\r\nfeet. Children throw flowers before Him, sing, and cry hosannah. \xe2\x80\x98It is\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x94it is He!\xe2\x80\x99 all repeat. \xe2\x80\x98It must be He, it can be no one but Him!\xe2\x80\x99 He\r\nstops at the steps of the Seville cathedral at the moment when the\r\nweeping mourners are bringing in a little open white coffin. In it lies\r\na child of seven, the only daughter of a prominent citizen. The dead\r\nchild lies hidden in flowers. \xe2\x80\x98He will raise your child,\xe2\x80\x99 the crowd\r\nshouts to the weeping mother. The priest, coming to meet the coffin,\r\nlooks perplexed, and frowns, but the mother of the dead child throws\r\nherself at His feet with a wail. \xe2\x80\x98If it is Thou, raise my child!\xe2\x80\x99 she\r\ncries, holding out her hands to Him. The procession halts, the coffin\r\nis laid on the steps at His feet. He looks with compassion, and His\r\nlips once more softly pronounce, \xe2\x80\x98Maiden, arise!\xe2\x80\x99 and the maiden\r\narises. The little girl sits up in the coffin and looks round, smiling\r\nwith wide\xe2\x80\x90 open wondering eyes, holding a bunch of white roses they had\r\nput in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are cries, sobs, confusion among the people, and at that moment\r\nthe cardinal himself, the Grand Inquisitor, passes by the cathedral. He\r\nis an old man, almost ninety, tall and erect, with a withered face and\r\nsunken eyes, in which there is still a gleam of light. He is not\r\ndressed in his gorgeous cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s robes, as he was the day before,\r\nwhen he was burning the enemies of the Roman Church\xe2\x80\x94at this moment he\r\nis wearing his coarse, old, monk\xe2\x80\x99s cassock. At a distance behind him\r\ncome his gloomy assistants and slaves and the \xe2\x80\x98holy guard.\xe2\x80\x99 He stops at\r\nthe sight of the crowd and watches it from a distance. He sees\r\neverything; he sees them set the coffin down at His feet, sees the\r\nchild rise up, and his face darkens. He knits his thick gray brows and\r\nhis eyes gleam with a sinister fire. He holds out his finger and bids\r\nthe guards take Him. And such is his power, so completely are the\r\npeople cowed into submission and trembling obedience to him, that the\r\ncrowd immediately makes way for the guards, and in the midst of\r\ndeathlike silence they lay hands on Him and lead Him away. The crowd\r\ninstantly bows down to the earth, like one man, before the old\r\nInquisitor. He blesses the people in silence and passes on. The guards\r\nlead their prisoner to the close, gloomy vaulted prison in the ancient\r\npalace of the Holy Inquisition and shut Him in it. The day passes and\r\nis followed by the dark, burning, \xe2\x80\x98breathless\xe2\x80\x99 night of Seville. The\r\nair is \xe2\x80\x98fragrant with laurel and lemon.\xe2\x80\x99 In the pitch darkness the iron\r\ndoor of the prison is suddenly opened and the Grand Inquisitor himself\r\ncomes in with a light in his hand. He is alone; the door is closed at\r\nonce behind him. He stands in the doorway and for a minute or two gazes\r\ninto His face. At last he goes up slowly, sets the light on the table\r\nand speaks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98Is it Thou? Thou?\xe2\x80\x99 but receiving no answer, he adds at once, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nanswer, be silent. What canst Thou say, indeed? I know too well what\r\nThou wouldst say. And Thou hast no right to add anything to what Thou\r\nhadst said of old. Why, then, art Thou come to hinder us? For Thou hast\r\ncome to hinder us, and Thou knowest that. But dost Thou know what will\r\nbe to\xe2\x80\x90 morrow? I know not who Thou art and care not to know whether it\r\nis Thou or only a semblance of Him, but to\xe2\x80\x90morrow I shall condemn Thee\r\nand burn Thee at the stake as the worst of heretics. And the very\r\npeople who have to\xe2\x80\x90day kissed Thy feet, to\xe2\x80\x90morrow at the faintest sign\r\nfrom me will rush to heap up the embers of Thy fire. Knowest Thou that?\r\nYes, maybe Thou knowest it,\xe2\x80\x99 he added with thoughtful penetration,\r\nnever for a moment taking his eyes off the Prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand, Ivan. What does it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha, who had\r\nbeen listening in silence, said with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it simply a wild\r\nfantasy, or a mistake on the part of the old man\xe2\x80\x94some impossible\r\n_quiproquo_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it as the last,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cif you are so corrupted by\r\nmodern realism and can\xe2\x80\x99t stand anything fantastic. If you like it to be\r\na case of mistaken identity, let it be so. It is true,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on,\r\nlaughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthe old man was ninety, and he might well be crazy over his\r\nset idea. He might have been struck by the appearance of the Prisoner.\r\nIt might, in fact, be simply his ravings, the delusion of an old man of\r\nninety, over\xe2\x80\x90excited by the _auto da f\xc3\xa9_ of a hundred heretics the day\r\nbefore. But does it matter to us after all whether it was a mistake of\r\nidentity or a wild fantasy? All that matters is that the old man should\r\nspeak out, should speak openly of what he has thought in silence for\r\nninety years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the Prisoner too is silent? Does He look at him and not say a\r\nword?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s inevitable in any case,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan laughed again. \xe2\x80\x9cThe old man has\r\ntold Him He hasn\xe2\x80\x99t the right to add anything to what He has said of\r\nold. One may say it is the most fundamental feature of Roman\r\nCatholicism, in my opinion at least. \xe2\x80\x98All has been given by Thee to the\r\nPope,\xe2\x80\x99 they say, \xe2\x80\x98and all, therefore, is still in the Pope\xe2\x80\x99s hands, and\r\nthere is no need for Thee to come now at all. Thou must not meddle for\r\nthe time, at least.\xe2\x80\x99 That\xe2\x80\x99s how they speak and write too\xe2\x80\x94the Jesuits,\r\nat any rate. I have read it myself in the works of their theologians.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hast Thou the right to reveal to us one of the mysteries of that world\r\nfrom which Thou hast come?\xe2\x80\x99 my old man asks Him, and answers the\r\nquestion for Him. \xe2\x80\x98No, Thou hast not; that Thou mayest not add to what\r\nhas been said of old, and mayest not take from men the freedom which\r\nThou didst exalt when Thou wast on earth. Whatsoever Thou revealest\r\nanew will encroach on men\xe2\x80\x99s freedom of faith; for it will be manifest\r\nas a miracle, and the freedom of their faith was dearer to Thee than\r\nanything in those days fifteen hundred years ago. Didst Thou not often\r\nsay then, \xe2\x80\x9cI will make you free\xe2\x80\x9d? But now Thou hast seen these \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nmen,\xe2\x80\x99 the old man adds suddenly, with a pensive smile. \xe2\x80\x98Yes, we\xe2\x80\x99ve paid\r\ndearly for it,\xe2\x80\x99 he goes on, looking sternly at Him, \xe2\x80\x98but at last we\r\nhave completed that work in Thy name. For fifteen centuries we have\r\nbeen wrestling with Thy freedom, but now it is ended and over for good.\r\nDost Thou not believe that it\xe2\x80\x99s over for good? Thou lookest meekly at\r\nme and deignest not even to be wroth with me. But let me tell Thee that\r\nnow, to\xe2\x80\x90day, people are more persuaded than ever that they have perfect\r\nfreedom, yet they have brought their freedom to us and laid it humbly\r\nat our feet. But that has been our doing. Was this what Thou didst? Was\r\nthis Thy freedom?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand again,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha broke in. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he ironical, is he\r\njesting?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit of it! He claims it as a merit for himself and his Church\r\nthat at last they have vanquished freedom and have done so to make men\r\nhappy. \xe2\x80\x98For now\xe2\x80\x99 (he is speaking of the Inquisition, of course) \xe2\x80\x98for\r\nthe first time it has become possible to think of the happiness of men.\r\nMan was created a rebel; and how can rebels be happy? Thou wast\r\nwarned,\xe2\x80\x99 he says to Him. \xe2\x80\x98Thou hast had no lack of admonitions and\r\nwarnings, but Thou didst not listen to those warnings; Thou didst\r\nreject the only way by which men might be made happy. But, fortunately,\r\ndeparting Thou didst hand on the work to us. Thou hast promised, Thou\r\nhast established by Thy word, Thou hast given to us the right to bind\r\nand to unbind, and now, of course, Thou canst not think of taking it\r\naway.
