Every one followed him out, bowing and wishing him good luck.\r\nAndrey, coughing from the brandy he had just swallowed, jumped up on\r\nthe box. He played a second game, and suddenly began telling\r\none of his partners that Dmitri Karamazov had come in for some cash\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94something like three thousand roubles, and had gone to Mokroe\r\nagain to spend it with Grushenka.... When he reached the market\xe2\x80\x90place\r\nhe stood still in perplexity, wondering at himself. He realized that\r\nwhat he wanted was to go to Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s and find out if\r\nanything had happened there. \xe2\x80\x9cOn account of some stupid nonsense\xe2\x80\x94as\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s sure to turn out\xe2\x80\x94am I going to wake up the household and make a\r\nscandal? And no one answered him; every one in the house was\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I shall be making a fuss!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, with a feeling of positive\r\ndiscomfort. It was a little\r\nmore than twenty versts to Mokroe, but Andrey\xe2\x80\x99s three horses galloped\r\nat such a pace that the distance might be covered in an hour and a\r\nquarter. The swift motion revived Mitya. The air was fresh and cool,\r\nthere were big stars shining in the sky. It was the very night, and\r\nperhaps the very hour, in which Alyosha fell on the earth, and\r\nrapturously swore to love it for ever and ever.\r\n\r\nAll was confusion, confusion, in Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s soul, but although many things\r\nwere goading his heart, at that moment his whole being was yearning for\r\nher, his queen, to whom he was flying to look on her for the last time.\r\nOne thing I can say for certain; his heart did not waver for one\r\ninstant. I shall perhaps not be believed when I say that this jealous\r\nlover felt not the slightest jealousy of this new rival, who seemed to\r\nhave sprung out of the earth. If any other had appeared on the scene,\r\nhe would have been jealous at once, and would perhaps have stained his\r\nfierce hands with blood again. But as he flew through the night, he\r\nfelt no envy, no hostility even, for the man who had been her first\r\nlover.... It is true he had not yet seen him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere there was no room for dispute: it was her right and his; this was\r\nher first love which, after five years, she had not forgotten; so she\r\nhad loved him only for those five years, and I, how do I come in? What\r\nright have I? Step aside, Mitya, and make way! What am I now? Now\r\neverything is over apart from the officer\xe2\x80\x94even if he had not appeared,\r\neverything would be over ...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words would roughly have expressed his feelings, if he had been\r\ncapable of reasoning. But he could not reason at that moment. His\r\npresent plan of action had arisen without reasoning. At Fenya\xe2\x80\x99s first\r\nwords, it had sprung from feeling, and been adopted in a flash, with\r\nall its consequences. And yet, in spite of his resolution, there was\r\nconfusion in his soul, an agonizing confusion: his resolution did not\r\ngive him peace. There was so much behind that tortured him. And it\r\nseemed strange to him, at moments, to think that he had written his own\r\nsentence of death with pen and paper: \xe2\x80\x9cI punish myself,\xe2\x80\x9d and the paper\r\nwas lying there in his pocket, ready; the pistol was loaded; he had\r\nalready resolved how, next morning, he would meet the first warm ray of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgolden\xe2\x80\x90haired Ph\xc5\x93bus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd yet he could not be quit of the past, of all that he had left\r\nbehind and that tortured him. But that moment flew by like a spark. The horses galloped on,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdevouring space,\xe2\x80\x9d and as he drew near his goal, again the thought of\r\nher, of her alone, took more and more complete possession of his soul,\r\nchasing away the fearful images that had been haunting it. I\r\nshall gallop up, I shall fall before her and say, \xe2\x80\x98You are right to\r\npass on and leave me. Farewell and forget your victim ... never fret\r\nyourself about me!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMokroe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Andrey, pointing ahead with his whip.\r\n\r\nThrough the pale darkness of the night loomed a solid black mass of\r\nbuildings, flung down, as it were, in the vast plain. The village of\r\nMokroe numbered two thousand inhabitants, but at that hour all were\r\nasleep, and only here and there a few lights still twinkled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrive on, Andrey, I come!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya exclaimed, feverishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not asleep,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrey again, pointing with his whip to the\r\nPlastunovs\xe2\x80\x99 inn, which was at the entrance to the village. The six\r\nwindows, looking on the street, were all brightly lighted up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not asleep,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya repeated joyously. \xe2\x80\x9cQuicker, Andrey!\r\nGallop! Drive up with a dash! Set the bells ringing! Let all know that\r\nI have come. I\xe2\x80\x99m coming! I\xe2\x80\x99m coming, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrey lashed his exhausted team into a gallop, drove with a dash and\r\npulled up his steaming, panting horses at the high flight of steps.\r\n\r\nMitya jumped out of the cart just as the innkeeper, on his way to bed,\r\npeeped out from the steps curious to see who had arrived.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrifon Borissovitch, is that you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe innkeeper bent down, looked intently, ran down the steps, and\r\nrushed up to the guest with obsequious delight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDmitri Fyodorovitch, your honor! Do I see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTrifon Borissovitch was a thick\xe2\x80\x90set, healthy peasant, of middle height,\r\nwith a rather fat face. His expression was severe and uncompromising,\r\nespecially with the peasants of Mokroe, but he had the power of\r\nassuming the most obsequious countenance, when he had an inkling that\r\nit was to his interest. He dressed in Russian style, with a shirt\r\nbuttoning down on one side, and a full\xe2\x80\x90skirted coat. He had saved a\r\ngood sum of money, but was for ever dreaming of improving his position.\r\nMore than half the peasants were in his clutches, every one in the\r\nneighborhood was in debt to him. From the neighboring landowners he\r\nbought and rented lands which were worked by the peasants, in payment\r\nof debts which they could never shake off. He was a widower, with four\r\ngrown\xe2\x80\x90up daughters. One of them was already a widow and lived in the\r\ninn with her two children, his grandchildren, and worked for him like a\r\ncharwoman. Another of his daughters was married to a petty official,\r\nand in one of the rooms of the inn, on the wall could be seen, among\r\nthe family photographs, a miniature photograph of this official in\r\nuniform and official epaulettes. The two younger daughters used to wear\r\nfashionable blue or green dresses, fitting tight at the back, and with\r\ntrains a yard long, on Church holidays or when they went to pay visits.\r\nBut next morning they would get up at dawn, as usual, sweep out the\r\nrooms with a birch\xe2\x80\x90broom, empty the slops, and clean up after lodgers.\r\n\r\nIn spite of the thousands of roubles he had saved, Trifon Borissovitch\r\nwas very fond of emptying the pockets of a drunken guest, and\r\nremembering that not a month ago he had, in twenty\xe2\x80\x90four hours, made two\r\nif not three hundred roubles out of Dmitri, when he had come on his\r\nescapade with Grushenka, he met him now with eager welcome, scenting\r\nhis prey the moment Mitya drove up to the steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDmitri Fyodorovitch, dear sir, we see you once more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Trifon Borissovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d began Mitya, \xe2\x80\x9cfirst and foremost, where is\r\nshe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgrafena Alexandrovna?\xe2\x80\x9d The inn\xe2\x80\x90keeper understood at once, looking\r\nsharply into Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s face. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s here, too ...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom? With whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome strangers. One is an official gentleman, a Pole, to judge from\r\nhis speech. He sent the horses for her from here; and there\xe2\x80\x99s another\r\nwith him, a friend of his, or a fellow traveler, there\xe2\x80\x99s no telling.\r\nThey\xe2\x80\x99re dressed like civilians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are they feasting? Have they money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor sort of a feast! Nothing to boast of, Dmitri Fyodorovitch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to boast of? And who are the others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re two gentlemen from the town.... They\xe2\x80\x99ve come back from\r\nTcherny, and are putting up here. One\xe2\x80\x99s quite a young gentleman, a\r\nrelative of Mr. Mi\xc3\xbcsov, he must be, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten his name ... and\r\nI expect you know the other, too, a gentleman called Maximov. He\xe2\x80\x99s been\r\non a pilgrimage, so he says, to the monastery in the town. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntraveling with this young relation of Mr. Mi\xc3\xbcsov.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, listen, Trifon Borissovitch. Tell me the chief thing: What of\r\nher? How is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, she\xe2\x80\x99s only just come. She\xe2\x80\x99s sitting with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs she cheerful? Is she laughing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I think she\xe2\x80\x99s not laughing much. She\xe2\x80\x99s sitting quite dull. She\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncombing the young gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s hair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Pole\xe2\x80\x94the officer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s not young, and he\xe2\x80\x99s not an officer, either. Not him, sir. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe young gentleman that\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Mi\xc3\xbcsov\xe2\x80\x99s relation ... I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten his\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKalganov.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, Kalganov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see for myself. Are they playing cards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have been playing, but they\xe2\x80\x99ve left off. They\xe2\x80\x99ve been drinking\r\ntea, the official gentleman asked for liqueurs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Trifon Borissovitch, stay, my good soul, I\xe2\x80\x99ll see for myself.\r\nNow answer one more question: are the gypsies here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t have the gypsies now, Dmitri Fyodorovitch. The authorities\r\nhave sent them away. But we\xe2\x80\x99ve Jews that play the cymbals and the\r\nfiddle in the village, so one might send for them. They\xe2\x80\x99d come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend for them. Certainly send for them!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can get\r\nthe girls together as you did then, Marya especially, Stepanida, too,\r\nand Arina. Two hundred roubles for a chorus!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, for a sum like that I can get all the village together, though by\r\nnow they\xe2\x80\x99re asleep. Are the peasants here worth such kindness, Dmitri\r\nFyodorovitch, or the girls either? To spend a sum like that on such\r\ncoarseness and rudeness! What\xe2\x80\x99s the good of giving a peasant a cigar to\r\nsmoke, the stinking ruffian! And the girls are all lousy. Besides, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nget my daughters up for nothing, let alone a sum like that. They\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nonly just gone to bed, I\xe2\x80\x99ll give them a kick and set them singing for\r\nyou. You gave the peasants champagne to drink the other day, e\xe2\x80\x94ech!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor all his pretended compassion for Mitya, Trifon Borissovitch had\r\nhidden half a dozen bottles of champagne on that last occasion, and had\r\npicked up a hundred\xe2\x80\x90rouble note under the table, and it had remained in\r\nhis clutches.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrifon Borissovitch, I sent more than one thousand flying last time I\r\nwas here. Do you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did send it flying. I may well remember. You must have left three\r\nthousand behind you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to do the same again, do you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he pulled out his roll of notes, and held them up before the\r\ninnkeeper\xe2\x80\x99s nose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, listen and remember. In an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time the wine will arrive,\r\nsavories, pies, and sweets\xe2\x80\x94bring them all up at once. That box Andrey\r\nhas got is to be brought up at once, too. Open it, and hand champagne\r\nimmediately. And the girls, we must have the girls, Marya especially.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned to the cart and pulled out the box of pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Andrey, let\xe2\x80\x99s settle. Here\xe2\x80\x99s fifteen roubles for the drive, and\r\nfifty for vodka ... for your readiness, for your love.... Remember\r\nKaramazov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d faltered Andrey. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me five roubles extra, but\r\nmore I won\xe2\x80\x99t take. Trifon Borissovitch, bear witness. Forgive my\r\nfoolish words ...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you afraid of?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mitya, scanning him. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, go to the\r\ndevil, if that\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, flinging him five roubles. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, Trifon\r\nBorissovitch, take me up quietly and let me first get a look at them,\r\nso that they don\xe2\x80\x99t see me. Where are they? In the blue room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTrifon Borissovitch looked apprehensively at Mitya, but at once\r\nobediently did his bidding. Leading him into the passage, he went\r\nhimself into the first large room, adjoining that in which the visitors\r\nwere sitting, and took the light away. Then he stealthily led Mitya in,\r\nand put him in a corner in the dark, whence he could freely watch the\r\ncompany without being seen. But Mitya did not look long, and, indeed,\r\nhe could not see them, he saw her, his heart throbbed violently, and\r\nall was dark before his eyes.\r\n\r\nShe was sitting sideways to the table in a low chair, and beside her,\r\non the sofa, was the pretty youth, Kalganov. She was holding his hand\r\nand seemed to be laughing, while he, seeming vexed and not looking at\r\nher, was saying something in a loud voice to Maximov, who sat the other\r\nside of the table, facing Grushenka. Maximov was laughing violently at\r\nsomething. On the sofa sat _he_, and on a chair by the sofa there was\r\nanother stranger. The one on the sofa was lolling backwards, smoking a\r\npipe, and Mitya had an impression of a stoutish, broad\xe2\x80\x90faced, short\r\nlittle man, who was apparently angry about something. His friend, the\r\nother stranger, struck Mitya as extraordinarily tall, but he could make\r\nout nothing more. He caught his breath. He could not bear it for a\r\nminute, he put the pistol\xe2\x80\x90 case on a chest, and with a throbbing heart\r\nhe walked, feeling cold all over, straight into the blue room to face\r\nthe company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAie!\xe2\x80\x9d shrieked Grushenka, the first to notice him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\nThe First And Rightful Lover\r\n\r\n\r\nWith his long, rapid strides, Mitya walked straight up to the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a loud voice, almost shouting, yet stammering\r\nat every word, \xe2\x80\x9cI ... I\xe2\x80\x99m all right! Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing the matter,\xe2\x80\x9d he turned suddenly to Grushenka, who\r\nhad shrunk back in her chair towards Kalganov, and clasped his hand\r\ntightly. \xe2\x80\x9cI ... I\xe2\x80\x99m coming, too. I\xe2\x80\x99m here till morning. Gentlemen, may\r\nI stay with you till morning? Only till morning, for the last time, in\r\nthis same room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo he finished, turning to the fat little man, with the pipe, sitting\r\non the sofa. The latter removed his pipe from his lips with dignity and\r\nobserved severely:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Panie_, we\xe2\x80\x99re here in private. There are other rooms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it\xe2\x80\x99s you, Dmitri Fyodorovitch! What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nKalganov suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cSit down with us. How are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelighted to see you, dear ... and precious fellow, I always thought a\r\nlot of you.\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya responded, joyfully and eagerly, at once holding out\r\nhis hand across the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAie! How tight you squeeze! You\xe2\x80\x99ve quite broken my fingers,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed\r\nKalganov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe always squeezes like that, always,\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka put in gayly, with a\r\ntimid smile, seeming suddenly convinced from Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s face that he was\r\nnot going to make a scene. She was watching him with intense curiosity\r\nand still some uneasiness. She was impressed by something about him,\r\nand indeed the last thing she expected of him was that he would come in\r\nand speak like this at such a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood evening,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov ventured blandly on the left. Mitya rushed up\r\nto him, too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood evening. You\xe2\x80\x99re here, too! How glad I am to find you here, too!\r\nGentlemen, gentlemen, I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d (He addressed the Polish gentleman with the\r\npipe again, evidently taking him for the most important person\r\npresent.) \xe2\x80\x9cI flew here.... I wanted to spend my last day, my last hour\r\nin this room, in this very room ... where I, too, adored ... my\r\nqueen.... Forgive me, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried wildly, \xe2\x80\x9cI flew here and\r\nvowed\xe2\x80\x94 Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, it\xe2\x80\x99s my last night! Let\xe2\x80\x99s drink to our good\r\nunderstanding. They\xe2\x80\x99ll bring the wine at once.... I brought this with\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d (Something made him pull out his bundle of notes.) \xe2\x80\x9cAllow me,\r\n_panie_! I want to have music, singing, a revel, as we had before. But\r\nthe worm, the unnecessary worm, will crawl away, and there\xe2\x80\x99ll be no\r\nmore of him. I will commemorate my day of joy on my last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was almost choking. There was so much, so much he wanted to say, but\r\nstrange exclamations were all that came from his lips. The Pole gazed\r\nfixedly at him, at the bundle of notes in his hand; looked at\r\nGrushenka, and was in evident perplexity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my suverin lady is permitting\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he was beginning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does \xe2\x80\x98suverin\xe2\x80\x99 mean? \xe2\x80\x98Sovereign,\xe2\x80\x99 I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\r\nGrushenka. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t help laughing at you, the way you talk. Sit down,\r\nMitya, what are you talking about? Don\xe2\x80\x99t frighten us, please. You won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfrighten us, will you? If you won\xe2\x80\x99t, I am glad to see you ...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe, me frighten you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, flinging up his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, pass me\r\nby, go your way, I won\xe2\x80\x99t hinder you!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd suddenly he surprised them all, and no doubt himself as well, by\r\nflinging himself on a chair, and bursting into tears, turning his head\r\naway to the opposite wall, while his arms clasped the back of the chair\r\ntight, as though embracing it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, what a fellow you are!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grushenka reproachfully.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just how he comes to see me\xe2\x80\x94he begins talking, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t make\r\nout what he means. He cried like that once before, and now he\xe2\x80\x99s crying\r\nagain! It\xe2\x80\x99s shameful! Why are you crying? _As though you had anything\r\nto cry for!_\xe2\x80\x9d she added enigmatically, emphasizing each word with some\r\nirritability.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ... I\xe2\x80\x99m not crying.... Well, good evening!\xe2\x80\x9d He instantly turned\r\nround in his chair, and suddenly laughed, not his abrupt wooden laugh,\r\nbut a long, quivering, inaudible nervous laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there you are again.... Come, cheer up, cheer up!\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka\r\nsaid to him persuasively. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m very glad you\xe2\x80\x99ve come, very glad, Mitya,\r\ndo you hear, I\xe2\x80\x99m very glad! I want him to stay here with us,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\r\nperemptorily, addressing the whole company, though her words were\r\nobviously meant for the man sitting on the sofa. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish it, I wish it!\r\nAnd if he goes away I shall go, too!\xe2\x80\x9d she added with flashing eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat my queen commands is law!\xe2\x80\x9d pronounced the Pole, gallantly kissing\r\nGrushenka\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI beg you, _panie_, to join our company,\xe2\x80\x9d he added\r\npolitely, addressing Mitya.\r\n\r\nMitya was jumping up with the obvious intention of delivering another\r\ntirade, but the words did not come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s drink, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x9d he blurted out instead of making a speech.\r\nEvery one laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens! I thought he was going to begin again!\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka\r\nexclaimed nervously. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear, Mitya,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on insistently,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t prance about, but it\xe2\x80\x99s nice you\xe2\x80\x99ve brought the champagne. I want\r\nsome myself, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear liqueurs. And best of all, you\xe2\x80\x99ve come\r\nyourself. We were fearfully dull here.... You\xe2\x80\x99ve come for a spree\r\nagain, I suppose? But put your money in your pocket. Where did you get\r\nsuch a lot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya had been, all this time, holding in his hand the crumpled bundle\r\nof notes on which the eyes of all, especially of the Poles, were fixed.\r\nIn confusion he thrust them hurriedly into his pocket. He flushed. At\r\nthat moment the innkeeper brought in an uncorked bottle of champagne,\r\nand glasses on a tray. Mitya snatched up the bottle, but he was so\r\nbewildered that he did not know what to do with it. Kalganov took it\r\nfrom him and poured out the champagne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother! Another bottle!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya cried to the innkeeper, and,\r\nforgetting to clink glasses with the Pole whom he had so solemnly\r\ninvited to drink to their good understanding, he drank off his glass\r\nwithout waiting for any one else. His whole countenance suddenly\r\nchanged. The solemn and tragic expression with which he had entered\r\nvanished completely, and a look of something childlike came into his\r\nface. He seemed to have become suddenly gentle and subdued. He looked\r\nshyly and happily at every one, with a continual nervous little laugh,\r\nand the blissful expression of a dog who has done wrong, been punished,\r\nand forgiven. He seemed to have forgotten everything, and was looking\r\nround at every one with a childlike smile of delight. He looked at\r\nGrushenka, laughing continually, and bringing his chair close up to\r\nher. By degrees he had gained some idea of the two Poles, though he had\r\nformed no definite conception of them yet.\r\n\r\nThe Pole on the sofa struck him by his dignified demeanor and his\r\nPolish accent; and, above all, by his pipe. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what of it? It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ngood thing he\xe2\x80\x99s smoking a pipe,\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected. The Pole\xe2\x80\x99s puffy,\r\nmiddle\xe2\x80\x90aged face, with its tiny nose and two very thin, pointed, dyed\r\nand impudent\xe2\x80\x90looking mustaches, had not so far roused the faintest\r\ndoubts in Mitya. He was not even particularly struck by the Pole\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsurd wig made in Siberia, with love\xe2\x80\x90locks foolishly combed forward\r\nover the temples. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s all right since he wears a wig,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nwent on, musing blissfully. The other, younger Pole, who was staring\r\ninsolently and defiantly at the company and listening to the\r\nconversation with silent contempt, still only impressed Mitya by his\r\ngreat height, which was in striking contrast to the Pole on the sofa.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he stood up he\xe2\x80\x99d be six foot three.\xe2\x80\x9d The thought flitted through\r\nMitya\xe2\x80\x99s mind. It occurred to him, too, that this Pole must be the\r\nfriend of the other, as it were, a \xe2\x80\x9cbodyguard,\xe2\x80\x9d and no doubt the big\r\nPole was at the disposal of the little Pole with the pipe. But this all\r\nseemed to Mitya perfectly right and not to be questioned. In his mood\r\nof doglike submissiveness all feeling of rivalry had died away.\r\n\r\nGrushenka\xe2\x80\x99s mood and the enigmatic tone of some of her words he\r\ncompletely failed to grasp. All he understood, with thrilling heart,\r\nwas that she was kind to him, that she had forgiven him, and made him\r\nsit by her. He was beside himself with delight, watching her sip her\r\nglass of champagne. The silence of the company seemed somehow to strike\r\nhim, however, and he looked round at every one with expectant eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are we sitting here though, gentlemen? Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you begin doing\r\nsomething?\xe2\x80\x9d his smiling eyes seemed to ask.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe keeps talking nonsense, and we were all laughing,\xe2\x80\x9d Kalganov began\r\nsuddenly, as though divining his thought, and pointing to Maximov.\r\n\r\nMitya immediately stared at Kalganov and then at Maximov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s talking nonsense?\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed, his short, wooden laugh, seeming\r\nsuddenly delighted at something\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cha ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Would you believe it, he will have it that all our cavalry\r\nofficers in the twenties married Polish women. That\xe2\x80\x99s awful rot, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPolish women?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mitya, perfectly ecstatic.\r\n\r\nKalganov was well aware of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s attitude to Grushenka, and he\r\nguessed about the Pole, too, but that did not so much interest him,\r\nperhaps did not interest him at all; what he was interested in was\r\nMaximov. He had come here with Maximov by chance, and he met the Poles\r\nhere at the inn for the first time in his life. Grushenka he knew\r\nbefore, and had once been with some one to see her; but she had not\r\ntaken to him. But here she looked at him very affectionately: before\r\nMitya\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, she had been making much of him, but he seemed somehow\r\nto be unmoved by it. He was a boy, not over twenty, dressed like a\r\ndandy, with a very charming fair\xe2\x80\x90 skinned face, and splendid thick,\r\nfair hair. From his fair face looked out beautiful pale blue eyes, with\r\nan intelligent and sometimes even deep expression, beyond his age\r\nindeed, although the young man sometimes looked and talked quite like a\r\nchild, and was not at all ashamed of it, even when he was aware of it\r\nhimself. As a rule he was very willful, even capricious, though always\r\nfriendly. Sometimes there was something fixed and obstinate in his\r\nexpression. He would look at you and listen, seeming all the while to\r\nbe persistently dreaming over something else. Often he was listless and\r\nlazy, at other times he would grow excited, sometimes, apparently, over\r\nthe most trivial matters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly imagine, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been taking him about with me for the last four\r\ndays,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, indolently drawling his words, quite naturally\r\nthough, without the slightest affectation. \xe2\x80\x9cEver since your brother, do\r\nyou remember, shoved him off the carriage and sent him flying. That\r\nmade me take an interest in him at the time, and I took him into the\r\ncountry, but he keeps talking such rot I\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed to be with him. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ntaking him back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gentleman has not seen Polish ladies, and says what is\r\nimpossible,\xe2\x80\x9d the Pole with the pipe observed to Maximov.\r\n\r\nHe spoke Russian fairly well, much better, anyway, than he pretended.\r\nIf he used Russian words, he always distorted them into a Polish form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I was married to a Polish lady myself,\xe2\x80\x9d tittered Maximov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut did you serve in the cavalry? You were talking about the cavalry.\r\nWere you a cavalry officer?\xe2\x80\x9d put in Kalganov at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he a cavalry officer indeed? Ha ha!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, listening\r\neagerly, and turning his inquiring eyes to each as he spoke, as though\r\nthere were no knowing what he might hear from each.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov turned to him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I mean is that those pretty\r\nPolish ladies ... when they danced the mazurka with our Uhlans ... when\r\none of them dances a mazurka with a Uhlan she jumps on his knee like a\r\nkitten ... a little white one ... and the _pan_\xe2\x80\x90father and _pan_\xe2\x80\x90mother\r\nlook on and allow it.... They allow it ... and next day the Uhlan comes\r\nand offers her his hand.... That\xe2\x80\x99s how it is ... offers her his hand,\r\nhe he!\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov ended, tittering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _pan_ is a _lajdak_!\xe2\x80\x9d the tall Pole on the chair growled suddenly\r\nand crossed one leg over the other. Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s eye was caught by his huge\r\ngreased boot, with its thick, dirty sole. The dress of both the Poles\r\nlooked rather greasy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now it\xe2\x80\x99s _lajdak_! Let him talk! People talk, why hinder them? It makes it\r\ncheerful,\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka said crossly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not hindering them, _pani_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pole in the wig, with a long\r\nlook at Grushenka, and relapsing into dignified silence he sucked his\r\npipe again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no. The Polish gentleman spoke the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d Kalganov got excited\r\nagain, as though it were a question of vast import. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s never been in\r\nPoland, so how can he talk about it? I suppose you weren\xe2\x80\x99t married in\r\nPoland, were you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, in the Province of Smolensk. Only, a Uhlan had brought her to\r\nRussia before that, my future wife, with her mamma and her aunt, and\r\nanother female relation with a grown\xe2\x80\x90up son. He brought her straight\r\nfrom Poland and gave her up to me. He was a lieutenant in our regiment,\r\na very nice young man. At first he meant to marry her himself. But he\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t marry her, because she turned out to be lame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you married a lame woman?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kalganov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. They both deceived me a little bit at the time, and concealed it.\r\nI thought she was hopping; she kept hopping.... I thought it was for\r\nfun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo pleased she was going to marry you!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled Kalganov, in a ringing,\r\nchildish voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, so pleased. He couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been\r\nthrashed then, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t, could he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was difficult to imagine what Kalganov was excited about, but his\r\nexcitement was genuine. What do you mean by \xe2\x80\x98lite\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Grushenka.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLate, _pani_! \xe2\x80\x98a late hour\xe2\x80\x99 I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d the Pole on the sofa explained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s always late with them. Before you came, Mitya, they were just as silent and\r\nkept turning up their noses at me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy goddess!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Pole on the sofa, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you\xe2\x80\x99re not\r\nwell\xe2\x80\x90disposed to me, that\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m gloomy. I\xe2\x80\x99m ready, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nhe, addressing Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegin, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya assented, pulling his notes out of his pocket,\r\nand laying two hundred\xe2\x80\x90rouble notes on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to lose a lot\r\nto you. Take your cards. Make the bank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll have cards from the landlord, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little Pole,\r\ngravely and emphatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s much the best way,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in Pan Vrublevsky.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the landlord? Very good, I understand, let\xe2\x80\x99s get them from him.\r\nCards!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya shouted to the landlord.\r\n\r\nThe landlord brought in a new, unopened pack, and informed Mitya that\r\nthe girls were getting ready, and that the Jews with the cymbals would\r\nmost likely be here soon; but the cart with the provisions had not yet\r\narrived. Mitya jumped up from the table and ran into the next room to\r\ngive orders, but only three girls had arrived, and Marya was not there\r\nyet. And he did not know himself what orders to give and why he had run\r\nout. He only told them to take out of the box the presents for the\r\ngirls, the sweets, the toffee and the fondants. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd vodka for Andrey,\r\nvodka for Andrey!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried in haste. \xe2\x80\x9cI was rude to Andrey!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly Maximov, who had followed him out, touched him on the\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me five roubles,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered to Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stake something at\r\nfaro, too, he he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital! Splendid! Take ten, here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain he took all the notes out of his pocket and picked out one for\r\nten roubles. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you lose that, come again, come again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov whispered joyfully, and he ran back again. Mitya,\r\ntoo, returned, apologizing for having kept them waiting. The Poles had\r\nalready sat down, and opened the pack. They looked much more amiable,\r\nalmost cordial. The Pole on the sofa had lighted another pipe and was\r\npreparing to throw. He wore an air of solemnity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your places, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pan Vrublevsky.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to play any more,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Kalganov, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve lost\r\nfifty roubles to them just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _pan_ had no luck, perhaps he\xe2\x80\x99ll be lucky this time,\xe2\x80\x9d the Pole on\r\nthe sofa observed in his direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much in the bank? To correspond?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s according, _panie_, maybe a hundred, maybe two hundred, as much\r\nas you will stake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA million!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Pan Captain has heard of Pan Podvysotsky, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat Podvysotsky?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Warsaw there was a bank and any one comes and stakes against it.\r\nPodvysotsky comes, sees a thousand gold pieces, stakes against the\r\nbank. The banker says, \xe2\x80\x98_Panie_ Podvysotsky, are you laying down the\r\ngold, or must we trust to your honor?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98To my honor, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nPodvysotsky. \xe2\x80\x98So much the better.\xe2\x80\x99 The banker throws the dice.\r\nPodvysotsky wins. \xe2\x80\x98Take it, _panie_,\xe2\x80\x99 says the banker, and pulling out\r\nthe drawer he gives him a million. \xe2\x80\x98Take it, _panie_, this is your\r\ngain.\xe2\x80\x99 There was a million in the bank. \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know that,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nPodvysotsky. \xe2\x80\x98_Panie_ Podvysotsky,\xe2\x80\x99 said the banker, \xe2\x80\x98you pledged your\r\nhonor and we pledged ours.\xe2\x80\x99 Podvysotsky took the million.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kalganov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Panie_ Kalganov, in gentlemanly society one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say such things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs if a Polish gambler would give away a million!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, but\r\nchecked himself at once. \xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, _panie_, it\xe2\x80\x99s my fault again, he\r\nwould, he would give away a million, for honor, for Polish honor. You\r\nsee how I talk Polish, ha ha! Here, I stake ten roubles, the knave\r\nleads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I put a rouble on the queen, the queen of hearts, the pretty\r\nlittle _panienotchka_, he he!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Maximov, pulling out his queen,\r\nand, as though trying to conceal it from every one, he moved right up\r\nand crossed himself hurriedly under the table. Mitya won. The rouble\r\nwon, too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA corner!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bet another rouble, a \xe2\x80\x98single\xe2\x80\x99 stake,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov muttered\r\ngleefully, hugely delighted at having won a rouble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLost!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cA \xe2\x80\x98double\xe2\x80\x99 on the seven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe seven too was trumped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kalganov suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDouble! Double!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya doubled his stakes, and each time he doubled\r\nthe stake, the card he doubled was trumped by the Poles. The rouble\r\nstakes kept winning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the double!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Mitya furiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve lost two hundred, _panie_. All\r\ndoubles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd pulling his money out of his pocket, Mitya was about to fling two\r\nhundred roubles on the queen, but Kalganov covered it with his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s enough!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted in his ringing voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya stared at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s enough! He\r\nagreed at once, however, on condition that Pan Vrublevsky went with\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bodyguard? Let him come, and I want him, too. There was a\r\nlighted candle on a small deal table in the corner. The small man and\r\nMitya sat down to this table, facing each other, while the huge\r\nVrublevsky stood beside them, his hands behind his back. The Poles\r\nlooked severe but were evidently inquisitive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do for you, _panie_?\xe2\x80\x9d lisped the little Pole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, look here, _panie_, I won\xe2\x80\x99t keep you long. The Pole walked into the\r\nroom and threw himself in a theatrical attitude before Grushenka.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pani_ Agrippina, I have received a mortal insult!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. Where did you get your wig from?\r\nHe was a falcon, but this is a gander. He used to laugh and sing to\r\nme.... I could send\r\nyou to Siberia for playing with false cards, d\xe2\x80\x99you know that, for it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njust the same as false banknotes....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd going up to the sofa he thrust his fingers between the sofa back\r\nand the cushion, and pulled out an unopened pack of cards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s my pack unopened!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe held it up and showed it to all in the room. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom where I stood I\r\nsaw him slip my pack away, and put his in place of it\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re a cheat\r\nand not a gentleman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I twice saw the _pan_ change a card!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kalganov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow shameful! How shameful!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Grushenka, clasping her hands,\r\nand blushing for genuine shame. \xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord, he\xe2\x80\x99s come to that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so, too!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mitya. But before he had uttered the words,\r\nVrublevsky, with a confused and infuriated face, shook his fist at\r\nGrushenka, shouting:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou low harlot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya flew at him at once, clutched him in both hands, lifted him in\r\nthe air, and in one instant had carried him into the room on the right,\r\nfrom which they had just come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve laid him on the floor, there,\xe2\x80\x9d he announced, returning at once,\r\ngasping with excitement. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s struggling, the scoundrel! But he won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome back, no fear of that!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe closed one half of the folding doors, and holding the other ajar\r\ncalled out to the little Pole:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost illustrious, will you be pleased to retire as well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Dmitri Fyodorovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d said Trifon Borissovitch, \xe2\x80\x9cmake them\r\ngive you back the money you lost. It\xe2\x80\x99s as good as stolen from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want my fifty roubles back,\xe2\x80\x9d Kalganov declared suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want my two hundred, either,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take it\r\nfor anything! Let him keep it as a consolation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, Mitya! You\xe2\x80\x99re a trump, Mitya!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grushenka, and there was a\r\nnote of fierce anger in the exclamation.\r\n\r\nThe little _pan_, crimson with fury but still mindful of his dignity,\r\nwas making for the door, but he stopped short and said suddenly,\r\naddressing Grushenka:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pani_, if you want to come with me, come. If not, good\xe2\x80\x90by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd swelling with indignation and importance he went to the door. This\r\nwas a man of character: he had so good an opinion of himself that after\r\nall that had passed, he still expected that she would marry him. Mitya\r\nslammed the door after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLock it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kalganov. But the key clicked on the other side, they\r\nhad locked it from within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s capital!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Grushenka relentlessly. \xe2\x80\x9cServe them right!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.\r\nDelirium\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat followed was almost an orgy, a feast to which all were welcome.\r\nGrushenka was the first to call for wine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to drink. I want to be quite drunk, as we were before. Do you\r\nremember, Mitya, do you remember how we made friends here last time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya himself was almost delirious, feeling that his happiness was at\r\nhand. But Grushenka was continually sending him away from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and enjoy yourself. Tell them to dance, to make merry, \xe2\x80\x98let the\r\nstove and cottage dance\xe2\x80\x99; as we had it last time,\xe2\x80\x9d she kept exclaiming.\r\nShe was tremendously excited. And Mitya hastened to obey her. The\r\nchorus were in the next room. The room in which they had been sitting\r\ntill that moment was too small, and was divided in two by cotton\r\ncurtains, behind which was a huge bed with a puffy feather mattress and\r\na pyramid of cotton pillows. In the four rooms for visitors there were\r\nbeds. Grushenka settled herself just at the door. Mitya set an easy\r\nchair for her. She had sat in the same place to watch the dancing and\r\nsinging \xe2\x80\x9cthe time before,\xe2\x80\x9d when they had made merry there. All the\r\ngirls who had come had been there then; the Jewish band with fiddles\r\nand zithers had come, too, and at last the long expected cart had\r\narrived with the wines and provisions.\r\n\r\nMitya bustled about. All sorts of people began coming into the room to\r\nlook on, peasants and their women, who had been roused from sleep and\r\nattracted by the hopes of another marvelous entertainment such as they\r\nhad enjoyed a month before. Mitya remembered their faces, greeting and\r\nembracing every one he knew. He uncorked bottles and poured out wine\r\nfor every one who presented himself. Only the girls were very eager for\r\nthe champagne. The men preferred rum, brandy, and, above all, hot\r\npunch. Mitya had chocolate made for all the girls, and ordered that\r\nthree samovars should be kept boiling all night to provide tea and\r\npunch for everyone to help himself.\r\n\r\nAn absurd chaotic confusion followed, but Mitya was in his natural\r\nelement, and the more foolish it became, the more his spirits rose. If\r\nthe peasants had asked him for money at that moment, he would have\r\npulled out his notes and given them away right and left. This was\r\nprobably why the landlord, Trifon Borissovitch, kept hovering about\r\nMitya to protect him. He seemed to have given up all idea of going to\r\nbed that night; but he drank little, only one glass of punch, and kept\r\na sharp look\xe2\x80\x90out on Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s interests after his own fashion. He\r\nintervened in the nick of time, civilly and obsequiously persuading\r\nMitya not to give away \xe2\x80\x9ccigars and Rhine wine,\xe2\x80\x9d and, above all, money\r\nto the peasants as he had done before. He was very indignant, too, at\r\nthe peasant girls drinking liqueur, and eating sweets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re a lousy lot, Dmitri Fyodorovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d give them a\r\nkick, every one of them, and they\xe2\x80\x99d take it as an honor\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re worth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya remembered Andrey again, and ordered punch to be sent out to him.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was rude to him just now,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated with a sinking, softened\r\nvoice. Kalganov did not want to drink, and at first did not care for\r\nthe girls\xe2\x80\x99 singing; but after he had drunk a couple of glasses of\r\nchampagne he became extraordinarily lively, strolling about the room,\r\nlaughing and praising the music and the songs, admiring every one and\r\neverything. Maximov, blissfully drunk, never left his side. Grushenka,\r\ntoo, was beginning to get drunk. Pointing to Kalganov, she said to\r\nMitya:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a dear, charming boy he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Mitya, delighted, ran to kiss Kalganov and Maximov. Oh, great were\r\nhis hopes! She had said nothing yet, and seemed, indeed, purposely to\r\nrefrain from speaking. But she looked at him from time to time with\r\ncaressing and passionate eyes. At last she suddenly gripped his hand\r\nand drew him vigorously to her. She was sitting at the moment in the\r\nlow chair by the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it you came just now, eh? Have you walked in!... I was\r\nfrightened. So you wanted to give me up to him, did you? Did you really\r\nwant to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to spoil your happiness!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya faltered blissfully. But\r\nshe did not need his answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go and enjoy yourself ...\xe2\x80\x9d she sent him away once more. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncry, I\xe2\x80\x99ll call you back again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe would run away, and she listened to the singing and looked at the\r\ndancing, though her eyes followed him wherever he went. But in another\r\nquarter of an hour she would call him once more and again he would run\r\nback to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, sit beside me, tell me, how did you hear about me, and my coming\r\nhere yesterday? From whom did you first hear it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Mitya began telling her all about it, disconnectedly, incoherently,\r\nfeverishly. He spoke strangely, often frowning, and stopping abruptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you frowning at?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.... I left a man ill there. I\xe2\x80\x99d give ten years of my life for\r\nhim to get well, to know he was all right!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind him, if he\xe2\x80\x99s ill. So you meant to shoot yourself to\xe2\x80\x90\r\nmorrow! What a silly boy! What for? I like such reckless fellows as\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d she lisped, with a rather halting tongue. \xe2\x80\x9cSo you would go any\r\nlength for me, eh? Did you really mean to shoot yourself to\xe2\x80\x90morrow, you\r\nstupid? No, wait a little. To\xe2\x80\x90morrow I may have something to say to\r\nyou.... I won\xe2\x80\x99t say it to\xe2\x80\x90day, but to\xe2\x80\x90morrow. You\xe2\x80\x99d like it to be\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day? No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to to\xe2\x80\x90day. Come, go along now, go and amuse\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnce, however, she called him, as it were, puzzled and uneasy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you sad? I see you\xe2\x80\x99re sad.... Yes, I see it,\xe2\x80\x9d she added,\r\nlooking intently into his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cThough you keep kissing the peasants\r\nand shouting, I see something. No, be merry. I\xe2\x80\x99m merry; you be merry,\r\ntoo.... I love somebody here. Guess who it is. Ah, look, my boy has\r\nfallen asleep, poor dear, he\xe2\x80\x99s drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe meant Kalganov. He was, in fact, drunk, and had dropped asleep for\r\na moment, sitting on the sofa. But he was not merely drowsy from drink;\r\nhe felt suddenly dejected, or, as he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbored.\xe2\x80\x9d He was intensely\r\ndepressed by the girls\xe2\x80\x99 songs, which, as the drinking went on,\r\ngradually became coarse and more reckless. And the dances were as bad.\r\nTwo girls dressed up as bears, and a lively girl, called Stepanida,\r\nwith a stick in her hand, acted the part of keeper, and began to \xe2\x80\x9cshow\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook alive, Marya, or you\xe2\x80\x99ll get the stick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bears rolled on the ground at last in the most unseemly fashion,\r\namid roars of laughter from the closely\xe2\x80\x90packed crowd of men and women.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let them! Let them!\xe2\x80\x9d said Grushenka sententiously, with an\r\necstatic expression on her face. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen they do get a day to enjoy\r\nthemselves, why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t folks be happy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKalganov looked as though he had been besmirched with dirt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s swinish, all this peasant foolery,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, moving away;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s the game they play when it\xe2\x80\x99s light all night in summer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe particularly disliked one \xe2\x80\x9cnew\xe2\x80\x9d song to a jaunty dance\xe2\x80\x90tune. It\r\ndescribed how a gentleman came and tried his luck with the girls, to\r\nsee whether they would love him:\r\n\r\nThe master came to try the girls:\r\nWould they love him, would they not?\r\n\r\n\r\nBut the girls could not love the master:\r\n\r\nHe would beat me cruelly\r\nAnd such love won\xe2\x80\x99t do for me.\r\n\r\n\r\nThen a gypsy comes along and he, too, tries:\r\n\r\nThe gypsy came to try the girls:\r\nWould they love him, would they not?\r\n\r\n\r\nBut they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t love the gypsy either:\r\n\r\nHe would be a thief, I fear,\r\nAnd would cause me many a tear.\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd many more men come to try their luck, among them a soldier:\r\n\r\nThe soldier came to try the girls:\r\nWould they love him, would they not?\r\n\r\n\r\nBut the soldier is rejected with contempt, in two indecent lines, sung\r\nwith absolute frankness and producing a furore in the audience. The\r\nsong ends with a merchant:\r\n\r\nThe merchant came to try the girls:\r\nWould they love him, would they not?\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd it appears that he wins their love because:\r\n\r\nThe merchant will make gold for me\r\nAnd his queen I\xe2\x80\x99ll gladly be.\r\n\r\n\r\nKalvanov was positively indignant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just a song of yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d he said aloud. \xe2\x80\x9cWho writes such\r\nthings for them? They might just as well have had a railwayman or a Jew\r\ncome to try his luck with the girls; they\xe2\x80\x99d have carried all before\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, almost as though it were a personal affront, he declared, on the\r\nspot, that he was bored, sat down on the sofa and immediately fell\r\nasleep. His pretty little face looked rather pale, as it fell back on\r\nthe sofa cushion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook how pretty he is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Grushenka, taking Mitya up to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI was\r\ncombing his hair just now; his hair\xe2\x80\x99s like flax, and so thick....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, bending over him tenderly, she kissed his forehead. Kalganov\r\ninstantly opened his eyes, looked at her, stood up, and with the most\r\nanxious air inquired where was Maximov?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that\xe2\x80\x99s who it is you want.\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cStay with me a\r\nminute. Mitya, run and find his Maximov.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaximov, it appeared, could not tear himself away from the girls, only\r\nrunning away from time to time to pour himself out a glass of liqueur.\r\nHe had drunk two cups of chocolate. His face was red, and his nose was\r\ncrimson; his eyes were moist and mawkishly sweet. He ran up and\r\nannounced that he was going to dance the \xe2\x80\x9csaboti\xc3\xa8re.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey taught me all those well\xe2\x80\x90bred, aristocratic dances when I was\r\nlittle....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, go with him, Mitya, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll watch from here how he dances,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nGrushenka.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, I\xe2\x80\x99m coming to look on, too,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Kalganov, brushing\r\naside in the most na\xc3\xafve way Grushenka\xe2\x80\x99s offer to sit with him. They all\r\nwent to look on. Maximov danced his dance. But it roused no great\r\nadmiration in any one but Mitya. It consisted of nothing but skipping\r\nand hopping, kicking up the feet, and at every skip Maximov slapped the\r\nupturned sole of his foot. Kalganov did not like it at all, but Mitya\r\nkissed the dancer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks. You\xe2\x80\x99re tired perhaps? What are you looking for here? Would you\r\nlike some sweets? A cigar, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA cigarette.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you want a drink?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll just have a liqueur.... Have you any chocolates?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, there\xe2\x80\x99s a heap of them on the table there. Choose one, my dear\r\nsoul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like one with vanilla ... for old people. He he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, brother, we\xe2\x80\x99ve none of that special sort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d the old man bent down to whisper in Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s ear. \xe2\x80\x9cThat girl\r\nthere, little Marya, he he! How would it be if you were to help me make\r\nfriends with her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that\xe2\x80\x99s what you\xe2\x80\x99re after! No, brother, that won\xe2\x80\x99t do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d do no harm to any one,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov muttered disconsolately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right, all right. They only come here to dance and sing, you\r\nknow, brother. But damn it all, wait a bit!... Eat and drink and be\r\nmerry, meanwhile. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you want money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLater on, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Maximov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya\xe2\x80\x99s head was burning. He went outside to the wooden balcony which\r\nran round the whole building on the inner side, overlooking the\r\ncourtyard. The fresh air revived him. He stood alone in a dark corner,\r\nand suddenly clutched his head in both hands. His scattered thoughts\r\ncame together; his sensations blended into a whole and threw a sudden\r\nlight into his mind. A fearful and terrible light! \xe2\x80\x9cIf I\xe2\x80\x99m to shoot\r\nmyself, why not now?\xe2\x80\x9d passed through his mind. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not go for the\r\npistols, bring them here, and here, in this dark dirty corner, make an\r\nend?\xe2\x80\x9d Almost a minute he stood, undecided. A few hours earlier, when he\r\nhad been dashing here, he was pursued by disgrace, by the theft he had\r\ncommitted, and that blood, that blood!... But yet it was easier for him\r\nthen. Then everything was over: he had lost her, given her up. She was\r\ngone, for him\xe2\x80\x94oh, then his death sentence had been easier for him; at\r\nleast it had seemed necessary, inevitable, for what had he to stay on\r\nearth for?\r\n\r\nBut now? Was it the same as then? Now one phantom, one terror at least\r\nwas at an end: that first, rightful lover, that fateful figure had\r\nvanished, leaving no trace. The terrible phantom had turned into\r\nsomething so small, so comic; it had been carried into the bedroom and\r\nlocked in. It would never return. She was ashamed, and from her eyes he\r\ncould see now whom she loved. Now he had everything to make life happy\r\n... but he could not go on living, he could not; oh, damnation! \xe2\x80\x9cO God!\r\nrestore to life the man I knocked down at the fence! Let this fearful\r\ncup pass from me! Lord, thou hast wrought miracles for such sinners as\r\nme! But what, what if the old man\xe2\x80\x99s alive? Oh, then the shame of the\r\nother disgrace I would wipe away. I would restore the stolen money. I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ngive it back; I\xe2\x80\x99d get it somehow.... No trace of that shame will remain\r\nexcept in my heart for ever! But no, no; oh, impossible cowardly\r\ndreams! Oh, damnation!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYet there was a ray of light and hope in his darkness. He jumped up and\r\nran back to the room\xe2\x80\x94to her, to her, his queen for ever! Was not one\r\nmoment of her love worth all the rest of life, even in the agonies of\r\ndisgrace? This wild question clutched at his heart. \xe2\x80\x9cTo her, to her\r\nalone, to see her, to hear her, to think of nothing, to forget\r\neverything, if only for that night, for an hour, for a moment!\xe2\x80\x9d Just as\r\nhe turned from the balcony into the passage, he came upon the landlord,\r\nTrifon Borissovitch. He thought he looked gloomy and worried, and\r\nfancied he had come to find him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Trifon Borissovitch? are you looking for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d The landlord seemed disconcerted. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I be looking\r\nfor you? Where have you been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you look so glum? You\xe2\x80\x99re not angry, are you? Wait a bit, you\r\nshall soon get to bed.... What\xe2\x80\x99s the time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be three o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Past three, it must be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll leave off soon. We\xe2\x80\x99ll leave off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t mention it; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter. Keep it up as long as you\r\nlike....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with him?\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya wondered for an instant, and he ran\r\nback to the room where the girls were dancing. But she was not there.\r\nShe was not in the blue room either; there was no one but Kalganov\r\nasleep on the sofa. Mitya peeped behind the curtain\xe2\x80\x94she was there. She\r\nwas sitting in the corner, on a trunk. Bent forward, with her head and\r\narms on the bed close by, she was crying bitterly, doing her utmost to\r\nstifle her sobs that she might not be heard. Seeing Mitya, she beckoned\r\nhim to her, and when he ran to her, she grasped his hand tightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMitya, Mitya, I loved him, you know. How I have loved him these five\r\nyears, all that time! Did I love him or only my own anger? No, him,\r\nhim! It\xe2\x80\x99s a lie that it was my anger I loved and not him. Mitya, I was\r\nonly seventeen then; he was so kind to me, so merry; he used to sing to\r\nme.... Or so it seemed to a silly girl like me.... And now, O Lord,\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s not the same man. Even his face is not the same; he\xe2\x80\x99s different\r\naltogether. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have known him. I drove here with Timofey, and\r\nall the way I was thinking how I should meet him, what I should say to\r\nhim, how we should look at one another. My soul was faint, and all of a\r\nsudden it was just as though he had emptied a pail of dirty water over\r\nme.
