It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndelirium!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you most earnestly, dear Mihail Makarovitch, to restrain your\r\nfeelings,\xe2\x80\x9d the prosecutor said in a rapid whisper to the old police\r\ncaptain, \xe2\x80\x9cor I shall be forced to resort to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the little lawyer did not allow him to finish. He turned to Mitya,\r\nand delivered himself in a loud, firm, dignified voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEx\xe2\x80\x90Lieutenant Karamazov, it is my duty to inform you that you are\r\ncharged with the murder of your father, Fyodor Pavlovitch Karamazov,\r\nperpetrated this night....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said something more, and the prosecutor, too, put in something, but\r\nthough Mitya heard them he did not understand them. He stared at them\r\nall with wild eyes.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBook IX. The Preliminary Investigation\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter I.\r\nThe Beginning Of Perhotin\xe2\x80\x99s Official Career\r\n\r\n\r\nPyotr Ilyitch Perhotin, whom we left knocking at the strong locked\r\ngates of the widow Morozov\xe2\x80\x99s house, ended, of course, by making himself\r\nheard. Fenya, who was still excited by the fright she had had two hours\r\nbefore, and too much \xe2\x80\x9cupset\xe2\x80\x9d to go to bed, was almost frightened into\r\nhysterics on hearing the furious knocking at the gate. Though she had\r\nherself seen him drive away, she fancied that it must be Dmitri\r\nFyodorovitch knocking again, no one else could knock so savagely. She\r\nran to the house\xe2\x80\x90porter, who had already waked up and gone out to the\r\ngate, and began imploring him not to open it. But having questioned\r\nPyotr Ilyitch, and learned that he wanted to see Fenya on very\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cimportant business,\xe2\x80\x9d the man made up his mind at last to open. Pyotr\r\nIlyitch was admitted into Fenya\xe2\x80\x99s kitchen, but the girl begged him to\r\nallow the house\xe2\x80\x90porter to be present, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause of her misgivings.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nbegan questioning her and at once learnt the most vital fact, that is,\r\nthat when Dmitri Fyodorovitch had run out to look for Grushenka, he had\r\nsnatched up a pestle from the mortar, and that when he returned, the\r\npestle was not with him and his hands were smeared with blood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the blood was simply flowing, dripping from him, dripping!\xe2\x80\x9d Fenya\r\nkept exclaiming. This horrible detail was simply the product of her\r\ndisordered imagination. But although not \xe2\x80\x9cdripping,\xe2\x80\x9d Pyotr Ilyitch had\r\nhimself seen those hands stained with blood, and had helped to wash\r\nthem. Moreover, the question he had to decide was not how soon the\r\nblood had dried, but where Dmitri Fyodorovitch had run with the pestle,\r\nor rather, whether it really was to Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s, and how he\r\ncould satisfactorily ascertain. Pyotr Ilyitch persisted in returning to\r\nthis point, and though he found out nothing conclusive, yet he carried\r\naway a conviction that Dmitri Fyodorovitch could have gone nowhere but\r\nto his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, and that therefore something must have happened\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when he came back,\xe2\x80\x9d Fenya added with excitement, \xe2\x80\x9cI told him the\r\nwhole story, and then I began asking him, \xe2\x80\x98Why have you got blood on\r\nyour hands, Dmitri Fyodorovitch?\xe2\x80\x99 and he answered that that was human\r\nblood, and that he had just killed some one. He confessed it all to me,\r\nand suddenly ran off like a madman. I sat down and began thinking,\r\nwhere\xe2\x80\x99s he run off to now like a madman? He\xe2\x80\x99ll go to Mokroe, I thought,\r\nand kill my mistress there. I ran out to beg him not to kill her. I was\r\nrunning to his lodgings, but I looked at Plotnikov\xe2\x80\x99s shop, and saw him\r\njust setting off, and there was no blood on his hands then.\xe2\x80\x9d (Fenya had\r\nnoticed this and remembered it.) Fenya\xe2\x80\x99s old grandmother confirmed her\r\nevidence as far as she was capable. After asking some further\r\nquestions, Pyotr Ilyitch left the house, even more upset and uneasy\r\nthan he had been when he entered it.\r\n\r\nThe most direct and the easiest thing for him to do would have been to\r\ngo straight to Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s, to find out whether anything had\r\nhappened there, and if so, what; and only to go to the police captain,\r\nas Pyotr Ilyitch firmly intended doing, when he had satisfied himself\r\nof the fact. But the night was dark, Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s gates were\r\nstrong, and he would have to knock again. His acquaintance with Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch was of the slightest, and what if, after he had been\r\nknocking, they opened to him, and nothing had happened? Then Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch in his jeering way would go telling the story all over the\r\ntown, how a stranger, called Perhotin, had broken in upon him at\r\nmidnight to ask if any one had killed him. It would make a scandal. And\r\nscandal was what Pyotr Ilyitch dreaded more than anything in the world.\r\n\r\nYet the feeling that possessed him was so strong, that though he\r\nstamped his foot angrily and swore at himself, he set off again, not to\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s but to Madame Hohlakov\xe2\x80\x99s. He decided that if she\r\ndenied having just given Dmitri Fyodorovitch three thousand roubles, he\r\nwould go straight to the police captain, but if she admitted having\r\ngiven him the money, he would go home and let the matter rest till next\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\nIt is, of course, perfectly evident that there was even more likelihood\r\nof causing scandal by going at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night to a fashionable\r\nlady, a complete stranger, and perhaps rousing her from her bed to ask\r\nher an amazing question, than by going to Fyodor Pavlovitch. But that\r\nis just how it is, sometimes, especially in cases like the present one,\r\nwith the decisions of the most precise and phlegmatic people. Pyotr\r\nIlyitch was by no means phlegmatic at that moment. He remembered all\r\nhis life how a haunting uneasiness gradually gained possession of him,\r\ngrowing more and more painful and driving him on, against his will. Yet\r\nhe kept cursing himself, of course, all the way for going to this lady,\r\nbut \xe2\x80\x9cI will get to the bottom of it, I will!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated for the tenth\r\ntime, grinding his teeth, and he carried out his intention.\r\n\r\nIt was exactly eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock when he entered Madame Hohlakov\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\nHe was admitted into the yard pretty quickly, but, in response to his\r\ninquiry whether the lady was still up, the porter could give no answer,\r\nexcept that she was usually in bed by that time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk at the top of the stairs. If the lady wants to receive you, she\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nreceive you. If she won\xe2\x80\x99t, she won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPyotr Ilyitch went up, but did not find things so easy here. The\r\nfootman was unwilling to take in his name, but finally called a maid.\r\nPyotr Ilyitch politely but insistently begged her to inform her lady\r\nthat an official, living in the town, called Perhotin, had called on\r\nparticular business, and that if it were not of the greatest importance\r\nhe would not have ventured to come. \xe2\x80\x9cTell her in those words, in those\r\nwords exactly,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked the girl.\r\n\r\nShe went away. He remained waiting in the entry. Madame Hohlakov\r\nherself was already in her bedroom, though not yet asleep. She had felt\r\nupset ever since Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s visit, and had a presentiment that she would\r\nnot get through the night without the sick headache which always, with\r\nher, followed such excitement. She was surprised on hearing the\r\nannouncement from the maid. She irritably declined to see him, however,\r\nthough the unexpected visit at such an hour, of an \xe2\x80\x9cofficial living in\r\nthe town,\xe2\x80\x9d who was a total stranger, roused her feminine curiosity\r\nintensely. But this time Pyotr Ilyitch was as obstinate as a mule. He\r\nbegged the maid most earnestly to take another message in these very\r\nwords:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he had come on business of the greatest importance, and that\r\nMadame Hohlakov might have cause to regret it later, if she refused to\r\nsee him now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI plunged headlong,\xe2\x80\x9d he described it afterwards.\r\n\r\nThe maid, gazing at him in amazement, went to take his message again.\r\nMadame Hohlakov was impressed. She thought a little, asked what he\r\nlooked like, and learned that he was \xe2\x80\x9cvery well dressed, young and so\r\npolite.\xe2\x80\x9d We may note, parenthetically, that Pyotr Ilyitch was a rather\r\ngood\xe2\x80\x90looking young man, and well aware of the fact. Madame Hohlakov\r\nmade up her mind to see him. She was in her dressing\xe2\x80\x90gown and slippers,\r\nbut she flung a black shawl over her shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cThe official\xe2\x80\x9d was\r\nasked to walk into the drawing\xe2\x80\x90room, the very room in which Mitya had\r\nbeen received shortly before. The lady came to meet her visitor, with a\r\nsternly inquiring countenance, and, without asking him to sit down,\r\nbegan at once with the question:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have ventured to disturb you, madam, on a matter concerning our\r\ncommon acquaintance, Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov,\xe2\x80\x9d Perhotin began.\r\n\r\nBut he had hardly uttered the name, when the lady\xe2\x80\x99s face showed signs\r\nof acute irritation. She almost shrieked, and interrupted him in a\r\nfury:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much longer am I to be worried by that awful man?\xe2\x80\x9d she cried\r\nhysterically. \xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you, sir, how could you venture to disturb a\r\nlady who is a stranger to you, in her own house at such an hour!... And\r\nto force yourself upon her to talk of a man who came here, to this very\r\ndrawing\xe2\x80\x90room, only three hours ago, to murder me, and went stamping out\r\nof the room, as no one would go out of a decent house. Let me tell you,\r\nsir, that I shall lodge a complaint against you, that I will not let it\r\npass. Kindly leave me at once.... I am a mother.... I ... I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMurder! then he tried to murder you, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, has he killed somebody else?\xe2\x80\x9d Madame Hohlakov asked impulsively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you would kindly listen, madam, for half a moment, I\xe2\x80\x99ll explain it\r\nall in a couple of words,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Perhotin, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cAt five o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nthis afternoon Dmitri Fyodorovitch borrowed ten roubles from me, and I\r\nknow for a fact he had no money. Yet at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he came to see me\r\nwith a bundle of hundred\xe2\x80\x90rouble notes in his hand, about two or three\r\nthousand roubles. His hands and face were all covered with blood, and\r\nhe looked like a madman. When I asked him where he had got so much\r\nmoney, he answered that he had just received it from you, that you had\r\ngiven him a sum of three thousand to go to the gold\xe2\x80\x90mines....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Hohlakov\xe2\x80\x99s face assumed an expression of intense and painful\r\nexcitement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God! He must have killed his old father!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, clasping her\r\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cI have never given him money, never! Oh, run, run!... Don\xe2\x80\x99t say\r\nanother word! Save the old man ... run to his father ... run!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, madam, then you did not give him money? You remember for a\r\nfact that you did not give him any money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t! I refused to give it him, for he could not\r\nappreciate it. He ran out in a fury, stamping. He rushed at me, but I\r\nslipped away.... And let me tell you, as I wish to hide nothing from\r\nyou now, that he positively spat at me. Can you fancy that! But why are\r\nwe standing? Ah, sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, I....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr better run, run, you must run and save the poor old man from an\r\nawful death!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he has killed him already?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, good heavens, yes! Then what are we to do now? What do you think\r\nwe must do now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeantime she had made Pyotr Ilyitch sit down and sat down herself,\r\nfacing him. Briefly, but fairly clearly, Pyotr Ilyitch told her the\r\nhistory of the affair, that part of it at least which he had himself\r\nwitnessed. He described, too, his visit to Fenya, and told her about\r\nthe pestle. All these details produced an overwhelming effect on the\r\ndistracted lady, who kept uttering shrieks, and covering her face with\r\nher hands....\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you believe it, I foresaw all this! I have that special faculty,\r\nwhatever I imagine comes to pass. And how often I\xe2\x80\x99ve looked at that\r\nawful man and always thought, that man will end by murdering me. And\r\nnow it\xe2\x80\x99s happened ... that is, if he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t murdered me, but only his\r\nown father, it\xe2\x80\x99s only because the finger of God preserved me, and\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s more, he was ashamed to murder me because, in this very place, I\r\nput the holy ikon from the relics of the holy martyr, Saint Varvara, on\r\nhis neck.... And to think how near I was to death at that minute, I\r\nwent close up to him and he stretched out his neck to me!... Do you\r\nknow, Pyotr Ilyitch (I think you said your name was Pyotr Ilyitch), I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t believe in miracles, but that ikon and this unmistakable miracle\r\nwith me now\xe2\x80\x94that shakes me, and I\xe2\x80\x99m ready to believe in anything you\r\nlike. Have you heard about Father Zossima?... But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsaying ... and only fancy, with the ikon on his neck he spat at me....\r\nHe only spat, it\xe2\x80\x99s true, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t murder me and ... he dashed away!\r\nBut what shall we do, what must we do now? What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPyotr Ilyitch got up, and announced that he was going straight to the\r\npolice captain, to tell him all about it, and leave him to do what he\r\nthought fit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s an excellent man, excellent! Mihail Makarovitch, I know him.\r\nOf course, he\xe2\x80\x99s the person to go to. How practical you are, Pyotr\r\nIlyitch! How well you\xe2\x80\x99ve thought of everything! I should never have\r\nthought of it in your place!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEspecially as I know the police captain very well, too,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\nPyotr Ilyitch, who still continued to stand, and was obviously anxious\r\nto escape as quickly as possible from the impulsive lady, who would not\r\nlet him say good\xe2\x80\x90by and go away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd be sure, be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d she prattled on, \xe2\x80\x9cto come back and tell me what\r\nyou see there, and what you find out ... what comes to light ... how\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ll try him ... and what he\xe2\x80\x99s condemned to.... Tell me, we have no\r\ncapital punishment, have we? But be sure to come, even if it\xe2\x80\x99s at three\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock at night, at four, at half\xe2\x80\x90past four.... Tell them to wake me,\r\nto wake me, to shake me, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t get up.... But, good heavens, I\r\nshan\xe2\x80\x99t sleep! But wait, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t I better come with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cN\xe2\x80\x94no. But if you would write three lines with your own hand, stating\r\nthat you did not give Dmitri Fyodorovitch money, it might, perhaps, be\r\nof use ... in case it\xe2\x80\x99s needed....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d Madame Hohlakov skipped, delighted, to her bureau. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nyou know I\xe2\x80\x99m simply struck, amazed at your resourcefulness, your good\r\nsense in such affairs. Are you in the service here? I\xe2\x80\x99m delighted to\r\nthink that you\xe2\x80\x99re in the service here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd still speaking, she scribbled on half a sheet of notepaper the\r\nfollowing lines:\r\n\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve never in my life lent to that unhappy man, Dmitri Fyodorovitch\r\nKaramazov (for, in spite of all, he is unhappy), three thousand roubles\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never given him money, never: That I swear by all that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nholy!\r\n\r\n\r\nK. HOHLAKOV.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the note!\xe2\x80\x9d she turned quickly to Pyotr Ilyitch. \xe2\x80\x9cGo, save him.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a noble deed on your part!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she made the sign of the cross three times over him. She ran out to\r\naccompany him to the passage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow grateful I am to you! You can\xe2\x80\x99t think how grateful I am to you for\r\nhaving come to me, first. How is it I haven\xe2\x80\x99t met you before? I shall\r\nfeel flattered at seeing you at my house in the future. How delightful\r\nit is that you are living here!... Such precision! Such practical\r\nability!... They must appreciate you, they must understand you. If\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s anything I can do, believe me ... oh, I love young people! I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nin love with young people! The younger generation are the one prop of\r\nour suffering country. Her one hope.... Oh, go, go!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Pyotr Ilyitch had already run away or she would not have let him go\r\nso soon. Yet Madame Hohlakov had made a rather agreeable impression on\r\nhim, which had somewhat softened his anxiety at being drawn into such\r\nan unpleasant affair. Tastes differ, as we all know. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s by no means\r\nso elderly,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, feeling pleased, \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary I should\r\nhave taken her for her daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs for Madame Hohlakov, she was simply enchanted by the young man.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch sense! such exactness! in so young a man! in our day! and all\r\nthat with such manners and appearance! People say the young people of\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day are no good for anything, but here\xe2\x80\x99s an example!\xe2\x80\x9d etc. So she\r\nsimply forgot this \xe2\x80\x9cdreadful affair,\xe2\x80\x9d and it was only as she was\r\ngetting into bed, that, suddenly recalling \xe2\x80\x9chow near death she had\r\nbeen,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed: \xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is awful, awful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she fell at once into a sound, sweet sleep.\r\n\r\nI would not, however, have dwelt on such trivial and irrelevant\r\ndetails, if this eccentric meeting of the young official with the by no\r\nmeans elderly widow had not subsequently turned out to be the\r\nfoundation of the whole career of that practical and precise young man.\r\nHis story is remembered to this day with amazement in our town, and I\r\nshall perhaps have something to say about it, when I have finished my\r\nlong history of the Brothers Karamazov.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II.\r\nThe Alarm\r\n\r\n\r\nOur police captain, Mihail Makarovitch Makarov, a retired lieutenant\xe2\x80\x90\r\ncolonel, was a widower and an excellent man. He had only come to us\r\nthree years previously, but had won general esteem, chiefly because he\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cknew how to keep society together.\xe2\x80\x9d He was never without visitors, and\r\ncould not have got on without them. Some one or other was always dining\r\nwith him; he never sat down to table without guests. He gave regular\r\ndinners, too, on all sorts of occasions, sometimes most surprising\r\nones. Though the fare was not _recherch\xc3\xa9_, it was abundant. The\r\nfish\xe2\x80\x90pies were excellent, and the wine made up in quantity for what it\r\nlacked in quality.\r\n\r\nThe first room his guests entered was a well\xe2\x80\x90fitted billiard\xe2\x80\x90room, with\r\npictures of English race\xe2\x80\x90horses, in black frames on the walls, an\r\nessential decoration, as we all know, for a bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s billiard\xe2\x80\x90room.\r\nThere was card\xe2\x80\x90playing every evening at his house, if only at one\r\ntable. But at frequent intervals, all the society of our town, with the\r\nmammas and young ladies, assembled at his house to dance. Though Mihail\r\nMakarovitch was a widower, he did not live alone. His widowed daughter\r\nlived with him, with her two unmarried daughters, grown\xe2\x80\x90up girls, who\r\nhad finished their education. They were of agreeable appearance and\r\nlively character, and though every one knew they would have no dowry,\r\nthey attracted all the young men of fashion to their grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nMihail Makarovitch was by no means very efficient in his work, though\r\nhe performed his duties no worse than many others. To speak plainly, he\r\nwas a man of rather narrow education. His understanding of the limits\r\nof his administrative power could not always be relied upon. It was not\r\nso much that he failed to grasp certain reforms enacted during the\r\npresent reign, as that he made conspicuous blunders in his\r\ninterpretation of them. This was not from any special lack of\r\nintelligence, but from carelessness, for he was always in too great a\r\nhurry to go into the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the heart of a soldier rather than of a civilian,\xe2\x80\x9d he used to\r\nsay of himself. He had not even formed a definite idea of the\r\nfundamental principles of the reforms connected with the emancipation\r\nof the serfs, and only picked it up, so to speak, from year to year,\r\ninvoluntarily increasing his knowledge by practice. And yet he was\r\nhimself a landowner. Pyotr Ilyitch knew for certain that he would meet\r\nsome of Mihail Makarovitch\xe2\x80\x99s visitors there that evening, but he didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow which. As it happened, at that moment the prosecutor, and\r\nVarvinsky, our district doctor, a young man, who had only just come to\r\nus from Petersburg after taking a brilliant degree at the Academy of\r\nMedicine, were playing whist at the police captain\xe2\x80\x99s. Ippolit\r\nKirillovitch, the prosecutor (he was really the deputy prosecutor, but\r\nwe always called him the prosecutor), was rather a peculiar man, of\r\nabout five and thirty, inclined to be consumptive, and married to a fat\r\nand childless woman. He was vain and irritable, though he had a good\r\nintellect, and even a kind heart. It seemed that all that was wrong\r\nwith him was that he had a better opinion of himself than his ability\r\nwarranted. And that made him seem constantly uneasy. He had, moreover,\r\ncertain higher, even artistic, leanings, towards psychology, for\r\ninstance, a special study of the human heart, a special knowledge of\r\nthe criminal and his crime. He cherished a grievance on this ground,\r\nconsidering that he had been passed over in the service, and being\r\nfirmly persuaded that in higher spheres he had not been properly\r\nappreciated, and had enemies. In gloomy moments he even threatened to\r\ngive up his post, and practice as a barrister in criminal cases. The\r\nunexpected Karamazov case agitated him profoundly: \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a case that\r\nmight well be talked about all over Russia.\xe2\x80\x9d But I am anticipating.\r\n\r\nNikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov, the young investigating lawyer, who had\r\nonly come from Petersburg two months before, was sitting in the next\r\nroom with the young ladies. People talked about it afterwards and\r\nwondered that all the gentlemen should, as though intentionally, on the\r\nevening of \xe2\x80\x9cthe crime\xe2\x80\x9d have been gathered together at the house of the\r\nexecutive authority. Yet it was perfectly simple and happened quite\r\nnaturally.\r\n\r\nIppolit Kirillovitch\xe2\x80\x99s wife had had toothache for the last two days,\r\nand he was obliged to go out to escape from her groans. The doctor,\r\nfrom the very nature of his being, could not spend an evening except at\r\ncards. Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov had been intending for three days\r\npast to drop in that evening at Mihail Makarovitch\xe2\x80\x99s, so to speak\r\ncasually, so as slyly to startle the eldest granddaughter, Olga\r\nMihailovna, by showing that he knew her secret, that he knew it was her\r\nbirthday, and that she was trying to conceal it on purpose, so as not\r\nto be obliged to give a dance. He anticipated a great deal of\r\nmerriment, many playful jests about her age, and her being afraid to\r\nreveal it, about his knowing her secret and telling everybody, and so\r\non. The charming young man was a great adept at such teasing; the\r\nladies had christened him \xe2\x80\x9cthe naughty man,\xe2\x80\x9d and he seemed to be\r\ndelighted at the name. He was extremely well\xe2\x80\x90bred, however, of good\r\nfamily, education and feelings, and, though leading a life of pleasure,\r\nhis sallies were always innocent and in good taste. He was short, and\r\ndelicate\xe2\x80\x90looking. On his white, slender, little fingers he always wore\r\na number of big, glittering rings. When he was engaged in his official\r\nduties, he always became extraordinarily grave, as though realizing his\r\nposition and the sanctity of the obligations laid upon him. He had a\r\nspecial gift for mystifying murderers and other criminals of the\r\npeasant class during interrogation, and if he did not win their\r\nrespect, he certainly succeeded in arousing their wonder.\r\n\r\nPyotr Ilyitch was simply dumbfounded when he went into the police\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s. He saw instantly that every one knew. They had positively\r\nthrown down their cards, all were standing up and talking. Even Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch had left the young ladies and run in, looking strenuous\r\nand ready for action. Pyotr Ilyitch was met with the astounding news\r\nthat old Fyodor Pavlovitch really had been murdered that evening in his\r\nown house, murdered and robbed. The news had only just reached them in\r\nthe following manner.\r\n\r\nMarfa Ignatyevna, the wife of old Grigory, who had been knocked\r\nsenseless near the fence, was sleeping soundly in her bed and might\r\nwell have slept till morning after the draught she had taken. But, all\r\nof a sudden she waked up, no doubt roused by a fearful epileptic scream\r\nfrom Smerdyakov, who was lying in the next room unconscious. That\r\nscream always preceded his fits, and always terrified and upset Marfa\r\nIgnatyevna. She could never get accustomed to it. She jumped up and ran\r\nhalf\xe2\x80\x90awake to Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s room. But it was dark there, and she could\r\nonly hear the invalid beginning to gasp and struggle. Then Marfa\r\nIgnatyevna herself screamed out and was going to call her husband, but\r\nsuddenly realized that when she had got up, he was not beside her in\r\nbed. She ran back to the bedstead and began groping with her hands, but\r\nthe bed was really empty. Then he must have gone out\xe2\x80\x94where? She ran to\r\nthe steps and timidly called him. She got no answer, of course, but she\r\ncaught the sound of groans far away in the garden in the darkness. She\r\nlistened. The groans were repeated, and it was evident they came from\r\nthe garden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord! Just as it was with Lizaveta Smerdyastchaya!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought\r\ndistractedly. She went timidly down the steps and saw that the gate\r\ninto the garden was open.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be out there, poor dear,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. She went up to the gate\r\nand all at once she distinctly heard Grigory calling her by name,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarfa! Marfa!\xe2\x80\x9d in a weak, moaning, dreadful voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord, preserve us from harm!\xe2\x80\x9d Marfa Ignatyevna murmured, and ran\r\ntowards the voice, and that was how she found Grigory. But she found\r\nhim not by the fence where he had been knocked down, but about twenty\r\npaces off. It appeared later, that he had crawled away on coming to\r\nhimself, and probably had been a long time getting so far, losing\r\nconsciousness several times. She noticed at once that he was covered\r\nwith blood, and screamed at the top of her voice. Grigory was muttering\r\nincoherently:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has murdered ... his father murdered.... Why scream, silly ... run\r\n... fetch some one....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Marfa continued screaming, and seeing that her master\xe2\x80\x99s window was\r\nopen and that there was a candle alight in the window, she ran there\r\nand began calling Fyodor Pavlovitch. But peeping in at the window, she\r\nsaw a fearful sight. Her master was lying on his back, motionless, on\r\nthe floor. His light\xe2\x80\x90colored dressing\xe2\x80\x90gown and white shirt were soaked\r\nwith blood. The candle on the table brightly lighted up the blood and\r\nthe motionless dead face of Fyodor Pavlovitch. Terror\xe2\x80\x90stricken, Marfa\r\nrushed away from the window, ran out of the garden, drew the bolt of\r\nthe big gate and ran headlong by the back way to the neighbor, Marya\r\nKondratyevna. Both mother and daughter were asleep, but they waked up\r\nat Marfa\xe2\x80\x99s desperate and persistent screaming and knocking at the\r\nshutter. Marfa, shrieking and screaming incoherently, managed to tell\r\nthem the main fact, and to beg for assistance. It happened that Foma\r\nhad come back from his wanderings and was staying the night with them.\r\nThey got him up immediately and all three ran to the scene of the\r\ncrime. On the way, Marya Kondratyevna remembered that at about eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock she heard a dreadful scream from their garden, and this was no\r\ndoubt Grigory\xe2\x80\x99s scream, \xe2\x80\x9cParricide!\xe2\x80\x9d uttered when he caught hold of\r\nMitya\xe2\x80\x99s leg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome one person screamed out and then was silent,\xe2\x80\x9d Marya Kondratyevna\r\nexplained as she ran. Running to the place where Grigory lay, the two\r\nwomen with the help of Foma carried him to the lodge. They lighted a\r\ncandle and saw that Smerdyakov was no better, that he was writhing in\r\nconvulsions, his eyes fixed in a squint, and that foam was flowing from\r\nhis lips. They moistened Grigory\xe2\x80\x99s forehead with water mixed with\r\nvinegar, and the water revived him at once. He asked immediately:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the master murdered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Foma and both the women ran to the house and saw this time that\r\nnot only the window, but also the door into the garden was wide open,\r\nthough Fyodor Pavlovitch had for the last week locked himself in every\r\nnight and did not allow even Grigory to come in on any pretext. Seeing\r\nthat door open, they were afraid to go in to Fyodor Pavlovitch \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nfear anything should happen afterwards.\xe2\x80\x9d And when they returned to\r\nGrigory, the old man told them to go straight to the police captain.\r\nMarya Kondratyevna ran there and gave the alarm to the whole party at\r\nthe police captain\xe2\x80\x99s. She arrived only five minutes before Pyotr\r\nIlyitch, so that his story came, not as his own surmise and theory, but\r\nas the direct confirmation, by a witness, of the theory held by all, as\r\nto the identity of the criminal (a theory he had in the bottom of his\r\nheart refused to believe till that moment).\r\n\r\nIt was resolved to act with energy. The deputy police inspector of the\r\ntown was commissioned to take four witnesses, to enter Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s house and there to open an inquiry on the spot, according\r\nto the regular forms, which I will not go into here. The district\r\ndoctor, a zealous man, new to his work, almost insisted on accompanying\r\nthe police captain, the prosecutor, and the investigating lawyer.\r\n\r\nI will note briefly that Fyodor Pavlovitch was found to be quite dead,\r\nwith his skull battered in. But with what? Most likely with the same\r\nweapon with which Grigory had been attacked. And immediately that\r\nweapon was found, Grigory, to whom all possible medical assistance was\r\nat once given, described in a weak and breaking voice how he had been\r\nknocked down. They began looking with a lantern by the fence and found\r\nthe brass pestle dropped in a most conspicuous place on the garden\r\npath. There were no signs of disturbance in the room where Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch was lying. But by the bed, behind the screen, they picked up\r\nfrom the floor a big and thick envelope with the inscription: \xe2\x80\x9cA\r\npresent of three thousand roubles for my angel Grushenka, if she is\r\nwilling to come.\xe2\x80\x9d And below had been added by Fyodor Pavlovitch, \xe2\x80\x9cFor\r\nmy little chicken.\xe2\x80\x9d There were three seals of red sealing\xe2\x80\x90wax on the\r\nenvelope, but it had been torn open and was empty: the money had been\r\nremoved. They found also on the floor a piece of narrow pink ribbon,\r\nwith which the envelope had been tied up.\r\n\r\nOne piece of Pyotr Ilyitch\xe2\x80\x99s evidence made a great impression on the\r\nprosecutor and the investigating magistrate, namely, his idea that\r\nDmitri Fyodorovitch would shoot himself before daybreak, that he had\r\nresolved to do so, had spoken of it to Ilyitch, had taken the pistols,\r\nloaded them before him, written a letter, put it in his pocket, etc.\r\nWhen Pyotr Ilyitch, though still unwilling to believe in it, threatened\r\nto tell some one so as to prevent the suicide, Mitya had answered\r\ngrinning: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll be too late.\xe2\x80\x9d So they must make haste to Mokroe to\r\nfind the criminal, before he really did shoot himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s clear, that\xe2\x80\x99s clear!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the prosecutor in great\r\nexcitement. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just the way with mad fellows like that: \xe2\x80\x98I shall\r\nkill myself to\xe2\x80\x90 morrow, so I\xe2\x80\x99ll make merry till I die!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe story of how he had bought the wine and provisions excited the\r\nprosecutor more than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember the fellow that murdered a merchant called Olsufyev,\r\ngentlemen? He stole fifteen hundred, went at once to have his hair\r\ncurled, and then, without even hiding the money, carrying it almost in\r\nhis hand in the same way, he went off to the girls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll were delayed, however, by the inquiry, the search, and the\r\nformalities, etc., in the house of Fyodor Pavlovitch. It all took time\r\nand so, two hours before starting, they sent on ahead to Mokroe the\r\nofficer of the rural police, Mavriky Mavrikyevitch Schmertsov, who had\r\narrived in the town the morning before to get his pay. He was\r\ninstructed to avoid raising the alarm when he reached Mokroe, but to\r\nkeep constant watch over the \xe2\x80\x9ccriminal\xe2\x80\x9d till the arrival of the proper\r\nauthorities, to procure also witnesses for the arrest, police\r\nconstables, and so on. Mavriky Mavrikyevitch did as he was told,\r\npreserving his incognito, and giving no one but his old acquaintance,\r\nTrifon Borissovitch, the slightest hint of his secret business. He had\r\nspoken to him just before Mitya met the landlord in the balcony,\r\nlooking for him in the dark, and noticed at once a change in Trifon\r\nBorissovitch\xe2\x80\x99s face and voice. So neither Mitya nor any one else knew\r\nthat he was being watched. The box with the pistols had been carried\r\noff by Trifon Borissovitch and put in a suitable place. Only after four\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, almost at sunrise, all the officials, the police captain, the\r\nprosecutor, the investigating lawyer, drove up in two carriages, each\r\ndrawn by three horses. The doctor remained at Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s to\r\nmake a post\xe2\x80\x90mortem next day on the body. But he was particularly\r\ninterested in the condition of the servant, Smerdyakov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch violent and protracted epileptic fits, recurring continually for\r\ntwenty\xe2\x80\x90four hours, are rarely to be met with, and are of interest to\r\nscience,\xe2\x80\x9d he declared enthusiastically to his companions, and as they\r\nleft they laughingly congratulated him on his find. The prosecutor and\r\nthe investigating lawyer distinctly remembered the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s saying that\r\nSmerdyakov could not outlive the night.\r\n\r\nAfter these long, but I think necessary explanations, we will return to\r\nthat moment of our tale at which we broke off.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III.\r\nThe Sufferings Of A Soul, The First Ordeal\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd so Mitya sat looking wildly at the people round him, not\r\nunderstanding what was said to him. Suddenly he got up, flung up his\r\nhands, and shouted aloud:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not guilty! I\xe2\x80\x99m not guilty of that blood! I\xe2\x80\x99m not guilty of my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s blood.... I meant to kill him. But I\xe2\x80\x99m not guilty. Not I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he had hardly said this, before Grushenka rushed from behind the\r\ncurtain and flung herself at the police captain\xe2\x80\x99s feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was my fault! Mine! My wickedness!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, in a heartrending\r\nvoice, bathed in tears, stretching out her clasped hands towards them.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did it through me. I tortured him and drove him to it. I tortured\r\nthat poor old man that\xe2\x80\x99s dead, too, in my wickedness, and brought him\r\nto this! It\xe2\x80\x99s my fault, mine first, mine most, my fault!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it\xe2\x80\x99s your fault! You\xe2\x80\x99re the chief criminal! You fury! You harlot!\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re the most to blame!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the police captain, threatening her\r\nwith his hand. But he was quickly and resolutely suppressed. The\r\nprosecutor positively seized hold of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is absolutely irregular, Mihail Makarovitch!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\r\npositively hindering the inquiry.... You\xe2\x80\x99re ruining the case....\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nalmost gasped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow the regular course! Follow the regular course!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch, fearfully excited too, \xe2\x80\x9cotherwise it\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely\r\nimpossible!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudge us together!\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka cried frantically, still kneeling.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPunish us together. I will go with him now, if it\xe2\x80\x99s to death!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrusha, my life, my blood, my holy one!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya fell on his knees\r\nbeside her and held her tight in his arms. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t believe her,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncried, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s not guilty of anything, of any blood, of anything!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe remembered afterwards that he was forcibly dragged away from her by\r\nseveral men, and that she was led out, and that when he recovered\r\nhimself he was sitting at the table. Beside him and behind him stood\r\nthe men with metal plates. Facing him on the other side of the table\r\nsat Nikolay Parfenovitch, the investigating lawyer. He kept persuading\r\nhim to drink a little water out of a glass that stood on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will refresh you, that will calm you. Be calm, don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nfrightened,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, extremely politely. Mitya (he remembered it\r\nafterwards) became suddenly intensely interested in his big rings, one\r\nwith an amethyst, and another with a transparent bright yellow stone,\r\nof great brilliance. And long afterwards he remembered with wonder how\r\nthose rings had riveted his attention through all those terrible hours\r\nof interrogation, so that he was utterly unable to tear himself away\r\nfrom them and dismiss them, as things that had nothing to do with his\r\nposition. On Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s left side, in the place where Maximov had been\r\nsitting at the beginning of the evening, the prosecutor was now seated,\r\nand on Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s right hand, where Grushenka had been, was a rosy\xe2\x80\x90cheeked\r\nyoung man in a sort of shabby hunting\xe2\x80\x90jacket, with ink and paper before\r\nhim. This was the secretary of the investigating lawyer, who had\r\nbrought him with him. The police captain was now standing by the window\r\nat the other end of the room, beside Kalganov, who was sitting there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink some water,\xe2\x80\x9d said the investigating lawyer softly, for the tenth\r\ntime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have drunk it, gentlemen, I have ... but ... come, gentlemen, crush\r\nme, punish me, decide my fate!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, staring with terribly\r\nfixed wide\xe2\x80\x90 open eyes at the investigating lawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you positively declare that you are not guilty of the death of your\r\nfather, Fyodor Pavlovitch?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the investigating lawyer, softly but\r\ninsistently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not guilty. I am guilty of the blood of another old man but not\r\nof my father\xe2\x80\x99s. And I weep for it! I killed, I killed the old man and\r\nknocked him down.... But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to have to answer for that murder\r\nwith another, a terrible murder of which I am not guilty.... It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nterrible accusation, gentlemen, a knock\xe2\x80\x90down blow. But who has killed\r\nmy father, who has killed him? Who can have killed him if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t?\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s marvelous, extraordinary, impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, who can have killed him?\xe2\x80\x9d the investigating lawyer was beginning,\r\nbut Ippolit Kirillovitch, the prosecutor, glancing at him, addressed\r\nMitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need not worry yourself about the old servant, Grigory\r\nVassilyevitch. He is alive, he has recovered, and in spite of the\r\nterrible blows inflicted, according to his own and your evidence, by\r\nyou, there seems no doubt that he will live, so the doctor says, at\r\nleast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlive? He\xe2\x80\x99s alive?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, flinging up his hands. His face\r\nbeamed. \xe2\x80\x9cLord, I thank Thee for the miracle Thou has wrought for me, a\r\nsinner and evildoer. That\xe2\x80\x99s an answer to my prayer. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been praying\r\nall night.\xe2\x80\x9d And he crossed himself three times. He was almost\r\nbreathless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo from this Grigory we have received such important evidence\r\nconcerning you, that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d The prosecutor would have continued, but Mitya\r\nsuddenly jumped up from his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne minute, gentlemen, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, one minute; I will run to her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, at this moment it\xe2\x80\x99s quite impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d Nikolay Parfenovitch\r\nalmost shrieked. He, too, leapt to his feet. Mitya was seized by the\r\nmen with the metal plates, but he sat down of his own accord....\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, what a pity! I wanted to see her for one minute only; I\r\nwanted to tell her that it has been washed away, it has gone, that\r\nblood that was weighing on my heart all night, and that I am not a\r\nmurderer now! Gentlemen, she is my betrothed!\xe2\x80\x9d he said ecstatically and\r\nreverently, looking round at them all. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, thank you, gentlemen! Oh,\r\nin one minute you have given me new life, new heart!... That old man\r\nused to carry me in his arms, gentlemen. He used to wash me in the tub\r\nwhen I was a baby three years old, abandoned by every one, he was like\r\na father to me!...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d the investigating lawyer began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me, gentlemen, allow me one minute more,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Mitya,\r\nputting his elbows on the table and covering his face with his hands.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me have a moment to think, let me breathe, gentlemen. All this is\r\nhorribly upsetting, horribly. A man is not a drum, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink a little more water,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Nikolay Parfenovitch.\r\n\r\nMitya took his hands from his face and laughed. His eyes were\r\nconfident. He seemed completely transformed in a moment. His whole\r\nbearing was changed; he was once more the equal of these men, with all\r\nof whom he was acquainted, as though they had all met the day before,\r\nwhen nothing had happened, at some social gathering. We may note in\r\npassing that, on his first arrival, Mitya had been made very welcome at\r\nthe police captain\xe2\x80\x99s, but later, during the last month especially,\r\nMitya had hardly called at all, and when the police captain met him, in\r\nthe street, for instance, Mitya noticed that he frowned and only bowed\r\nout of politeness. His acquaintance with the prosecutor was less\r\nintimate, though he sometimes paid his wife, a nervous and fanciful\r\nlady, visits of politeness, without quite knowing why, and she always\r\nreceived him graciously and had, for some reason, taken an interest in\r\nhim up to the last. He had not had time to get to know the\r\ninvestigating lawyer, though he had met him and talked to him twice,\r\neach time about the fair sex.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a most skillful lawyer, I see, Nikolay Parfenovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nMitya, laughing gayly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I can help you now. Oh, gentlemen, I feel\r\nlike a new man, and don\xe2\x80\x99t be offended at my addressing you so simply\r\nand directly. I\xe2\x80\x99m rather drunk, too, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you that frankly. I\r\nbelieve I\xe2\x80\x99ve had the honor and pleasure of meeting you, Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch, at my kinsman Mi\xc3\xbcsov\xe2\x80\x99s. The interrogation began again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV.\r\nThe Second Ordeal\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you encourage us, Dmitri Fyodorovitch, by your\r\nreadiness to answer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nikolay Parfenovitch, with an animated air,\r\nand obvious satisfaction beaming in his very prominent, short\xe2\x80\x90sighted,\r\nlight gray eyes, from which he had removed his spectacles a moment\r\nbefore. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have made a very just remark about the mutual\r\nconfidence, without which it is sometimes positively impossible to get\r\non in cases of such importance, if the suspected party really hopes and\r\ndesires to defend himself and is in a position to do so. When did you step? And on what did you step?\xe2\x80\x99 I shall get\r\nmixed up, if you go on like this, and you will put it all down against\r\nme. And what will that lead to? To nothing! And even if it\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m talking now, let me finish, and you, gentlemen, being men of honor\r\nand refinement, will forgive me! I\xe2\x80\x99ll finish by asking you, gentlemen,\r\nto drop that conventional method of questioning. I mean, beginning from\r\nsome miserable trifle, how I got up, what I had for breakfast, how I\r\nspat, and where I spat, and so distracting the attention of the\r\ncriminal, suddenly stun him with an overwhelming question, \xe2\x80\x98Whom did\r\nyou murder? Whom did you rob?\xe2\x80\x99 Ha ha! That\xe2\x80\x99s your regulation method,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s where all your cunning comes in. You can put peasants off their\r\nguard like that, but not me. I know the tricks. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been in the\r\nservice, too. Ha ha ha! You\xe2\x80\x99re not angry, gentlemen? You forgive my\r\nimpertinence?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, looking at them with a good\xe2\x80\x90nature that was\r\nalmost surprising. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only Mitya Karamazov, you know, so you can\r\noverlook it. It would be inexcusable in a sensible man; but you can\r\nforgive it in Mitya. Ha ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNikolay Parfenovitch listened, and laughed too. Though the prosecutor\r\ndid not laugh, he kept his eyes fixed keenly on Mitya, as though\r\nanxious not to miss the least syllable, the slightest movement, the\r\nsmallest twitch of any feature of his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s how we have treated you from the beginning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch, still laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cWe haven\xe2\x80\x99t tried to put you out by\r\nasking how you got up in the morning and what you had for breakfast. We\r\nbegan, indeed, with questions of the greatest importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand. I saw it and appreciated it, and I appreciate still more\r\nyour present kindness to me, an unprecedented kindness, worthy of your\r\nnoble hearts. We three here are gentlemen, and let everything be on the\r\nfooting of mutual confidence between educated, well\xe2\x80\x90bred people, who\r\nhave the common bond of noble birth and honor. In any case, allow me to\r\nlook upon you as my best friends at this moment of my life, at this\r\nmoment when my honor is assailed. That\xe2\x80\x99s no offense to you, gentlemen,\r\nis it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary. You\xe2\x80\x99ve expressed all that so well, Dmitri\r\nFyodorovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d Nikolay Parfenovitch answered with dignified\r\napprobation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd enough of those trivial questions, gentlemen, all those tricky\r\nquestions!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya enthusiastically. \xe2\x80\x9cOr there\xe2\x80\x99s simply no knowing\r\nwhere we shall get to! Is there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will follow your sensible advice entirely,\xe2\x80\x9d the prosecutor\r\ninterposed, addressing Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t withdraw my question, however.\r\nIt is now vitally important for us to know exactly why you needed that\r\nsum, I mean precisely three thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy I needed it?... Oh, for one thing and another.... Well, it was to\r\npay a debt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA debt to whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I absolutely refuse to answer, gentlemen. Not because I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nor because I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t dare, or because it would be damaging, for it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall a paltry matter and absolutely trifling, but\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t, because it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na matter of principle: that\xe2\x80\x99s my private life, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t allow any\r\nintrusion into my private life. That\xe2\x80\x99s my principle. Your question has\r\nno bearing on the case, and whatever has nothing to do with the case is\r\nmy private affair. I wanted to pay a debt. I wanted to pay a debt of\r\nhonor but to whom I won\xe2\x80\x99t say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to make a note of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prosecutor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means. Write down that I won\xe2\x80\x99t say, that I won\xe2\x80\x99t. Write that I\r\nshould think it dishonorable to say. Ech! you can write it; you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nnothing else to do with your time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to caution you, sir, and to remind you once more, if you are\r\nunaware of it,\xe2\x80\x9d the prosecutor began, with a peculiar and stern\r\nimpressiveness, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have a perfect right not to answer the\r\nquestions put to you now, and we on our side have no right to extort an\r\nanswer from you, if you decline to give it for one reason or another.\r\nThat is entirely a matter for your personal decision. But it is our\r\nduty, on the other hand, in such cases as the present, to explain and\r\nset before you the degree of injury you will be doing yourself by\r\nrefusing to give this or that piece of evidence. After which I will beg\r\nyou to continue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I\xe2\x80\x99m not angry ... I ...\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya muttered in a rather\r\ndisconcerted tone. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, gentlemen, you see, that Samsonov to whom I\r\nwent then ...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe will, of course, not reproduce his account of what is known to the\r\nreader already. Mitya was impatiently anxious not to omit the slightest\r\ndetail. At the same time he was in a hurry to get it over. But as he\r\ngave his evidence it was written down, and therefore they had\r\ncontinually to pull him up. Mitya disliked this, but submitted; got\r\nangry, though still good\xe2\x80\x90humoredly. He did, it is true, exclaim, from\r\ntime to time, \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough to make an angel out of\r\npatience!\xe2\x80\x9d Or, \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, it\xe2\x80\x99s no good your irritating me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut even though he exclaimed he still preserved for a time his genially\r\nexpansive mood. So he told them how Samsonov had made a fool of him two\r\ndays before. (He had completely realized by now that he had been\r\nfooled.) The sale of his watch for six roubles to obtain money for the\r\njourney was something new to the lawyers. They were at once greatly\r\ninterested, and even, to Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s intense indignation, thought it\r\nnecessary to write the fact down as a secondary confirmation of the\r\ncircumstance that he had hardly a farthing in his pocket at the time.\r\nLittle by little Mitya began to grow surly. Then, after describing his\r\njourney to see Lyagavy, the night spent in the stifling hut, and so on,\r\nhe came to his return to the town. Here he began, without being\r\nparticularly urged, to give a minute account of the agonies of jealousy\r\nhe endured on Grushenka\xe2\x80\x99s account.\r\n\r\nHe was heard with silent attention. They inquired particularly into the\r\ncircumstance of his having a place of ambush in Marya Kondratyevna\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse at the back of Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s garden to keep watch on\r\nGrushenka, and of Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s bringing him information. They laid\r\nparticular stress on this, and noted it down. Of his jealousy he spoke\r\nwarmly and at length, and though inwardly ashamed at exposing his most\r\nintimate feelings to \xe2\x80\x9cpublic ignominy,\xe2\x80\x9d so to speak, he evidently\r\novercame his shame in order to tell the truth. The frigid severity,\r\nwith which the investigating lawyer, and still more the prosecutor,\r\nstared intently at him as he told his story, disconcerted him at last\r\nconsiderably.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat boy, Nikolay Parfenovitch, to whom I was talking nonsense about\r\nwomen only a few days ago, and that sickly prosecutor are not worth my\r\ntelling this to,\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected mournfully. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s ignominious. \xe2\x80\x98Be\r\npatient, humble, hold thy peace.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d He wound up his reflections with\r\nthat line. But he pulled himself together to go on again. When he came\r\nto telling of his visit to Madame Hohlakov, he regained his spirits and\r\neven wished to tell a little anecdote of that lady which had nothing to\r\ndo with the case. But the investigating lawyer stopped him, and civilly\r\nsuggested that he should pass on to \xe2\x80\x9cmore essential matters.\xe2\x80\x9d At last,\r\nwhen he described his despair and told them how, when he left Madame\r\nHohlakov\xe2\x80\x99s, he thought that he\xe2\x80\x99d \xe2\x80\x9cget three thousand if he had to\r\nmurder some one to do it,\xe2\x80\x9d they stopped him again and noted down that\r\nhe had \xe2\x80\x9cmeant to murder some one.\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya let them write it without\r\nprotest. At last he reached the point in his story when he learned that\r\nGrushenka had deceived him and had returned from Samsonov\xe2\x80\x99s as soon as\r\nhe left her there, though she had said that she would stay there till\r\nmidnight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I didn\xe2\x80\x99t kill Fenya then, gentlemen, it was only because I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntime,\xe2\x80\x9d broke from him suddenly at that point in his story. That, too,\r\nwas carefully written down. Mitya waited gloomily, and was beginning to\r\ntell how he ran into his father\xe2\x80\x99s garden when the investigating lawyer\r\nsuddenly stopped him, and opening the big portfolio that lay on the\r\nsofa beside him he brought out the brass pestle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recognize this object?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, showing it to Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed gloomily. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course I recognize it. Let me have\r\na look at it.... Damn it, never mind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have forgotten to mention it,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the investigating lawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHang it all, I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have concealed it from you. Do you suppose I\r\ncould have managed without it? It simply escaped my memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe so good as to tell us precisely how you came to arm yourself with\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I will be so good, gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Mitya described how he took the pestle and ran.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what object had you in view in arming yourself with such a\r\nweapon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat object? No object. I just picked it up and ran off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for, if you had no object?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya\xe2\x80\x99s wrath flared up. He looked intently at \xe2\x80\x9cthe boy\xe2\x80\x9d and smiled\r\ngloomily and malignantly. He was feeling more and more ashamed at\r\nhaving told \xe2\x80\x9csuch people\xe2\x80\x9d the story of his jealousy so sincerely and\r\nspontaneously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBother the pestle!\xe2\x80\x9d broke from him suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, to keep off dogs.... Oh, because it was dark.... In case anything\r\nturned up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut have you ever on previous occasions taken a weapon with you when\r\nyou went out, since you\xe2\x80\x99re afraid of the dark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh! damn it all, gentlemen! There\xe2\x80\x99s positively no talking to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncried Mitya, exasperated beyond endurance, and turning to the\r\nsecretary, crimson with anger, he said quickly, with a note of fury in\r\nhis voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite down at once ... at once ... \xe2\x80\x98that I snatched up the pestle to\r\ngo and kill my father ... Fyodor Pavlovitch ... by hitting him on the\r\nhead with it!\xe2\x80\x99 Well, now are you satisfied, gentlemen? Are your minds\r\nrelieved?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, glaring defiantly at the lawyers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe quite understand that you made that statement just now through\r\nexasperation with us and the questions we put to you, which you\r\nconsider trivial, though they are, in fact, essential,\xe2\x80\x9d the prosecutor\r\nremarked dryly in reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, upon my word, gentlemen! Yes, I took the pestle.... What does\r\none pick things up for at such moments? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what for. I\r\nsnatched it up and ran\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all. For to me, gentlemen, _passons_, or\r\nI declare I won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you any more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat with his elbows on the table and his head in his hand. He sat\r\nsideways to them and gazed at the wall, struggling against a feeling of\r\nnausea. He had, in fact, an awful inclination to get up and declare\r\nthat he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t say another word, \xe2\x80\x9cnot if you hang me for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last, with difficulty controlling\r\nhimself, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see. I often dream it\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s always the\r\nsame ... that some one is hunting me, some one I\xe2\x80\x99m awfully afraid of\r\n... that he\xe2\x80\x99s hunting me in the dark, in the night ... tracking me, and\r\nI hide somewhere from him, behind a door or cupboard, hide in a\r\ndegrading way, and the worst of it is, he always knows where I am, but\r\nhe pretends not to know where I am on purpose, to prolong my agony, to\r\nenjoy my terror.... That\xe2\x80\x99s just what you\xe2\x80\x99re doing now. It\xe2\x80\x99s just like\r\nthat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that the sort of thing you dream about?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the prosecutor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you want to write it down?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mitya, with a\r\ndistorted smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; no need to write it down. But still you do have curious dreams.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not a question of dreams now, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94this is realism, this is\r\nreal life! I\xe2\x80\x99m a wolf and you\xe2\x80\x99re the hunters. Well, hunt him down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong to make such comparisons ...\xe2\x80\x9d began Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch, with extraordinary softness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99m not wrong, not at all!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya flared up again, though his\r\noutburst of wrath had obviously relieved his heart. He grew more good\xe2\x80\x90\r\nhumored at every word. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may not trust a criminal or a man on trial\r\ntortured by your questions, but an honorable man, the honorable\r\nimpulses of the heart (I say that boldly!)\xe2\x80\x94no! That you must believe\r\nyou have no right indeed ... but\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nBe silent, heart,\r\nBe patient, humble, hold thy peace.\r\n\r\n\r\nWell, shall I go on?\xe2\x80\x9d he broke off gloomily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99ll be so kind,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nikolay Parfenovitch.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter V.\r\nThe Third Ordeal\r\n\r\n\r\nThough Mitya spoke sullenly, it was evident that he was trying more\r\nthan ever not to forget or miss a single detail of his story. He told\r\nthem how he had leapt over the fence into his father\xe2\x80\x99s garden; how he\r\nhad gone up to the window; told them all that had passed under the\r\nwindow. Clearly, precisely, distinctly, he described the feelings that\r\ntroubled him during those moments in the garden when he longed so\r\nterribly to know whether Grushenka was with his father or not. But,\r\nstrange to say, both the lawyers listened now with a sort of awful\r\nreserve, looked coldly at him, asked few questions. Mitya could gather\r\nnothing from their faces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re angry and offended,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, bother them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he described how he made up his mind at last to make the \xe2\x80\x9csignal\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nto his father that Grushenka had come, so that he should open the\r\nwindow, the lawyers paid no attention to the word \xe2\x80\x9csignal,\xe2\x80\x9d as though\r\nthey entirely failed to grasp the meaning of the word in this\r\nconnection: so much so, that Mitya noticed it. Coming at last to the\r\nmoment when, seeing his father peering out of the window, his hatred\r\nflared up and he pulled the pestle out of his pocket, he suddenly, as\r\nthough of design, stopped short. He sat gazing at the wall and was\r\naware that their eyes were fixed upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the investigating lawyer. \xe2\x80\x9cYou pulled out the weapon and\r\n... and what happened then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen? Why, then I murdered him ... hit him on the head and cracked his\r\nskull.... I suppose that\xe2\x80\x99s your story. That\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis eyes suddenly flashed. All his smothered wrath suddenly flamed up\r\nwith extraordinary violence in his soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur story?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Nikolay Parfenovitch. \xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94and yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya dropped his eyes and was a long time silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy story, gentlemen? Well, it was like this,\xe2\x80\x9d he began softly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether it was some one\xe2\x80\x99s tears, or my mother prayed to God, or a good\r\nangel kissed me at that instant, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. But the devil was\r\nconquered. I rushed from the window and ran to the fence. My father was\r\nalarmed and, for the first time, he saw me then, cried out, and sprang\r\nback from the window. I remember that very well. I ran across the\r\ngarden to the fence ... and there Grigory caught me, when I was sitting\r\non the fence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that point he raised his eyes at last and looked at his listeners.\r\nThey seemed to be staring at him with perfectly unruffled attention. A\r\nsort of paroxysm of indignation seized on Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you\xe2\x80\x99re laughing at me at this moment, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d he broke off\r\nsuddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you think that?\xe2\x80\x9d observed Nikolay Parfenovitch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe one word\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s why! I understand, of course, that I\r\nhave come to the vital point. The old man\xe2\x80\x99s lying there now with his\r\nskull broken, while I\xe2\x80\x94after dramatically describing how I wanted to\r\nkill him, and how I snatched up the pestle\xe2\x80\x94I suddenly run away from the\r\nwindow. A romance! Poetry! As though one could believe a fellow on his\r\nword. Ha ha! You are scoffers, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he swung round on his chair so that it creaked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you notice,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the prosecutor suddenly, as though not\r\nobserving Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s excitement, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you notice when you ran away from\r\nthe window, whether the door into the garden was open?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it was not open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was shut. And who could open it? Bah! the door. Wait a bit!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nseemed suddenly to bethink himself, and almost with a start:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, did you find the door open?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, who could have opened it if you did not open it yourselves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncried Mitya, greatly astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe door stood open, and your father\xe2\x80\x99s murderer undoubtedly went in at\r\nthat door, and, having accomplished the crime, went out again by the\r\nsame door,\xe2\x80\x9d the prosecutor pronounced deliberately, as though chiseling\r\nout each word separately. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is perfectly clear. The murder was\r\ncommitted in the room and _not through the window_; that is absolutely\r\ncertain from the examination that has been made, from the position of\r\nthe body and everything. There can be no doubt of that circumstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya was absolutely dumbfounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s utterly impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, completely at a loss. \xe2\x80\x9cI ...\r\nI didn\xe2\x80\x99t go in.... I tell you positively, definitely, the door was shut\r\nthe whole time I was in the garden, and when I ran out of the garden. I\r\nonly stood at the window and saw him through the window. That\xe2\x80\x99s all,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s all.... I remember to the last minute. And if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t remember,\r\nit would be just the same. I know it, for no one knew the signals\r\nexcept Smerdyakov, and me, and the dead man. And he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\nopened the door to any one in the world without the signals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSignals? What signals?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the prosecutor, with greedy, almost\r\nhysterical, curiosity. He instantly lost all trace of his reserve and\r\ndignity. He asked the question with a sort of cringing timidity. He\r\nscented an important fact of which he had known nothing, and was\r\nalready filled with dread that Mitya might be unwilling to disclose it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you didn\xe2\x80\x99t know!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya winked at him with a malicious and mocking\r\nsmile. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat if I won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you? He told them exactly what every tap on the window meant,\r\ntapped the signals on the table, and when Nikolay Parfenovitch said\r\nthat he supposed he, Mitya, had tapped the signal \xe2\x80\x9cGrushenka has come,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwhen he tapped to his father, he answered precisely that he had tapped\r\nthat signal, that \xe2\x80\x9cGrushenka had come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo now you can build up your tower,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya broke off, and again turned\r\naway from them contemptuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo no one knew of the signals but your dead father, you, and the valet\r\nSmerdyakov? It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible and\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it! But I don\xe2\x80\x99t blame you. You can\xe2\x80\x99t believe it all\r\nsimply on my word. The answer to the question where I got the money would expose me\r\nto far greater disgrace than the murder and robbing of my father, if I\r\nhad murdered and robbed him. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you. I can\xe2\x80\x99t for\r\nfear of disgrace. What, gentlemen, are you going to write that down?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we\xe2\x80\x99ll write it down,\xe2\x80\x9d lisped Nikolay Parfenovitch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought not to write that down about \xe2\x80\x98disgrace.\xe2\x80\x99 I only told you\r\nthat in the goodness of my heart. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was said too peremptorily. Nikolay Parfenovitch did not insist\r\nfurther, but from Ippolit Kirillovitch\xe2\x80\x99s eyes he saw that he had not\r\ngiven up hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you not, at least, tell us what sum you had in your hands when you\r\nwent into Mr. Perhotin\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94how many roubles exactly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou spoke to Mr. Perhotin, I believe, of having received three\r\nthousand from Madame Hohlakov.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I did. I won\xe2\x80\x99t say how much I had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you be so good then as to tell us how you came here and what you\r\nhave done since you arrived?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you might ask the people here about that. Of the raptures of his love he said nothing, but told them\r\nthat he abandoned his determination to shoot himself, owing to \xe2\x80\x9cnew\r\nfactors in the case.\xe2\x80\x9d He told the story without going into motives or\r\ndetails. And this time the lawyers did not worry him much. It was\r\nobvious that there was no essential point of interest to them here.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall verify all that. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntrue I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get away anywhere. I\xe2\x80\x99m sitting here where I can be\r\nseen. But here\xe2\x80\x99s my money\xe2\x80\x94count it\xe2\x80\x94take it. You gave Perhotin ten, your driver twenty, here\r\nyou lost two hundred, then....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNikolay Parfenovitch reckoned it all up. Mitya helped him readily. They\r\nrecollected every farthing and included it in the reckoning. Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch hurriedly added up the total.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith this eight hundred you must have had about fifteen hundred at\r\nfirst?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose so,\xe2\x80\x9d snapped Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it they all assert there was much more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them assert it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you asserted it yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I did, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will compare all this with the evidence of other persons not yet\r\nexamined. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious about your money. It will be properly taken\r\ncare of and be at your disposal at the conclusion of ... what is\r\nbeginning ... if it appears, or, so to speak, is proved that you have\r\nundisputed right to it. Well, and now....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNikolay Parfenovitch suddenly got up, and informed Mitya firmly that it\r\nwas his duty and obligation to conduct a minute and thorough search \xe2\x80\x9cof\r\nyour clothes and everything else....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means, gentlemen. I\xe2\x80\x99ll turn out all my pockets, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he did, in fact, begin turning out his pockets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be necessary to take off your clothes, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Undress? Ugh! Damn it! Won\xe2\x80\x99t you search me as I am! Can\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s utterly impossible, Dmitri Fyodorovitch. You must take off your\r\nclothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you like,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya submitted gloomily; \xe2\x80\x9conly, please, not here, but\r\nbehind the curtains. Who will search them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBehind the curtains, of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNikolay Parfenovitch bent his head in assent. His small face wore an\r\nexpression of peculiar solemnity.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI.\r\nThe Prosecutor Catches Mitya\r\n\r\n\r\nSomething utterly unexpected and amazing to Mitya followed. He could\r\nnever, even a minute before, have conceived that any one could behave\r\nlike that to him, Mitya Karamazov. What was worst of all, there was\r\nsomething humiliating in it, and on their side something \xe2\x80\x9csupercilious\r\nand scornful.\xe2\x80\x9d It was nothing to take off his coat, but he was asked to\r\nundress further, or rather not asked but \xe2\x80\x9ccommanded,\xe2\x80\x9d he quite\r\nunderstood that. From pride and contempt he submitted without a word.\r\nSeveral peasants accompanied the lawyers and remained on the same side\r\nof the curtain. \xe2\x80\x9cTo be ready if force is required,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Mitya, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nperhaps for some other reason, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, must I take off my shirt, too?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked sharply, but Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch did not answer. He was busily engaged with the prosecutor\r\nin examining the coat, the trousers, the waistcoat and the cap; and it\r\nwas evident that they were both much interested in the scrutiny. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\r\nmake no bones about it,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Mitya, \xe2\x80\x9cthey don\xe2\x80\x99t keep up the most\r\nelementary politeness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask you for the second time\xe2\x80\x94need I take off my shirt or not?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, still more sharply and irritably.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t trouble yourself. We will tell you what to do,\xe2\x80\x9d Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch said, and his voice was positively peremptory, or so it\r\nseemed to Mitya.\r\n\r\nMeantime a consultation was going on in undertones between the lawyers.\r\nThere turned out to be on the coat, especially on the left side at the\r\nback, a huge patch of blood, dry, and still stiff. There were\r\nbloodstains on the trousers, too. Nikolay Parfenovitch, moreover, in\r\nthe presence of the peasant witnesses, passed his fingers along the\r\ncollar, the cuffs, and all the seams of the coat and trousers,\r\nobviously looking for something\xe2\x80\x94money, of course. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t even hide\r\nfrom Mitya his suspicion that he was capable of sewing money up in his\r\nclothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe treats me not as an officer but as a thief,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya muttered to\r\nhimself. They communicated their ideas to one another with amazing\r\nfrankness. The secretary, for instance, who was also behind the\r\ncurtain, fussing about and listening, called Nikolay Parfenovitch\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattention to the cap, which they were also fingering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember Gridyenko, the copying\xe2\x80\x90clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the secretary.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast summer he received the wages of the whole office, and pretended\r\nto have lost the money when he was drunk. And where was it found? Why,\r\nin just such pipings in his cap. The hundred\xe2\x80\x90rouble notes were screwed\r\nup in little rolls and sewed in the piping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth the lawyers remembered Gridyenko\xe2\x80\x99s case perfectly, and so laid\r\naside Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s cap, and decided that all his clothes must be more\r\nthoroughly examined later.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nikolay Parfenovitch, suddenly, noticing that the\r\nright cuff of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s shirt was turned in, and covered with blood,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cexcuse me, what\xe2\x80\x99s that, blood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya jerked out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, what blood? ... and why is the cuff turned in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya told him how he had got the sleeve stained with blood looking\r\nafter Grigory, and had turned it inside when he was washing his hands\r\nat Perhotin\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must take off your shirt, too. That\xe2\x80\x99s very important as material\r\nevidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya flushed red and flew into a rage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, am I to stay naked?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t disturb yourself. He felt unbearably awkward. All were clothed, while he\r\nwas naked, and strange to say, when he was undressed he felt somehow\r\nguilty in their presence, and was almost ready to believe himself that\r\nhe was inferior to them, and that now they had a perfect right to\r\ndespise him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen all are undressed, one is somehow not ashamed, but when one\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nonly one undressed and everybody is looking, it\xe2\x80\x99s degrading,\xe2\x80\x9d he kept\r\nrepeating to himself, again and again. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like a dream, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nsometimes dreamed of being in such degrading positions.\xe2\x80\x9d It was a\r\nmisery to him to take off his socks. They were very dirty, and so were\r\nhis underclothes, and now every one could see it. And what was worse,\r\nhe disliked his feet. All his life he had thought both his big toes\r\nhideous. He particularly loathed the coarse, flat, crooked nail on the\r\nright one, and now they would all see it. Feeling intolerably ashamed\r\nmade him, at once and intentionally, rougher. He pulled off his shirt,\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to look anywhere else if you\xe2\x80\x99re not ashamed to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, there\xe2\x80\x99s no need to, at present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, am I to stay naked like this?\xe2\x80\x9d he added savagely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped for the time....
