I did not sneak on him, of course, and\r\nI made them all keep quiet, so it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come to the ears of the\r\nmasters. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even tell my mother till it had healed up. And the\r\nwound was a mere scratch. And then I heard that the same day he\xe2\x80\x99d been\r\nthrowing stones and had bitten your finger\xe2\x80\x94but you understand now what\r\na state he was in! Well, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped: it was stupid of me not to\r\ncome and forgive him\xe2\x80\x94that is, to make it up with him\xe2\x80\x94when he was taken\r\nill. I am sorry for it now. But I had a special reason. So now I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ntold you all about it ... but I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid it was stupid of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a pity,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Alyosha, with feeling, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nbefore what terms you were on with him, or I\xe2\x80\x99d have come to you long\r\nago to beg you to go to him with me. Would you believe it, when he was\r\nfeverish he talked about you in delirium. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how much you\r\nwere to him! And you\xe2\x80\x99ve really not succeeded in finding that dog? His\r\nfather and the boys have been hunting all over the town for it. Would\r\nyou believe it, since he\xe2\x80\x99s been ill, I\xe2\x80\x99ve three times heard him repeat\r\nwith tears, \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s because I killed Zhutchka, father, that I am ill now.\r\nGod is punishing me for it.\xe2\x80\x99 He can\xe2\x80\x99t get that idea out of his head.\r\nAnd if the dog were found and proved to be alive, one might almost\r\nfancy the joy would cure him. We have all rested our hopes on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, what made you hope that I should be the one to find him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nKolya asked, with great curiosity. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you reckon on me rather\r\nthan any one else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a report that you were looking for the dog, and that you\r\nwould bring it when you\xe2\x80\x99d found it. Smurov said something of the sort.\r\nWe\xe2\x80\x99ve all been trying to persuade Ilusha that the dog is alive, that\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s been seen. The boys brought him a live hare; he just looked at it,\r\nwith a faint smile, and asked them to set it free in the fields. And so\r\nwe did. His father has just this moment come back, bringing him a\r\nmastiff pup, hoping to comfort him with that; but I think it only makes\r\nit worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, Karamazov, what sort of man is the father? I know him, but\r\nwhat do you make of him\xe2\x80\x94a mountebank, a buffoon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; there are people of deep feeling who have been somehow\r\ncrushed. Buffoonery in them is a form of resentful irony against those\r\nto whom they daren\xe2\x80\x99t speak the truth, from having been for years\r\nhumiliated and intimidated by them. Believe me, Krassotkin, that sort\r\nof buffoonery is sometimes tragic in the extreme. His whole life now is\r\ncentered in Ilusha, and if Ilusha dies, he will either go mad with\r\ngrief or kill himself. I feel almost certain of that when I look at him\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand you, Karamazov. I see you understand human nature,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya\r\nadded, with feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as soon as I saw you with a dog, I thought it was Zhutchka you\r\nwere bringing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, Karamazov, perhaps we shall find it yet; but this is\r\nPerezvon. I\xe2\x80\x99ll let him go in now and perhaps it will amuse Ilusha more\r\nthan the mastiff pup. Wait a bit, Karamazov, you will know something in\r\na minute. But, I say, I am keeping you here!\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya cried suddenly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve no overcoat on in this bitter cold. You see what an egoist I\r\nam. Oh, we are all egoists, Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t trouble; it is cold, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t often catch cold. Let us go in,\r\nthough, and, by the way, what is your name? I know you are called\r\nKolya, but what else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNikolay\xe2\x80\x94Nikolay Ivanovitch Krassotkin, or, as they say in official\r\ndocuments, \xe2\x80\x98Krassotkin son.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d Kolya laughed for some reason, but added\r\nsuddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cOf course I hate my name Nikolay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so trivial, so ordinary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are thirteen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, fourteen\xe2\x80\x94that is, I shall be fourteen very soon, in a fortnight.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll confess one weakness of mine, Karamazov, just to you, since it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nour first meeting, so that you may understand my character at once. I\r\nhate being asked my age, more than that ... and in fact ... there\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nlibelous story going about me, that last week I played robbers with the\r\npreparatory boys. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fact that I did play with them, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nperfect libel to say I did it for my own amusement. I have reasons for\r\nbelieving that you\xe2\x80\x99ve heard the story; but I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t playing for my own\r\namusement, it was for the sake of the children, because they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink of anything to do by themselves. But they\xe2\x80\x99ve always got some\r\nsilly tale. This is an awful town for gossip, I can tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what if you had been playing for your own amusement, what\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nharm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, I say, for my own amusement! You don\xe2\x80\x99t play horses, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you must look at it like this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cGrown\xe2\x80\x90up\r\npeople go to the theater and there the adventures of all sorts of\r\nheroes are represented\xe2\x80\x94sometimes there are robbers and battles, too\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t that just the same thing, in a different form, of course? And\r\nyoung people\xe2\x80\x99s games of soldiers or robbers in their playtime are also\r\nart in its first stage. You know, they spring from the growing artistic\r\ninstincts of the young. And sometimes these games are much better than\r\nperformances in the theater, the only difference is that people go\r\nthere to look at the actors, while in these games the young people are\r\nthe actors themselves. But that\xe2\x80\x99s only natural.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so? Is that your idea?\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya looked at him intently. \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\nyou know, that\xe2\x80\x99s rather an interesting view. When I go home, I\xe2\x80\x99ll think\r\nit over. I\xe2\x80\x99ll admit I thought I might learn something from you. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ncome to learn of you, Karamazov,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya concluded, in a voice full of\r\nspontaneous feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, smiling and pressing his hand.\r\n\r\nKolya was much pleased with Alyosha. What struck him most was that he\r\ntreated him exactly like an equal and that he talked to him just as if\r\nhe were \xe2\x80\x9cquite grown up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you something directly, Karamazov; it\xe2\x80\x99s a theatrical\r\nperformance, too,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, laughing nervously. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99ve come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go first to the people of the house, on the left. All the boys\r\nleave their coats in there, because the room is small and hot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99m only coming in for a minute. I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep on my overcoat.\r\nPerezvon will stay here in the passage and be dead. _Ici_, Perezvon,\r\nlie down and be dead! You see how he\xe2\x80\x99s dead. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go in first and\r\nexplore, then I\xe2\x80\x99ll whistle to him when I think fit, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99ll dash in like mad. Only Smurov must not forget to open the door at\r\nthe moment. I\xe2\x80\x99ll arrange it all and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter V.\r\nBy Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s Bedside\r\n\r\n\r\nThe room inhabited by the family of the retired captain Snegiryov is\r\nalready familiar to the reader. It was close and crowded at that moment\r\nwith a number of visitors. Several boys were sitting with Ilusha, and\r\nthough all of them, like Smurov, were prepared to deny that it was\r\nAlyosha who had brought them and reconciled them with Ilusha, it was\r\nreally the fact. All the art he had used had been to take them, one by\r\none, to Ilusha, without \xe2\x80\x9csheepish sentimentality,\xe2\x80\x9d appearing to do so\r\ncasually and without design. It was a great consolation to Ilusha in\r\nhis suffering. He was greatly touched by seeing the almost tender\r\naffection and sympathy shown him by these boys, who had been his\r\nenemies. Krassotkin was the only one missing and his absence was a\r\nheavy load on Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s heart. Perhaps the bitterest of all his bitter\r\nmemories was his stabbing Krassotkin, who had been his one friend and\r\nprotector. Clever little Smurov, who was the first to make it up with\r\nIlusha, thought it was so. But when Smurov hinted to Krassotkin that\r\nAlyosha wanted to come and see him about something, the latter cut him\r\nshort, bidding Smurov tell \xe2\x80\x9cKaramazov\xe2\x80\x9d at once that he knew best what\r\nto do, that he wanted no one\xe2\x80\x99s advice, and that, if he went to see\r\nIlusha, he would choose his own time for he had \xe2\x80\x9chis own reasons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat was a fortnight before this Sunday. That was why Alyosha had not\r\nbeen to see him, as he had meant to. But though he waited, he sent\r\nSmurov to him twice again. Both times Krassotkin met him with a curt,\r\nimpatient refusal, sending Alyosha a message not to bother him any\r\nmore, that if he came himself, he, Krassotkin, would not go to Ilusha\r\nat all. Up to the very last day, Smurov did not know that Kolya meant\r\nto go to Ilusha that morning, and only the evening before, as he parted\r\nfrom Smurov, Kolya abruptly told him to wait at home for him next\r\nmorning, for he would go with him to the Snegiryovs\xe2\x80\x99, but warned him on\r\nno account to say he was coming, as he wanted to drop in casually.\r\nSmurov obeyed. Smurov\xe2\x80\x99s fancy that Kolya would bring back the lost dog\r\nwas based on the words Kolya had dropped that \xe2\x80\x9cthey must be asses not\r\nto find the dog, if it was alive.\xe2\x80\x9d When Smurov, waiting for an\r\nopportunity, timidly hinted at his guess about the dog, Krassotkin flew\r\ninto a violent rage. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not such an ass as to go hunting about the\r\ntown for other people\xe2\x80\x99s dogs when I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a dog of my own! And how can\r\nyou imagine a dog could be alive after swallowing a pin? Sheepish\r\nsentimentality, that\xe2\x80\x99s what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor the last fortnight Ilusha had not left his little bed under the\r\nikons in the corner. He had not been to school since the day he met\r\nAlyosha and bit his finger. He was taken ill the same day, though for a\r\nmonth afterwards he was sometimes able to get up and walk about the\r\nroom and passage. But latterly he had become so weak that he could not\r\nmove without help from his father. His father was terribly concerned\r\nabout him. He even gave up drinking and was almost crazy with terror\r\nthat his boy would die. And often, especially after leading him round\r\nthe room on his arm and putting him back to bed, he would run to a dark\r\ncorner in the passage and, leaning his head against the wall, he would\r\nbreak into paroxysms of violent weeping, stifling his sobs that they\r\nmight not be heard by Ilusha.\r\n\r\nReturning to the room, he would usually begin doing something to amuse\r\nand comfort his precious boy; he would tell him stories, funny\r\nanecdotes, or would mimic comic people he had happened to meet, even\r\nimitate the howls and cries of animals. But Ilusha could not bear to\r\nsee his father fooling and playing the buffoon. Though the boy tried\r\nnot to show how he disliked it, he saw with an aching heart that his\r\nfather was an object of contempt, and he was continually haunted by the\r\nmemory of the \xe2\x80\x9cwisp of tow\xe2\x80\x9d and that \xe2\x80\x9cterrible day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNina, Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s gentle, crippled sister, did not like her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbuffoonery either (Varvara had been gone for some time past to\r\nPetersburg to study at the university). But the half\xe2\x80\x90imbecile mother\r\nwas greatly diverted and laughed heartily when her husband began\r\ncapering about or performing something. It was the only way she could\r\nbe amused; all the rest of the time she was grumbling and complaining\r\nthat now every one had forgotten her, that no one treated her with\r\nrespect, that she was slighted, and so on. But during the last few days\r\nshe had completely changed. She began looking constantly at Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbed in the corner and seemed lost in thought. She was more silent,\r\nquieter, and, if she cried, she cried quietly so as not to be heard.\r\nThe captain noticed the change in her with mournful perplexity. The\r\nboys\xe2\x80\x99 visits at first only angered her, but later on their merry shouts\r\nand stories began to divert her, and at last she liked them so much\r\nthat, if the boys had given up coming, she would have felt dreary\r\nwithout them. When the children told some story or played a game, she\r\nlaughed and clapped her hands. She called some of them to her and\r\nkissed them. She was particularly fond of Smurov.\r\n\r\nAs for the captain, the presence in his room of the children, who came\r\nto cheer up Ilusha, filled his heart from the first with ecstatic joy.\r\nHe even hoped that Ilusha would now get over his depression, and that\r\nthat would hasten his recovery. In spite of his alarm about Ilusha, he\r\nhad not, till lately, felt one minute\xe2\x80\x99s doubt of his boy\xe2\x80\x99s ultimate\r\nrecovery.\r\n\r\nHe met his little visitors with homage, waited upon them hand and foot;\r\nhe was ready to be their horse and even began letting them ride on his\r\nback, but Ilusha did not like the game and it was given up. He began\r\nbuying little things for them, gingerbread and nuts, gave them tea and\r\ncut them sandwiches. It must be noted that all this time he had plenty\r\nof money. He had taken the two hundred roubles from Katerina Ivanovna\r\njust as Alyosha had predicted he would. And afterwards Katerina\r\nIvanovna, learning more about their circumstances and Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s illness,\r\nvisited them herself, made the acquaintance of the family, and\r\nsucceeded in fascinating the half\xe2\x80\x90 imbecile mother. Since then she had\r\nbeen lavish in helping them, and the captain, terror\xe2\x80\x90stricken at the\r\nthought that his boy might be dying, forgot his pride and humbly\r\naccepted her assistance.\r\n\r\nAll this time Doctor Herzenstube, who was called in by Katerina\r\nIvanovna, came punctually every other day, but little was gained by his\r\nvisits and he dosed the invalid mercilessly. But on that Sunday morning\r\na new doctor was expected, who had come from Moscow, where he had a\r\ngreat reputation. Katerina Ivanovna had sent for him from Moscow at\r\ngreat expense, not expressly for Ilusha, but for another object of\r\nwhich more will be said in its place hereafter. But, as he had come,\r\nshe had asked him to see Ilusha as well, and the captain had been told\r\nto expect him. He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t the slightest idea that Kolya Krassotkin was\r\ncoming, though he had long wished for a visit from the boy for whom\r\nIlusha was fretting.\r\n\r\nAt the moment when Krassotkin opened the door and came into the room,\r\nthe captain and all the boys were round Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s bed, looking at a tiny\r\nmastiff pup, which had only been born the day before, though the\r\ncaptain had bespoken it a week ago to comfort and amuse Ilusha, who was\r\nstill fretting over the lost and probably dead Zhutchka. Ilusha, who\r\nhad heard three days before that he was to be presented with a puppy,\r\nnot an ordinary puppy, but a pedigree mastiff (a very important point,\r\nof course), tried from delicacy of feeling to pretend that he was\r\npleased. But his father and the boys could not help seeing that the\r\npuppy only served to recall to his little heart the thought of the\r\nunhappy dog he had killed. The puppy lay beside him feebly moving and\r\nhe, smiling sadly, stroked it with his thin, pale, wasted hand. Clearly\r\nhe liked the puppy, but ... it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Zhutchka; if he could have had\r\nZhutchka and the puppy, too, then he would have been completely happy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKrassotkin!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the boys suddenly. He was the first to see\r\nhim come in.\r\n\r\nKrassotkin\xe2\x80\x99s entrance made a general sensation; the boys moved away and\r\nstood on each side of the bed, so that he could get a full view of\r\nIlusha. The captain ran eagerly to meet Kolya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease come in ... you are welcome!\xe2\x80\x9d he said hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x9cIlusha, Mr.\r\nKrassotkin has come to see you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Krassotkin, shaking hands with him hurriedly, instantly showed his\r\ncomplete knowledge of the manners of good society. He turned first to\r\nthe captain\xe2\x80\x99s wife sitting in her arm\xe2\x80\x90chair, who was very ill\xe2\x80\x90humored\r\nat the moment, and was grumbling that the boys stood between her and\r\nIlusha\xe2\x80\x99s bed and did not let her see the new puppy. With the greatest\r\ncourtesy he made her a bow, scraping his foot, and turning to Nina, he\r\nmade her, as the only other lady present, a similar bow. This polite\r\nbehavior made an extremely favorable impression on the deranged lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you can see at once he is a young man that has been well\r\nbrought up,\xe2\x80\x9d she commented aloud, throwing up her hands; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as for\r\nour other visitors they come in one on the top of another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you mean, mamma, one on the top of another, how is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nmuttered the captain affectionately, though a little anxious on her\r\naccount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s how they ride in. They get on each other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders in the\r\npassage and prance in like that on a respectable family. Strange sort\r\nof visitors!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who\xe2\x80\x99s come in like that, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that boy came in riding on that one\xe2\x80\x99s back and this one on that\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKolya was already by Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s bedside. The sick boy turned visibly\r\npaler. He raised himself in the bed and looked intently at Kolya. Kolya\r\nhad not seen his little friend for two months, and he was overwhelmed\r\nat the sight of him. He had never imagined that he would see such a\r\nwasted, yellow face, such enormous, feverishly glowing eyes and such\r\nthin little hands. He saw, with grieved surprise, Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s rapid, hard\r\nbreathing and dry lips. He stepped close to him, held out his hand, and\r\nalmost overwhelmed, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, old man ... how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d But his voice failed him, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nachieve an appearance of ease; his face suddenly twitched and the\r\ncorners of his mouth quivered. Ilusha smiled a pitiful little smile,\r\nstill unable to utter a word. Something moved Kolya to raise his hand\r\nand pass it over Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s hair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured softly to him to cheer him up, or perhaps not\r\nknowing why he said it. For a minute they were silent again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo, so you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a new puppy?\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya said suddenly, in a most\r\ncallous voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x94es,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ilusha in a long whisper, gasping for breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA black nose, that means he\xe2\x80\x99ll be fierce, a good house\xe2\x80\x90dog,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya\r\nobserved gravely and stolidly, as if the only thing he cared about was\r\nthe puppy and its black nose. But in reality he still had to do his\r\nutmost to control his feelings not to burst out crying like a child,\r\nand do what he would he could not control it. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen it grows up, you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nhave to keep it on the chain, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be a huge dog!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the boys.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course he will,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca mastiff,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clarge,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clike this,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cas big as a\r\ncalf,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted several voices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs big as a calf, as a real calf,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cI got one\r\nlike that on purpose, one of the fiercest breed, and his parents are\r\nhuge and very fierce, they stand as high as this from the floor.... Sit\r\ndown here, on Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s bed, or here on the bench. You are welcome,\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ve been hoping to see you a long time.... What makes you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, Karamazov, have you an awful contempt for me?\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya rapped\r\nout suddenly and drew himself up before Alyosha, as though he were on\r\ndrill. \xe2\x80\x9cBe so kind as to tell me, without beating about the bush.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a contempt for you?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha looked at him wondering. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nfor? Not long ago I read the criticism made by a German who had\r\nlived in Russia, on our students and schoolboys of to\xe2\x80\x90day. \xe2\x80\x98Show a\r\nRussian schoolboy,\xe2\x80\x99 he writes, \xe2\x80\x98a map of the stars, which he knows\r\nnothing about, and he will give you back the map next day with\r\ncorrections on it.\xe2\x80\x99 No knowledge and unbounded conceit\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s what the\r\nGerman meant to say about the Russian schoolboy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly right,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya laughed suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cexactly so!\r\nBravo the German! Look at his face!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\nIlusha\r\n\r\n\r\nThe doctor came out of the room again, muffled in his fur coat and with\r\nhis cap on his head. His face looked almost angry and disgusted, as\r\nthough he were afraid of getting dirty. He cast a cursory glance round\r\nthe passage, looking sternly at Alyosha and Kolya as he did so. Alyosha\r\nwaved from the door to the coachman, and the carriage that had brought\r\nthe doctor drove up. The captain darted out after the doctor, and,\r\nbowing apologetically, stopped him to get the last word. The poor\r\nfellow looked utterly crushed; there was a scared look in his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Excellency, your Excellency ... is it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d he began, but\r\ncould not go on and clasped his hands in despair. But you see!\xe2\x80\x9d The captain flung wide his hands again\r\ndespairingly, indicating the bare wooden walls of the passage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s not my business,\xe2\x80\x9d grinned the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cI have only told\r\nyou the answer of medical science to your question as to possible\r\ntreatment. As for the rest, to my regret\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, apothecary, my dog won\xe2\x80\x99t bite you,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya rapped out\r\nloudly, noticing the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s rather uneasy glance at Perezvon, who was\r\nstanding in the doorway. Oh, how I curse myself for not having come before!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered\r\nKolya, crying, and no longer ashamed of it.\r\n\r\nAt that moment the captain flew out of the room, and at once closed the\r\ndoor behind him. His face looked frenzied, his lips were trembling. He\r\nstood before the two and flung up his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want a good boy! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want another boy!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered in a\r\nwild whisper, clenching his teeth. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I forget thee, Jerusalem, may my\r\ntongue\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He broke off with a sob and sank on his knees before the\r\nwooden bench. Pressing his fists against his head, he began sobbing\r\nwith absurd whimpering cries, doing his utmost that his cries should\r\nnot be heard in the room.\r\n\r\nKolya ran out into the street.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood\xe2\x80\x90by, Karamazov? Will you come yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried sharply and\r\nangrily to Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will certainly come in the evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was that he said about Jerusalem?... What did he mean by that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s from the Bible. \xe2\x80\x98If I forget thee, Jerusalem,\xe2\x80\x99 that is, if I\r\nforget all that is most precious to me, if I let anything take its\r\nplace, then may\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough! Mind you come! _Ici_, Perezvon!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried\r\nwith positive ferocity to the dog, and with rapid strides he went home.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBook XI. Ivan\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter I.\r\nAt Grushenka\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n\r\n\r\nAlyosha went towards the cathedral square to the widow Morozov\xe2\x80\x99s house\r\nto see Grushenka, who had sent Fenya to him early in the morning with\r\nan urgent message begging him to come. Questioning Fenya, Alyosha\r\nlearned that her mistress had been particularly distressed since the\r\nprevious day. During the two months that had passed since Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narrest, Alyosha had called frequently at the widow Morozov\xe2\x80\x99s house,\r\nboth from his own inclination and to take messages for Mitya. Three\r\ndays after Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s arrest, Grushenka was taken very ill and was ill for\r\nnearly five weeks. For one whole week she was unconscious. She was very\r\nmuch changed\xe2\x80\x94thinner and a little sallow, though she had for the past\r\nfortnight been well enough to go out. But to Alyosha her face was even\r\nmore attractive than before, and he liked to meet her eyes when he went\r\nin to her. A look of firmness and intelligent purpose had developed in\r\nher face. There were signs of a spiritual transformation in her, and a\r\nsteadfast, fine and humble determination that nothing could shake could\r\nbe discerned in her. There was a small vertical line between her brows\r\nwhich gave her charming face a look of concentrated thought, almost\r\naustere at the first glance. There was scarcely a trace of her former\r\nfrivolity.\r\n\r\nIt seemed strange to Alyosha, too, that in spite of the calamity that\r\nhad overtaken the poor girl, betrothed to a man who had been arrested\r\nfor a terrible crime, almost at the instant of their betrothal, in\r\nspite of her illness and the almost inevitable sentence hanging over\r\nMitya, Grushenka had not yet lost her youthful cheerfulness. There was\r\na soft light in the once proud eyes, though at times they gleamed with\r\nthe old vindictive fire when she was visited by one disturbing thought\r\nstronger than ever in her heart. The object of that uneasiness was the\r\nsame as ever\xe2\x80\x94Katerina Ivanovna, of whom Grushenka had even raved when\r\nshe lay in delirium. Alyosha knew that she was fearfully jealous of\r\nher. Yet Katerina Ivanovna had not once visited Mitya in his prison,\r\nthough she might have done it whenever she liked. All this made a\r\ndifficult problem for Alyosha, for he was the only person to whom\r\nGrushenka opened her heart and from whom she was continually asking\r\nadvice. Sometimes he was unable to say anything.\r\n\r\nFull of anxiety he entered her lodging. She was at home. She had\r\nreturned from seeing Mitya half an hour before, and from the rapid\r\nmovement with which she leapt up from her chair to meet him he saw that\r\nshe had been expecting him with great impatience. A pack of cards dealt\r\nfor a game of \xe2\x80\x9cfools\xe2\x80\x9d lay on the table. A bed had been made up on the\r\nleather sofa on the other side and Maximov lay, half\xe2\x80\x90reclining, on it.\r\nHe wore a dressing\xe2\x80\x90 gown and a cotton nightcap, and was evidently ill\r\nand weak, though he was smiling blissfully. When the homeless old man\r\nreturned with Grushenka from Mokroe two months before, he had simply\r\nstayed on and was still staying with her. He arrived with her in rain\r\nand sleet, sat down on the sofa, drenched and scared, and gazed mutely\r\nat her with a timid, appealing smile. Grushenka, who was in terrible\r\ngrief and in the first stage of fever, almost forgot his existence in\r\nall she had to do the first half\xe2\x80\x90 hour after her arrival. Suddenly she\r\nchanced to look at him intently: he laughed a pitiful, helpless little\r\nlaugh. She called Fenya and told her to give him something to eat. All\r\nthat day he sat in the same place, almost without stirring. When it got\r\ndark and the shutters were closed, Fenya asked her mistress:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the gentleman going to stay the night, mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; make him a bed on the sofa,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Grushenka.\r\n\r\nQuestioning him more in detail, Grushenka learned from him that he had\r\nliterally nowhere to go, and that \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Kalganov, my benefactor, told me\r\nstraight that he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t receive me again and gave me five roubles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, God bless you, you\xe2\x80\x99d better stay, then,\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka decided in\r\nher grief, smiling compassionately at him. Her smile wrung the old\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s heart and his lips twitched with grateful tears. And so the\r\ndestitute wanderer had stayed with her ever since. He did not leave the\r\nhouse even when she was ill. Fenya and her grandmother, the cook, did\r\nnot turn him out, but went on serving him meals and making up his bed\r\non the sofa. Grushenka had grown used to him, and coming back from\r\nseeing Mitya (whom she had begun to visit in prison before she was\r\nreally well) she would sit down and begin talking to \xe2\x80\x9cMaximushka\xe2\x80\x9d about\r\ntrifling matters, to keep her from thinking of her sorrow. The old man\r\nturned out to be a good story\xe2\x80\x90teller on occasions, so that at last he\r\nbecame necessary to her. Grushenka saw scarcely any one else beside\r\nAlyosha, who did not come every day and never stayed long. Her old\r\nmerchant lay seriously ill at this time, \xe2\x80\x9cat his last gasp\xe2\x80\x9d as they\r\nsaid in the town, and he did, in fact, die a week after Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s trial.\r\nThree weeks before his death, feeling the end approaching, he made his\r\nsons, their wives and children, come upstairs to him at last and bade\r\nthem not leave him again. From that moment he gave strict orders to his\r\nservants not to admit Grushenka and to tell her if she came, \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nmaster wishes you long life and happiness and tells you to forget him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nBut Grushenka sent almost every day to inquire after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve come at last!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, flinging down the cards and joyfully\r\ngreeting Alyosha, \xe2\x80\x9cand Maximushka\xe2\x80\x99s been scaring me that perhaps you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come. Ah, how I need you! Sit down to the table. What will you\r\nhave\xe2\x80\x94coffee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, sitting down at the table. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very\r\nhungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right. Fenya, Fenya, coffee,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grushenka. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been made\r\na long time ready for you. And bring some little pies, and mind they\r\nare hot. Do you know, we\xe2\x80\x99ve had a storm over those pies to\xe2\x80\x90day. I took\r\nthem to the prison for him, and would you believe it, he threw them\r\nback to me: he would not eat them. He flung one of them on the floor\r\nand stamped on it. So I said to him: \xe2\x80\x98I shall leave them with the\r\nwarder; if you don\xe2\x80\x99t eat them before evening, it will be that your\r\nvenomous spite is enough for you!\xe2\x80\x99 With that I went away. We quarreled\r\nagain, would you believe it? Whenever I go we quarrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrushenka said all this in one breath in her agitation. Maximov,\r\nfeeling nervous, at once smiled and looked on the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you quarrel about this time?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect it in the least. He even took it into his head to be jealous of Kuzma last\r\nweek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he knew about the Pole before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but there it is. Rakitin went in as I came\r\nout. Perhaps Rakitin is egging him on. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d she added\r\ncarelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe loves you, that\xe2\x80\x99s what it is: he loves you so much. And I went to\r\nhim to say something about to\xe2\x80\x90morrow, for I dread to think what\xe2\x80\x99s going\r\nto happen then. You say that he is worried, but how worried I am! He is not jealous of\r\nMaximushka yet, anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife was dreadfully jealous over me, too,\xe2\x80\x9d Maximov put in his word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJealous of you?\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka laughed in spite of herself. \xe2\x80\x9cOf whom could\r\nshe have been jealous?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the servant girls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, Maximushka, I am in no laughing mood now; I feel\r\nangry. And I\r\nshall send him some pies, too, on purpose. I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t sent him any, but\r\nMitya accused me of it, so now I shall send some! Ah, here\xe2\x80\x99s Fenya with\r\na letter! Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s from the Poles\xe2\x80\x94begging again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPan Mussyalovitch had indeed sent an extremely long and\r\ncharacteristically eloquent letter in which he begged her to lend him\r\nthree roubles. In the letter was enclosed a receipt for the sum, with a\r\npromise to repay it within three months, signed by Pan Vrublevsky as\r\nwell. Grushenka had received many such letters, accompanied by such\r\nreceipts, from her former lover during the fortnight of her\r\nconvalescence. But she knew that the two Poles had been to ask after\r\nher health during her illness. The first letter Grushenka got from them\r\nwas a long one, written on large notepaper and with a big family crest\r\non the seal. It was so obscure and rhetorical that Grushenka put it\r\ndown before she had read half, unable to make head or tail of it. She\r\ncould not attend to letters then. The first letter was followed next\r\nday by another in which Pan Mussyalovitch begged her for a loan of two\r\nthousand roubles for a very short period. Grushenka left that letter,\r\ntoo, unanswered. A whole series of letters had followed\xe2\x80\x94one every\r\nday\xe2\x80\x94all as pompous and rhetorical, but the loan asked for, gradually\r\ndiminishing, dropped to a hundred roubles, then to twenty\xe2\x80\x90five, to ten,\r\nand finally Grushenka received a letter in which both the Poles begged\r\nher for only one rouble and included a receipt signed by both.\r\n\r\nThen Grushenka suddenly felt sorry for them, and at dusk she went round\r\nherself to their lodging. She found the two Poles in great poverty,\r\nalmost destitution, without food or fuel, without cigarettes, in debt\r\nto their landlady. The two hundred roubles they had carried off from\r\nMitya at Mokroe had soon disappeared. But Grushenka was surprised at\r\ntheir meeting her with arrogant dignity and self\xe2\x80\x90assertion, with the\r\ngreatest punctilio and pompous speeches. Grushenka simply laughed, and\r\ngave her former admirer ten roubles. Then, laughing, she told Mitya of\r\nit and he was not in the least jealous. But ever since, the Poles had\r\nattached themselves to Grushenka and bombarded her daily with requests\r\nfor money and she had always sent them small sums. And now that day\r\nMitya had taken it into his head to be fearfully jealous.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike a fool, I went round to him just for a minute, on the way to see\r\nMitya, for he is ill, too, my Pole,\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka began again with nervous\r\nhaste. \xe2\x80\x9cI was laughing, telling Mitya about it. \xe2\x80\x98Fancy,\xe2\x80\x99 I said, \xe2\x80\x98my\r\nPole had the happy thought to sing his old songs to me to the guitar.\r\nHe thought I would be touched and marry him!\xe2\x80\x99 Mitya leapt up\r\nswearing.... You must know all about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod will censure you.\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha was watching her steadily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just what I should like. I would go up and they would censure\r\nme, and I would burst out laughing in their faces. I should dreadfully\r\nlike to set fire to the house, Alyosha, to our house; you still don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? There are children of twelve years old, who have a longing to set\r\nfire to something and they do set things on fire, too. It\xe2\x80\x99s a sort of\r\ndisease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not true, that\xe2\x80\x99s not true; there may be children, but that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot what I mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou take evil for good; it\xe2\x80\x99s a passing crisis, it\xe2\x80\x99s the result of your\r\nillness, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do despise me, though! It\xe2\x80\x99s simply that I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do good, I\r\nwant to do evil, and it has nothing to do with illness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do evil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that everything might be destroyed. Ah, how nice it would be if\r\neverything were destroyed! You know, Alyosha, I sometimes think of\r\ndoing a fearful lot of harm and everything bad, and I should do it for\r\na long while on the sly and suddenly every one would find it out. Every\r\none will stand round and point their fingers at me and I would look at\r\nthem all. That would be awfully nice. Why would it be so nice,\r\nAlyosha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. It\xe2\x80\x99s a craving to destroy something good or, as you say,\r\nto set fire to something. It happens sometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI not only say it, I shall do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how I love you for saying you believe me. There was not\r\na trace of humor or jesting in her face now, though, in old days, fun\r\nand gayety never deserted her even at her most \xe2\x80\x9cearnest\xe2\x80\x9d moments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are moments when people love crime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! You have uttered my thought; they love crime, every one\r\nloves crime, they love it always, not at some \xe2\x80\x98moments.\xe2\x80\x99 You know, it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nas though people have made an agreement to lie about it and have lied\r\nabout it ever since. They all declare that they hate evil, but secretly\r\nthey all love it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd are you still reading nasty books?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am. There\xe2\x80\x99s a boy here, who lay down between the\r\nrailway lines when the train was passing. Lucky fellow! Listen, your\r\nbrother is being tried now for murdering his father and every one loves\r\nhis having killed his father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLoves his having killed his father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, loves it; every one loves it! Everybody says it\xe2\x80\x99s so awful, but\r\nsecretly they simply love it. I for one love it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is some truth in what you say about every one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha\r\nsoftly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what ideas you have!\xe2\x80\x9d Lise shrieked in delight. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you a monk,\r\ntoo! You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe how I respect you, Alyosha, for never telling\r\nlies. Oh, I must tell you a funny dream of mine. I sometimes dream of\r\ndevils. It\xe2\x80\x99s night; I am in my room with a candle and suddenly there\r\nare devils all over the place, in all the corners, under the table, and\r\nthey open the doors; there\xe2\x80\x99s a crowd of them behind the doors and they\r\nwant to come and seize me. And they are just coming, just seizing me.\r\nBut I suddenly cross myself and they all draw back, though they don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngo away altogether, they stand at the doors and in the corners,\r\nwaiting. And suddenly I have a frightful longing to revile God aloud,\r\nand so I begin, and then they come crowding back to me, delighted, and\r\nseize me again and I cross myself again and they all draw back. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nawful fun. it takes one\xe2\x80\x99s breath away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had the same dream, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lise, surprised. \xe2\x80\x9cI say, Alyosha, don\xe2\x80\x99t laugh, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nawfully important. Could two different people have the same dream?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems they can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha, I tell you, it\xe2\x80\x99s awfully important,\xe2\x80\x9d Lise went on, with\r\nreally excessive amazement. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not the dream that\xe2\x80\x99s important, but\r\nyour having the same dream as me. Only you in the whole world. And to\r\nyou more readily than to myself. And I am not a bit ashamed with you,\r\nnot a bit. Alyosha, why am I not ashamed with you, not a bit? Alyosha,\r\nis it true that at Easter the Jews steal a child and kill it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a book here in which I read about the trial of a Jew, who took\r\na child of four years old and cut off the fingers from both hands, and\r\nthen crucified him on the wall, hammered nails into him and crucified\r\nhim, and afterwards, when he was tried, he said that the child died\r\nsoon, within four hours. That was \xe2\x80\x98soon\xe2\x80\x99! He said the child moaned,\r\nkept on moaning and he stood admiring it. That\xe2\x80\x99s nice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNice; I sometimes imagine that it was I who crucified him. He would\r\nhang there moaning and I would sit opposite him eating pineapple\r\n_compote_. I am awfully fond of pineapple _compote_. Do you like it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha looked at her in silence. Her pale, sallow face was suddenly\r\ncontorted, her eyes burned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, when I read about that Jew I shook with sobs all night. I\r\nkept fancying how the little thing cried and moaned (a child of four\r\nyears old understands, you know), and all the while the thought of\r\npineapple _compote_ haunted me. In the morning I wrote a letter to a\r\ncertain person, begging him _particularly_ to come and see me. He came\r\nand I suddenly told him all about the child and the pineapple\r\n_compote_. _All_ about it, _all_, and said that it was nice. He laughed\r\nand said it really was nice. Then he got up and went away. He was only\r\nhere five minutes. Did he despise me? Did he despise me? Tell me, tell\r\nme, Alyosha, did he despise me or not?\xe2\x80\x9d She sat up on the couch, with\r\nflashing eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha asked anxiously, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you send for that person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you send him a letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimply to ask about that, about that child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not about that at all. He answered, laughed, got up and went away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat person behaved honorably,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha murmured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did he despise me? Did he laugh at me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for perhaps he believes in the pineapple _compote_ himself. He is\r\nvery ill now, too, Lise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he does believe in it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lise, with flashing eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t despise any one,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha went on. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly he does not\r\nbelieve any one. If he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t believe in people, of course, he does\r\ndespise them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he despises me, me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d Lise seemed to grind her teeth. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen he went out laughing, I\r\nfelt that it was nice to be despised. The child with fingers cut off is\r\nnice, and to be despised is nice....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she laughed in Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s face, a feverish malicious laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Alyosha, do you know, I should like\xe2\x80\x94Alyosha, save me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nShe suddenly jumped from the couch, rushed to him and seized him with\r\nboth hands. \xe2\x80\x9cSave me!\xe2\x80\x9d she almost groaned. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there any one in the\r\nworld I could tell what I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you? I loathe everything, everything.\r\nAlyosha, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you love me in the least?\xe2\x80\x9d she finished in a frenzy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do love you!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alyosha warmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will you weep over me, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot because I won\xe2\x80\x99t be your wife, but simply weep for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you! Do you hear, not any one! On the\r\ncontrary, I hate him! Go, Alyosha; it\xe2\x80\x99s time you went to your brother\xe2\x80\x9d;\r\nshe tore herself away from him suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I leave you like this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, almost in alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to your brother, the prison will be shut; go, here\xe2\x80\x99s your hat. Give\r\nmy love to Mitya, go, go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she almost forcibly pushed Alyosha out of the door. He looked at\r\nher with pained surprise, when he was suddenly aware of a letter in his\r\nright hand, a tiny letter folded up tight and sealed. He glanced at it\r\nand instantly read the address, \xe2\x80\x9cTo Ivan Fyodorovitch Karamazov.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nlooked quickly at Lise. Her face had become almost menacing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it to him, you must give it to him!\xe2\x80\x9d she ordered him, trembling\r\nand beside herself. \xe2\x80\x9cTo\xe2\x80\x90day, at once, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll poison myself! That\xe2\x80\x99s why\r\nI sent for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she slammed the door quickly. The bolt clicked. Alyosha put the\r\nnote in his pocket and went straight downstairs, without going back to\r\nMadame Hohlakov; forgetting her, in fact. As soon as Alyosha had gone,\r\nLise unbolted the door, opened it a little, put her finger in the crack\r\nand slammed the door with all her might, pinching her finger. Ten\r\nseconds after, releasing her finger, she walked softly, slowly to her\r\nchair, sat up straight in it and looked intently at her blackened\r\nfinger and at the blood that oozed from under the nail. Her lips were\r\nquivering and she kept whispering rapidly to herself:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a wretch, wretch, wretch, wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV.\r\nA Hymn And A Secret\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was quite late (days are short in November) when Alyosha rang at the\r\nprison gate. It was beginning to get dusk. But Alyosha knew that he\r\nwould be admitted without difficulty. Things were managed in our little\r\ntown, as everywhere else. At first, of course, on the conclusion of the\r\npreliminary inquiry, relations and a few other persons could only\r\nobtain interviews with Mitya by going through certain inevitable\r\nformalities. But later, though the formalities were not relaxed,\r\nexceptions were made for some, at least, of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s visitors. So much\r\nso, that sometimes the interviews with the prisoner in the room set\r\naside for the purpose were practically _t\xc3\xaate\xe2\x80\x90\xc3\xa0\xe2\x80\x90t\xc3\xaate_.\r\n\r\nThese exceptions, however, were few in number; only Grushenka, Alyosha\r\nand Rakitin were treated like this. But the captain of the police,\r\nMihail Mihailovitch, was very favorably disposed to Grushenka. His\r\nabuse of her at Mokroe weighed on the old man\xe2\x80\x99s conscience, and when he\r\nlearned the whole story, he completely changed his view of her. And\r\nstrange to say, though he was firmly persuaded of his guilt, yet after\r\nMitya was once in prison, the old man came to take a more and more\r\nlenient view of him. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was a man of good heart, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwho had come to grief from drinking and dissipation.\xe2\x80\x9d His first horror\r\nhad been succeeded by pity. As for Alyosha, the police captain was very\r\nfond of him and had known him for a long time. Rakitin, who had of late\r\ntaken to coming very often to see the prisoner, was one of the most\r\nintimate acquaintances of the \xe2\x80\x9cpolice captain\xe2\x80\x99s young ladies,\xe2\x80\x9d as he\r\ncalled them, and was always hanging about their house. He gave lessons\r\nin the house of the prison superintendent, too, who, though scrupulous\r\nin the performance of his duties, was a kind\xe2\x80\x90 hearted old man. Alyosha,\r\nagain, had an intimate acquaintance of long standing with the\r\nsuperintendent, who was fond of talking to him, generally on sacred\r\nsubjects. He respected Ivan Fyodorovitch, and stood in awe of his\r\nopinion, though he was a great philosopher himself; \xe2\x80\x9cself\xe2\x80\x90 taught,\xe2\x80\x9d of\r\ncourse. But Alyosha had an irresistible attraction for him. During the\r\nlast year the old man had taken to studying the Apocryphal Gospels, and\r\nconstantly talked over his impressions with his young friend. He used\r\nto come and see him in the monastery and discussed for hours together\r\nwith him and with the monks. So even if Alyosha were late at the\r\nprison, he had only to go to the superintendent and everything was made\r\neasy. Besides, every one in the prison, down to the humblest warder,\r\nhad grown used to Alyosha. The sentry, of course, did not trouble him\r\nso long as the authorities were satisfied.\r\n\r\nWhen Mitya was summoned from his cell, he always went downstairs, to\r\nthe place set aside for interviews. As Alyosha entered the room he came\r\nupon Rakitin, who was just taking leave of Mitya. They were both\r\ntalking loudly. Mitya was laughing heartily as he saw him out, while\r\nRakitin seemed grumbling. Rakitin did not like meeting Alyosha,\r\nespecially of late. He scarcely spoke to him, and bowed to him stiffly.\r\nSeeing Alyosha enter now, he frowned and looked away, as though he were\r\nentirely absorbed in buttoning his big, warm, fur\xe2\x80\x90trimmed overcoat.\r\nThen he began looking at once for his umbrella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must mind not to forget my belongings,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, simply to say\r\nsomething.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind you don\xe2\x80\x99t forget other people\xe2\x80\x99s belongings,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mitya, as a\r\njoke, and laughed at once at his own wit. Rakitin fired up instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better give that advice to your own family, who\xe2\x80\x99ve always been a\r\nslave\xe2\x80\x90driving lot, and not to Rakitin,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, suddenly trembling\r\nwith anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter? I was joking,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cDamn it all! They are\r\nall like that,\xe2\x80\x9d he turned to Alyosha, nodding towards Rakitin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhurriedly retreating figure. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was sitting here, laughing and\r\ncheerful, and all at once he boils up like that. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t even nod to\r\nyou. Have you broken with him completely? Why are you so late? I\xe2\x80\x99ve not\r\nbeen simply waiting, but thirsting for you the whole morning. But never\r\nmind. We\xe2\x80\x99ll make up for it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy does he come here so often? Surely you are not such great\r\nfriends?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha. He, too, nodded at the door through which\r\nRakitin had disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat friends with Rakitin? No, not as much as that. Is it likely\xe2\x80\x94a\r\npig like that? He considers I am ... a blackguard. They can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nunderstand a joke either, that\xe2\x80\x99s the worst of such people. They never\r\nunderstand a joke, and their souls are dry, dry and flat; they remind\r\nme of prison walls when I was first brought here. But he is a clever\r\nfellow, very clever. Well, Alexey, it\xe2\x80\x99s all over with me now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat down on the bench and made Alyosha sit down beside him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the trial\xe2\x80\x99s to\xe2\x80\x90morrow. Are you so hopeless, brother?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha\r\nsaid, with an apprehensive feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mitya, looking at him rather\r\nuncertainly. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, you mean the trial! Damn it all! Till now we\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\ntalking of things that don\xe2\x80\x99t matter, about this trial, but I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsaid a word to you about the chief thing. Yes, the trial is to\xe2\x80\x90morrow;\r\nbut it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the trial I meant, when I said it was all over with me.\r\nWhy do you look at me so critically?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Mitya?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdeas, ideas, that\xe2\x80\x99s all! Ethics! What is ethics?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEthics?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alyosha, wondering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; is it a science?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, there is such a science ... but ...
