You look very ill,\r\nIvan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan walked on without stopping. Alyosha followed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know, Alexey Fyodorovitch, how people do go out of their\r\nmind?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan asked in a voice suddenly quiet, without a trace of\r\nirritation, with a note of the simplest curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t. I suppose there are all kinds of insanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd can one observe that one\xe2\x80\x99s going mad oneself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI imagine one can\xe2\x80\x99t see oneself clearly in such circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAlyosha answered with surprise.\r\n\r\nIvan paused for half a minute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you want to talk to me, please change the subject,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\r\nsuddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, while I think of it, I have a letter for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha\r\ntimidly, and he took Lise\xe2\x80\x99s note from his pocket and held it out to\r\nIvan. They were just under a lamp\xe2\x80\x90post. Ivan recognized the handwriting\r\nat once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, from that little demon!\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed maliciously, and, without\r\nopening the envelope, he tore it into bits and threw it in the air. The\r\nbits were scattered by the wind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s not sixteen yet, I believe, and already offering herself,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid contemptuously, striding along the street again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you mean, offering herself?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs wanton women offer themselves, to be sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you, Ivan, how can you?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha cried warmly, in a grieved\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is a child; you are insulting a child! She is ill; she is\r\nvery ill, too. She is on the verge of insanity, too, perhaps.... I had\r\nhoped to hear something from you ... that would save her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll hear nothing from me. If she is a child I am not her nurse. Be\r\nquiet, Alexey. Don\xe2\x80\x99t go on about her. I am not even thinking about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were silent again for a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will be praying all night now to the Mother of God to show her how\r\nto act to\xe2\x80\x90morrow at the trial,\xe2\x80\x9d he said sharply and angrily again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ... you mean Katerina Ivanovna?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Whether she\xe2\x80\x99s to save Mitya or ruin him. She\xe2\x80\x99ll pray for light\r\nfrom above. She can\xe2\x80\x99t make up her mind for herself, you see. She has\r\nnot had time to decide yet. She takes me for her nurse, too. She wants\r\nme to sing lullabies to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKaterina Ivanovna loves you, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps; but I am not very keen on her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is suffering. Why do you ... sometimes say things to her that give\r\nher hope?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha went on, with timid reproach. \xe2\x80\x9cI know that you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngiven her hope. Forgive me for speaking to you like this,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t behave to her as I ought\xe2\x80\x94break off altogether and tell her so\r\nstraight out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan, irritably. \xe2\x80\x9cI must wait till sentence is\r\npassed on the murderer. If I break off with her now, she will avenge\r\nherself on me by ruining that scoundrel to\xe2\x80\x90morrow at the trial, for she\r\nhates him and knows she hates him. It\xe2\x80\x99s all a lie\xe2\x80\x94lie upon lie! As long\r\nas I don\xe2\x80\x99t break off with her, she goes on hoping, and she won\xe2\x80\x99t ruin\r\nthat monster, knowing how I want to get him out of trouble. If only\r\nthat damned verdict would come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words \xe2\x80\x9cmurderer\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmonster\xe2\x80\x9d echoed painfully in Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how can she ruin Mitya?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, pondering on Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s words.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat evidence can she give that would ruin Mitya?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know that yet. She\xe2\x80\x99s got a document in her hands, in Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nown writing, that proves conclusively that he did murder Fyodor\r\nPavlovitch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy is it impossible? I\xe2\x80\x99ve read it myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere can\xe2\x80\x99t be such a document!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha repeated warmly. \xe2\x80\x9cThere can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe, because he\xe2\x80\x99s not the murderer. It\xe2\x80\x99s not he murdered father, not\r\nhe!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan suddenly stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is the murderer then, according to you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, with apparent\r\ncoldness. There was even a supercilious note in his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know who,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha pronounced in a low, penetrating voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho? You mean the myth about that crazy idiot, the epileptic,\r\nSmerdyakov?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha suddenly felt himself trembling all over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know who,\xe2\x80\x9d broke helplessly from him. He could scarcely breathe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho? Who?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan cried almost fiercely. All his restraint suddenly\r\nvanished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only know one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha went on, still almost in a whisper,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t you_ killed father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98Not you\xe2\x80\x99! What do you mean by \xe2\x80\x98not you\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan was thunderstruck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not you killed father, not you!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha repeated firmly.\r\n\r\nThe silence lasted for half a minute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know I didn\xe2\x80\x99t. Are you raving?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan, with a pale, distorted\r\nsmile. His eyes were riveted on Alyosha. They were standing again under\r\na lamp\xe2\x80\x90post.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Ivan. You\xe2\x80\x99ve told yourself several times that you are the\r\nmurderer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did I say so? I was in Moscow.... When have I said so?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan\r\nfaltered helplessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve said so to yourself many times, when you\xe2\x80\x99ve been alone during\r\nthese two dreadful months,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha went on softly and distinctly as\r\nbefore. Yet he was speaking now, as it were, not of himself, not of his\r\nown will, but obeying some irresistible command. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have accused\r\nyourself and have confessed to yourself that you are the murderer and\r\nno one else. But you didn\xe2\x80\x99t do it: you are mistaken: you are not the\r\nmurderer. Do you hear? It was not you! God has sent me to tell you so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were both silent. The silence lasted a whole long minute. They\r\nwere both standing still, gazing into each other\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. They were both\r\npale. Suddenly Ivan began trembling all over, and clutched Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been in my room!\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered hoarsely. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been there at\r\nnight, when he came.... Confess ... have you seen him, have you seen\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you mean\xe2\x80\x94Mitya?\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha asked, bewildered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot him, damn the monster!\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan shouted, in a frenzy. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know\r\nthat he visits me? How did you find out? Speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is _he_! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whom you are talking about,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha\r\nfaltered, beginning to be alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you do know ... or how could you\xe2\x80\x94? It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible that you don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly he seemed to check himself. He stood still and seemed to\r\nreflect. A strange grin contorted his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha began again, in a shaking voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI have said this\r\nto you, because you\xe2\x80\x99ll believe my word, I know that. I tell you once\r\nand for all, it\xe2\x80\x99s not you. You hear, once for all! God has put it into\r\nmy heart to say this to you, even though it may make you hate me from\r\nthis hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut by now Ivan had apparently regained his self\xe2\x80\x90control.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlexey Fyodorovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a cold smile, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t endure\r\nprophets and epileptics\xe2\x80\x94messengers from God especially\xe2\x80\x94and you know\r\nthat only too well. I break off all relations with you from this moment\r\nand probably for ever. I beg you to leave me at this turning. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nway to your lodgings, too. You\xe2\x80\x99d better be particularly careful not to\r\ncome to me to\xe2\x80\x90day! Do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned and walked on with a firm step, not looking back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha called after him, \xe2\x80\x9cif anything happens to you\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day, turn to me before any one!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Ivan made no reply. Alyosha stood under the lamp\xe2\x80\x90post at the cross\r\nroads, till Ivan had vanished into the darkness. Then he turned and\r\nwalked slowly homewards. Both Alyosha and Ivan were living in lodgings;\r\nneither of them was willing to live in Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s empty house.\r\nAlyosha had a furnished room in the house of some working people. Ivan\r\nlived some distance from him. He had taken a roomy and fairly\r\ncomfortable lodge attached to a fine house that belonged to a\r\nwell\xe2\x80\x90to\xe2\x80\x90do lady, the widow of an official. But his only attendant was a\r\ndeaf and rheumatic old crone who went to bed at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock every\r\nevening and got up at six in the morning. Ivan had become remarkably\r\nindifferent to his comforts of late, and very fond of being alone. He\r\ndid everything for himself in the one room he lived in, and rarely\r\nentered any of the other rooms in his abode.\r\n\r\nHe reached the gate of the house and had his hand on the bell, when he\r\nsuddenly stopped. He felt that he was trembling all over with anger.\r\nSuddenly he let go of the bell, turned back with a curse, and walked\r\nwith rapid steps in the opposite direction. He walked a mile and a half\r\nto a tiny, slanting, wooden house, almost a hut, where Marya\r\nKondratyevna, the neighbor who used to come to Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nkitchen for soup and to whom Smerdyakov had once sung his songs and\r\nplayed on the guitar, was now lodging. She had sold their little house,\r\nand was now living here with her mother. Smerdyakov, who was ill\xe2\x80\x94almost\r\ndying\xe2\x80\x94had been with them ever since Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s death. It was\r\nto him Ivan was going now, drawn by a sudden and irresistible\r\nprompting.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI.\r\nThe First Interview With Smerdyakov\r\n\r\n\r\nThis was the third time that Ivan had been to see Smerdyakov since his\r\nreturn from Moscow. The first time he had seen him and talked to him\r\nwas on the first day of his arrival, then he had visited him once more,\r\na fortnight later. But his visits had ended with that second one, so\r\nthat it was now over a month since he had seen him. And he had scarcely\r\nheard anything of him.\r\n\r\nIvan had only returned five days after his father\xe2\x80\x99s death, so that he\r\nwas not present at the funeral, which took place the day before he came\r\nback. The cause of his delay was that Alyosha, not knowing his Moscow\r\naddress, had to apply to Katerina Ivanovna to telegraph to him, and\r\nshe, not knowing his address either, telegraphed to her sister and\r\naunt, reckoning on Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s going to see them as soon as he arrived in\r\nMoscow. But he did not go to them till four days after his arrival.\r\nWhen he got the telegram, he had, of course, set off post\xe2\x80\x90haste to our\r\ntown. The first to meet him was Alyosha, and Ivan was greatly surprised\r\nto find that, in opposition to the general opinion of the town, he\r\nrefused to entertain a suspicion against Mitya, and spoke openly of\r\nSmerdyakov as the murderer. Later on, after seeing the police captain\r\nand the prosecutor, and hearing the details of the charge and the\r\narrest, he was still more surprised at Alyosha, and ascribed his\r\nopinion only to his exaggerated brotherly feeling and sympathy with\r\nMitya, of whom Alyosha, as Ivan knew, was very fond.\r\n\r\nBy the way, let us say a word or two of Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s feeling to his brother\r\nDmitri. He positively disliked him; at most, felt sometimes a\r\ncompassion for him, and even that was mixed with great contempt, almost\r\nrepugnance. Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s whole personality, even his appearance, was\r\nextremely unattractive to him. Ivan looked with indignation on Katerina\r\nIvanovna\xe2\x80\x99s love for his brother. Yet he went to see Mitya on the first\r\nday of his arrival, and that interview, far from shaking Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s belief\r\nin his guilt, positively strengthened it. He found his brother\r\nagitated, nervously excited. Mitya had been talkative, but very\r\nabsent\xe2\x80\x90minded and incoherent. He used violent language, accused\r\nSmerdyakov, and was fearfully muddled. He talked principally about the\r\nthree thousand roubles, which he said had been \xe2\x80\x9cstolen\xe2\x80\x9d from him by his\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe money was mine, it was my money,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya kept repeating. \xe2\x80\x9cEven if I\r\nhad stolen it, I should have had the right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hardly contested the evidence against him, and if he tried to turn a\r\nfact to his advantage, it was in an absurd and incoherent way. He\r\nhardly seemed to wish to defend himself to Ivan or any one else. Quite\r\nthe contrary, he was angry and proudly scornful of the charges against\r\nhim; he was continually firing up and abusing every one. He only\r\nlaughed contemptuously at Grigory\xe2\x80\x99s evidence about the open door, and\r\ndeclared that it was \xe2\x80\x9cthe devil that opened it.\xe2\x80\x9d But he could not bring\r\nforward any coherent explanation of the fact. He even succeeded in\r\ninsulting Ivan during their first interview, telling him sharply that\r\nit was not for people who declared that \xe2\x80\x9ceverything was lawful,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\nsuspect and question him. Altogether he was anything but friendly with\r\nIvan on that occasion. Immediately after that interview with Mitya,\r\nIvan went for the first time to see Smerdyakov.\r\n\r\nIn the railway train on his way from Moscow, he kept thinking of\r\nSmerdyakov and of his last conversation with him on the evening before\r\nhe went away. Many things seemed to him puzzling and suspicious. But\r\nwhen he gave his evidence to the investigating lawyer Ivan said\r\nnothing, for the time, of that conversation. He put that off till he\r\nhad seen Smerdyakov, who was at that time in the hospital.\r\n\r\nDoctor Herzenstube and Varvinsky, the doctor he met in the hospital,\r\nconfidently asserted in reply to Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s persistent questions, that\r\nSmerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s epileptic attack was unmistakably genuine, and were\r\nsurprised indeed at Ivan asking whether he might not have been shamming\r\non the day of the catastrophe. They gave him to understand that the\r\nattack was an exceptional one, the fits persisting and recurring\r\nseveral times, so that the patient\xe2\x80\x99s life was positively in danger, and\r\nit was only now, after they had applied remedies, that they could\r\nassert with confidence that the patient would survive. \xe2\x80\x9cThough it might\r\nwell be,\xe2\x80\x9d added Doctor Herzenstube, \xe2\x80\x9cthat his reason would be impaired\r\nfor a considerable period, if not permanently.\xe2\x80\x9d On Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s asking\r\nimpatiently whether that meant that he was now mad, they told him that\r\nthis was not yet the case, in the full sense of the word, but that\r\ncertain abnormalities were perceptible. Ivan decided to find out for\r\nhimself what those abnormalities were.\r\n\r\nAt the hospital he was at once allowed to see the patient. Smerdyakov\r\nwas lying on a truckle\xe2\x80\x90bed in a separate ward. There was only one other\r\nbed in the room, and in it lay a tradesman of the town, swollen with\r\ndropsy, who was obviously almost dying; he could be no hindrance to\r\ntheir conversation. Smerdyakov grinned uncertainly on seeing Ivan, and\r\nfor the first instant seemed nervous. So at least Ivan fancied. But\r\nthat was only momentary. For the rest of the time he was struck, on the\r\ncontrary, by Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s composure. From the first glance Ivan had no\r\ndoubt that he was very ill. He was very weak; he spoke slowly, seeming\r\nto move his tongue with difficulty; he was much thinner and sallower.\r\nThroughout the interview, which lasted twenty minutes, he kept\r\ncomplaining of headache and of pain in all his limbs. His thin\r\nemasculate face seemed to have become so tiny; his hair was ruffled,\r\nand his crest of curls in front stood up in a thin tuft. But in the\r\nleft eye, which was screwed up and seemed to be insinuating something,\r\nSmerdyakov showed himself unchanged. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s always worth while speaking\r\nto a clever man.\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan was reminded of that at once. He sat down on the\r\nstool at his feet. Smerdyakov, with painful effort, shifted his\r\nposition in bed, but he was not the first to speak. He remained dumb,\r\nand did not even look much interested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you talk to me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ivan. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t tire you much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I can,\xe2\x80\x9d mumbled Smerdyakov, in a faint voice. \xe2\x80\x9cHas your\r\nhonor been back long?\xe2\x80\x9d he added patronizingly, as though encouraging a\r\nnervous visitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only arrived to\xe2\x80\x90day.... To see the mess you are in here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you sigh? You knew of it all along,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan blurted out.\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov was stolidly silent for a while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I help knowing? It was clear beforehand. But how could I\r\ntell it would turn out like that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would turn out? Don\xe2\x80\x99t prevaricate! You\xe2\x80\x99ve foretold you\xe2\x80\x99d have a\r\nfit; on the way down to the cellar, you know. You mentioned the very\r\nspot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you said so at the examination yet?\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov queried with\r\ncomposure.\r\n\r\nIvan felt suddenly angry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t yet, but I certainly shall. You must explain a great\r\ndeal to me, my man; and let me tell you, I am not going to let you play\r\nwith me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I play with you, when I put my whole trust in you, as in\r\nGod Almighty?\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov, with the same composure, only for a\r\nmoment closing his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place,\xe2\x80\x9d began Ivan, \xe2\x80\x9cI know that epileptic fits can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\ntold beforehand. I\xe2\x80\x99ve inquired; don\xe2\x80\x99t try and take me in. You can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nforetell the day and the hour. How was it you told me the day and the\r\nhour beforehand, and about the cellar, too? How could you tell that you\r\nwould fall down the cellar stairs in a fit, if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t sham a fit on\r\npurpose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had to go to the cellar anyway, several times a day, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSmerdyakov drawled deliberately. \xe2\x80\x9cI fell from the garret just in the\r\nsame way a year ago. It\xe2\x80\x99s quite true you can\xe2\x80\x99t tell the day and hour of\r\na fit beforehand, but you can always have a presentiment of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you did foretell the day and the hour!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn regard to my epilepsy, sir, you had much better inquire of the\r\ndoctors here. You can ask them whether it was a real fit or a sham;\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s no use my saying any more about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the cellar? How could you know beforehand of the cellar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t seem able to get over that cellar! As I was going down to\r\nthe cellar, I was in terrible dread and doubt. What frightened me most\r\nwas losing you and being left without defense in all the world. So I\r\nwent down into the cellar thinking, \xe2\x80\x98Here, it\xe2\x80\x99ll come on directly,\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99ll strike me down directly, shall I fall?\xe2\x80\x99 And it was through this\r\nfear that I suddenly felt the spasm that always comes ... and so I went\r\nflying. All that and all my previous conversation with you at the gate\r\nthe evening before, when I told you how frightened I was and spoke of\r\nthe cellar, I told all that to Doctor Herzenstube and Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch, the investigating lawyer, and it\xe2\x80\x99s all been written down\r\nin the protocol. And the doctor here, Mr. Varvinsky, maintained to all\r\nof them that it was just the thought of it brought it on, the\r\napprehension that I might fall. It was just then that the fit seized\r\nme. And so they\xe2\x80\x99ve written it down, that it\xe2\x80\x99s just how it must have\r\nhappened, simply from my fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he finished, Smerdyakov drew a deep breath, as though exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have said all that in your evidence?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan, somewhat\r\ntaken aback. He had meant to frighten him with the threat of repeating\r\ntheir conversation, and it appeared that Smerdyakov had already\r\nreported it all himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I to be afraid of? Let them write down the whole truth,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSmerdyakov pronounced firmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you told them every word of our conversation at the gate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not to say every word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you tell them that you can sham fits, as you boasted then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell them that either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me now, why did you send me then to Tchermashnya?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid you\xe2\x80\x99d go away to Moscow; Tchermashnya is nearer, anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are lying; you suggested my going away yourself; you told me to\r\nget out of the way of trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was simply out of affection and my sincere devotion to you,\r\nforeseeing trouble in the house, to spare you. Only I wanted to spare\r\nmyself even more. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I told you to get out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way, that\r\nyou might understand that there would be trouble in the house, and\r\nwould remain at home to protect your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have said it more directly, you blockhead!\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan suddenly\r\nfired up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I have said it more directly then? It was simply my fear\r\nthat made me speak, and you might have been angry, too. I might well\r\nhave been apprehensive that Dmitri Fyodorovitch would make a scene and\r\ncarry away that money, for he considered it as good as his own; but who\r\ncould tell that it would end in a murder like this? I thought that he\r\nwould only carry off the three thousand that lay under the master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmattress in the envelope, and you see, he\xe2\x80\x99s murdered him. How could you\r\nguess it either, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if you say yourself that it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be guessed, how could I have\r\nguessed and stayed at home? You contradict yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivan,\r\npondering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have guessed from my sending you to Tchermashnya and not to\r\nMoscow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I guess it from that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov seemed much exhausted, and again he was silent for a minute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have guessed from the fact of my asking you not to go to\r\nMoscow, but to Tchermashnya, that I wanted to have you nearer, for\r\nMoscow\xe2\x80\x99s a long way off, and Dmitri Fyodorovitch, knowing you are not\r\nfar off, would not be so bold. And if anything had happened, you might\r\nhave come to protect me, too, for I warned you of Grigory\r\nVassilyevitch\xe2\x80\x99s illness, and that I was afraid of having a fit. And\r\nwhen I explained those knocks to you, by means of which one could go in\r\nto the deceased, and that Dmitri Fyodorovitch knew them all through me,\r\nI thought that you would guess yourself that he would be sure to do\r\nsomething, and so wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go to Tchermashnya even, but would stay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe talks very coherently,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Ivan, \xe2\x80\x9cthough he does mumble;\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the derangement of his faculties that Herzenstube talked of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are cunning with me, damn you!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, getting angry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I thought at the time that you quite guessed,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov parried\r\nwith the simplest air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I\xe2\x80\x99d guessed, I should have stayed,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I thought that it was because you guessed, that you went away in\r\nsuch a hurry, only to get out of trouble, only to run away and save\r\nyourself in your fright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think that every one is as great a coward as yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, I thought you were like me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I ought to have guessed,\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan said in agitation; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\ndid guess there was some mischief brewing on your part ... only you are\r\nlying, you are lying again,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, suddenly recollecting. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nremember how you went up to the carriage and said to me, \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s always\r\nworth while speaking to a clever man\xe2\x80\x99? So you were glad I went away,\r\nsince you praised me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov sighed again and again. A trace of color came into his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I was pleased,\xe2\x80\x9d he articulated rather breathlessly, \xe2\x80\x9cit was simply\r\nbecause you agreed not to go to Moscow, but to Tchermashnya. For it was\r\nnearer, anyway. Only when I said these words to you, it was not by way\r\nof praise, but of reproach. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat reproach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that foreseeing such a calamity you deserted your own father, and\r\nwould not protect us, for I might have been taken up any time for\r\nstealing that three thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn you!\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan swore again. \xe2\x80\x9cStay, did you tell the prosecutor and\r\nthe investigating lawyer about those knocks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told them everything just as it was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan wondered inwardly again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I thought of anything then,\xe2\x80\x9d he began again, \xe2\x80\x9cit was solely of some\r\nwickedness on your part. Dmitri might kill him, but that he would\r\nsteal\xe2\x80\x94I did not believe that then.... But I was prepared for any\r\nwickedness from you. You told me yourself you could sham a fit. What\r\ndid you say that for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was just through my simplicity, and I never have shammed a fit on\r\npurpose in my life. And I only said so then to boast to you. It was\r\njust foolishness. I liked you so much then, and was open\xe2\x80\x90hearted with\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother directly accuses you of the murder and theft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else is left for him to do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov, with a bitter grin.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who will believe him with all the proofs against him? Grigory\r\nVassilyevitch saw the door open. What can he say after that? But never\r\nmind him! He is trembling to save himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe slowly ceased speaking; then suddenly, as though on reflection,\r\nadded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd look here again. He wants to throw it on me and make out that it\r\nis the work of my hands\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard that already. But as to my being\r\nclever at shamming a fit: should I have told you beforehand that I\r\ncould sham one, if I really had had such a design against your father?\r\nIf I had been planning such a murder could I have been such a fool as\r\nto give such evidence against myself beforehand? And to his son, too!\r\nUpon my word! Is that likely? As if that could be, such a thing has\r\nnever happened. No one hears this talk of ours now, except Providence\r\nitself, and if you were to tell of it to the prosecutor and Nikolay\r\nParfenovitch you might defend me completely by doing so, for who would\r\nbe likely to be such a criminal, if he is so open\xe2\x80\x90hearted beforehand?\r\nAny one can see that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d and Ivan got up to cut short the conversation, struck by\r\nSmerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s last argument. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t suspect you at all, and I think\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s absurd, indeed, to suspect you. On the contrary, I am grateful to\r\nyou for setting my mind at rest. Now I am going, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll come again.\r\nMeanwhile, good\xe2\x80\x90by. Get well. Is there anything you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very thankful for everything. Marfa Ignatyevna does not forget\r\nme, and provides me anything I want, according to her kindness. Good\r\npeople visit me every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood\xe2\x80\x90by. And if you don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of that, I shall say\r\nnothing of that conversation of ours at the gate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen it happened that Ivan went out, and only when he had gone a dozen\r\nsteps along the corridor, he suddenly felt that there was an insulting\r\nsignificance in Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s last words. He was almost on the point of\r\nturning back, but it was only a passing impulse, and muttering,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d he went out of the hospital.\r\n\r\nHis chief feeling was one of relief at the fact that it was not\r\nSmerdyakov, but Mitya, who had committed the murder, though he might\r\nhave been expected to feel the opposite. He did not want to analyze the\r\nreason for this feeling, and even felt a positive repugnance at prying\r\ninto his sensations. He felt as though he wanted to make haste to\r\nforget something. In the following days he became convinced of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nguilt, as he got to know all the weight of evidence against him. There\r\nwas evidence of people of no importance, Fenya and her mother, for\r\ninstance, but the effect of it was almost overpowering. As to Perhotin,\r\nthe people at the tavern, and at Plotnikov\xe2\x80\x99s shop, as well as the\r\nwitnesses at Mokroe, their evidence seemed conclusive. It was the\r\ndetails that were so damning. The secret of the knocks impressed the\r\nlawyers almost as much as Grigory\xe2\x80\x99s evidence as to the open door.\r\nGrigory\xe2\x80\x99s wife, Marfa, in answer to Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s questions, declared that\r\nSmerdyakov had been lying all night the other side of the partition\r\nwall. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was not three paces from our bed,\xe2\x80\x9d and that although she was\r\na sound sleeper she waked several times and heard him moaning, \xe2\x80\x9cHe was\r\nmoaning the whole time, moaning continually.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTalking to Herzenstube, and giving it as his opinion that Smerdyakov\r\nwas not mad, but only rather weak, Ivan only evoked from the old man a\r\nsubtle smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know how he spends his time now?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked; \xe2\x80\x9clearning lists of\r\nFrench words by heart. He has an exercise\xe2\x80\x90book under his pillow with\r\nthe French words written out in Russian letters for him by some one, he\r\nhe he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan ended by dismissing all doubts. He could not think of Dmitri\r\nwithout repulsion. Only one thing was strange, however. Alyosha\r\npersisted that Dmitri was not the murderer, and that \xe2\x80\x9cin all\r\nprobability\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov was. Ivan always felt that Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s opinion\r\nmeant a great deal to him, and so he was astonished at it now. Another\r\nthing that was strange was that Alyosha did not make any attempt to\r\ntalk about Mitya with Ivan, that he never began on the subject and only\r\nanswered his questions. This, too, struck Ivan particularly.\r\n\r\nBut he was very much preoccupied at that time with something quite\r\napart from that. On his return from Moscow, he abandoned himself\r\nhopelessly to his mad and consuming passion for Katerina Ivanovna. This\r\nis not the time to begin to speak of this new passion of Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s, which\r\nleft its mark on all the rest of his life: this would furnish the\r\nsubject for another novel, which I may perhaps never write. But I\r\ncannot omit to mention here that when Ivan, on leaving Katerina\r\nIvanovna with Alyosha, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve related already, told him, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not\r\nkeen on her,\xe2\x80\x9d it was an absolute lie: he loved her madly, though at\r\ntimes he hated her so that he might have murdered her. Many causes\r\nhelped to bring about this feeling. Shattered by what had happened with\r\nMitya, she rushed on Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s return to meet him as her one salvation.\r\nShe was hurt, insulted and humiliated in her feelings. And here the man\r\nhad come back to her, who had loved her so ardently before (oh! she\r\nknew that very well), and whose heart and intellect she considered so\r\nsuperior to her own. But the sternly virtuous girl did not abandon\r\nherself altogether to the man she loved, in spite of the Karamazov\r\nviolence of his passions and the great fascination he had for her. She\r\nwas continually tormented at the same time by remorse for having\r\ndeserted Mitya, and in moments of discord and violent anger (and they\r\nwere numerous) she told Ivan so plainly. This was what he had called to\r\nAlyosha \xe2\x80\x9clies upon lies.\xe2\x80\x9d There was, of course, much that was false in\r\nit, and that angered Ivan more than anything.... But of all this later.\r\n\r\nHe did, in fact, for a time almost forget Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s existence, and\r\nyet, a fortnight after his first visit to him, he began to be haunted\r\nby the same strange thoughts as before. It\xe2\x80\x99s enough to say that he was\r\ncontinually asking himself, why was it that on that last night in\r\nFyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s house he had crept out on to the stairs like a\r\nthief and listened to hear what his father was doing below? Why had he\r\nrecalled that afterwards with repulsion? Why next morning, had he been\r\nsuddenly so depressed on the journey? Why, as he reached Moscow, had he\r\nsaid to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a scoundrel\xe2\x80\x9d? And now he almost fancied that\r\nthese tormenting thoughts would make him even forget Katerina Ivanovna,\r\nso completely did they take possession of him again. It was just after\r\nfancying this, that he met Alyosha in the street. He stopped him at\r\nonce, and put a question to him:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember when Dmitri burst in after dinner and beat father, and\r\nafterwards I told you in the yard that I reserved \xe2\x80\x98the right to\r\ndesire\xe2\x80\x99?... Tell me, did you think then that I desired father\xe2\x80\x99s death\r\nor not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did think so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alyosha, softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was so, too; it was not a matter of guessing. But didn\xe2\x80\x99t you fancy\r\nthen that what I wished was just that \xe2\x80\x98one reptile should devour\r\nanother\xe2\x80\x99; that is, just that Dmitri should kill father, and as soon as\r\npossible ... and that I myself was even prepared to help to bring that\r\nabout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlyosha turned rather pale, and looked silently into his brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivan, \xe2\x80\x9cI want above everything to know what you thought\r\nthen. I want the truth, the truth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew a deep breath, looking angrily at Alyosha before his answer\r\ncame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, I did think that, too, at the time,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Alyosha,\r\nand he did not add one softening phrase.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d snapped Ivan, and, leaving Alyosha, he went quickly on his\r\nway. From that time Alyosha noticed that Ivan began obviously to avoid\r\nhim and seemed even to have taken a dislike to him, so much so that\r\nAlyosha gave up going to see him. Immediately after that meeting with\r\nhim, Ivan had not gone home, but went straight to Smerdyakov again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\nThe Second Visit To Smerdyakov\r\n\r\n\r\nBy that time Smerdyakov had been discharged from the hospital. Ivan\r\nknew his new lodging, the dilapidated little wooden house, divided in\r\ntwo by a passage on one side of which lived Marya Kondratyevna and her\r\nmother, and on the other, Smerdyakov. No one knew on what terms he\r\nlived with them, whether as a friend or as a lodger. It was supposed\r\nafterwards that he had come to stay with them as Marya Kondratyevna\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbetrothed, and was living there for a time without paying for board or\r\nlodging. Both mother and daughter had the greatest respect for him and\r\nlooked upon him as greatly superior to themselves.\r\n\r\nIvan knocked, and, on the door being opened, went straight into the\r\npassage. By Marya Kondratyevna\xe2\x80\x99s directions he went straight to the\r\nbetter room on the left, occupied by Smerdyakov. There was a tiled\r\nstove in the room and it was extremely hot. The walls were gay with\r\nblue paper, which was a good deal used however, and in the cracks under\r\nit cockroaches swarmed in amazing numbers, so that there was a\r\ncontinual rustling from them. The furniture was very scanty: two\r\nbenches against each wall and two chairs by the table. The table of\r\nplain wood was covered with a cloth with pink patterns on it. There was\r\na pot of geranium on each of the two little windows. In the corner\r\nthere was a case of ikons. On the table stood a little copper samovar\r\nwith many dents in it, and a tray with two cups. But Smerdyakov had\r\nfinished tea and the samovar was out. He was sitting at the table on a\r\nbench. He was looking at an exercise\xe2\x80\x90book and slowly writing with a\r\npen. There was a bottle of ink by him and a flat iron candlestick, but\r\nwith a composite candle. Ivan saw at once from Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s face that\r\nhe had completely recovered from his illness. His face was fresher,\r\nfuller, his hair stood up jauntily in front, and was plastered down at\r\nthe sides. He was sitting in a parti\xe2\x80\x90colored, wadded dressing\xe2\x80\x90gown,\r\nrather dirty and frayed, however. He had spectacles on his nose, which\r\nIvan had never seen him wearing before. This trifling circumstance\r\nsuddenly redoubled Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s anger: \xe2\x80\x9cA creature like that and wearing\r\nspectacles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov slowly raised his head and looked intently at his visitor\r\nthrough his spectacles; then he slowly took them off and rose from the\r\nbench, but by no means respectfully, almost lazily, doing the least\r\npossible required by common civility. All this struck Ivan instantly;\r\nhe took it all in and noted it at once\xe2\x80\x94most of all the look in\r\nSmerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, positively malicious, churlish and haughty. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do\r\nyou want to intrude for?\xe2\x80\x9d it seemed to say; \xe2\x80\x9cwe settled everything\r\nthen; why have you come again?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan could scarcely control himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hot here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, still standing, and unbuttoned his overcoat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake off your coat,\xe2\x80\x9d Smerdyakov conceded.\r\n\r\nIvan took off his coat and threw it on a bench with trembling hands. He\r\ntook a chair, moved it quickly to the table and sat down. Smerdyakov\r\nmanaged to sit down on his bench before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo begin with, are we alone?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan asked sternly and impulsively. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\r\nthey overhear us in there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one can hear anything. You\xe2\x80\x99ve seen for yourself: there\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\npassage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, my good fellow; what was that you babbled, as I was leaving\r\nthe hospital, that if I said nothing about your faculty of shamming\r\nfits, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell the investigating lawyer all our conversation\r\nat the gate? What do you mean by _all_? What could you mean by it? Were\r\nyou threatening me? Have I entered into some sort of compact with you?\r\nDo you suppose I am afraid of you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan said this in a perfect fury, giving him to understand with obvious\r\nintention that he scorned any subterfuge or indirectness and meant to\r\nshow his cards. Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s eyes gleamed resentfully, his left eye\r\nwinked, and he at once gave his answer, with his habitual composure and\r\ndeliberation. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to have everything above\xe2\x80\x90board; very well, you\r\nshall have it,\xe2\x80\x9d he seemed to say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what I meant then, and this is why I said that, that you,\r\nknowing beforehand of this murder of your own parent, left him to his\r\nfate, and that people mightn\xe2\x80\x99t after that conclude any evil about your\r\nfeelings and perhaps of something else, too\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s what I promised not\r\nto tell the authorities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough Smerdyakov spoke without haste and obviously controlling\r\nhimself, yet there was something in his voice, determined and emphatic,\r\nresentful and insolently defiant. He stared impudently at Ivan. A mist\r\npassed before Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s eyes for the first moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? What? Are you out of your mind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m perfectly in possession of all my faculties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you suppose I _knew_ of the murder?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan cried at last, and he\r\nbrought his fist violently on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by\r\n\xe2\x80\x98something else, too\xe2\x80\x99? Speak, scoundrel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov was silent and still scanned Ivan with the same insolent\r\nstare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, you stinking rogue, what is that \xe2\x80\x98something else, too\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98something else\xe2\x80\x99 I meant was that you probably, too, were very\r\ndesirous of your parent\xe2\x80\x99s death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan jumped up and struck him with all his might on the shoulder, so\r\nthat he fell back against the wall. Saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a shame, sir, to strike a sick man,\xe2\x80\x9d he dried\r\nhis eyes with a very dirty blue check handkerchief and sank into quiet\r\nweeping. A minute passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s enough! Every line of his puckered face\r\nreflected the insult he had just received.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you thought then, you scoundrel, that together with Dmitri I meant\r\nto kill my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what thoughts were in your mind then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov\r\nresentfully; \xe2\x80\x9cand so I stopped you then at the gate to sound you on\r\nthat very point.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo sound what, what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that very circumstance, whether you wanted your father to be\r\nmurdered or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat infuriated Ivan more than anything was the aggressive, insolent\r\ntone to which Smerdyakov persistently adhered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was you murdered him?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried suddenly.\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov smiled contemptuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know of yourself, for a fact, that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t I murdered him. And I\r\nshould have thought that there was no need for a sensible man to speak\r\nof it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why, why had you such a suspicion about me at the time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you know already, it was simply from fear. For I was in such a\r\nposition, shaking with fear, that I suspected every one. I resolved to\r\nsound you, too, for I thought if you wanted the same as your brother,\r\nthen the business was as good as settled and I should be crushed like a\r\nfly, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, you didn\xe2\x80\x99t say that a fortnight ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI meant the same when I talked to you in the hospital, only I thought\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d understand without wasting words, and that being such a sensible\r\nman you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care to talk of it openly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next! What about the inheritance?\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov\r\nsarcastically, and, as it were, vindictively. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, after your parent\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath there was at least forty thousand to come to each of you, and\r\nvery likely more, but if Fyodor Pavlovitch got married then to that\r\nlady, Agrafena Alexandrovna, she would have had all his capital made\r\nover to her directly after the wedding, for she\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of sense, so\r\nthat your parent would not have left you two roubles between the three\r\nof you. And were they far from a wedding, either? Not a hair\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x90breadth:\r\nthat lady had only to lift her little finger and he would have run\r\nafter her to church, with his tongue out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan restrained himself with painful effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d he commented at last. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t jumped up, I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t knocked you down, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t killed you. Speak on. So, according\r\nto you, I had fixed on Dmitri to do it; I was reckoning on him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could you help reckoning on him? If he killed him, then he would\r\nlose all the rights of a nobleman, his rank and property, and would go\r\noff to exile; so his share of the inheritance would come to you and\r\nyour brother Alexey Fyodorovitch in equal parts; so you\xe2\x80\x99d each have not\r\nforty, but sixty thousand each. There\xe2\x80\x99s not a doubt you did reckon on\r\nDmitri Fyodorovitch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I put up with from you! Listen, scoundrel, if I had reckoned on\r\nany one then, it would have been on you, not on Dmitri, and I swear I\r\ndid expect some wickedness from you ... at the time.... I remember my\r\nimpression!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought, too, for a minute, at the time, that you were reckoning on\r\nme as well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Smerdyakov, with a sarcastic grin. \xe2\x80\x9cSo that it was\r\njust by that more than anything you showed me what was in your mind.\r\nFor if you had a foreboding about me and yet went away, you as good as\r\nsaid to me, \xe2\x80\x98You can murder my parent, I won\xe2\x80\x99t hinder you!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou scoundrel! So that\xe2\x80\x99s how you understood it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was all that going to Tchermashnya. Why! You were meaning to go to\r\nMoscow and refused all your father\xe2\x80\x99s entreaties to go to\r\nTchermashnya\xe2\x80\x94and simply at a foolish word from me you consented at\r\nonce! What reason had you to consent to Tchermashnya? Since you went to\r\nTchermashnya with no reason, simply at my word, it shows that you must\r\nhave expected something from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I swear I didn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Ivan, grinding his teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t? Who would\r\nhave believed me and what charge could I bring against you? But the\r\npunch in the face ... oh, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think of it. Though blows\r\nare forbidden, I should have pounded your ugly face to a jelly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSmerdyakov looked at him almost with relish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the ordinary occasions of life,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in the same complacent and\r\nsententious tone in which he had taunted Grigory and argued with him\r\nabout religion at Fyodor Pavlovitch\xe2\x80\x99s table, \xe2\x80\x9cin the ordinary occasions\r\nof life, blows on the face are forbidden nowadays by law, and people\r\nhave given them up, but in exceptional occasions of life people still\r\nfly to blows, not only among us but all over the world, be it even the\r\nfullest Republic of France, just as in the time of Adam and Eve, and\r\nthey never will leave off, but you, even in an exceptional case, did\r\nnot dare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you learning French words for?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan nodded towards the\r\nexercise\xe2\x80\x90book lying on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I learn them so as to improve my education, supposing\r\nthat I may myself chance to go some day to those happy parts of\r\nEurope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, monster.\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s eyes flashed and he trembled all over. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nnot afraid of your accusations; you can say what you like about me, and\r\nif I don\xe2\x80\x99t beat you to death, it\xe2\x80\x99s simply because I suspect you of that\r\ncrime and I\xe2\x80\x99ll drag you to justice. I\xe2\x80\x99ll unmask you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo my thinking, you\xe2\x80\x99d better keep quiet, for what can you accuse me\r\nof, considering my absolute innocence? and who would believe you? Only\r\nif you begin, I shall tell everything, too, for I must defend myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I am afraid of you now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the court doesn\xe2\x80\x99t believe all I\xe2\x80\x99ve said to you just now, the public\r\nwill, and you will be ashamed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s always worth while speaking to a\r\nsensible man,\xe2\x80\x99 eh?\xe2\x80\x9d snarled Ivan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hit the mark, indeed. And you\xe2\x80\x99d better be sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan got up, shaking all over with indignation, put on his coat, and\r\nwithout replying further to Smerdyakov, without even looking at him,\r\nwalked quickly out of the cottage. The cool evening air refreshed him.\r\nThere was a bright moon in the sky. A nightmare of ideas and sensations\r\nfilled his soul. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I go at once and give information against\r\nSmerdyakov? But what information can I give? He is not guilty, anyway.\r\nOn the contrary, he\xe2\x80\x99ll accuse me. And in fact, why did I set off for\r\nTchermashnya then? What for? What for?\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan asked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, of\r\ncourse, I was expecting something and he is right....\xe2\x80\x9d And he\r\nremembered for the hundredth time how, on the last night in his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s house, he had listened on the stairs. But he remembered it now\r\nwith such anguish that he stood still on the spot as though he had been\r\nstabbed. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I expected it then, that\xe2\x80\x99s true! I wanted the murder, I\r\ndid want the murder! Did I want the murder? Did I want it? I must kill\r\nSmerdyakov! If I don\xe2\x80\x99t dare kill Smerdyakov now, life is not worth\r\nliving!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvan did not go home, but went straight to Katerina Ivanovna and\r\nalarmed her by his appearance. He was like a madman. He repeated all\r\nhis conversation with Smerdyakov, every syllable of it. He couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\ncalmed, however much she tried to soothe him: he kept walking about the\r\nroom, speaking strangely, disconnectedly. At last he sat down, put his\r\nelbows on the table, leaned his head on his hands and pronounced this\r\nstrange sentence: \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s not Dmitri, but Smerdyakov who\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmurderer, I share his guilt, for I put him up to it. Whether I did, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know yet. But if he is the murderer, and not Dmitri, then, of\r\ncourse, I am the murderer, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Katerina Ivanovna heard that, she got up from her seat without a\r\nword, went to her writing\xe2\x80\x90table, opened a box standing on it, took out\r\na sheet of paper and laid it before Ivan. This was the document of\r\nwhich Ivan spoke to Alyosha later on as a \xe2\x80\x9cconclusive proof\xe2\x80\x9d that\r\nDmitri had killed his father. It was the letter written by Mitya to\r\nKaterina Ivanovna when he was drunk, on the very evening he met Alyosha\r\nat the crossroads on the way to the monastery, after the scene at\r\nKaterina Ivanovna\xe2\x80\x99s, when Grushenka had insulted her. Then, parting\r\nfrom Alyosha, Mitya had rushed to Grushenka. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether he\r\nsaw her, but in the evening he was at the \xe2\x80\x9cMetropolis,\xe2\x80\x9d where he got\r\nthoroughly drunk. Then he asked for pen and paper and wrote a document\r\nof weighty consequences to himself. It was a wordy, disconnected,\r\nfrantic letter, a drunken letter in fact. It was like the talk of a\r\ndrunken man, who, on his return home, begins with extraordinary heat\r\ntelling his wife or one of his household how he has just been insulted,\r\nwhat a rascal had just insulted him, what a fine fellow he is on the\r\nother hand, and how he will pay that scoundrel out; and all that at\r\ngreat length, with great excitement and incoherence, with drunken tears\r\nand blows on the table. The letter was written on a dirty piece of\r\nordinary paper of the cheapest kind. It had been provided by the tavern\r\nand there were figures scrawled on the back of it. There was evidently\r\nnot space enough for his drunken verbosity and Mitya not only filled\r\nthe margins but had written the last line right across the rest. The\r\nletter ran as follows:\r\n\r\nFATAL KATYA: To\xe2\x80\x90morrow I will get the money and repay your three\r\nthousand and farewell, woman of great wrath, but farewell, too, my\r\nlove! Let us make an end! To\xe2\x80\x90morrow I shall try and get it from every\r\none, and if I can\xe2\x80\x99t borrow it, I give you my word of honor I shall go\r\nto my father and break his skull and take the money from under the\r\npillow, if only Ivan has gone. If I have to go to Siberia for it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ngive you back your three thousand. And farewell. I bow down to the\r\nground before you, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a scoundrel to you. Forgive me! No,\r\nbetter not forgive me, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be happier and so shall I! Better Siberia\r\nthan your love, for I love another woman and you got to know her too\r\nwell to\xe2\x80\x90day, so how can you forgive? I will murder the man who\xe2\x80\x99s robbed\r\nme! I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave you all and go to the East so as to see no one again.\r\nNot _her_ either, for you are not my only tormentress; she is too.\r\nFarewell!\r\n    P.S.\xe2\x80\x94I write my curse, but I adore you! I hear it in my heart. One\r\n    string is left, and it vibrates. Better tear my heart in two! I\r\n    shall kill myself, but first of all that cur. I shall tear three\r\n    thousand from him and fling it to you. Though I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a scoundrel\r\n    to you, I am not a thief! You can expect three thousand. The cur\r\n    keeps it under his mattress, in pink ribbon. I am not a thief, but\r\n    I\xe2\x80\x99ll murder my thief. Katya, don\xe2\x80\x99t look disdainful. Dmitri is not a\r\n    thief! but a murderer! He has murdered his father and ruined\r\n    himself to hold his ground, rather than endure your pride. And he\r\n    doesn\xe2\x80\x99t love you.\r\n    P.P.S.\xe2\x80\x94I kiss your feet, farewell! P.P.P.S.\xe2\x80\x94Katya, pray to God that\r\n    some one\xe2\x80\x99ll give me the money. Then I shall not be steeped in gore,\r\n    and if no one does\xe2\x80\x94I shall! Kill me!\r\n\r\n\r\nYour slave and enemy,\r\nD. KARAMAZOV.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Ivan read this \xe2\x80\x9cdocument\xe2\x80\x9d he was convinced. So then it was his\r\nbrother, not Smerdyakov. And if not Smerdyakov, then not he, Ivan. This\r\nletter at once assumed in his eyes the aspect of a logical proof. There\r\ncould be no longer the slightest doubt of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s guilt. The suspicion\r\nnever occurred to Ivan, by the way, that Mitya might have committed the\r\nmurder in conjunction with Smerdyakov, and, indeed, such a theory did\r\nnot fit in with the facts. Ivan was completely reassured. The next\r\nmorning he only thought of Smerdyakov and his gibes with contempt. A\r\nfew days later he positively wondered how he could have been so\r\nhorribly distressed at his suspicions. He resolved to dismiss him with\r\ncontempt and forget him. So passed a month. He made no further inquiry\r\nabout Smerdyakov, but twice he happened to hear that he was very ill\r\nand out of his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll end in madness,\xe2\x80\x9d the young doctor Varvinsky observed about him,\r\nand Ivan remembered this. During the last week of that month Ivan\r\nhimself began to feel very ill. He went to consult the Moscow doctor\r\nwho had been sent for by Katerina Ivanovna just before the trial. And\r\njust at that time his relations with Katerina Ivanovna became acutely\r\nstrained. They were like two enemies in love with one another. Katerina\r\nIvanovna\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9creturns\xe2\x80\x9d to Mitya, that is, her brief but violent\r\nrevulsions of feeling in his favor, drove Ivan to perfect frenzy.\r\nStrange to say, until that last scene described above, when Alyosha\r\ncame from Mitya to Katerina Ivanovna, Ivan had never once, during that\r\nmonth, heard her express a doubt of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s guilt, in spite of those\r\n\xe2\x80\x9creturns\xe2\x80\x9d that were so hateful to him. It is remarkable, too, that\r\nwhile he felt that he hated Mitya more and more every day, he realized\r\nthat it was not on account of Katya\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9creturns\xe2\x80\x9d that he hated him, but\r\njust _because he was the murderer of his father_. He was conscious of\r\nthis and fully recognized it to himself.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, he went to see Mitya ten days before the trial and\r\nproposed to him a plan of escape\xe2\x80\x94a plan he had obviously thought over a\r\nlong time. He was partly impelled to do this by a sore place still left\r\nin his heart from a phrase of Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s, that it was to his, Ivan\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nadvantage that his brother should be convicted, as that would increase\r\nhis inheritance and Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s from forty to sixty thousand roubles. He\r\ndetermined to sacrifice thirty thousand on arranging Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s escape. On\r\nhis return from seeing him, he was very mournful and dispirited; he\r\nsuddenly began to feel that he was anxious for Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s escape, not only\r\nto heal that sore place by sacrificing thirty thousand, but for another\r\nreason. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it because I am as much a murderer at heart?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked\r\nhimself. Something very deep down seemed burning and rankling in his\r\nsoul. His pride above all suffered cruelly all that month. But of that\r\nlater....\r\n\r\nWhen, after his conversation with Alyosha, Ivan suddenly decided with\r\nhis hand on the bell of his lodging to go to Smerdyakov, he obeyed a\r\nsudden and peculiar impulse of indignation. He suddenly remembered how\r\nKaterina Ivanovna had only just cried out to him in Alyosha\xe2\x80\x99s presence:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was you, you, persuaded me of his\xe2\x80\x9d (that is, Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s) \xe2\x80\x9cguilt!\xe2\x80\x9d Ivan\r\nwas thunderstruck when he recalled it. He had never once tried to\r\npersuade her that Mitya was the murderer; on the contrary, he had\r\nsuspected himself in her presence, that time when he came back from\r\nSmerdyakov. It was _she_, she, who had produced that \xe2\x80\x9cdocument\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nproved his brother\xe2\x80\x99s guilt. And now she suddenly exclaimed: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nat Smerdyakov\xe2\x80\x99s myself!\xe2\x80\x9d When had she been there? Ivan had known\r\nnothing of it. So she was not at all so sure of Mitya\xe2\x80\x99s guilt! And what\r\ncould Smerdyakov have told her? What, what, had he said to her? His\r\nheart burned with violent anger. He could not understand how he could,\r\nhalf an hour before, have let those words pass and not have cried out\r\nat the moment. He let go of the bell and rushed off to Smerdyakov. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshall kill him, perhaps, this time,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought on the way.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.\r\nThe Third And Last Interview With Smerdyakov\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen he was half\xe2\x80\x90way there, the keen dry wind that had been blowing\r\nearly that morning rose again, and a fine dry snow began falling\r\nthickly. It did not lie on the ground, but was whirled about by the\r\nwind, and soon there was a regular snowstorm. There were scarcely any\r\nlamp\xe2\x80\x90posts in the part of the town where Smerdyakov lived. Ivan strode\r\nalone in the darkness, unconscious of the storm, instinctively picking\r\nout his way. His head ached and there was a painful throbbing in his\r\ntemples. He felt that his hands were twitching convulsively. Not far\r\nfrom Marya Kondratyevna\xe2\x80\x99s cottage, Ivan suddenly came upon a solitary\r\ndrunken little peasant. He was wearing a coarse and patched coat, and\r\nwas walking in zigzags, grumbling and swearing to himself. Then\r\nsuddenly he would begin singing in a husky drunken voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAch, Vanka\xe2\x80\x99s gone to Petersburg;\r\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t wait till he comes back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBut he broke off every time at the second line and began swearing\r\nagain; then he would begin the same song again. Ivan felt an intense\r\nhatred for him before he had thought about him at all. Suddenly he\r\nrealized his presence and felt an irresistible impulse to knock him\r\ndown. At that moment they met, and the peasant with a violent lurch\r\nfell full tilt against Ivan, who pushed him back furiously. The peasant\r\nwent flying backwards and fell like a log on the frozen ground. He\r\nuttered one plaintive \xe2\x80\x9cO\xe2\x80\x94oh!\xe2\x80\x9d and then was silent. Ivan stepped up to\r\nhim. One\r\nof the benches at the side had been removed, and in its place had been\r\nput a large old mahogany leather sofa, on which a bed had been made up,\r\nwith fairly clean white pillows.
