I am the cause\r\nof it all, I alone am to blame!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKatya never had made such confessions to Alyosha before, and he felt\r\nthat she was now at that stage of unbearable suffering when even the\r\nproudest heart painfully crushes its pride and falls vanquished by\r\ngrief. Oh, Alyosha knew another terrible reason of her present misery,\r\nthough she had carefully concealed it from him during those days since\r\nthe trial; but it would have been for some reason too painful to him if\r\nshe had been brought so low as to speak to him now about that. She was\r\nsuffering for her \xe2\x80\x9ctreachery\xe2\x80\x9d at the trial, and Alyosha felt that her\r\nconscience was impelling her to confess it to him, to him, Alyosha,\r\nwith tears and cries and hysterical writhings on the floor. But he\r\ndreaded that moment and longed to spare her. It made the commission on\r\nwhich he had come even more difficult. He spoke of Mitya again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all right, it\xe2\x80\x99s all right, don\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious about him!\xe2\x80\x9d she began\r\nagain, sharply and stubbornly. \xe2\x80\x9cAll that is only momentary, I know him,\r\nI know his heart only too well. You may be sure he will consent to\r\nescape. It\xe2\x80\x99s not as though it would be immediately; he will have time\r\nto make up his mind to it. Ivan Fyodorovitch will be well by that time\r\nand will manage it all himself, so that I shall have nothing to do with\r\nit. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious; he will consent to run away. He has agreed\r\nalready: do you suppose he would give up that creature? And they won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlet her go to him, so he is bound to escape. It\xe2\x80\x99s you he\xe2\x80\x99s most afraid\r\nof, he is afraid you won\xe2\x80\x99t approve of his escape on moral grounds. But\r\nyou must generously _allow_ it, if your sanction is so necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nKatya added viciously. She paused and smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe talks about some hymn,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on again, \xe2\x80\x9csome cross he has to\r\nbear, some duty; I remember Ivan Fyodorovitch told me a great deal\r\nabout it, and if you knew how he talked!\xe2\x80\x9d Katya cried suddenly, with\r\nfeeling she could not repress, \xe2\x80\x9cif you knew how he loved that wretched\r\nman at the moment he told me, and how he hated him, perhaps, at the\r\nsame moment. And I heard his story and his tears with sneering disdain.\r\nBrute! Yes, I am a brute. I am responsible for his fever. But that man\r\nin prison is incapable of suffering,\xe2\x80\x9d Katya concluded irritably. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\r\nsuch a man suffer? Men like him never suffer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a note of hatred and contemptuous repulsion in her words. And\r\nyet it was she who had betrayed him. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps because she feels how\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s wronged him she hates him at moments,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha thought to\r\nhimself. He hoped that it was only \xe2\x80\x9cat moments.\xe2\x80\x9d In Katya\xe2\x80\x99s last words\r\nhe detected a challenging note, but he did not take it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sent for you this morning to make you promise to persuade him\r\nyourself. She started, and drew back a little from him on the sofa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe? Can that be?\xe2\x80\x9d she faltered, turning pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt can and ought to be!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha began emphatically, growing more\r\nanimated. \xe2\x80\x9cHe needs you particularly just now. It is not to be reconciled\r\nwith you that he wants you, but only that you would go and show\r\nyourself at his door. So much has happened to him since that day. He\r\nrealizes that he has injured you beyond all reckoning. He does not ask\r\nyour forgiveness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to forgive me,\xe2\x80\x99 he says himself\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nonly that you would show yourself in his doorway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so sudden....\xe2\x80\x9d faltered Katya. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had a presentiment all these\r\ndays that you would come with that message. He said, \xe2\x80\x98If she refuses to come I shall be\r\nunhappy all my life.\xe2\x80\x99 Do you hear? though he is condemned to penal\r\nservitude for twenty years, he is still planning to be happy\xe2\x80\x94is not\r\nthat piteous? You ought to do it, you\r\nought to!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha concluded, laying immense stress on the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought to ... but I cannot....\xe2\x80\x9d Katya moaned. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will look at me....\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour eyes ought to meet. I can\xe2\x80\x99t leave our patient\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can for a moment. It will only be a moment. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know yet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer voice failed her. She gasped for breath. Alyosha got up to go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what if I meet any one?\xe2\x80\x9d she said suddenly, in a low voice,\r\nturning white again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just why you must go now, to avoid meeting any one. There will\r\nbe no one there, I can tell you that for certain. We will expect you,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe concluded emphatically, and went out of the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II.\r\nFor A Moment The Lie Becomes Truth\r\n\r\n\r\nHe hurried to the hospital where Mitya was lying now. The day after his\r\nfate was determined, Mitya had fallen ill with nervous fever, and was\r\nsent to the prison division of the town hospital. But at the request of\r\nseveral persons (Alyosha, Madame Hohlakov, Lise, etc.), Doctor\r\nVarvinsky had put Mitya not with other prisoners, but in a separate\r\nlittle room, the one where Smerdyakov had been. It is true that there\r\nwas a sentinel at the other end of the corridor, and there was a\r\ngrating over the window, so that Varvinsky could be at ease about the\r\nindulgence he had shown, which was not quite legal, indeed; but he was\r\na kind\xe2\x80\x90hearted and compassionate young man. He knew how hard it would\r\nbe for a man like Mitya to pass at once so suddenly into the society of\r\nrobbers and murderers, and that he must get used to it by degrees. The\r\nvisits of relations and friends were informally sanctioned by the\r\ndoctor and overseer, and even by the police captain. But only Alyosha\r\nand Grushenka had visited Mitya. Rakitin had tried to force his way in\r\ntwice, but Mitya persistently begged Varvinsky not to admit him.\r\n\r\nAlyosha found him sitting on his bed in a hospital dressing\xe2\x80\x90gown,\r\nrather feverish, with a towel, soaked in vinegar and water, on his\r\nhead. He looked at Alyosha as he came in with an undefined expression,\r\nbut there was a shade of something like dread discernible in it. He had\r\nbecome terribly preoccupied since the trial; sometimes he would be\r\nsilent for half an hour together, and seemed to be pondering something\r\nheavily and painfully, oblivious of everything about him. If he roused\r\nhimself from his brooding and began to talk, he always spoke with a\r\nkind of abruptness and never of what he really wanted to say. He looked\r\nsometimes with a face of suffering at his brother. He seemed to be more\r\nat ease with Grushenka than with Alyosha. It is true, he scarcely spoke\r\nto her at all, but as soon as she came in, his whole face lighted up\r\nwith joy.\r\n\r\nAlyosha sat down beside him on the bed in silence. This time Mitya was\r\nwaiting for Alyosha in suspense, but he did not dare ask him a\r\nquestion. He felt it almost unthinkable that Katya would consent to\r\ncome, and at the same time he felt that if she did not come, something\r\ninconceivable would happen. Alyosha understood his feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrifon Borissovitch,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya began nervously, \xe2\x80\x9chas pulled his whole inn\r\nto pieces, I am told. He\xe2\x80\x99s taken up the flooring, pulled apart the\r\nplanks, split up all the gallery, I am told. He is seeking treasure all\r\nthe time\xe2\x80\x94the fifteen hundred roubles which the prosecutor said I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhidden there. He began playing these tricks, they say, as soon as he\r\ngot home. Serve him right, the swindler! The guard here told me\r\nyesterday; he comes from there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d began Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cShe will come, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know when. Perhaps\r\nto\xe2\x80\x90day, perhaps in a few days, that I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell. But she will come,\r\nshe will, that\xe2\x80\x99s certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMitya started, would have said something, but was silent. The news had\r\na tremendous effect on him. It was evident that he would have liked\r\nterribly to know what had been said, but he was again afraid to ask.\r\nSomething cruel and contemptuous from Katya would have cut him like a\r\nknife at that moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was what she said among other things; that I must be sure to set\r\nyour conscience at rest about escaping. If Ivan is not well by then she\r\nwill see to it all herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve spoken of that already,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya observed musingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have repeated it to Grusha,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya admitted. \xe2\x80\x9cShe won\xe2\x80\x99t come this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d He looked timidly\r\nat his brother. \xe2\x80\x9cShe won\xe2\x80\x99t come till the evening. When I told her\r\nyesterday that Katya was taking measures, she was silent, but she set\r\nher mouth. She only whispered, \xe2\x80\x98Let her!\xe2\x80\x99 She understood that it was\r\nimportant. I did not dare to try her further. She understands now, I\r\nthink, that Katya no longer cares for me, but loves Ivan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes she?\xe2\x80\x9d broke from Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps she does not. Only she is not coming this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya\r\nhastened to explain again; \xe2\x80\x9cI asked her to do something for me. You\r\nknow, Ivan is superior to all of us. He ought to live, not us. He will\r\nrecover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you believe it, though Katya is alarmed about him, she scarcely\r\ndoubts of his recovery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat means that she is convinced he will die. It\xe2\x80\x99s because she is\r\nfrightened she\xe2\x80\x99s so sure he will get well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIvan has a strong constitution, and I, too, believe there\xe2\x80\x99s every hope\r\nthat he will get well,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha observed anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he will get well. A grave anxiety\r\nwas fretting Mitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha, I love Grusha terribly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly in a shaking voice,\r\nfull of tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey won\xe2\x80\x99t let her go out there to you,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha put in at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is something else I wanted to tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya went on, with\r\na sudden ring in his voice. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they beat me on the way or out there, I\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t submit to it. I shall kill some one, and shall be shot for it.\r\nAnd this will be going on for twenty years! They speak to me rudely as\r\nit is. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been lying here all night, passing judgment on myself. I am\r\nnot ready! I am not able to resign myself. I wanted to sing a \xe2\x80\x98hymn\xe2\x80\x99;\r\nbut if a guard speaks rudely to me, I have not the strength to bear it.\r\nFor Grusha I would bear anything ... anything except blows.... What\xe2\x80\x99s more, you don\xe2\x80\x99t need\r\nsuch a martyr\xe2\x80\x99s cross when you are not ready for it. If you had\r\nmurdered our father, it would grieve me that you should reject your\r\npunishment. But you are innocent, and such a cross is too much for you.\r\nYou wanted to make yourself another man by suffering. I say, only\r\nremember that other man always, all your life and wherever you go; and\r\nthat will be enough for you. Your refusal of that great cross will only\r\nserve to make you feel all your life an even greater duty, and that\r\nconstant feeling will do more to make you a new man, perhaps, than if\r\nyou went there. For there you would not endure it and would repine, and\r\nperhaps at last would say: \xe2\x80\x98I am quits.\xe2\x80\x99 The lawyer was right about\r\nthat. Such heavy burdens are not for all men. For some they are\r\nimpossible. These are my thoughts about it, if you want them so much.\r\nIf other men would have to answer for your escape, officers or\r\nsoldiers, then I would not have \xe2\x80\x98allowed\xe2\x80\x99 you,\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\nthey declare\xe2\x80\x94the superintendent of that _\xc3\xa9tape_ told Ivan himself\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nif it\xe2\x80\x99s well managed there will be no great inquiry, and that they can\r\nget off easily. Of course, bribing is dishonest even in such a case,\r\nbut I can\xe2\x80\x99t undertake to judge about it, because if Ivan and Katya\r\ncommissioned me to act for you, I know I should go and give bribes. I\r\nmust tell you the truth. And so I can\xe2\x80\x99t judge of your own action. But\r\nlet me assure you that I shall never condemn you. And it would be a\r\nstrange thing if I could judge you in this. Now I think I\xe2\x80\x99ve gone into\r\neverything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do condemn myself!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall escape, that was\r\nsettled apart from you; could Mitya Karamazov do anything but run away?\r\nBut I shall condemn myself, and I will pray for my sin for ever. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhow the Jesuits talk, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Just as we are doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha smiled gently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love you for always telling the whole truth and never hiding\r\nanything,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, with a joyful laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cSo I\xe2\x80\x99ve caught my Alyosha\r\nbeing Jesuitical. I must kiss you for that. Now listen to the rest;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll open the other side of my heart to you. This is what I planned and\r\ndecided. If I run away, even with money and a passport, and even to\r\nAmerica, I should be cheered up by the thought that I am not running\r\naway for pleasure, not for happiness, but to another exile as bad,\r\nperhaps, as Siberia. It is as bad, Alyosha, it is! I hate that America,\r\ndamn it, already. Even though Grusha will be with me. Just look at her;\r\nis she an American? She is Russian, Russian to the marrow of her bones;\r\nshe will be homesick for the mother country, and I shall see every hour\r\nthat she is suffering for my sake, that she has taken up that cross for\r\nme. And what harm has she done? And how shall I, too, put up with the\r\nrabble out there, though they may be better than I, every one of them?\r\nI hate that America already! And though they may be wonderful at\r\nmachinery, every one of them, damn them, they are not of my soul. I\r\nlove Russia, Alyosha, I love the Russian God, though I am a scoundrel\r\nmyself. I shall choke there!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, his eyes suddenly flashing.\r\nHis voice was trembling with tears. \xe2\x80\x9cSo this is what I\xe2\x80\x99ve decided,\r\nAlyosha, listen,\xe2\x80\x9d he began again, mastering his emotion. \xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as I\r\narrive there with Grusha, we will set to work at once on the land, in\r\nsolitude, somewhere very remote, with wild bears. There must be some\r\nremote parts even there. I am told there are still Redskins there,\r\nsomewhere, on the edge of the horizon. So to the country of the _Last\r\nof the Mohicans_, and there we\xe2\x80\x99ll tackle the grammar at once, Grusha\r\nand I. Work and grammar\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s how we\xe2\x80\x99ll spend three years. And by that\r\ntime we shall speak English like any Englishman. I shall\r\nbe changed by that time, and she will, too, in America. The doctors\r\nshall make me some sort of wart on my face\xe2\x80\x94what\xe2\x80\x99s the use of their\r\nbeing so mechanical!\xe2\x80\x94or else I\xe2\x80\x99ll put out one eye, let my beard grow a\r\nyard, and I shall turn gray, fretting for Russia. We\xe2\x80\x99ll work on the land here, too,\r\nsomewhere in the wilds, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll make up as an American all my life.\r\nBut we shall die on our own soil. That\xe2\x80\x99s my plan, and it shan\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\naltered. Do you approve?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, not wanting to contradict him. Mitya paused for a\r\nminute and said suddenly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how they worked it up at the trial! Didn\xe2\x80\x99t they work it up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they had not, you would have been convicted just the same,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAlyosha, with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, people are sick of me here! It\xe2\x80\x99s hard for her, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha looked timidly at his\r\nbrother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think it is hard for her! Alyosha, it will drive me out of my\r\nmind. So passed two\r\nminutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you forgiven me?\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya faltered at last, and at the same moment\r\nturning to Alyosha, his face working with joy, he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear\r\nwhat I am asking, do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I loved you for, that you are generous at heart!\xe2\x80\x9d broke\r\nfrom Katya. \xe2\x80\x9cMy forgiveness is no good to you, nor yours to me; whether\r\nyou forgive me or not, you will always be a sore place in my heart, and\r\nI in yours\xe2\x80\x94so it must be....\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped to take breath. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I\r\ncome for?\xe2\x80\x9d she began again with nervous haste: \xe2\x80\x9cto embrace your feet,\r\nto press your hands like this, till it hurts\xe2\x80\x94you remember how in Moscow\r\nI used to squeeze them\xe2\x80\x94to tell you again that you are my god, my joy,\r\nto tell you that I love you madly,\xe2\x80\x9d she moaned in anguish, and suddenly\r\npressed his hand greedily to her lips. Tears streamed from her eyes.\r\nAlyosha stood speechless and confounded; he had never expected what he\r\nwas seeing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove is over, Mitya!\xe2\x80\x9d Katya began again, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the past is painfully\r\ndear to me. Know that you will always be so. But now let what might\r\nhave been come true for one minute,\xe2\x80\x9d she faltered, with a drawn smile,\r\nlooking into his face joyfully again. \xe2\x80\x9cYou love another woman, and I\r\nlove another man, and yet I shall love you for ever, and you will love\r\nme; do you know that? Do you hear? Love me, love me all your life!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\ncried, with a quiver almost of menace in her voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall love you, and ... do you know, Katya,\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya began, drawing a\r\ndeep breath at each word, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know, five days ago, that same\r\nevening, I loved you.... When you fell down and were carried out ...\r\nAll my life! So it will be, so it will always be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo they murmured to one another frantic words, almost meaningless,\r\nperhaps not even true, but at that moment it was all true, and they\r\nboth believed what they said implicitly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKatya,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you believe I murdered him? I know\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it now, but then ... when you gave evidence....\r\nSurely, surely you did not believe it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not believe it even then. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never believed it. I hated you,\r\nand for a moment I persuaded myself. While I was giving evidence I\r\npersuaded myself and believed it, but when I\xe2\x80\x99d finished speaking I left\r\noff believing it at once. Don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt that! I have forgotten that I\r\ncame here to punish myself,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a new expression in her\r\nvoice, quite unlike the loving tones of a moment before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman, yours is a heavy burden,\xe2\x80\x9d broke, as it were, involuntarily from\r\nMitya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go,\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come again. It\xe2\x80\x99s more than I can bear\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was getting up from her place, but suddenly uttered a loud scream\r\nand staggered back. Grushenka walked suddenly and noiselessly into the\r\nroom. No one had expected her. Katya moved swiftly to the door, but\r\nwhen she reached Grushenka, she stopped suddenly, turned as white as\r\nchalk and moaned softly, almost in a whisper:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrushenka stared at her and, pausing for an instant, in a vindictive,\r\nvenomous voice, answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are full of hatred, my girl, you and I! We are both full of hatred!\r\nAs though we could forgive one another! Save him, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll worship you\r\nall my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t forgive her!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mitya, with frantic reproach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be anxious, I\xe2\x80\x99ll save him for you!\xe2\x80\x9d Katya whispered rapidly, and\r\nshe ran out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you could refuse to forgive her when she begged your forgiveness\r\nherself?\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya exclaimed bitterly again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMitya, don\xe2\x80\x99t dare to blame her; you have no right to!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha cried\r\nhotly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer proud lips spoke, not her heart,\xe2\x80\x9d Grushenka brought out in a tone\r\nof disgust. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she saves you I\xe2\x80\x99ll forgive her everything\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped speaking, as though suppressing something. She could not\r\nyet recover herself. She had come in, as appeared afterwards,\r\naccidentally, with no suspicion of what she would meet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlyosha, run after her!\xe2\x80\x9d Mitya cried to his brother; \xe2\x80\x9ctell her ... I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know ... don\xe2\x80\x99t let her go away like this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come to you again at nightfall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, and he ran after\r\nKatya. He overtook her outside the hospital grounds. She was walking\r\nfast, but as soon as Alyosha caught her up she said quickly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, before that woman I can\xe2\x80\x99t punish myself! I asked her forgiveness\r\nbecause I wanted to punish myself to the bitter end. She would not\r\nforgive me.... I like her for that!\xe2\x80\x9d she added, in an unnatural voice,\r\nand her eyes flashed with fierce resentment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother did not expect this in the least,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nwas sure she would not come\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt. Let us leave that,\xe2\x80\x9d she snapped. \xe2\x80\x9cListen: I can\xe2\x80\x99t go with\r\nyou to the funeral now. I\xe2\x80\x99ve sent them flowers. I think they still have\r\nmoney. If necessary, tell them I\xe2\x80\x99ll never abandon them.... Now leave\r\nme, leave me, please. You are late as it is\xe2\x80\x94the bells are ringing for\r\nthe service.... Leave me, please!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III.\r\nIlusha\xe2\x80\x99s Funeral. The Speech At The Stone\r\n\r\n\r\nHe really was late. They had waited for him and had already decided to\r\nbear the pretty flower\xe2\x80\x90decked little coffin to the church without him.\r\nIt was the coffin of poor little Ilusha. He had died two days after\r\nMitya was sentenced. At the gate of the house Alyosha was met by the\r\nshouts of the boys, Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s schoolfellows. They had all been\r\nimpatiently expecting him and were glad that he had come at last. There\r\nwere about twelve of them, they all had their school\xe2\x80\x90bags or satchels\r\non their shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cFather will cry, be with father,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilusha had told\r\nthem as he lay dying, and the boys remembered it. Kolya Krassotkin was\r\nthe foremost of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow glad I am you\xe2\x80\x99ve come, Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, holding out his hand\r\nto Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s awful here. It\xe2\x80\x99s really horrible to see it. Snegiryov\r\nis not drunk, we know for a fact he\xe2\x80\x99s had nothing to drink to\xe2\x80\x90day, but\r\nhe seems as if he were drunk ... I am always manly, but this is awful.\r\nKaramazov, if I am not keeping you, one question before you go in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Kolya?\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your brother innocent or guilty? Was it he killed your father or\r\nwas it the valet? As you say, so it will be. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t slept for the\r\nlast four nights for thinking of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe valet killed him, my brother is innocent,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I said,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Smurov.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo he will perish an innocent victim!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Kolya; \xe2\x80\x9cthough he is\r\nruined he is happy! I could envy him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? How can you? Why?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alyosha surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if I, too, could sacrifice myself some day for truth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kolya\r\nwith enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not in such a cause, not with such disgrace and such horror!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAlyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course ... I should like to die for all humanity, and as for\r\ndisgrace, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care about that\xe2\x80\x94our names may perish. I respect your\r\nbrother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so do I!\xe2\x80\x9d the boy, who had once declared that he knew who had\r\nfounded Troy, cried suddenly and unexpectedly, and he blushed up to his\r\nears like a peony as he had done on that occasion.\r\n\r\nAlyosha went into the room. Ilusha lay with his hands folded and his\r\neyes closed in a blue coffin with a white frill round it. His thin face\r\nwas hardly changed at all, and strange to say there was no smell of\r\ndecay from the corpse. The expression of his face was serious and, as\r\nit were, thoughtful. His hands, crossed over his breast, looked\r\nparticularly beautiful, as though chiseled in marble. There were\r\nflowers in his hands and the coffin, inside and out, was decked with\r\nflowers, which had been sent early in the morning by Lise Hohlakov. But\r\nthere were flowers too from Katerina Ivanovna, and when Alyosha opened\r\nthe door, the captain had a bunch in his trembling hands and was\r\nstrewing them again over his dear boy. He scarcely glanced at Alyosha\r\nwhen he came in, and he would not look at any one, even at his crazy\r\nweeping wife, \xe2\x80\x9cmamma,\xe2\x80\x9d who kept trying to stand on her crippled legs to\r\nget a nearer look at her dead boy. Nina had been pushed in her chair by\r\nthe boys close up to the coffin. She sat with her head pressed to it\r\nand she too was no doubt quietly weeping. Snegiryov\xe2\x80\x99s face looked\r\neager, yet bewildered and exasperated. There was something crazy about\r\nhis gestures and the words that broke from him. \xe2\x80\x9cOld man, dear old\r\nman!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed every minute, gazing at Ilusha. It was his habit to\r\ncall Ilusha \xe2\x80\x9cold man,\xe2\x80\x9d as a term of affection when he was alive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, give me a flower, too; take that white one out of his hand and\r\ngive it me,\xe2\x80\x9d the crazy mother begged, whimpering. Either because the\r\nlittle white rose in Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s hand had caught her fancy or that she\r\nwanted one from his hand to keep in memory of him, she moved\r\nrestlessly, stretching out her hands for the flower.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t give it to any one, I won\xe2\x80\x99t give you anything,\xe2\x80\x9d Snegiryov\r\ncried callously. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are his flowers, not yours! Everything is his,\r\nnothing is yours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, give mother a flower!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nina, lifting her face wet with\r\ntears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t give away anything and to her less than any one! She didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlove Ilusha. She took away his little cannon and he gave it to her,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe captain broke into loud sobs at the thought of how Ilusha had given\r\nup his cannon to his mother. The poor, crazy creature was bathed in\r\nnoiseless tears, hiding her face in her hands.\r\n\r\nThe boys, seeing that the father would not leave the coffin and that it\r\nwas time to carry it out, stood round it in a close circle and began to\r\nlift it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want him to be buried in the churchyard,\xe2\x80\x9d Snegiryov wailed\r\nsuddenly; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bury him by the stone, by our stone! Ilusha told me to.\r\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t let him be carried out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had been saying for the last three days that he would bury him by\r\nthe stone, but Alyosha, Krassotkin, the landlady, her sister and all\r\nthe boys interfered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an idea, bury him by an unholy stone, as though he had hanged\r\nhimself!\xe2\x80\x9d the old landlady said sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cThere in the churchyard the\r\nground has been crossed. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be prayed for there. One can hear the\r\nsinging in church and the deacon reads so plainly and verbally that it\r\nwill reach him every time just as though it were read over his grave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt last the captain made a gesture of despair as though to say, \xe2\x80\x9cTake\r\nhim where you will.\xe2\x80\x9d The boys raised the coffin, but as they passed the\r\nmother, they stopped for a moment and lowered it that she might say\r\ngood\xe2\x80\x90 by to Ilusha. But on seeing that precious little face, which for\r\nthe last three days she had only looked at from a distance, she\r\ntrembled all over and her gray head began twitching spasmodically over\r\nthe coffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, make the sign of the cross over him, give him your blessing,\r\nkiss him,\xe2\x80\x9d Nina cried to her. But her head still twitched like an\r\nautomaton and with a face contorted with bitter grief she began,\r\nwithout a word, beating her breast with her fist. They carried the\r\ncoffin past her. Nina pressed her lips to her brother\xe2\x80\x99s for the last\r\ntime as they bore the coffin by her. As Alyosha went out of the house\r\nhe begged the landlady to look after those who were left behind, but\r\nshe interrupted him before he had finished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay with them, we are Christians, too.\xe2\x80\x9d The old\r\nwoman wept as she said it.\r\n\r\nThey had not far to carry the coffin to the church, not more than three\r\nhundred paces. It was a still, clear day, with a slight frost. The\r\nchurch bells were still ringing. Snegiryov ran fussing and distracted\r\nafter the coffin, in his short old summer overcoat, with his head bare\r\nand his soft, old, wide\xe2\x80\x90brimmed hat in his hand. He seemed in a state\r\nof bewildered anxiety. At one minute he stretched out his hand to\r\nsupport the head of the coffin and only hindered the bearers, at\r\nanother he ran alongside and tried to find a place for himself there. A\r\nflower fell on the snow and he rushed to pick it up as though\r\neverything in the world depended on the loss of that flower.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the crust of bread, we\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten the crust!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried suddenly\r\nin dismay. But the boys reminded him at once that he had taken the\r\ncrust of bread already and that it was in his pocket. He instantly\r\npulled it out and was reassured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIlusha told me to, Ilusha,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained at once to Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cI was\r\nsitting by him one night and he suddenly told me: \xe2\x80\x98Father, when my\r\ngrave is filled up crumble a piece of bread on it so that the sparrows\r\nmay fly down, I shall hear and it will cheer me up not to be lying\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must often take some.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery day, every day!\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain quickly, seeming cheered at\r\nthe thought.\r\n\r\nThey reached the church at last and set the coffin in the middle of it.\r\nThe boys surrounded it and remained reverently standing so, all through\r\nthe service. It was an old and rather poor church; many of the ikons\r\nwere without settings; but such churches are the best for praying in.\r\nDuring the mass Snegiryov became somewhat calmer, though at times he\r\nhad outbursts of the same unconscious and, as it were, incoherent\r\nanxiety. At one moment he went up to the coffin to set straight the\r\ncover or the wreath, when a candle fell out of the candlestick he\r\nrushed to replace it and was a fearful time fumbling over it, then he\r\nsubsided and stood quietly by the coffin with a look of blank\r\nuneasiness and perplexity. After the Epistle he suddenly whispered to\r\nAlyosha, who was standing beside him, that the Epistle had not been\r\nread properly but did not explain what he meant. During the prayer,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike the Cherubim,\xe2\x80\x9d he joined in the singing but did not go on to the\r\nend. Falling on his knees, he pressed his forehead to the stone floor\r\nand lay so for a long while.\r\n\r\nAt last came the funeral service itself and candles were distributed.\r\nThe distracted father began fussing about again, but the touching and\r\nimpressive funeral prayers moved and roused his soul. He seemed\r\nsuddenly to shrink together and broke into rapid, short sobs, which he\r\ntried at first to smother, but at last he sobbed aloud. When they began\r\ntaking leave of the dead and closing the coffin, he flung his arms\r\nabout, as though he would not allow them to cover Ilusha, and began\r\ngreedily and persistently kissing his dead boy on the lips. At last\r\nthey succeeded in persuading him to come away from the step, but\r\nsuddenly he impulsively stretched out his hand and snatched a few\r\nflowers from the coffin. He looked at them and a new idea seemed to\r\ndawn upon him, so that he apparently forgot his grief for a minute.\r\nGradually he seemed to sink into brooding and did not resist when the\r\ncoffin was lifted up and carried to the grave. It was an expensive one\r\nin the churchyard close to the church, Katerina Ivanovna had paid for\r\nit. After the customary rites the grave\xe2\x80\x90 diggers lowered the coffin.\r\nSnegiryov with his flowers in his hands bent down so low over the open\r\ngrave that the boys caught hold of his coat in alarm and pulled him\r\nback. He did not seem to understand fully what was happening. When they\r\nbegan filling up the grave, he suddenly pointed anxiously at the\r\nfalling earth and began trying to say something, but no one could make\r\nout what he meant, and he stopped suddenly. Then he was reminded that\r\nhe must crumble the bread and he was awfully excited, snatched up the\r\nbread and began pulling it to pieces and flinging the morsels on the\r\ngrave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, fly down, birds, fly down, sparrows!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered anxiously.\r\n\r\nOne of the boys observed that it was awkward for him to crumble the\r\nbread with the flowers in his hands and suggested he should give them\r\nto some one to hold for a time. But he would not do this and seemed\r\nindeed suddenly alarmed for his flowers, as though they wanted to take\r\nthem from him altogether. And after looking at the grave, and as it\r\nwere, satisfying himself that everything had been done and the bread\r\nhad been crumbled, he suddenly, to the surprise of every one, turned,\r\nquite composedly even, and made his way homewards. But his steps became\r\nmore and more hurried, he almost ran. The boys and Alyosha kept up with\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe flowers are for mamma, the flowers are for mamma! I was unkind to\r\nmamma,\xe2\x80\x9d he began exclaiming suddenly.\r\n\r\nSome one called to him to put on his hat as it was cold. But he flung\r\nthe hat in the snow as though he were angry and kept repeating, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t have the hat, I won\xe2\x80\x99t have the hat.\xe2\x80\x9d Smurov picked it up and\r\ncarried it after him. All the boys were crying, and Kolya and the boy\r\nwho discovered about Troy most of all. Though Smurov, with the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s hat in his hand, was crying bitterly too, he managed, as he\r\nran, to snatch up a piece of red brick that lay on the snow of the\r\npath, to fling it at the flock of sparrows that was flying by. He\r\nmissed them, of course, and went on crying as he ran. Half\xe2\x80\x90way,\r\nSnegiryov suddenly stopped, stood still for half a minute, as though\r\nstruck by something, and suddenly turning back to the church, ran\r\ntowards the deserted grave. But the boys instantly overtook him and\r\ncaught hold of him on all sides. Then he fell helpless on the snow as\r\nthough he had been knocked down, and struggling, sobbing, and wailing,\r\nhe began crying out, \xe2\x80\x9cIlusha, old man, dear old man!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha and Kolya\r\ntried to make him get up, soothing and persuading him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, give over, a brave man must show fortitude,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Kolya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll spoil the flowers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha, \xe2\x80\x9cand mamma is expecting them,\r\nshe is sitting crying because you would not give her any before.\r\nIlusha\xe2\x80\x99s little bed is still there\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, mamma!\xe2\x80\x9d Snegiryov suddenly recollected, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99ll take away\r\nthe bed, they\xe2\x80\x99ll take it away,\xe2\x80\x9d he added as though alarmed that they\r\nreally would. He jumped up and ran homewards again. But it was not far\r\noff and they all arrived together. Snegiryov opened the door hurriedly\r\nand called to his wife with whom he had so cruelly quarreled just\r\nbefore:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, poor crippled darling, Ilusha has sent you these flowers,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncried, holding out to her a little bunch of flowers that had been\r\nfrozen and broken while he was struggling in the snow. But at that\r\ninstant he saw in the corner, by the little bed, Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s little boots,\r\nwhich the landlady had put tidily side by side. Seeing the old,\r\npatched, rusty\xe2\x80\x90 looking, stiff boots he flung up his hands and rushed\r\nto them, fell on his knees, snatched up one boot and, pressing his lips\r\nto it, began kissing it greedily, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cIlusha, old man, dear old\r\nman, where are your little feet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere have you taken him away? Where have you taken him?\xe2\x80\x9d the lunatic\r\ncried in a heartrending voice. Nina, too, broke into sobs. Kolya ran\r\nout of the room, the boys followed him. At last Alyosha too went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them weep,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Kolya, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s no use trying to comfort them\r\njust now. Let us wait a minute and then go back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s no use, it\xe2\x80\x99s awful,\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya assented. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\r\nKaramazov,\xe2\x80\x9d he dropped his voice so that no one could hear them, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nfeel dreadfully sad, and if it were only possible to bring him back,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d give anything in the world to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, so would I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think, Karamazov? Had we better come back here to\xe2\x80\x90night?\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be drunk, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he will. Let us come together, you and I, that will be enough,\r\nto spend an hour with them, with the mother and Nina. If we all come\r\ntogether we shall remind them of everything again,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha suggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe landlady is laying the table for them now\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99ll be a funeral\r\ndinner or something, the priest is coming; shall we go back to it,\r\nKaramazov?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alyosha.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all so strange, Karamazov, such sorrow and then pancakes after\r\nit, it all seems so unnatural in our religion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are going to have salmon, too,\xe2\x80\x9d the boy who had discovered about\r\nTroy observed in a loud voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you most earnestly, Kartashov, not to interrupt again with your\r\nidiotic remarks, especially when one is not talking to you and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare to know whether you exist or not!\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya snapped out irritably.\r\nThe boy flushed crimson but did not dare to reply.\r\n\r\nMeantime they were strolling slowly along the path and suddenly Smurov\r\nexclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s stone, under which they wanted to bury him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey all stood still by the big stone. Alyosha looked and the whole\r\npicture of what Snegiryov had described to him that day, how Ilusha,\r\nweeping and hugging his father, had cried, \xe2\x80\x9cFather, father, how he\r\ninsulted you,\xe2\x80\x9d rose at once before his imagination.\r\n\r\nA sudden impulse seemed to come into his soul. With a serious and\r\nearnest expression he looked from one to another of the bright,\r\npleasant faces of Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s schoolfellows, and suddenly said to them:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoys, I should like to say one word to you, here at this place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boys stood round him and at once bent attentive and expectant eyes\r\nupon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoys, we shall soon part. I shall be for some time with my two\r\nbrothers, of whom one is going to Siberia and the other is lying at\r\ndeath\xe2\x80\x99s door. But soon I shall leave this town, perhaps for a long\r\ntime, so we shall part. Let us make a compact here, at Ilusha\xe2\x80\x99s stone,\r\nthat we will never forget Ilusha and one another. And whatever happens\r\nto us later in life, if we don\xe2\x80\x99t meet for twenty years afterwards, let\r\nus always remember how we buried the poor boy at whom we once threw\r\nstones, do you remember, by the bridge? and afterwards we all grew so\r\nfond of him. He was a fine boy, a kind\xe2\x80\x90hearted, brave boy, he felt for\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s honor and resented the cruel insult to him and stood up\r\nfor him. And so in the first place, we will remember him, boys, all our\r\nlives. And even if we are occupied with most important things, if we\r\nattain to honor or fall into great misfortune\xe2\x80\x94still let us remember how\r\ngood it was once here, when we were all together, united by a good and\r\nkind feeling which made us, for the time we were loving that poor boy,\r\nbetter perhaps than we are. My little doves\xe2\x80\x94let me call you so, for you\r\nare very like them, those pretty blue birds, at this minute as I look\r\nat your good dear faces. My dear children, perhaps you won\xe2\x80\x99t understand\r\nwhat I am saying to you, because I often speak very unintelligibly, but\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll remember it all the same and will agree with my words some time.\r\nYou must know that there is nothing higher and stronger and more\r\nwholesome and good for life in the future than some good memory,\r\nespecially a memory of childhood, of home. People talk to you a great\r\ndeal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preserved from\r\nchildhood, is perhaps the best education. If a man carries many such\r\nmemories with him into life, he is safe to the end of his days, and if\r\none has only one good memory left in one\xe2\x80\x99s heart, even that may\r\nsometime be the means of saving us. Perhaps we may even grow wicked\r\nlater on, may be unable to refrain from a bad action, may laugh at\r\nmen\xe2\x80\x99s tears and at those people who say as Kolya did just now, \xe2\x80\x98I want\r\nto suffer for all men,\xe2\x80\x99 and may even jeer spitefully at such people.\r\nBut however bad we may become\xe2\x80\x94which God forbid\xe2\x80\x94yet, when we recall how\r\nwe buried Ilusha, how we loved him in his last days, and how we have\r\nbeen talking like friends all together, at this stone, the cruelest and\r\nmost mocking of us\xe2\x80\x94if we do become so\xe2\x80\x94will not dare to laugh inwardly\r\nat having been kind and good at this moment! What\xe2\x80\x99s more, perhaps, that\r\none memory may keep him from great evil and he will reflect and say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I was good and brave and honest then!\xe2\x80\x99 Let him laugh to himself,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s no matter, a man often laughs at what\xe2\x80\x99s good and kind. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nonly from thoughtlessness. But I assure you, boys, that as he laughs he\r\nwill say at once in his heart, \xe2\x80\x98No, I do wrong to laugh, for that\xe2\x80\x99s not\r\na thing to laugh at.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be so, I understand you, Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kolya, with\r\nflashing eyes.\r\n\r\nThe boys were excited and they, too, wanted to say something, but they\r\nrestrained themselves, looking with intentness and emotion at the\r\nspeaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say this in case we become bad,\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha went on, \xe2\x80\x9cbut there\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nreason why we should become bad, is there, boys? Let us be, first and\r\nabove all, kind, then honest and then let us never forget each other! I\r\nsay that again. I give you my word for my part that I\xe2\x80\x99ll never forget\r\none of you. Every face looking at me now I shall remember even for\r\nthirty years. Just now Kolya said to Kartashov that we did not care to\r\nknow whether he exists or not. But I cannot forget that Kartashov\r\nexists and that he is not blushing now as he did when he discovered the\r\nfounders of Troy, but is looking at me with his jolly, kind, dear\r\nlittle eyes. Boys, my dear boys, let us all be generous and brave like\r\nIlusha, clever, brave and generous like Kolya (though he will be ever\r\nso much cleverer when he is grown up), and let us all be as modest, as\r\nclever and sweet as Kartashov. But why am I talking about those two?\r\nYou are all dear to me, boys, from this day forth, I have a place in my\r\nheart for you all, and I beg you to keep a place in your hearts for me!\r\nWell, and who has united us in this kind, good feeling which we shall\r\nremember and intend to remember all our lives? Who, if not Ilusha, the\r\ngood boy, the dear boy, precious to us for ever! Let us never forget\r\nhim. May his memory live for ever in our hearts from this time forth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, for ever, for ever!\xe2\x80\x9d the boys cried in their ringing voices,\r\nwith softened faces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us remember his face and his clothes and his poor little boots,\r\nhis coffin and his unhappy, sinful father, and how boldly he stood up\r\nfor him alone against the whole school.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will remember, we will remember,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the boys. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was brave, he\r\nwas good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how I loved him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Kolya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, children, ah, dear friends, don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid of life! How good life\r\nis when one does something good and just!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d the boys repeated enthusiastically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKaramazov, we love you!\xe2\x80\x9d a voice, probably Kartashov\xe2\x80\x99s, cried\r\nimpulsively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe love you, we love you!\xe2\x80\x9d they all caught it up. There were tears in\r\nthe eyes of many of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah for Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d Kolya shouted ecstatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd may the dead boy\xe2\x80\x99s memory live for ever!\xe2\x80\x9d Alyosha added again with\r\nfeeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor ever!\xe2\x80\x9d the boys chimed in again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKaramazov,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kolya, \xe2\x80\x9ccan it be true what\xe2\x80\x99s taught us in religion,\r\nthat we shall all rise again from the dead and shall live and see each\r\nother again, all, Ilusha too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly we shall all rise again, certainly we shall see each other\r\nand shall tell each other with joy and gladness all that has happened!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAlyosha answered, half laughing, half enthusiastic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how splendid it will be!\xe2\x80\x9d broke from Kolya.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now we will finish talking and go to his funeral dinner. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe put out at our eating pancakes\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a very old custom and there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsomething nice in that!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Alyosha. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, let us go! And now we\r\ngo hand in hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd always so, all our lives hand in hand! Hurrah for Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nKolya cried once more rapturously, and once more the boys took up his\r\nexclamation: \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah for Karamazov!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFOOTNOTES\r\n\r\n\r\n [1] In Russian, \xe2\x80\x9csilen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n [2] A proverbial expression in Russia.\r\n\r\n [3] Grushenka.\r\n\r\n [4] i.e. setter dog.\r\n\r\n [5] Probably the public event was the Decabrist plot against the Tsar,\r\n of December 1825, in which the most distinguished men in Russia were\r\n concerned.\xe2\x80\x94TRANSLATOR\xe2\x80\x99S NOTE.\r\n\r\n [6] When a monk\xe2\x80\x99s body is carried out from the cell to the church and\r\n from the church to the graveyard, the canticle \xe2\x80\x9cWhat earthly joy...\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n is sung.
